'\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nReliance Cap to buy AMP Sanmar for Rs 100 crore ; Reliance Capital will acquire AMP Sanmar Life\nInsurance Company for...\n\nFRENY PATEL & KAUSIK DATTA Mumbai\n223 words\n17 August 2005\nBusiness Standard\nBSTN\n1\nEnglish\n(c) 2005 Business Standard Ltd.\nReliance Capital will acquire AMP Sanmar Life Insurance Company for Rs 100 crore. Since the\nChennai-based life insurance entity has net free assets of Rs 60-65 crore, Reliance Cap will pay a premium\nof Rs 35-40 crore.\n\nNet free assets essentially denote the book value of an insurance company, calculated after deducting losses\nfrom its share capital. AMP Sanmar has a capital base of Rs 217.5 crore.\n\nThe non-banking finance arm of the Anil Dhirubhai Ambani Enterprise (ADAE) had initially decided to acquire\nAMP Sanmar through Reliance Life Insurance Company. But it was not possible as Reliance Life Insurance\nwas not a legal entity since it did not have a licence from the Insurance Regulatory and Development\nAuthority (IRDA).\n\nIRDA Chairman CS Rao told Business Standard since Reliance Life Insurance was not a legal entity, it could\nnot acquire AMP Sanmar. "It is important for Reliance to identify the acquirer as the next step will be the due\ndiligence exercise to be undertaken by the insurance regulator," he added. Declining to comment on the\nactual value of the deal, Graham Meyer, AMP Sanmar CEO, said it had not been a distress sale.\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nBANKING/FINANCE\nAMP Sanmar Life is now Reliance Life\n\nOur Bureau\n173 words\n3 February 2006\nBusiness Line (The Hindu)\nBSNLNE\n06\nEnglish\n(c) 2006 The Hindu Business Line\nHyderabad , Feb. 2\n\nCONSEQUENT to the acquisition by Reliance Capital Ltdof the entire equity capital of AMP of Australia and\nSanmar Group in AMP Sanmar Life Insurance Co Ltd , the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority\n(IRDA) has taken note of the change of company name, `AMP Sanmar Life Insurance Co Ltd\', to that of\nReliance Life Insurance Co Ltd (RLICL) and the fresh certificate of incorporation consequent to change of\nname issued by the Registrar of Companies, Tamil Nadu, dated January 17.\n\nThe insurance regulator said it had permitted RLICL to carry on life insurance business in India subject to the\ncondition that RLICL should honour its commitments to the policyholders of AMP Sanmar Life Insurance on\nthe same terms and conditions subject to which they were issued.\n\nFurther, the regulator said in a notice here that RLICL should take necessary steps to protect the interests of\nthe policyholders in accordance with the provisions of IRDA Act 1999 and Insurance Act 1938.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nMax Hypermarkets, Auchan end ties\n\nRaghavendra Kamath\n232 words\n12 August 2014\nBusiness Standard\nBSTN\nEnglish\n(c) 2014 Business Standard Ltd.\nMax Hypermarkets, part of Dubai\'s Landmark Group, and French retailer Groupe Auchan have ended their\ntwo year old licence agreement in India.\n\nThe failure to convert that agreement into a joint venture is the reason for ending the relationship, Max\nHypermarkets said today.\n\n"Max Hypermarkets and Groupe Auchan continued deep into 2013 to look into the possibilities of creating a\njoint venture to facilitate Groupe Auchan investment in India, which could comply with Indian FDI regulations.\nDespite their best efforts, the parties could not facilitate this proposition," Max said in a statement.\n\n"Therefore, by common agreement, the 13 Max Hypermarkets will no longer operate under the Auchan\nbanner by January 2015 at the latest," it said\n\nThis is the second break-up for Max as it ended its ties with Dutch retailer Spar International in May 2012.\nAfter tying up with Auchan, Max rebranded its existing \'SPAR\' stores in Bangalore and Mangalore to\n\'Auchan\'.\n\nIn September 2012, the UPA government allowed foreign direct investment in multi brand retail subject to\napproval of respective states. Barring UK-based Tesco, none of the foreign chains has applied for FDI in multi\nbrand retail so far.\n\nMax Hypermarket is committed to growth and development of the hypermarket and supermarket business in\nIndia and will continue its investments under a new brand name, the Bangalore based company said.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nRetail\nWalmart Stores spent $334 mn to end its deal with Bharti Enterprises, resulting in a net loss of $151\nmn\n\nRasul Bailay & Sagar Malviya\n765 words\n29 April 2014\nThe Economic Times\nECTIM\nEnglish\n(c) 2014 The Times of India Group. All rights reserved.\nNEW DELHI | MUMBAI: Walmart Stores spent $334 million (Rs2,025 crore at current rates) to end its\nhigh-profile retail partnership with Bharti Enterprises, resulting in a net loss of $151 million (Rs915.6 crore)\naccruing to the US company’s consolidated income in 2013.\n\nWhile the world’s largest retailer paid $100 million (Rs606 crore) to acquire Bharti’s stake in its India\nwholesale joint venture and go solo, it also took a $234-million (Rs1,418 crore) hit that included debt and\nother investments in back-end partner Bharti Retail that it waived as part of the October 2013 separation,\naccording to its annual report issued last week.\n\nWalmart paid the $100 million to acquire Bharti Enterprises’ 50% stake in the erstwhile Bharti Walmart Pvt Ltd\nthat ran 20 Best Price-branded cash-andcarry stores. It was widely speculated that Walmart had\ncompensated Bharti well to call off their six-year-old alliance but this is the first time the amount of money the\nUS company paid to end its India equal JV has come to light. Bharti officials couldn’t be reached immediately\nfor comment. Walmart India said it had nothing to add to the information already disclosed.\n\nET reported previously that it cost Walmart around Rs1,000 crore to purchase Bharti’s stake in the joint\nventure. After going well for the first four years since its inception in 2007, the Bharti-Walmart alliance turned\nrocky in the last two as the US firm focused attention on an internal probe to check if the unit had in any way\nviolated US anti-bribery laws.\n\nBharti, Walmart Trying to Expand Independently\n\nScott Price, Walmart’s Asia head who has now been elevated to a global role, told ET in an interview earlier\nthis month that the two partners had an "amicable" end to their six-year alliance. The two-year probe carried\nout by independent investigators, including US law firm Greenberg Traurig and consulting firm KPMG,\nprompted Bharti-Walmart to stall all expansion, suspend or sack top officials and ultimately drove a wedge\nbetween the partners.\n\nWalmart was intent on making sure that it hadn’t committed any violations of the US Foreign Corrupt\nPractices Act, which outlaws bribes to foreign government officials by US-listed entities to run or secure\nbusinesses.\n\nThis followed a corruption scandal in Mexico, where company officials allegedly paid tens of millions of dollars\nin bribes to local officials to expand faster in the biggest foreign market for Walmart. After the Mexico episode,\nWalmart started investigating global operations including India and China. Walmart faced other difficulties in\nIndia as well. The Bentonville-based retail giant was hounded by Indian politicians for what was construed as\nlobbying to get India to open multi-brand retail to global supermarket chains.\n\nIt also came under attack for its $100-million investment in Bharti Retail’s holding firm in 2010 at a time India\nbarred any sort of overseas investment in multi-brand retail. Politicians alleged that Walmart broke India’s\nforeign exchange laws through what they called illegal and indirect capital infinfusion into Bharti Retail, which\nran a nationwide network of Easyday stores. Subsequently, India would change its rules to allow foreign\ndirect investment in multi-brand retail but with strict conditions attached.\n\nBharti will acquire the compulsory convertible debentures (CCDs) worth $100 million that Walmart’s\nMauritius-based investment arm had infused into Cedar Support Services, which owned Bharti Retail, as part\nof the separation agreement. In addition to the termination of the wholesale joint venture, Walmart also\n\n\n\nPage 2 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nsnapped its "franchisee and supply agreement with Bharti Retail Ltd which operates Bharti’s retail business in\nIndia and transferred its (Walmart’s) investment in that business to Bharti", the annual report said, apparently\nwith reference to the $100-million CCD investment.\n\nBoth Walmart and Bharti are trying to expand their businesses independent of each other. Walmart this\nmonth said it’s bullish on the India cash-and-carry business and plans to add 50 Best Price stores in the next\nfive years. ET has reported that Walmart, which has formed a new company called Walmart India, has\ninjected an additional Rs1,328 crore into its operations in the country after its break-up with Bharti. A\nsubstantial chunk of this will go into developing the cash-and-carry stores and allied infrastructure, according\nto people aware of the plans.\n\nFor Reprint Rights: timescontent.com\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nEmerging Markets\nBP Walks Away From India\'s Refining Renaissance\n\n728 words\n10 April 2006\nInternational Petroleum Finance\nIPF\nEnglish\n(c) 2006 Energy Intelligence Group. All rights reserved\nHarsh market conditions for downstream companies in India -- including hefty losses from sales of petroleum\nproducts below cost and a potential glut in domestic refining capacity -- are being blamed for last month\'s\ndecision by BP to pull out of a mooted refining and marketing joint venture with Hindustan Petroleum.\n\nBP had informed Hindustan that its board had found other projects more attractive at this time than the\nproposed Bhatinda refining venture, Hindustan Chief Executive MB Lal told a Mar. 24 press conference in\nNew Delhi.\n\nLal noted that India\'s downstream conditions had worsened since BP signed a letter of intent last October\nwith Hindustan to invest in a $3 billion refinery in Bhatinda in northern India. The agreement also involved\nsetting up a joint venture to market products from the proposed 180,000 barrel per day inland refinery through\na chain of cobranded retail outlets across India. "They had ambitious plans," Lal told IPF.\n\nBP explained that its decision to abandon the joint venture with Hindustan was made because the project\ndidn\'t fit with its current plans. "It\'s a robust project, but it\'s just not the right project for us at this moment in\ntime," a BP spokeswoman told IPF. "It doesn\'t fit in with what we\'re doing at the moment, so we\'ve decided\nthat we\'re not going to take the letter of intent forward." India remains "a place we would still look at," for both\nupstream and downstream, she added.\n\nShortly after the letter of intent was signed, BP Chief Executive John Browne cautioned that this was no\nguarantee of any future alliance. "We have a letter of intent, which is an agreement to agree," Browne had\nsaid. "We do not have a deal."\n\nLal told reporters that Hindustan would go ahead with the refinery, which will be designed to process 100%\nsour crudes. "We have a refinery on the east coast and one on the west," Lal said. "The Bhatinda refinery is\ninland and complements the other two refineries."\n\nIndia\'s northern region is short of products, and Bhatinda would help plug that gap, Lal said. Hindustan also\nplans to expand the east coast Vizag refinery, which processes 166,000 b/d, by 150,000 b/d at a cost of $1.7\nbillion. "By 2010 we want to process 100% sour crudes in all our refineries," said Lal. "Our refineries will have\nan 84% distillate content and make products suiting Euro-3 and Euro-4 standards."\n\nLal said Hindustan\'s coastal refineries could become largely export oriented, with Bhatinda catering to the\ndomestic market, if Indian product demand remains largely flat at 2.2 million b/d.\n\nBP\'s decision marks a blow to India\'s attempt to attract foreign investments in the energy sector. The country\nderegulated its petroleum sector in April 2002, but oil companies were not allowed to raise pump prices in line\nwith global price levels for the past year, leading to huge losses -- Hindustan incurred losses of around $350\nmillion for the nine months ending December 2005 from selling petroleum products below cost.\n\nIndia\'s petroleum sector, once touted as a high-growth market, is in the doldrums. The country\'s existing 2.6\nmillion b/d capacity, spread across 18 refineries, is already 15% higher than current product demand, which\nhas been negative in the current fiscal year to end-March.\n\nBut this has not stopped the country from witnessing a boom in domestic refining investment, aimed at\nturning India into a global refining hub targeting export markets in Europe and the US. Hindustan\'s Bathinda\nplant is one of eight refining projects that are set to add some 1.58 million b/d of new refining capacity to the\nIndian market by 2010, at a cost of around $12 billion.\n\nThe export drive has been led by private refiners such as Reliance Industries, which is adding a further\n540,000 b/d of processing capacity to its giant 660,000 b/d Jamnagar plant between now and 2009 (IPF\n\n\n\nPage 2 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nOct.,p16). But Oil & Natural Gas Corp. (ONGC) and Indian Oil Corp. (IOC) look set to jump on the export\nbandwagon, with both following the Jamnagar model by developing integrated refining and petrochemical\ncomplexes at Mangalore and Paradip, respectively.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nFood\nBritannia to buy out NZ dairy partner Fonterra\n\n513 words\n29 April 2009\nThe Economic Times\nECTIM\nEnglish\n(c) 2009 The Times of India Group. All rights reserved.\nBANGALORE: Nusli Wadia-controlled Britannia Industries has agreed to buy out New Zealand\'s Fonterra\nfrom an existing dairy joint venture, Britannia New Zealand Foods.\n\nBoth Britannia and Fonterra, one of the world\'s biggest milk co-operatives, agreed to call off the 51:49 JV,\nwith the acquirer assuming the cumulative losses and the exiting foreign partner writing down the investments\nmade into venture.\n\nThe deal will bolster and unlock further synergies in Britannia\'s go-to-market strategy. The company in recent\nmonths brought biscuits, cakes & rusks and dairy products like cheese, butter, ghee and dairy whitener under\none distribution vertical, while the \'daily fresh\' products, such as bread and dahi fall into another.\n\nThe company\'s distribution was fragmented till some time back, with all the business units approaching the\ntrade separately.\n\nThe mainstay biscuits, non-biscuit bakery (breads, cakes & rusks) and dairy constitute three strategic\nbusiness units within the Rs 3,000 crore company.\n\n"We have a single go-to-market strategy for Britannia as far as possible, which is helping us, especially with\nthe modern trade. The distribution has been streamlined into two verticals, with the fresh consumption\nproducts like bread and curd forming one and remaining products going to the market under a separate\nvertical," Britannia Industries MD Vinita Bali told ET.\n\nIn fact, Britannia has tweaked its brand strategy to accommodate the fresh consumption products under a\nnewly-scripted Britannia Daily Fresh umbrella. Ms Bali said the dairy JV was reporting a turnover of Rs 200\ncrore and an annualized growth of 15-18%.\n\nThe JV, which had turned profitable in recent years, has accumulated losses of around Rs 38 crore. "We will\nbe taking over the P/L of the JV and so the losses," she added.\n\nFonterra, a significant supplier of milk ingredients to global food giants such as Danone and Nestle, wanted to\nexit the Indian market since it could not deliver much value addition, given the fragmented nature of India\'s\ndairy industry.\n\nFonterra is known for managing large dairy farms. It is not a big player in the branded dairy sector even\nthough it has milk powder offering under Anchor brand in several south east Asian markets.\n\nBritannia will ramp up its presence in the dairy space through new product offerings post acquisition of the\nFonterra stake. "We will be looking at differentiated SKUs where we can innovate on the basic dairy\ntechnology.\n\nTake our cheese offering, for instance, where we have a market share of nearly 50%. We came out with slim\ncheese (with 33% lower fat) as well as cheese cubes and spreads that are clearly differentiated," Ms Bali\nsaid.\n\nThe Britannia-Fonterra JV exited the liquid milk market in 2004 in wake of mounting losses and has no plans\nof re-looking at the segment. "It is a high volume low margin play that does not fit into our business model in\ndairy," she explained, suggesting that Britannia\'s dairy play will essentially revolve around milk derivatives.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nAccel Buys British Telecom\'s 51% Stake In Accel Frontline\n\nCharmi Gutka\n590 words\n9 August 2011\nDealCurry\nDEALCU\nEnglish\nCopyright © 2011. EagleEye Research & Media Pvt. Ltd.\nIT firm, Accel Limited has bought out 51% stake held by British Telecom in Accel Frontline Limited for Rs.49.9\nCr.\n\nWith this buyout, Accel holds a majority 70.44% stake in Accel Frontline.\n\nAccel Limited is the promoter of Accel Frontline Ltd. In 2004, Frontline Technologies Corporation acquired a\n42% stake in Accel ICIM which was later renamed \'Accel Frontline Ltd\'.\n\nIn 2008, British Telecommunications Plc acquired 100% stake in Frontline Technologies Corporation Limited,.\nThereafter, Accel Ltd sold 9% stake in Accel Frontline to BT for Rs.120 Cr, thereby making Accel Frontline a\nsubsidiary of BT with 51% holding.\n\nTransacton Reference: Times Of India\n\nTransaction Note Founded in 1991 by N.R.Panicker, Chennai-based Accel Frontline provides system\nintegration solutions comprising network design, hardware, software, and website development and\nimplementation of customized software products.\n\nIt\'s products are used in various industries including banking, healthcare, manufacturing, education and\ngovernment.\n\nIn 1999, Accel Frontline received first round of venture capital from ICICI Ventures, while second round of PE\ninvestment came from Intel Asia Pacific (the investment arm of Intel) in 2000.\n\nAccel Limited operates in the domains of systems integration, technology services, software development\nand business process outsourcing. Accel\'s operations are spread across 59 cities in India, Singapore, Middle\nEast and US.\n\nAccel Limited operates through four independent corporate entities namely Accel Frontline Ltd, Accel\nTransmatic Ltd, Accel Systems Group Inc and Accel BPO.\n\nThe market cap of Accel Frontline is Rs.90 Cr. It posted total revenue of Rs.332.19 Cr with PAT of Rs.6.34 Cr\nfor FY11, while for quarter ending March 2011, it posted total revenue of Rs.96.05 Cr with PAT of Rs.2.31 Cr.\n\nIn December 2010, BT sold 5.5% in Tech Mahindra to partner Mahindra & Mahindra for about Rs 450 Cr.\nPost sale, BT\'s holding came down to 24.5% in Tech Mahindra.\n\nKVEZAR VIEW\n\nDEAL TRACKER FOR\n\nDate\nType\nSub Type\nBuyer\nSize\nBritish Telecom - Accel Frontline -\nAccel Ltd\n\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/Accel-buys-out-BT-stake-in-Accel-Frontline/articleshow/9537142.cms\n\n\nPage 2 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\n09/08/11 M&A Buyout Accel Limited\n499.00\n\nAccel Frontline - Intel Capital Exit\n28/09/06 Private Equity Capital Market Transaction\n\n0.00\nAccel Frontline Limited - IPO\n28/09/06 IPO / Offerings\nAccel Frontline - Intel Capital, ICICI Exit\n27/01/04 M&A\n\n0.00\nAccel Frontline - Frontline Technologies Corporation\n26/01/04 M&A Frontline Technologies\nCorporation Limited 0.00\nAccel Frontline - Intel Capital\n31/12/99 Venture capital Intel Capital\n\n0.00\nAccel Frontline - ICICI Emerging Sectors\n31/12/98 Venture capital ICICI Emerging Sectors Fund\n\n0.00\n\nRecent Transactions In The Sector\n\nDate\nType\nBuyer\nTarget\nSize\nState\n09/08/11 M&A Accel Limited\nAccel Frontline Limited 499.00 Completed\n\n05/08/11 Private Equity Sequoia Capital India Prizm Payment Services Private\nLimited 353.28 Completed\n\n05/08/11 Venture Capital Nexus India Capital Druva Software Private Limited\n441.60 Planned\n\n04/08/11 Venture Capital Accel Partners SureWaves Media Tech Private\nLimited 100.00 Completed\n\nProfiles\n\nCompany\nName\nPromoters\nOffice\nCompetitor\nWebsite\nAccel Frontline Limited Accel LimitedparabreakFrontline Technologies Corporation\nLimited 75, Nelson Manickam RoadparabreakAminjikarai\n\nwww.accelfrontline.inAccel Limited\nNo.124, 3rd Floor Nelson Manickam Road,\n\nAminjikarai www.accel-india.com\nTAGS\n\nAccel Limited | British Telecom | Accel frontline Limited | Frontline Technologies Corporation | Accel ICIM |\nBritish Telecommunications Plc | N.R.Panicker | ICICI Ventures | Intel Asia Pacific | Accel Transmatic Ltd |\nAccel Systems Group Inc | Accel BPO | Tech Mahindra | Mahindra & Mahindra\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nCelio Raises Stake In Future Group JV\n\nPranali Shah\n312 words\n25 November 2013\nDealCurry\nDEALCU\nEnglish\nCopyright © 2013. EagleEye Research & Media Pvt. Ltd.\nFrench menswear brand Celio has raised its stake to 65% in the 50:50 Future Group JV and would invest\nnearly R40 Cr to open new stores, BS states.\n\nCelio is a 50:50 JV between Celio International and Indus-League Clothing Limited. Celio International is a\nleader in men’s wear in France and has an international presence through 1000 stores in 66 countries. It\noperated through 30 exclusive brand outlets and 100 multi-brand outlets.\n\nThe company is now planning to increase its store presence to 42 by the end of this year, besides also\nadding over 20 shops every year. Celio currently sources nearly 27% of its requirements in India and is\ntargeting to raise it to over 30% by early next year.\n\nFuture\'s newly listed company Future Lifestyle Fashions owns 35% stake in the company Celio Future\nFashions, a JV between Indus-League Clothing Ltd. and Celio International. Celio International S.A. has also\nfiled an application with the GOI to increase its stake in Celio Future Fashion Ltd, to up to 100%.\n\nIndia is an important market for any international brand for a foray in Asia. Celio is in a position now to commit\nto the market. The approval will bring about more infusion of capital.\n\nRecently Future Lifestyle Fashion Limited exited its investment in ethnic wear firm BIBA apparel and Anita\nDongre owned AND for R450 Cr.\n\nThe Future Group’s sales and divestments are part of Biyani’s efforts to restructure and revive his retail\nempire that paid the price for rapid, and debt-fuelled expansion.\n\nIn this space, Mandhana Retail Ventures, the licensee of Salman Khan\'s Being Human brand was planning to\nraise R120-150 Cr by divesting 30% stake in the company. Also, L Capital Asia was planning to exit Genesis\nLuxury.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nContinental Acquires Joint-Venture Shares from RICO Auto\n\n367 words\n12 March 2012\nENP Newswire\nENPNEW\nEnglish\n(c) 2012, Electronic News Publishing. All Rights Reserved.\nRelease date - 09032012\n\nFrankfurt am Main, Germany/New Delhi, India. The international automotive supplier Continental, has\nacquired Rico Auto Industries Limited’s 50 percent shares in the joint venture Continental Rico Hydraulic\nBrakes India Ltd. With this transaction the company will be fully owned subsidiary of Continental.\n\nSince 2009 the plant in Gurgaon near New Delhi has been producing and supplying components for hydraulic\nbrake systems to OEM customers in India. These include products and services consisting of calipers for\nfront and rear axles, drum brakes, master cylinders, brake boosters and load sensing proportioning valves for\nall kind of passenger cars.\n\n‘India plays an important role in the growth strategy of our hydraulic brake systems business unit. The\ninvestment in the Gurgaon activities underlines our intention to add even more value to driving safety for the\nIndian automotive industry and end consumers. With our Indian operations we support worldwide OEMs with\ntheir production locations in India as well as Indian homebased OEMs’, said Dr. Peter Laier, Executive Vice\nPresident of the Hydraulic Brake Systems business unit, Continental Chassis & Safety division.\n\nAccording to Claude dGama Rose, Country Head of Continental in India ‘This acquisition also reinforces our\ncommitment to the Indian market. We have strong growth plans and we will continue to invest in both\ndevelopment and manufacturing to introduce future technologies to this lucrative market, both in our\nAutomotive and Rubber businesses in India.’\n\nContinental is continuing to concentrate on the key components of its business strategy, one of the main ones\nbeing above-average profitable growth in the growth regions, including BRIC, especially in China, India and\nother Asian countries.\n\nIn India, Continental had made significant investments in 2011 by acquiring Modi Tyres and further\ncommitting to an investment of 50 million Euros to ramp up the tyre business in the country. They also\nexpanded the India Technical Centre in 2011, and are planning expansion of its automotive facilities in Pune\nand Manesar in 2012. The company believes that India will see improvements and capacity addition in\ninfrastructure, which will trigger continuous growth.\n\n[Editorial queries for this story should be sent to newswire@enpublishing.co.uk]\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nBUSINESS & ECONOMY\nDBS exits India NBFC biz\n\nKhyati Dharamsi\n319 words\n31 March 2010\nDNA - Daily News & Analysis\nDNADAI\nEnglish\nCopyright 2010. Diligent Media Corporation Ltd.\nSells 37.48% in Cholamandalam DBS Finance to Murugappa Group\n\nDBS, Singapore\'s largest bank, is exiting its non-banking finance venture in India. It is selling off its 37.48%\nstake in Cholamandalam DBS Finance to partner Murugappa Group in a deal worth Rs 376 crore.\n\nThe shares would be purchased at Rs 91 per share, which is a 1.2% premium to the closing price of Rs 89.90\nat the Bombay Stock Exchange on Monday. Shares of Cholamandalam DBS Finance closed on Tuesday at\nRs 90 per share after touching a high of Rs 93.45 intraday.\n\n"The transaction is expected to be completed on or before 12 April 2010," a statement issued on Tuesday\nsaid.\n\nThe bank said the move was in line with its new target customer group. "DBS remains committed to India, a\nhigh-growth market, where it has enjoyed stellar performance over the past five years. The bank is executing\nswiftly on the new strategic roadmap unveiled by chief executive officer Piyush Gupta in February. In India,\nthe bank wants to focus on corporate clients as well as high-networth individuals and emerging affluent\nsegments," it said in a response to DNA Money.\n\nGupta took charge of DBS\'s India operations in November, 2009. The Murugappa Group also clarified on\nTuesday that options were open for future tie-ups.\n\nIndia contributes 8% to DBS\' total business, the third-largest after Singapore and Hong Kong. The India\nbusiness is seen growing 20-25% in 2010-11. "DBS and Murugappa Group remain open to future\ncollaboration opportunities in areas such as wealth management, distribution of financial products, etc."\n\nDBS had also earlier exited its mutual fund venture in the country, which was again in tie-up with Murugappa\nGroup, after DBS Cholamandalam Mutual Fund was acquired by L&T Finance early this year.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nTop Stories\nMahindra to Buy BAE Systems 26% Stake in India JV\n\nSantanu Choudhury\n207 words\n11 February 2013\n09:53\nDow Jones Top News & Commentary\nDJCOMM\nEnglish\nCopyright (c) 2013, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.\nMahindra & Mahindra Ltd. (500520.BY) will buy BAE Systems PLC\'s (BAESY) stake in Defence Land\nSystems, a joint venture, the two companies said Saturday.\n\n"This decision is a reflection of the shareholders\' belief that they can best meet emerging customer\nrequirements and address the opportunities in this dynamic market with a flexible, tailored approach that was\nnot easily facilitated by the structure of the existing Joint Venture entity," they said in a joint statement, without\nspecifying details of the stake buy.\n\nMahindra and BAE Systems will consider opportunities for working together on specific projects, they added.\n\nDefence Land Systems makes military vehicles at a facility on the outskirts of New Delhi.\n\nThe partners had said in January that they were reviewing the JV.\n\nMahindra also has a JV with U.S.-based Telephonics Corp. a unit of Griffon Corp. (GFF), to make radar\nsystems in India, and another with United Arab Emirates-based Arabia Holdings and Ras Al Khaimah\nTransport Investments LLC to make and sell armored vehicles in the Middle East and Central Asia as well as\nin Africa.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nTimes Sport\nPricol exits Denso JV on huge losses\n\nAllirajan.M@timesgroup.com\n159 words\n18 March 2015\nThe Times of India - Chennai Edition\nTOICHE\nEnglish\nCopyright © 2015. Bennett, Coleman & Co., Ltd.\nWith losses mounting, auto instruments manufacturer Pricol has exited its joint venture with Japanese partner\nDenso Corporation, when it sold its 49% stake in Denso Pricol India (DPIN) to Denso for a consideration of\nRs 20 crore. DPIN has now become the wholly-owned subsidiary of Denso. "The JV was making huge\nlosses. The business was not going as per plan," said Vikram Mohan, MD of Pricol. DPIN, which had\nrevenues of around Rs 70 crore in 201314, was supplying instrument clusters exclusively to Japanese\ncarmakers Toyota, Honda and Suzuki. The JV envisaged total buyout of Pricol by Denso in five years and\ninvolved transfer by Pricol, of its \'Denso Technology Instrument Cluster Undertaking\' relating to four-wheeler\npersonal passenger vehicles, situated at Coimbatore and Gurgaon to Pricol Components, a wholly-owned\nsubsidiary of Pricol. Denso acquired 51% stake in Pricol Components after the transfer.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nContinental Equipment Buys Desmon\'s Stake In JV\n\nTilak Devadiga\n425 words\n30 August 2013\nDealCurry\nDEALCU\nEnglish\nCopyright © 2013. EagleEye Research & Media Pvt. Ltd.\nContinental Equipment India has acquired complete stake of its JV partner, Desmon in Desmon Continental\nFrigo Pvt. Ltd, HospitalityBizIndia states. The company bought its partners 50% stake to make it a 100%\nsubsidiary.\n\nDesmon Continental Frigo Pvt. Ltd was formed in 2009 as a JV between Continental Equipment and Desmon\nSpA wherein both the partners held equal stake. It had set up a manufacturing facility for professional\nrefrigerators near Bhiwadi in Rajasthan. Post acquisition, the JV would be named Continental Frostline Pvt.\nLtd. and its products would be branded under the name Frostline.\n\nContinental Equipment, started in 1978, is a commercial food service equipment manufacturer and supplier.\nThe company\'s products include counter top range , ovens, veggie washer; its imported product portfolio\nincludes dish washer, coffee machine, food processing machine, etc.\n\nContinental is focused in the areas of Project and Key Accounts Management. The projects executed in India\nand abroad, range from 4 & 5 star hotels to canteens, schools, ashrams, hospitals, specialty restaurants etc.\n\nIt is a supplier to McDonalds, KFC, Pizza Hut, Papa Johns, Sbarro, Yo China, Nirula’s, Barista, Café coffee\nday, Costa and many other International and Indian QSRs and provides services in the form of equipment\ndesign, equipment fabrication, imported and indian equipment distribution, installation, warranty, service etc.\n\nDesmon SpA which was founded by the family De Santis in 1994 in Italy as a company for the marketing of\ncatering equipment however later it began production of refrigerators under its own brand. It has two factories\nin Nusco (AV) and other manufacturing facilities in India and China with three distribution centers live in\nFrance, UK and Germany.\n\nOther deals include;\n\nKVEZAR VIEW\n\nDEAL TRACKER FOR\n\nDate\nType\nSub Type\nBuyer\nSize ($mn)\nDesmon SpA - Desmon Continental Frigo - Continental Equipment\n30/08/13 M&A Acquisition Continental Equipment India Private Limited 0.00\n\nRecent Transactions In The Sector\n\nDate\nType\nBuyer\nTarget\nSize ($mn)\nState\n\n\n\nPage 2 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nUPDATE: DLF To Exit Mutual Fund JV With Prudential - Source\n\n457 words\n18 January 2010\n12:45\nDow Jones International News\nDJI\nEnglish\n(c) 2010 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.\n\n(Adds details on the mutual fund JV, background)\n\nBy Nikhil Gulati\nOf DOW JONES NEWSWIRES\n\nNEW DELHI (Dow Jones)--DLF Ltd. (532868.BY), India\'s biggest realty company by sales, will exit a mutual\nfund joint venture in the country with Prudential Financial Inc. (PRU) because of a proposed regulatory\nchange, a person with direct knowledge of the matter said Monday.\n\n"The move is prompted by a proposed regulatory change, which makes it mandatory for a company to have\nfive years of experience before selling mutual funds," the person, who didn\'t wish to be named, told Dow\nJones Newswires.\n\nThe move is also in line with the New Delhi-based company\'s strategy to focus on real estate development,\nthe person added.\n\nDLF currently owns 39% in the joint venture--DLF Pramerica Asset Managers Pvt. Ltd.--while Prudential\nowns the remaining 61%.\n\n"DLF will sell its 39% stake to Prudential," the person said, without disclosing details of the likely valuation of\nDLF\'s stake in the venture.\n\nSpokespeople from Prudential weren\'t immediately available for comment.\n\nThe person said also that the time frame for DLF\'s exit from the joint venture is yet to be decided.\n\nIn November 2008, DLF and Prudential had received an approval from the markets regulator, the Securities &\nExchange Board of India, to jointly sell mutual funds and said they will jointly invest $45 million in DLF\nPramerica.\n\nDLF Pramerica was planning to start selling mutual funds in 2009.\n\nEarlier Monday, The Economic Times newspaper reported that DLF plans to exit the venture to reduce its\ndebt of nearly INR120 billion.\n\nDLF has been exiting its non-core businesses as part of its strategy to focus more on property development.\nThe company\'s founders recently sold its multiplex-chain, DT Cinemas, to Indian multiplex operator PVR Ltd.\nThe real estate developer also previously announced plans to sell its wind power business.\n\nStill, DLF has a separate life insurance venture with Prudential, DLF Pramerica Life Insurance Co. Ltd., in\nwhich the Indian realty firm owns a majority 74% stake, while the remaining stake is held by the U.S.-based\ninsurance company.\n\n"The life insurance business is continuing and is doing very well for DLF," the person said.\n\nThe life insurance business began operations in September 2008 with an equity base of INR1.1 billion. In\nNovember 2008, DLF had said that the companies will jointly infuse INR10 billion of capital over next five to\nsix years in the life insurance venture.\n\n\n\nPage 2 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\n-By Nikhil Gulati, Dow Jones Newswires; +91-11-4356-3306; nikhil.gulati@dowjones.com\n\n(Shikhar Balwani in Mumbai also contributed to this story.) [ 18-01-10 0715GMT ]\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nDLF buys out Hiltons in 74:26 hotel JV\n\nDistributed by Contify.com\n340 words\n6 December 2011\nRealty Plus\nATREAP\nEnglish\nCopyright © 2011 Adsert Web Solutions Pvt. Ltd.\nThe country\'s largest realty firm DLF has bought out its foreign partner Hilton in its hospitality firm DLF Hotels\n(formerly known as DLF Hilton Hotels Ltd) for an undisclosed sum. DLF held majority stake in the 74:26 joint\nventure that clocked revenues of Rs 22.95 crore with profit after tax of Rs 14.5 crore during the year ended\nMarch 31, 2011. The financial details of the latest transaction stands undisclosed but it would run into several\ncrores, reports VCCircle.\n\nAlthough the JV did not manage to scale up as fast as hospitality industry analysts had hoped for, arguably\ndue to the economic slowdown that hit the hospitality business specially hard during 2008-10, the JV had paid\nup capital of Rs 534.5 crore as per balance sheet disclosure for FY2011.\n\nAmong the listed peers, a company like Hotel Leelaventure Ltd is currently trading 34 times its FY2011 net\nprofit. If this is taken as a benchmark, DLF Hotels could be valued at around Rs 510 crore or more and\nHilton\'s stake could then be worth around Rs 130 crore ($25 million), as per VCCircle estimates.\n\nDLF, which also owns and operates the luxury segment hospitality brand Aman Resorts across the world,\nhad formed an alliance with Hilton for development and management of hotels in India a few years ago.\n\nThe debt-laden realty firm had been taking a hard look at the hotel business and among the many options, it\nhas been looking at the possibility of selling Aman Resorts.\n\nDLF had formed the JV with Hilton a few years ago, in one of the first large foreign direct investment\ntransactions in the hospitality sector in the country. Although various international hotel brands operate in\nIndia, with some of them having been here for decades, most of them entered the market through\nmanagement contracts by lending their brand names to local partners.\n\nImages, graphs or charts, if any, have been removed\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nLimitless to divest Indian JV\n\n222 words\n15 December 2013\nMubasher\nMUBEN\nEnglish\n© 2013 Mubasher Info. All Rights Reserved. Provided by Syndigate.info, an Albawaba.com company\nThe Indian government has reported approved plans by Dubai-based developer\n\nLimitless to exit its joint venture with a real estate major after failing\n\nto progress on a proposed project, Arabian Business reported.Its\n\n2007 partnership with DLF, one of India\'s largest real estate companies,\n\nhad planned to develop a township in Karnataka.But according to\n\nlocal media reports, the venture failed to acquire the land required for\n\nthe project and no building work has taken place.Now, the\n\ngovernment has allowed Limitless to walk away while repatriating some of\n\nthe capital it put in to the joint venture, reports added.The\n\nForeign Investment Promotion Board (FIPB) has approved the proposal of DLF\n\nLimitless Developers Pvt Ltd, an official statement said."The\n\nproposal was related to exit of foreign investors and the repatriation of\n\ncapital as the construction sector project could not even acquire land,"\n\nit added.Last month, Limitless said it is set to restart\n\nconstruction of its first residential tower at The Galleries, with 323\n\nunits for lease at the company’s flagship project in Dubai.It\n\nsaid Galleries at Downtown Jebel Ali already comprised four completed,\n\nfully operational commercial buildings. Under an agreement with sister\n\ncompany Nakheel, Limitless will restart work on the first apartment\n\nbuilding, it said.\n\n;\n\nAll Rights Reserved - Mubasher Info\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nDubai s Limitless said to exit Indian joint venture\n\nAndy Sambidge\n220 words\n13 December 2013\nArabianBusiness.com\nARBUS\nEnglish\n© 2013, ArabianBusiness.com, All rights Reserved - Provided by SyndiGate Media Inc.\nThe Indian government has reported approved plans by Dubai-based developer Limitless to exit its joint\nventure with a real estate major after failing to progress on a proposed project.Its 2007 partnership with DLF,\none of India\'s largest real estate companies, had planned to develop a township in Karnataka.But according\nto local media reports, the venture failed to acquire the land required for the project and no building work has\ntaken place.Now, the government has allowed Limitless to walk away while repatriating some of the capital it\nput in to the joint venture, reports added.The Foreign Investment Promotion Board (FIPB) has approved the\nproposal of DLF Limitless Developers Pvt Ltd, an official statement said."The proposal was related to exit of\nforeign investors and the repatriation of capital as the construction sector project could not even acquire\nland," it added.Last month, Limitless said it is set to restart construction of its first residential tower at The\nGalleries, with\n\n323 units for lease at the company’s flagship project in Dubai.It said Galleries at Downtown Jebel Ali already\ncomprised four completed, fully operational commercial buildings. Under an agreement with sister company\nNakheel, Limitless will restart work on the first apartment building, it said.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. Provided by Syndigate.info, an Albawaba.com Company All Rights Reserved.\nThe Indian government has reported approved plans by Dubai-based developer Limitless to exit its joint\nventure with a real estate major after failing to progress on a proposed project.Its 2007 partnership with DLF,\none of India\'s largest real estate companies, had planned to develop a township in Karnataka.But according\nto local media reports, the venture failed to acquire the land required for the project and no building work has\ntaken place.Now, the government has allowed Limitless to walk away while repatriating some of the capital it\nput in to the joint venture, reports added.The Foreign Investment Promotion Board (FIPB) has approved the\nproposal of DLF Limitless Developers Pvt Ltd, an official statement said."The proposal was related to exit of\nforeign investors and the repatriation of capital as the construction sector project could not even acquire\nland," it added.Last month, Limitless said it is set to restart construction of its first residential tower at The\nGalleries, with\n\n323 units for lease at the company’s flagship project in Dubai.It said Galleries at Downtown Jebel Ali already\ncomprised four completed, fully operational commercial buildings. All rights reserved.\n\nCorporate\nDLF to End Ties with Ferragamo\n\nRAVI TEJA SHARMA NEW DELHI\n432 words\n2 May 2012\nThe Economic Times - Mumbai Edition\nECTMUM\nEnglish\nCopyright © 2012. Bennett, Coleman & Co., Ltd.\nRealtor to focus on selling premium, luxury fashion brands in the country\n\nLess than a fortnight after ending its joint venture with Giorgio Armani, DLF said it is in the process of\nbreaking its partnership with another Italian luxury brand Salvatore Ferragamo as part of a move to exit luxury\nbrands business."Luxury is a futuristic business in India at the moment and does not have scale," DLF\nBrands Chief Executive Officer Dipak Agarwal says.\n\nThe real estate major will instead focus on selling premium and bridge-to-luxury fashion brands such as\nBoggi, Alcott, Mango, Mothercare, Claire\'s and DKNY."This segment is much more profitable and scalable,"\nAgarwal says.\n\nHe says that while luxury brands have a big future in India, it will require another five to seven years to\nachieve scale and market size."For us, size with speed was important," he says.\n\nThe company has had only four Ferragamo and three Armani stores since it entered the luxury brands\nsegment in 2008 as expansion of these brands in a limited market was getting difficult.\n\nIn comparison, UK retailer Mothercare, which sells prams, pushchairs, car seats, baby clothes and also\nmaternity clothes, entered India in 2009 and already has 42 stores in the country.\n\nIt will add 15 more stores this year.\n\nBoggi has 12 stores and DLF will add another three stores in the next one-year.\n\nThe luxury market in India is bogged down with issues such as high import duties and lack of skilled\nmanpower and quality real estate.\n\nThere is only one luxury mall in the country currently, the DLF Emporio in Delhi, and brands are reluctant to\nenter high street locations due to poor infrastructure around them.\n\nThe cost of retail real estate is very high and that has been nibbling into the profits of luxury retailers in the\ncountry.\n\nToday, it costs.8-10 crore to set up a luxury store while a store for a premium brand can be made for.70-80\nlakh.\n\nTo offset this cost, some luxury brands have resorted to reducing the size of their stores to improve the sales\nper sq ft of space.\n\nDLF Brands currently operates 120 stores for its brands and Agarwal hopes to take the number to 500 in the\nnext three to four years.\n\nWhile the company has decided not to invest in new luxury brands at the moment, Agarwal says it may help\nsome top brands enter the country through support on the real estate and supply chain fronts.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nEducomp Sells Its 50% Stake in IndiaCan To Pearson; Selling To Consolidate\n\nBrindaalakshmi K\n459 words\n10 April 2013\nMediaNama\nHTMEDN\nEnglish\nCopyright 2013. MixedBag Media Pvt. Ltd.\nRIL_button( "http://www.medianama.com/2013/04/223-educomp-indiacan-pearson/", "Educomp Sells Its 50%\nStake in IndiaCan To Pearson; Selling To Consolidate" );\n\nEducation company, Educomp has sold 50% of its stake in IndiaCan, a vocational training business to\nPearson, its JV partner in the venture,  according to BSE filing.\n\nIndiaCan is a JV that was started between Educomp and Pearson in 2009 to tap on the vocational training\nmarket in India. Educomp in its press release has stated that this move is part of their “consolidation\nstrategy", a third in a series of exits from non-core businesses. The company says that this stake sale has\nbeen made to avoid the need to fund losses and other capital needs of a non-core business. It is not clear if\nIndiaCan has been making losses that Educomp has not been able to fund.\n\nEducomp\'s Consolidation: \n\nEducomp further plans to focus on digital content & IP offering and asset backed offerings like schools and\ncolleges.  Note that Educomp Online is Educomp\'s online education platform. It is not clear if there are other\nIP offerings or any in the pipeline. But it is clear that Educomp plans to keep its focus on digital. In January\n2013, Authorgen, a subsidiary of Educomp Solutions Ltd, had raised Rs 22 crore from Kaizen, a private\nequity firm and a German media company, Bertelsmann. Authorgen through its website, WizIQ.com enables\neducation service providers to create virtual classrooms and also convert document to flash. It appears that\nEducomp has also sold 50% stake in Eurokids International Ltd to a group of investors led by GPE India, last\nmonth. In 2011, Educomp merged Studyplaces.com after being acquired in 2010.  It is worth noting that\nKleiner Perkins, Caulfield & Byers (KPCB), Sherpalo Ventures and InfoEdge, all investors in Studyplaces.com\nhad reported that they lost money in the business.  Educomp plans to further continue this consolidation\nprocess.\n\nOther Developments in the Education Sector\n\nNote that IndiaCan is the second acquistion for Pearson this year. In February 2013, Pearson had\nacquired the remaining 20% stake in TutorVista thereby increasing its stake in the company to 100%.\nTutorVista provides online tutoring service to students. In the same month, e-learning site\nMeritNationraised Rs 30 crore funding from Info Edge (India). With this investment, InfoEdge became a\nmajority stakeholder in Applect Learning Systems, the company that owns MeritNation. In March 2013, online\ntest platform, Rank Junction had raised undisclosed sum of money from Indian Angel Network. In the same\nmonth, Skoolshop.com, an ecommerce site run by Occasion Kommerce Pvt. Ltd had raised series A funding\nfrom Blume Ventures & others.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nReal Estate\nEmaar to end JV with Indian partner MGF\n\nSwet Sarika\n508 words\n14 April 2016\nVC Circle\nMMVVCC\nEnglish\nCopyright 2016. Mosaic Media Ventures Pvt. Ltd.\nEmaar Properties PJSC, Dubai’s biggest developer, has decided to end its 11-year-old joint venture with\nMGF Developments Ltd in India following a year-long separation tussle between the partners.\n\nEmaar said in a statement on Wednesday it will take steps to reorganise Emaar MGF Land Ltd via a\ndemerger to sharpen its focus on its Indian operations and develop ongoing projects.\n\nThe development comes almost a year after reports first surfaced about a possible split due to disagreement\nbetween the partners but Emaar had denied any such move. The Dubai developer had brought in about Rs\n7,500 crore in the joint venture and owned roughly 49 per cent stake along with loans and guarantees while\nMGF held the remaining stake.\n\nWhile Emaar didn’t disclose details of the demerger, media reports have suggested that the Dubai firm is\nlikely to get a bigger share when the two partners split assets.\n\n“They were in discussion to thrash out the various issues with regard to debt and partly completed projects\nthat were stuck due to paucity of funds. It was a complicated process as it involves many running projects\nand large land parcels of about 7,500 acres spread over various cities in India," The Economic Times\nreported citing a person familiar with the development.\n\nEmaar MGF, formed in 2005, is known mainly for building the Commonwealth Games Village for athletes\ntaking part in the event’s 2010 edition in New Delhi. However, it faced massive criticism for delays and poor\nconstruction quality. It also tried to float an initial public offering but couldn’t do so after the stock markets\nplunged following the global economic crisis in 2008. It made more attempts to launch an IPO in 2009 and\n2010 but ultimately scrapped the plans.\n\nEmaar is famous for developing the world’s tallest building, the Burj Khalifa, in Dubai. Headed by chairman\nMohamed Ali Rashad Alabbar, Emaar has operations in 14 countries in the Middle East, North Africa, Asia\nand Europe.\n\nMGF Development was started by Shravan Gupta in 1996. It claims to have delivered 2 million square feet of\nretail space and is developing about 3 million square feet of retail space and 1 million square feet of\nresidential space.\n\nKnown for its retail assets at the time of forming the JV, MGF now has presence across residential,\ncommercial and retail segments with projects in Gurgaon, Mohali, Jaipur, Indore and Hyderabad. \n\nThe joint venture was formed during the heyday of real estate when huge capital flowed in. But exits have\nbeen a pain point with some markets under the grip of a slowdown. The past two years have been particularly\npainful for developers as tepid forced them to look for various financing options to survive. \n\nThe national capital region, where the company has maximum exposure, has been worst hit by the slowdown\nwith sales slipping significantly over the years. This has taken the unsold stock with developers to an\nalarming level.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nERGO, HERO GROUP NOT TO PURSUE JOINT VENTURE (Hero Group has decided against\ndiversification into life insurance)\n\nBusiness Line. Mar 19, 2009; pg 6\n104 words\n19 March 2009\nIndian Business Insight\nWIBI\n0971-7528\nEnglish\nCopyright (c) 2009 Informatics (India) Ltd.\nMunich Re\'s primary insurance unit ERGO Insurance Group and the Hero Group have called off their planned\nlife insurance joint venture. They had signed an agreement in May 2008 and the proposed venture was to\nstart operations in 2009. The Hero Group has decided against diversification into the life insurance business\nat this point while ERGO Insurance Group sees good potential in the domestic life insurance market and will\nactively seek an entry into the market.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nGeometric Rises on Deal With HCL Tech, Dassault -- Market Talk\n\n151 words\n4 April 2016\n10:28\nDow Jones Institutional News\nDJDN\nEnglish\nCopyright © 2016, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.\n0458 GMT [Dow Jones] Shares of Indian software firm Geometric Ltd. (532312.BY) are up 15.5% at 226.40\nrupees after it said over the weekend that it will sell to Indian outsourcing firm HCL Technologies Ltd.\n(532281.BY). Shareholders of Geometric will receive ten shares in HCL for every 43 shares held in a deal\nanalysts pegged at $188 million. Geometric\'s 58% share in its venture with Dassault Systemes S.A.\n(DSY.FR) will be deal with separately, with the Indian company merged into the venture 3DPLM Software\nSolutions Ltd. and the entire shareholding sold to Dassault. Geometric shareholders will get one listed\nredeemable preference share of 68 rupees carrying a dividend of 7% a year in 3DPLM.\n(kenan.machado@wsj.com)\n\nEditor: KLH\n\n(END) Dow Jones Newswires\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nHershey to Acquire All Outstanding Shares of the Godrej Hershey Joint Venture\n\n1,046 words\n7 September 2012\n19:30\nBusiness Wire\nBWR\nEnglish\n(c) 2012 Business Wire. All Rights Reserved.\n\nHERSHEY, Pa.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--September 07, 2012--\nThe Hershey Company ("Hershey") (NYSE: HSY) today announced that it has reached an agreement to\nacquire the 49 percent stake in Godrej Hershey Ltd. that it does not own, primarily from Godrej Industries Ltd.\n("Godrej") and another minority shareholder. Including the assumption of about $47.6 million in debt, which is\nalready consolidated by Hershey as the majority shareholder, the company will own the Maha Lacto and\nNutrine candy brands and the Jumpin and Sofit beverage brands as well as the related manufacturing\nfacilities. The transaction is expected to close by the end of the third quarter and the new entity will transition\nto use the name Hershey India as it becomes a wholly owned subsidiary of The Hershey Company. As part of\nthe transaction, the minority shareholders will receive an undisclosed cash consideration.\n\n"India is a key focus market for The Hershey Company," said J.P. Bilbrey, President and Chief Executive\nOfficer, The Hershey Company. "We have a great deal of respect for Godrej. Our partnership provided us\nwith insights and an understanding of the consumers and customers in India. Confectionery and beverage\ncategory growth in India is solid and we\'re excited about our opportunities. We\'ll make the necessary\ninvestments in India to accelerate growth, leveraging our core strengths and business model."\n\nThe transaction gives Hershey an opportunity to integrate Godrej Hershey into the company\'s global business\nplatform and leverage corporate resources across the chocolate and sweets and refreshment strategic\nbusiness units. Over time, Hershey\'s goal is to evolve into a faster growing India market leader in the food\nand beverage space.\n\n"With this new phase of the Hershey business in India, we aim to drive growth in this important market\nthrough product innovation, brand building and investment in our people and processes," said Matthew\nLindsay, Managing Director, Hershey India. "Leveraging the learnings from our Godrej partnership and the\nstrong management team in place, we are excited to move forward in this rapidly growing market," Lindsay\nconcluded.\n\nFor the year ended December 31, 2011, the Godrej Hershey joint venture had net sales of about $80 million.\nThe portion of the net loss for the full year attributable to Hershey was approximately $7 million. When the\nGodrej Hershey joint venture was announced in 2007, annual net sales were about $70 million.\n\nAs a result of this transaction there is no change to the financial outlook provided by Hershey on July 26,\n2012 in its second quarter earnings release.\n\nSafe Harbor Statement\n\nThis release contains statements that are forward-looking. These statements are made based upon current\nexpectations that are subject to risk and uncertainty. Because actual results may differ materially from those\ncontained in the forward-looking statements you should not place undue reliance on the forward looking\nstatements when deciding whether to buy, sell or hold the Company\'s securities. Factors that could cause\nresults to differ materially include, but are not limited to: issues or concerns related to the quality and safety of\nour products, ingredients or packaging; changes in raw material and other costs; selling price increases,\nincluding volume declines associated with pricing elasticity; market demand for our new and existing\nproducts; increased marketplace competition; disruption to our supply chain; failure to successfully identify,\nexecute and integrate acquisitions, divestitures and joint ventures; changes in governmental laws and\nregulations, including taxes; political, economic, and/or financial market conditions; risks and uncertainties\nrelated to our international operations and related growth targets; disruptions, failures or security breaches of\n\n\n\nPage 2 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nour information technology infrastructure; the impact of future developments related to the investigation by\ngovernment regulators of alleged pricing practices by members of the confectionery industry, including risks\nof subsequent litigation or further government action; pension cost factors, such as actuarial assumptions,\nmarket performance and employee retirement decisions and funding requirements; the ability to implement\nour supply chain realignment initiatives within the anticipated timeframe in accordance with our cost estimates\nand our ability to achieve the expected ongoing annual savings from these initiatives; and such other matters\nas discussed in our Annual Report on Form 10-K for 2011.\n\nAll information in this press release is as of September 7, 2012. The Company undertakes no duty to update\nany forward-looking statement to conform the statement to actual results or changes in the Company\'s\nexpectations.\n\nAbout The Hershey Company\n\nThe Hershey Company (NYSE: HSY) is the largest producer of quality chocolate in North America and a\nglobal leader in chocolate and sugar confectionery. Headquartered in Hershey, Pa., The Hershey Company\nhas operations throughout the world and approximately 12,000 employees. With revenues of more than $6\nbillion, Hershey offers confectionery products under more than 25 brand names, including such iconic brands\nas Hershey\'s, Reese\'s, Hershey\'s Kisses, Hershey\'s Bliss, Hershey\'s Special Dark, Kit Kat, Twizzlers, Jolly\nRancher and Ice Breakers. Hershey also offers premium and artisan chocolate products under such brands\nas Scharffen Berger and Dagoba through the Artisan Confections Company, a wholly owned subsidiary. The\ncompany is focused on growing its presence in key international markets such as China and Mexico while\ncontinuing to build its competitive advantage in the United States and Canada.\n\nFor more than 100 years, The Hershey Company has been a leader in making a positive difference in the\ncommunities where its employees live, work and do business. Corporate Social Responsibility is an integral\npart of the company\'s global business strategy, which includes goals and priorities focused on fair and ethical\nbusiness dealings, environmental stewardship, fostering a desirable workplace for employees, and positively\nimpacting society and local communities.\n\nMilton Hershey School, established in 1909 by the company\'s founder and administered by Hershey Trust\nCompany, provides a quality education, housing, and medical care at no cost to children in social and\nfinancial need. Students of Milton Hershey School are direct beneficiaries of The Hershey Company\'s\nsuccess.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nHershey to Acquire All Outstanding Shares of the Godrej Hershey Joint Venture\n\n1,046 words\n7 September 2012\n19:30\nBusiness Wire\nBWR\nEnglish\n(c) 2012 Business Wire. All Rights Reserved.\n\nHERSHEY, Pa.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--September 07, 2012--\nThe Hershey Company ("Hershey") (NYSE: HSY) today announced that it has reached an agreement to\nacquire the 49 percent stake in Godrej Hershey Ltd. that it does not own, primarily from Godrej Industries Ltd.\n("Godrej") and another minority shareholder. Including the assumption of about $47.6 million in debt, which is\nalready consolidated by Hershey as the majority shareholder, the company will own the Maha Lacto and\nNutrine candy brands and the Jumpin and Sofit beverage brands as well as the related manufacturing\nfacilities. The transaction is expected to close by the end of the third quarter and the new entity will transition\nto use the name Hershey India as it becomes a wholly owned subsidiary of The Hershey Company. As part of\nthe transaction, the minority shareholders will receive an undisclosed cash consideration.\n\n"India is a key focus market for The Hershey Company," said J.P. Bilbrey, President and Chief Executive\nOfficer, The Hershey Company. "We have a great deal of respect for Godrej. Our partnership provided us\nwith insights and an understanding of the consumers and customers in India. Confectionery and beverage\ncategory growth in India is solid and we\'re excited about our opportunities. We\'ll make the necessary\ninvestments in India to accelerate growth, leveraging our core strengths and business model."\n\nThe transaction gives Hershey an opportunity to integrate Godrej Hershey into the company\'s global business\nplatform and leverage corporate resources across the chocolate and sweets and refreshment strategic\nbusiness units. Over time, Hershey\'s goal is to evolve into a faster growing India market leader in the food\nand beverage space.\n\n"With this new phase of the Hershey business in India, we aim to drive growth in this important market\nthrough product innovation, brand building and investment in our people and processes," said Matthew\nLindsay, Managing Director, Hershey India. "Leveraging the learnings from our Godrej partnership and the\nstrong management team in place, we are excited to move forward in this rapidly growing market," Lindsay\nconcluded.\n\nFor the year ended December 31, 2011, the Godrej Hershey joint venture had net sales of about $80 million.\nThe portion of the net loss for the full year attributable to Hershey was approximately $7 million. When the\nGodrej Hershey joint venture was announced in 2007, annual net sales were about $70 million.\n\nAs a result of this transaction there is no change to the financial outlook provided by Hershey on July 26,\n2012 in its second quarter earnings release.\n\nSafe Harbor Statement\n\nThis release contains statements that are forward-looking. These statements are made based upon current\nexpectations that are subject to risk and uncertainty. Because actual results may differ materially from those\ncontained in the forward-looking statements you should not place undue reliance on the forward looking\nstatements when deciding whether to buy, sell or hold the Company\'s securities. All rights reserved.\n\nour information technology infrastructure; the impact of future developments related to the investigation by\ngovernment regulators of alleged pricing practices by members of the confectionery industry, including risks\nof subsequent litigation or further government action; pension cost factors, such as actuarial assumptions,\nmarket performance and employee retirement decisions and funding requirements; the ability to implement\nour supply chain realignment initiatives within the anticipated timeframe in accordance with our cost estimates\nand our ability to achieve the expected ongoing annual savings from these initiatives; and such other matters\nas discussed in our Annual Report on Form 10-K for 2011.\n\nAll information in this press release is as of September 7, 2012. The Company undertakes no duty to update\nany forward-looking statement to conform the statement to actual results or changes in the Company\'s\nexpectations.\n\nAbout The Hershey Company\n\nThe Hershey Company (NYSE: HSY) is the largest producer of quality chocolate in North America and a\nglobal leader in chocolate and sugar confectionery. Headquartered in Hershey, Pa., The Hershey Company\nhas operations throughout the world and approximately 12,000 employees. With revenues of more than $6\nbillion, Hershey offers confectionery products under more than 25 brand names, including such iconic brands\nas Hershey\'s, Reese\'s, Hershey\'s Kisses, Hershey\'s Bliss, Hershey\'s Special Dark, Kit Kat, Twizzlers, Jolly\nRancher and Ice Breakers. Hershey also offers premium and artisan chocolate products under such brands\nas Scharffen Berger and Dagoba through the Artisan Confections Company, a wholly owned subsidiary. Corporate Social Responsibility is an integral\npart of the company\'s global business strategy, which includes goals and priorities focused on fair and ethical\nbusiness dealings, environmental stewardship, fostering a desirable workplace for employees, and positively\nimpacting society and local communities.\n\nMilton Hershey School, established in 1909 by the company\'s founder and administered by Hershey Trust\nCompany, provides a quality education, housing, and medical care at no cost to children in social and\nfinancial need. All rights reserved.\n\nGodrej Consumer acquires Godrej SCA Hygiene\n\n171 words\n16 June 2009\nThe Press Trust of India Limited\nPRTRIN\nEnglish\n(c) 2009 Asia Pulse Pty Limited.\nMumbai, June 16 (PTI) FMCG major Godrej Consumer Products has bought out Sweden-based SCA\nHygiene Products AB in the joint venture Godrej SCA Hygiene.\n\nGodrej Consumer Products was a 50 per cent shareholder in Godrej SCA Hygiene, the company that owns\nthe "Snuggy" brand of baby diapers, among others. Now it owns 100 per cent.\n\nWith the acquisition of the balance 50 per cent stake in the firm, "Godrej SCA Hygiene has become a wholly\nowned subsidiary of the company with effect from April 1," it said in a filing to the Bombay Stock Exchange.\n\nHowever, the financial details were not disclosed.\n\nGodrej SCA Hygiene was a joint venture between Godrej Consumer Products and SCA Hygiene Products\nAB.\n\nThe board of Godrej Consumer Products had approved the acquisition of the 50 per cent stake in the joint\nventure on December 9, 2008.\n\nShares of Godrej Consumer today closed at Rs 171.80, down 1.55 per cent from its previous close on the\nBSE.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nNEC Acquires Full Ownership of Indian Software Company\n\n403 words\n29 March 2013\n10:24\nJCN Newswire\nJAPCOR\nEnglish\nCopyright 2013 JCN Newswire, a division of Japan Corporate News Network K.K. All rights reserved.\n- NEC Technologies India established -\n\nTokyo, Mar 28, 2013 - (JCN Newswire) - NEC Corporation (NEC; TSE: 6701) and HCL Technologies Limited\n(HCLT) reached an agreement for NEC to obtain full control of NEC HCL Systems Technologies (NHST), a\njoint venture software company. Based on the agreement, NEC will acquire HCLT\'s 49% share of NHST. As\na result, NHST will become a wholly owned subsidiary of NEC. The subsidiary\'s name is scheduled to\nbecome NEC Technologies India Limited in April 2013.\n\nNHST was established in October 2005 in order to enhance software developing resources in India. Since\nthen, the company has developed software products for the platform business in partnership with the\nexperience and knowledge of HCLT. The new subsidiary will play a key role in the development and system\nintegration of NEC\'s solutions business throughout the emerging India and Asia Pacific markets, as well as\nEurope and the US.\n\n"NEC Technologies India will lead a global deployment of product technology and development," said\nTakaaki Shimizu, Senior Vice President of NEC. "The company will become an offshore software\ndevelopment base for systems in Asia Pacific, Europe, the US and Japan, in addition to its current software\ndevelopment for the platform business. Moreover, NEC will strengthen its global sales and support by\nleveraging the new company\'s experience and know-how in development, technology and business\nchannels."\n\nGoing forward, NEC aims to continue strengthening the global competitiveness of its products, costs,\nbusiness promotions and human resources. Furthermore, NEC will create new value for customers as an IT\npartner that provides competitive products and support throughout the world.\n\nAbout NEC Corporation\n\nNEC Corporation (TSE: 6701) is a leader in the integration of IT and network technologies that benefit\nbusinesses and people around the world. By providing a combination of products and solutions that cross\nutilize the company\'s experience and global resources, NEC\'s advanced technologies meet the complex and\never-changing needs of its customers. NEC brings more than 100 years of expertise in technological\ninnovation to empower people, businesses and society. For more information, visit NEC at\nhttp://www.nec.com.\n\nSource: NEC Corporation\n\nContact:\n\nTakehiko Kato\nNEC Corporation\n+81-3-3798-6511\nE-Mail: t-kato@cj.jp.nec.com\n\nJoseph Jasper\nNEC Corporation\n+81-3-3798-6511\nE-Mail: j-jasper@ax.jp.nec.com\n\nhttp://www.nec.com\n\n\nPage 2 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc.
