All rights reserved.\n\nHome Page\nHDFC buys Chubb out of JV\n\nGayatri Ramanathan,feedback@livemint.com\nlivemint\n618 words\n16 May 2007\nMint\nHNMINT\nEnglish\nCopyright 2007. HT Media Ltd. All Rights Reserved.\nMortgage major Housing Development Finance Corporation (HDFC) on Tuesday announced it has bought\nthe 26% stake of Chubb Global Financial Services Corp. in their joint venture, HDFC Chubb General\nInsurance Co., for an undisclosed amount.\n\nThe general insurance joint venture was set up in 2001.\n\nAn executive at HDFC, who did not wish to be named, said the book value of the equity in the joint venture\nwas Rs100 crore; that would mean the book value of Chubb’s stake is Rs26 crore.\n\nConrad D’Souza, treasurer at HDFC, said the company has applied to the Insurance Regulatory and\nDevelopment Authority (Irda), the watchdog for the sector, seeking its approval for the change in the holding\npattern.\n\nPeople close to the development at HDFC, who did not wish to be identified, said Ergo, the insurance arm of\nthe world’s second-largest reinsurance company—Germany’s €37 billion (more than Rs2 lakh crore) Munich\nRe—is the front-runner to pick up the Chubb stake.\n\n“Till such time the Ergo deal is finalized, HDFC will hold 100% stake in the general insurance venture,” said\none of these people.\n\n“Initial joint venture strategies did not get translated,” said D’Souza.\n\nHDFC Chubb lags behind other general insurers such as ICICI Lombard General Insurance Co., Bajaj Allianz\nGeneral Insurance Co., and others in terms of premiums collected. HDFC Chubb collected premiums of\nRs200 crore for the year ended March 2006, compared with Bajaj Allianz’s Rs1,280 crore and ICICI\nLombard’s Rs1,590 crore.\n\nIn fact, according to figures provided by Irda, while companies such as ICICI Lombard and Reliance General\nInsurance are growing at 30-40%, HDFC Chubb was actually not growing at all.\n\nThe two companies differed on strategy, with HDFC favouring an aggressive customer acquisition strategy\nwith a range of products and Chubb preferring a more conservative approach; “Chubb’s focus and HDFC’s\nfocus were not the same,” said the executive at HDFC.\n\nShrirang Samant, the insurance firm’s chief executive officer, quit two weeks ago.\n\nIndian insurance law caps an overseas partner’s stake in an insurance venture at 26%, which restricts the\namount of equity a foreign partner can put into a business that is highly capital-intensive.\n\nHDFC, which also has a life insurance joint venture with the UK’s Standard Life, wants a strategic partner\nwith experience in general insurance, said the HDFC executive.\n\n“There are people interested in partnering with us,” said the executive.\n\nD’Souza said the proposed stake sale would be finalized only after the regulator’s approval. D’Souza also\nsaid insurance firms, both international and domestic, have expressed interest in picking up the Chubb stake.\n\n\n\nPage 2 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\n“As of now, we will run the business as it is. Who comes in as a partner or who will be the CEO will be\ndecided only after the regulator’s approval of the buyout,’’ D’Souza said.\n\nIndia has licensed 15 overseas and local non-life insurers as part of its plan to open the sector to expand\ncoverage of insurance in the world’s second fastest growing major economy. The foreign investment cap of\n26% has been an irritant for most foreign firms, which claim that this restricts their ability to invest in the\nbusiness.\n\nThe industry has been lobbying to raise the limit on foreign investment to 49%, but this has met with political\nopposition from some quarters. Several foreign insurance firms have informal arrangements with their Indian\npartners to increase their stake to 49%, should this be allowed.\n\nReuters andGautam Chakravorthy of Bloomberg contributed to this story.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nBUSINESS & ECONOMY\nHDFC, Chubb to go their separate ways\n\nNandini Goswami\n587 words\n16 May 2007\nDNA - Daily News & Analysis\nDNADAI\nEnglish\nCopyright 2007. Diligent Media Corporation Ltd.\nLocal partner will buy out Canadian major\'s 26% stake in the JV\n\nIt\'s almost official. HDFC and Chubb, financial giants in their own right who had joined hands for a general\ninsurance venture in the country, are parting ways.\n\nHDFC has agreed to buy out the 26% stake held by the foreign partner in the joint venture HDFC Chubb\nGeneral Insurance Company and has applied to the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority (IRDA)\nfor requisite approvals, an HDFC official told DNA Money on Tuesday.\n\nThe company will continue as HDFC Chubb till a name change comes about, for which it has to apply to the\nRegistrar of Companies.\n\nHDFC will now hold 100% in the venture, though it is open to a 26% foreign equity participation once it finds\nan appropriate foreign partner. The JV currently has an equity base of Rs 125 crore.\n\n"All employees will continue to be a part of the same company, where HDFC will have the entire stake and\nwe will chose someone to head the company once all this is through," the official said.\n\nFissures in the over four-year relationship have grown since last year because of differing risk appetites of the\npartners.\n\nHDFC, given its size and distribution strength, was keen to move fast.\n\nHowever, Chubb had an overcautious approach, particularly on commercial insurance, which was proving to\nbe a drag on the company, the official said.\n\nWhile all general insurance companies have grown their business, HDFC Chubb General reported a decline\nin business by 7.59% for 2006-07. Its total business premium was Rs 205.77 crore, one of the lowest in the\ngeneral insurance industry. Its counterparts and even later entrants have marched way ahead, even as the\npublic sector companies with a large base have also grown at higher rates.\n\nAlso, the dynamics of the Rs 25,000 crore general insurance industry has changed since the detariff regime\nkicked off in January this year and there was a crying need for a cohesive management structure to fight it\nout in the fiercely competitive market place. A formal split was thus waiting to happen.\n\nOn the kind of signals the split sends out, the official said, "In fact, investors should be happy as there was a\ngenuine concern for the company\'s falling numbers and now there is a concerted effort to grow the company.\nEveryone has a different way of functioning, and given the fact that all our other companies, like life\ninsurance, asset management, bank and the BPO, are doing so well, there should not be any misconception\non the break-up, which has been mutually agreed upon," the official added.\n\nSo, what happens to Chubb now? Sources indicated that the global insurance giant is unlikely to discontinue\ninsurance business in India. More so, as insurance analysts say, it would be a costly proposition to leave\nIndia at this juncture, at a time when the economy is booming, and re-entering later may see it lose two to\nthree years straightaway.\n\nMarket grapevine has it that Chubb is also scouting around for partners. This time, though, it may find some\ncomfort with a clutch of investors instead of one single company, possibly including some high net-worth\n\n\n\nPage 2 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nindividuals as well. The model could be on the lines of Metlife India. Whether it will be called \'Chubb India\' or\nnot, though, remains to be seen. This, however, could not be confirmed.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nEIH terminates co-branding alliance with Hilton ; EIH Ltd, the flagship company of The Oberoi Group,\ntoday...\n\nBS REPORTER New Delhi\n272 words\n27 September 2007\nBusiness Standard\nBSTN\nEnglish\n(c) 2007 Business Standard Ltd.\nEIH Ltd, the flagship company of The Oberoi Group, today announced that it has terminated a strategic\nmarketing and co-branding alliance with leading global hotel chain Hilton International Co. The decision will\ncome into effect from April 1, 2008.\n\nUnder the alliance, EIH managed and ran seven five-star hotels under the Trident Hilton brand Gurgaon,\nAgra, Cochin, Jaipur, Udaipur, Bhubaneshwar and Chennai. It also has a five-star deluxe property christened\nHilton Towers in Mumbai.\n\nEIH will develop the Trident brand independently. All seven hotels will now be called The Trident and the\ndeluxe property Trident Towers.\n\n"We felt there was a possibility of a dilution in the Trident brand with Hilton\'s overall development strategy in\nIndia. With Hilton planning to open the more downmarket Hilton Garden Inn in the country, we felt customers\nwould get confused between that and the Trident Hilton," said SS Mukherji, vice-chairman, EIH.\n\nRealty firm DLF Ltd had forged a 74:26 joint venture with Hilton International last year. It is this joint venture\ncompany that will be setting up the Hilton Garden Inn brand.\n\n"The first Trident opened way back in 1988 and we entered into an alliance with Hilton only in 2004. So we\nhave always had our own marketing set-up which only has to be revamped. The company is already\nmarketing The Oberoi brand very successfully," said Mukherji.\n\nOver the next three years, EIH will add 1,300 rooms across three Trident Hotels in Mumbai, Bangalore and\nHyderabad.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nFRONT PAGE\nICI India to sell entire stake in Quest\n\nOur Bureau\n460 words\n23 November 2006\nBusiness Line (The Hindu)\nBSNLNE\nEnglish\n(c) 2006 The Hindu Business Line\nNov. 22\n\nPaints and chemicals firm ICI India Ltd, a subsidiary of UK\'s ICI Plc, has announced its plans to sell its entire\nstake in its wholly owned subsidiary Quest International India Ltd (Quest India) for not less than Rs 390 crore\nto Switzerland\'s Givaudan Group.\n\nThe company\'s board of directors, at its meeting on Wednesday, approved the sale of its entire stake in\nQuest India — its flavours and fragrances business — to Givaudan Group, for a total consideration of not less\nthan Rs 390 crore, ICI India informed the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE).\n\nThe announcement followed news that ICI Plc had agreed to sell Netherlands-based Quest International B.V.\nto Givaudan for $ 2.25 billion (around Rs 9,900 crore).\n\nICI India said in a statement that "ICI Plc has, after due evaluation, agreed to accept the offer for sale of\nQuest International business received by them very recently from the Givaudan Group, who has expressed\ninterest in purchase of Quest India also. Considering the heavy linkages on the international business and the\nnature of the customers and the market, the board has decided to divest the company\'s entire shareholding in\nits subsidiary Quest lndia to the said Givaudan Group." The Indian transaction is expected to be completed\nbefore the end of the financial year, subject to the global deal happening within the same timeframe, it said.\n\nICI India has controlling interest in Quest India, which was established in 2001 as a joint venture between the\nICI Group and Hindustan Lever Ltd (HLL).\n\nAs per the joint venture agreement, ICI India acquired HLL\'s 49 per cent shareholding in May this year and\nsubsequently acquired the remaining one per cent of the share capital held by a group company of ICI Plc.\nConsequently, Quest India became a wholly owned subsidiary of ICI India. Quest India reported net sales of\nRs 116 crore and a net profit of Rs 7.8 crore for the financial year ended March 31. The company is\nheadquartered in Mumbai and has its manufacturing sites in Daman with about 100 employees on its rolls.\nShares of ICI India were up seven per cent at Rs 372.10 on BSE on Wednesday. ICI has been carrying out a\nrestructuring exercise wherein it will exit from non-core areas and focus on growing the core ones both\norganically and inorganically. As a step in this direction, ICI India, in June this year, announced the sale of the\ncompany\'s Uniqema business to UK-based Croda Group for around Rs 260 crore.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nING Vysya Life insurance gets new name \'Exide Life Insurance\'\n\n203 words\n6 May 2014\nAccord Fintech\nHTACCF\nEnglish\nCopyright 2014. Accord Fintech\nIndia, May 6 -- ING Vysya Life Insurance Company Limited, totally owned by the Raheja Group through\nbattery maker Exide Industries, has renamed itself as Exide Life Insurance Company Limited (Exide Life\nInsurance) with immediate effect following approvals from Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority\n(IRDA) and Ministry of Corporate Affairs with the formal exit of the Netherlands-based ING Group from the\ninsurance venture.Exide Industries has been our major shareholder for 8 years and acquired 100 percent\nownership of the company over a year back, said Exide Life Insurance managing director Kshitij Jain. The\ninsurance company will continue to honour its commitments and obligations under the insurance policies\nissued to customers in the name of ING Vysya Insurance Company Ltd.In addition to its presence in over 200\ncities across the country, Exide Life Insurance will expand the presence by opening offices in nine centres in\nEastern parts of the country this year.\n\nIt will look to enhance reach in tier-II cities.\n\nPublished by HT Syndication with permission from Accord Fintech.\n\nFor any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at\nhtsyndication@hindustantimes.com\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nGerdau buys partner out of Indian joint venture\n\n324 words\n19 March 2013\nSteel Business Briefing\nSTSCNW\nEnglish\n© 2013 McGraw-Hill, Inc.\nIndia’s Kalyani Group has exited its steelmaking joint venture with Gerdau with the sale of its 45%\nshareholding in the venture to the Brazilian steelmaking group, a Pune-based Kalyani Steel official confirmed\nto Platts Monday. The transaction was concluded in February, which was when Gerdau had announced the\nstart of commercial production at the 300,000 metric tons/year specialty steelworks at Tadipatri in southern\nIndia’s Andhra Pradesh state.\n\nKalyani’s decision to exit the venture was owing to uncertainties in iron ore supplies in India, the official said.\n“We want to wait for a better situation before proceeding with expansions,” he said, adding that Kalyani’s own\nplant – a 670,000 mt/y integrated alloy steelworks at Ginigera in Karnataka – has been operating at only 50%\ncapacity for nearly a year on ore supply disruptions.\n\nIron ore for the Tadipatri works is being sourced from the ongoing electronic auction sales in Karnataka and\nfrom elsewhere, the official added.\n\nThe jv – Kalyani Gerdau Steels – was formed in 2007 through the acquisition of the assets of the 275,000\nmillion mt/y SJK Steel Plant in Tadipatri. Each partner held a 45% shareholding.\n\nLast month, Gerdau revealed it had begun commercial production at the mill now comprising a 350,000\nmillion mt/y blast furnace, a 6-megawatt power plant using gases from the furnace, a sintering plant, and a\nnew 300,000 mt/y rolling mill for special quality steel (SBQ) for the automobile industry.\n\n“As we begin our 112th year of business, the start of the production of special steel in India represents our\nexpansion to an important country, with an impressive cultural richness, good economic prospects and very\ndedicated people,” said André B. Gerdau Johannpeter, Gerdau’s CEO.\n\nFor questions about editorial content, or to subscribe call +44 (0) 20 7626 0600, info@steelbb.com\n\n© Steel Business Briefing 2013\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nKemrock discontinues joint venture with Germany based SAERTEX\n\n205 words\n29 December 2011\nAccord Fintech\nHTACCF\nEnglish\nCopyright 2011. Accord Fintech\nIndia, Dec. 29 -- Kemrock Industries and Exports (Kemrock) has discontinued its joint venture (JV) -\nSAERTEX-KEMROCK India with effect from December 28, 2011. The JV is been discontinued with the\nmutual agreement of both the partners, in view of the change in business plan of the foreign JV partner.\nSAERTEX-KEMROCK India is a 50:50 JV between Kemrock Industries and Exports and SAERTEX\nBeteiligungsgesellschaft mbH, Germany.Further, the said entity is now being a wholly owned subsidiary and\nhas been renamed as Kemrock Aerospace India. The company shall continue to forge ahead with its plan to\nmanufacture materials and components for aeronautical industry with suitable partner(s) already under\nconsideration.Kemrock manufactures and exports high-performance reinforced thermoset composites,\ncommercially known as GRP/FRP Composites.\n\nIt manufactures products for major industrial sectors and its product range comprises of gratings, poles,\npipes, scaffolding (access system), pultruded profiles, cable management system, cage ladders, windmill\nblades and nacelle covers, railway interiors and exteriors, SMC/ FRP Doors, telecom towers etc.Published by\nHT Syndication with permission from Accord Fintech.\n\nFor any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at\nhtsyndication@hindustantimes.com\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nL&T buys out Demag from joint venture ; After 10 years of joint operations, Larsen and Toubro\n(L&T)...\n\nNEVIN JOHN Mumbai\n387 words\n14 June 2009\nBusiness Standard\nBSTN\n1\nEnglish\n(c) 2009 Business Standard Ltd.\nAfter 10 years of joint operations, Larsen and Toubro (L&T) and Germany’s Demag Plastics Group have\nparted ways. The joint venture, which was set up in 1999 for making plastics machinery, has ended after\nDemag’s new parent, Sumitomo, decided to go it alone in the Indian market by floating a wholly-owned\nsubsidiary.\n\n“L&T-Demag Plastics Machinery, the Chennai-based joint venture company, will no longer be in existence as\nL&T has bought out its partner’s 50 per cent stake. Sumitomo, which acquired Demag in early-2008, has its\nown plan for India and it decided to break the relations with L&T,” said a company executive.\n\nThe purchase gives L&T complete ownership of the operations in Chennai. After announcing its exit from the\njoint venture, Sumitomo Demag Plastics Machinery said in a statement, “As already announced in March\n2008, Sumitomo Heavy Industries is proceeding to establish a subsidiary in India.” L&T officials declined to\ncomment on the development.\n\nIn 2002, the joint venture company had built its first factory for injection moulding machines. Three years\nlater, it built a second factory in Chennai that doubled its production capacity to a thousand machines a year.\n\nSumitomo Heavy Industries inherited the 50 per cent stake in the operation when it bought Demag in March\n2008. However, for more that 10 years, Sumitomo has had a technical collaboration with another Indian\ninjection machinery maker, Windsor Machines in Mumbai.\n\nL&T had started manufacturing injection moulding machines in 1990 in association with Demag Plastics\nGroup. But the two formed the 50:50 joint venture company only after nine years. Soon after, the venture had\nemerged as the leading injection moulding solutions provider in India.\n\nL&T Demag launched a petition last year to the India government in which it accused Chinese rivals of\ndumping presses at below cost in the Indian market. The government responded earlier this year by imposing\nanti-dumping duties of up to 223 per cent on 10 Chinese companies. Among these, three are associated with\nChina’s largest injection machine maker, Ningbo Haitian Plastic Machinery Group.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nASPEN, LUPIN DISCONTINUE TB JOINT VENTURE\n\n168 words\n23 January 2007\nDaily International Pharma Alert\nFDAIA\nEnglish\nCopyright (c) 2007 Washington Business Information, Inc.\nSouth African drugmaker Aspen Pharmacare and Lupin announced they have mutually agreed not to pursue\nthe memorandum of understanding they signed in February 2006 for the development, manufacture and\nmarketing of tuberculosis (TB) drugs.\n\nThe companies had agreed to a 50-50 joint global marketing agreement. Though the companies have\ndiscontinued that agreement, they will continue to collaborate on marketing TB drugs in South Africa as per a\nprevious agreement.\n\nAt the time of the signing of the February 2006 agreement, the companies believed that there would be\nstrength in the combination of Lupin\'s TB and active pharmaceutical ingredient pipeline and Aspen\'s\nmultidrug-resistant TB product line and experience with antiretroviral drugs. The companies had also planned\nto explore opportunities in the malaria market.\n\nAspen is the largest generic drugmaker in the Southern Hemisphere and one of the top 20 generic\nmanufacturers worldwide, according to the company. It is also Africa\'s largest pharmaceutical company.\n\nRelease date: Jan. 23, 2007\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nEmerging Business & IT\nHetero Drugs buys out Lyka\'s stake in JV\n\n329 words\n29 March 2006\nThe Economic Times\nECTIM\nEnglish\n(c) 2006 The Times of India Group. All rights reserved.\nHYDERABAD: Hyderabad-based Hetero Drugs, makers of the Tamiflu capsules, has bought out the stake of\nGujarat-based Lyka Labs in the joint venture Lyka Hetero Healthcare for a consideration of Rs 6.1 crore.\n\nAfter gaining control of Lyka Hetero Healthcare, the company is busy drawing up a turnaround plan that\nincludes fresh investments for improving sales margins and addition of new molecules in cardiology and\nantibiotics.\n\nHetero expects the buyout of the JV partner\'s stake in Lyka Hetero will give them the much-needed stability\nand foothold in the domestic market.\n\nWith its expanded basket, including formulations in antibiotics, pain management and anti- asthmatic, Hetero\nis expecting to reduce its dependency on APIs considerably. "Most of our turnover comes from export of\nAPIs, where price volatility is high.\n\nBy attaining full ownership of Lyka Hetero Healthcare, we will be able to focus on marketing formulations in\ndomestic market. This will help us to circumvent the volatility, making our bottomline stronger," Hetero Drugs\ndirector (marketing), Srinivas Reddy, told ET.\n\nThe company is likely to undertake a management restructuring as part of the turnaround. For the erstwhile\njoint venture, Hetero Drugs is looking to achieve a turnover of Rs 70 crore in one year against the present Rs\n40 crore.\n\n"We found it difficult to chalk out marketing strategies within the confinement of a JV. Now we can focus on\nachieving sales volumes for the existing products. It will take 12-18 months for the new molecules to attain\ncritical mass," Mr Reddy said.\n\nHowever, the company refused to make any comments on management restructuring. "The valuation process\nis on. It will take at least one month for us to finalise investments and other changes," he said.\n\nLyka Hetero Healthcare was a 51:49 joint venture between Gujarat-based Lyka Labs and Hetero. It was\nfloated to market Lyka\'s products in the domestic market.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nMahindra & Mahindra ends 3-year defence JV with BAE Systems\n\nDistributed by Contify.com\n451 words\n9 February 2013\nDomain-B\nATDOMB\nEnglish\nCopyright © 2013. The Information Company Pvt. Ltd.\nMahindra & Mahindra (M&M) today said that its subsidiary Mahindra Defence Systems will acquire BAE\nSystems\' 26-per cent stake in their defence joint venture, Defence Land Systems India (DLSI), ending a\nthree-year partnership with Britain\'s biggest aerospace company.\n\nThe move comes just a year after the London-based company appointed Dean McCumiskey as managing\ndirector and chief executive of its Indian operations in place of Andrew Gallagher in order to lead the next\nphase of BAE Systems\' business development in the country. (See: Dean McCumiskey to head BAE\nSystems in India (http://www.domain-b.com/people/in_the_news/20120123_bae_systems.html))\n\n"This decision is a reflection of the shareholders\' belief that they can best meet emerging customer\nrequirements and address the opportunities in this dynamic market with a flexible, tailored approach that was\nnot easily facilitated by the structure of the existing joint-venture entity," both companies said in a joint\nstatement.\n\nThe two companies had set up the JV in 2009 to develop new technologies and the manufacture of trusted\narmoured vehicles like the Axe, Rakshak, Marksman, up-armoured and bulletproof Scorpios and Boleros, and\nRapid Intervention Vehicles. (See: Mahindra, BAE Systems set up defence JV for land systems\n(http://www.domain-b.com/companies/companies_m/Mahindra/20091130_mahindra_group_oneView.html))\n\nAt present, DLSI produces combat vehicles such as Rakshak, Rakshak Plus, Marksman and MPVi, armoured\nbus, riot intervention vehicle and Scorpio Uparmoured for VIP security.\n\nThe company\'s Prithla plant has a capacity to produce up to 800 vehicles a year, of which up to 120 are\nMPV-Is. In the last three to four years the company has invested about Rs60 crore on the plant.\n\nCommenting on the development, Brigadier (Retd) Khutub Hai, chairman and MD of Mahindra Defence\nSystems, "This is a strategic decision and will enable both the companies to approach opportunities\nindividually and to offer customised solutions to meet the needs of the Indian defence land systems domain."\n\nDean McCumiskey said, "Building domestic capabilities in partnership with Indian companies will remain a\ncornerstone of our strategy in India. We look forward to opportunities to collaborate with Mahindra and others\nto enhance the role of the private sector in the defence industry."\n\nM&M also has a JV with US-based Telephonics Corp to make radar systems and another with UAE-based\nArabia Holdings and Ras Al Khaimah Transport Investments to develop armored vehicles for the Middle East,\nCentral Asia and African market.\n\nBAE also has a software engineering joint venture in India called BAeHA with Hindustan Aeronautics Limited\n(HAL).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nM&M to acquire Navistar\'s stake in MNAL\n\nDistributed by Contify.com\n794 words\n22 January 2013\nCommercial Vehicle\nACOMVE\nEnglish\nCopyright © 2013 Next Gen Publishing, distributed by Contify.com\nM&M and partner Navistar International Corporation have entered into an MoU, wherein the former will buy\nout the latter\'s equity in their JVs, Mahindra Navistar Automotives Ltd (MNAL) and Mahindra Navistar Engines\nPvt Ltd (MNEPL). Following the purchase, both MNAL and MNEPL would become wholly-owned subsidiaries\nof Mahindra. Mahindra would take complete ownership of operations and continue to sell MNEPL and MNAL\nproducts albeit under its own brand name. The sale requires regulatory approval in India, is subject to the\nconclusion of definitive agreements, and is expected to be completed in early 2013. The terms of the\nproposed transaction call for Mahindra to pay approximately Rs.175 crores or USD 33 million, for Navistar\ngroup\'s stake in both ventures. The payout will happen in two parts.\n\nWhile, 66 percent will be paid out as and when the deal goes through (upon the receipt of regulatory\napprovals), the remainder will be payable five years from the date of the first payment.\n\nThe agreement allows Navistar to continue sourcing components from India while Mahindra would continue\nto provide engineering services to Navistar. Navistar Group would continue to support M&M through a license\nagreement and extend necessary support to MNAL and MNEPL for the purposes of business continuity.\nCrucially, the agreement covers the localised Maxxforce 7.2 litre engine. \'Under the terms of our agreement,\nwe can use the Maxxforce engine for as long as needed for business continuity. The engine may be deployed\nfor the domestic market as well as export operations,\' explains Dr. Goenka, President Automotive and Farm\nEquipment Sector. But, the engine is not exclusive to M&M.; Navistar can still commercially exploit it, subject\nto, \'a non-compete clause\'.\n\nFurther investments\n\nSo far, MNAL has registered sales of just 6,000 units in the last 2-3 years, significantly below expectation.\nThis is because, any new player entering the Indian truck market has to contend with the strong incumbents.\nAnd the going has not been easy this year, thanks to the slowdown-induced spell of heavy discounting.\nTherefore, the JV has seen accumulated losses to the tune of Rs 692 crore, as against investments of Rs\n1,066 crore. But this scenario has not dampened M&M\'s commitment to the CV industry. \'We stay committed\nto the truck and bus industry. Our dealers and trade partners are extremely happy with our intent to acquire\nNavistar\'s stake. As a matter of fact, we shall be investing more into the truck and bus business,\' asserts Dr.\nGoenka. M&M reportedly intends to plough Rs 200-300 crore in a bid to turnaround MNAL\'s operations over\nthe next three years. The investment is meant to support and expand the range of almost completely\nlocalised trucks and engines as also its robust dealer and service network.\n\nM&M is confident that it can succeed in the truck business on its own steam. \'Given that we have a product\nrange that is well-suited to the Indian market\'s needs, we do not feel the immediate need for a foreign JV\npartner. But, to be honest, we have not yet applied serious thought to this aspect,\' reveals Dr. Goenka.\n\nNavistar has decided to exit the JV because its finances are not in good shape. It has been the subject of\ninvestor activism and also the target of a speculated takeover by VW. What is more, a failed EPA 10\nemissions compliance strategy saw longstanding Chairman Dan Ustian quit his position.\n\nNot surprisingly, the new management led by President and Chief Operating Officer, Troy Clarke is focussing\non only those business areas that promise immediate return on capital under the \'Drive to Deliver\'\nprogramme. \'While the Indian market has not expanded as we had originally expected and industry\nchallenges there continue in the near term, we still see promise in India going forward. But given Navistar\'s\n2013 priorities, our capital and focus needs to be allocated to other business opportunities in the near term.\'\n\n\n\nPage 2 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nThe end to the MNAL JV follows the recent dissolution of the MANFORCE JV. Industry observers believes\nthat given the tough and competitive nature of India\'s auto industry, it is often difficult to align the visions of\nIndian and foreign partners. Indeed, buyout of a partner\'s stake is not an alien concept for M&M.; It has\nacquired Renault\'s stake in the erstwhile JV covering the localisation and sales of cars and utility vehicles\nunder the Logan brand. In a possibly encouraging precedent for the truck business, the Logan, now badged\nVerito has been performing better than it did under Mahindra- Renault.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. Force Motors is selling its 50 percent stake in MFPTL to its partner MTBA for 150\nmillion euros or about Rs1,050 crore. The joint venture had come into being in 2006 with MTBA picking up 30\npercent stake in MFTPL, which was later raised to 50 percent. The tie-up was intended to introduce world\nclass trucks at Indian prices. But soon differences between the two arose over specification of trucks for\nIndian and overseas markets. The decision to snap ties\ncomes almost five years after the two companies came together. All rights reserved.\n\nApollo gets t(y)red, rolls out of Michelin JV\n\n309 words\n1 October 2005\nThe Times of India\nTOI\nEnglish\n(c) 2005 The Times of India Group\nNEW DELHI: It was a mega tyre deal that Onkar Kanwar got tired of. Kanwar\'s Rs 2,600 crore Apollo Tyres\non Friday scrapped its much-touted two-year-old truck and bus radial tyre making joint venture with French\ntyre maker Michelin.\n\nApollo has decided to walk out of the venture blaming the slow growth in the radial tyre market and deferment\nin project implementation.\n\nApollo will now sell its 49% stake in the the JV - christened Michelin Apollo Tyres Pvt Ltd (MATPL) - to its\nFrench partner at book value. Though company officials refused to divulge details of the financial transaction,\nsources said Apollo would get around $10 million for its 49% holding in the JV.\n\nThe two firms, however, still remain partners as Michelin continues to hold 14.9% stake in Apollo Tyres.\n"There is no intention of buying back this stake from Michelin, and we will…\n\n… continue to explore opportunities for co-operation in India," a source said.\n\nThe board of directors of Apollo Tyres on Friday approved the transfer of the JV\'s assets to Michelin. The\nproceeds from the stake sale will be used to expand Apollo\'s existing facilities and grow its presence in tyre\nmarket.\n\nMATPL was floated nearly two years back and the partners had agreed to set up a plant in Ranjangaon\n(Pune) with an initial investment of $70 million, the project is yet to get underway.\n\n"The decision is based on prevailing market conditions and the pace of radialisation in the truck and bus tyre\nsegments. While the use of radial tyres has gone up in the past two years, it is at a pace slower than what\nwas projected by the partners," Apollo said.\n\nThe Ranjangaon venture will offer the existing range of Michelin products, it said.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nCORPORATE\n`Exit from Michelin joint venture not a setback for Apollo Tyres\'\n\nK.R. Srivats\n261 words\n3 October 2005\nBusiness Line (The Hindu)\nBSNLNE\n05\nEnglish\n(c) 2005 The Hindu Business Line\nNew Delhi , Oct 2\n\nAPOLLO Tyres Ltd does not see its exit from the Michelin Apollo Tyres Pvt Ltd (MATPL), a 51: 49 joint\nventure company with the Michelin group, as a "setback" in its efforts towards getting a slice of the\nhigh-potential truck and bus radial segment pie.\n\n"We will evolve a strategy for the truck and bus radial segment in the coming days. Our exit from the joint\nventure does not mean that we have had a setback or would not foray into truck and bus radial manufacturing\nin the future," Mr Sunam Sarkar, a member on the Apollo board, told Business Line. ,\n\nThe company and the Michelin group on Friday agreed to "realign their business plans" and announced\nApollo\'s exit from MATPL.\n\nApollo Tyres had invested close to $10 million in the joint venture company, which was set up to manufacture\ntruck and bus radial tyre for the domestic market.\n\nMr Sarkar said that the slow pace of radialisation in the Indian truck and bus tyre segment (contributed by\nsomewhat moderate progress in infrastructure build-up) had prompted Apollo Tyres to take a close look at its\nengagement with the joint venture company. "We will get almost entire amount invested in the joint venture\ncompany. We have neither lost or gained in financial terms," Mr Sarkar said.\n\nHe added that the Michelin group would continue to hold the 14.9 per cent stake it acquired in Apollo Tyres\ntwo years ago.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nMICHELIN GEARS UP FOR ITS STRATEGY ROLL SANS APOLLO (the joint venture will be renamed,\ndual branded truck and bus tyres will be replaced by single branded Michelin tyres)\n\nEconomic Times. Oct 17, 2005; pg 5\n174 words\n17 October 2005\nIndian Business Insight\nWIBI\n0013-0389\nEnglish\nCopyright (c) 2005 Informatics (India) Ltd.\nMichelin, the French tyre company, wants to continue its market approach strategy in India despite having\nlost its partner, Apollo Tyres, in its joint venture company, Michelin Apollo Tyres Ltd (MATL). The original plan\nwill continue and the focus will be on becoming the leader in the truck and bus radial market by 2010. The\njoint venture company will be renamed to reflect its new ownership structure and single branded Michelin\ntyres would replace the dual-branded truck and bus tyres. The proposed $70-million truck and bus radial plant\nat Ranjangaon, near Pune, to produce 3 lakh tyres has been temporarily shelved but will be taken up once\nthe radial market matures. In the meanwhile, Michelin will continue to import tyres mainly from China and\nThailand, depending on the specific requirements of the Indian market.\n\nABSTRACT|DAILY\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nMukand sells entire shareholding in JVC for Rs 5.25 crore\n\n135 words\n15 January 2014\nAccord Fintech\nHTACCF\nEnglish\nCopyright 2014. Accord Fintech\nIndia, Jan. 15 -- Mukand vide share purchase agreement dated January 11, 2014, has sold its entire\nshareholding in its erstwhile joint venture company (JVC) \'Bekaert Mukand Wire Industries\' to Bekaert\nIndustries for a sale consideration of Rs 5.25 crore. The company has sold 1.30 crore equity shares of JVC\nacquired at a cost of Rs 13 crore.Mukand, earlier known as Mukand Iron & Steel Works, is engaged in\nmanufacturing of alloy and stainless steel long products. The company operates in four segments namely\nsteel, industrial machinery, road construction and other products.\n\nPublished by HT Syndication with permission from Accord Fintech.\n\nFor any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at\nhtsyndication@hindustantimes.com\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nCorporate Trends\nNew York Life to exit Indian insurance JV\n\nKhomba Singh\n349 words\n15 February 2012\nThe Economic Times\nECTIM\nEnglish\n(c) 2012 The Times of India Group. All rights reserved.\nNEW DELHI: New York Life Insurance Company plans to sell its near-26% stake in Max New York Life\nInsurance in a transaction that could see it sharing about one-third of its sale proceeds with Analjit Singh-led\nMax India, its local partner in the joint venture.\n\nAccording to a person familiar with the development, New York Life, the US-based insurer, is in talks with a\nfew European and Japanese companies as it seeks to exit India as part of its strategy to withdraw from Asia\nand focus on its home market of North America. As part of the strategy, New York Life has divested its stake\nin operations in Thailand, Hong Kong, South Korea and China since last year.\n\nThe US insurer has agreed to pay around one-third of the sale proceeds to its local partner for its contribution\nin building the business and creating its valuation as well as for giving consent for the deal, even though Max\nIndia is not selling any shares itself.\n\nNew York Life\'s stake in the Indian insurance JV is estimated to be worth around Rs 3,500 crore and Max\nIndia could end up earning Rs 1,000-1,100 crore on the basis of this valuation.\n\n"Our JV is a highly successful operation that provides important insurance products to the people of India. We\ndo not comment on rumours," said a New York Life spokesman. Max India did not respond to an emailed\nquery. Max New York Life, the country\'s largest non-banking private insurer, was incorporated in 2000 and is\none of the earliest joint venture companies involving a foreign partner.\n\nIn addition to New York Life, Max India has a 70% stake in the company and Axis Bank holds the remaining\n4%. The money earned by Max India from the transaction will be used to make good its accumulated losses\nin the insurance business and also scout for inorganic growth opportunities, said the person quoted above.\n\nFor Reprint Rights: timescontent.com\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nNippon Chemiphar, Ranbaxy Terminate Alliance\n\n350 words\n21 December 2009\nPharma Japan\nPHJP\n41\nEnglish\n(c) 2009. Jiho, Inc. All rights reserved.\nNippon Chemiphar and Ranbaxy Laboratories terminated their comprehensive business alliance, including\ncapital ties, on December 8. How the two companies will move in the market for generics in Japan has been\nwatched with great interest since Daiichi Sankyo acquired Ranbaxy in 2008. They have finally decided to\nterminate their relationship initiated in 2002 and independently follow their own path.\n\nFifty percent of the shares of Nihon Pharmaceutical Industry (NPI) owned by Ranbaxy were acquired by\nNippon Chemiphar for Y1.6 billion on the same day. NPI will continue to market four generics introduced from\nRanbaxy and sell them through Nippon Chemiphar in Japan. Annual sales of these four products are\napproximately Y1 billion. The effect of the deal on its business will be “minimal,”according to Nippon\nChemiphar.\n\nRanbaxy acquired 10% of shares of NPI, a subsidiary of Nippon Chemiphar, in 2002, and increased its\nownership to 50% in 2005. However, its acquisition by Daiichi Sankyo has basically changed its strategy, and\nit has been obliged to reconsider its relationship with Nippon Chemiphar.\n\nAccording to Nippon Chemiphar, the two companies have been discussing the new partnership since\nsummer in 2008. At the beginning, they discussed how to continue, not to terminate, their partnership. As\nthey reviewed their mutual strategy, however, they have reached a conclusion that the best for both\ncompanies is to independently develop their own business. “This is a friendly, forward-looking\ndecision,”according to Nippon Chemiphar.\n\n“I don\'t think Nippon Chemiphar will be able to fully develop its generics business on its own. We will consider\npartnering,”said President Kazushiro Yamaguchi of Nippon Chemiphar at a press conference in July 2008\ncommenting on the possibility of M&As and alliances for the development of his company\'s generics\nbusiness. At present, however, the company is not negotiating alliances with any foreign-affiliated generic\ncompany, according to the company\'s Public Relations Department.\n\nDaiichi Sankyo has not clarified its generics business policy in Japan. “We are analyzing recent market trends\nand weighing all possible options,”said a spokesperson for the company.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nSpan Diagnostics strengthens on disinvesting its entire stake in Span Nihon Kohden Diagnostics\n\n271 words\n20 November 2015\nAccord Fintech\nHTACCF\nEnglish\nCopyright 2015. Accord Fintech\nIndia, Nov. 20 -- Span Diagnostics is currently trading at Rs. 61.40, up by 2.70 points or 4.60% from its\nprevious closing of Rs. 58.70 on the BSE.\n\nThe scrip opened at Rs. 58.00 and has touched a high and low of Rs. 64.85 and Rs. 58.00 respectively. So\nfar 1521 shares were traded on the counter.\n\nThe BSE group \'XD\' stock of face value Rs. 10 has touched a 52 week high of Rs. 70.00 on 21-Oct-2015 and\na 52 week low of Rs. 42.55 on 09-Feb-2015.\n\nLast one week high and low of the scrip stood at Rs. 64.85 and Rs. 56.05 respectively. The current market\ncap of the company is Rs. 42.71 crore.\n\nThe promoters holding in the company stood at 44.18% while Non-Institutions held 55.82% stake in the\ncompany.\n\nSpan Diagnostics has disinvested its entire 45% stake held in Joint Venture Company (JVC) namely Span\nNihon Kohden Diagnostics. The company has disinvested the same to Nihon Khoden Corporation, Japan for\nconsideration of Rs 8.02 crore.\n\nSpan Diagnostics caters to several different sections of diagnostics like Immunology, Biochemistry,\nMicrobiology, Serology, Histopathology and instrumentation. The company\'s manufacturing capabilities\ncomprise of advanced infrastructure, highly trained and motivated pool of scientific and technical personnel\nand years of experience.\n\nPublished by HT Syndication with permission from Accord Fintech.\n\nFor any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at\nhtsyndication@hindustantimes.com\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nAshok Leyland completes acquisition of LCV JVs with Nissan\n\nAnil Sharma\n278 words\n28 November 2016\nIHS Global Insight Daily Analysis\nWDAN\nEnglish\nCopyright 2016, IHS Global Insight Limited. All Rights Reserved.\nAshok Leyland has completed the acquisition of three joint ventures (JVs) with Nissan, the company said in a\nstatement. The three JVs in question are Ashok Leyland Nissan Vehicles Ltd (ALNVL) for vehicle\nmanufacturing; Nissan Ashok Leyland Power Train Ltd (NALPT) for making powertrains; and Nissan Ashok\nLeyland Technologies Ltd (NALT), a technology JV. All the three JVs operate in the light commercial vehicle\n(LCV) space. As part of the agreement reached between Ashok Leyland and Nissan, the latter transferred its\nshareholding in the three ventures to the former for a consolidated consideration of INR3 (USD0.04). Ashok\nLeyland will continue to build the Dost, Partner, and Mitr LCVs, while servicing and parts availability for\ncustomers will be taken care of by a Nissan technical support team.\n\nSignificance: The completion of the transaction is on expected lines as the competition watchdog in India had\nalready cleared the deal agreed between the partners (see India: 7 November 2016: ). The two companies\nsigned the JVs in 2008 in an effort to gain a foothold in India\'s light and medium commercial vehicle market.\nHowever, the partnership did not go as planned with delays in product launches, declining sales, widening\nlosses, and write-offs. Except for the Dost, the venture did not have any commercial success and the slower\nintroduction of additional variants further contributed to the losses. Early this year, the differences between\nthe partners came out into the public domain and subsequent development resulted in an exchange of legal\nnotices to each other before both the parties decided to call off the partnership in September (see Japan –\nIndia: 8 September 2016: ).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nIndustry\nEnd of the Road for Nissan\'s JVs with Ashok Leyland\n\n311 words\n9 September 2016\nThe Economic Times\nECTIM\nEnglish\n(c) 2016 The Times of India Group. All rights reserved.\nNew Delhi: Japanese auto major Nissan Motor agreed to sell its entire stake in three joint ventures to partner\nAshok Leyland, ending their eight-yearold collaboration.\n\nAshok Leyland and Nissan had formed the JVs -Ashok Leyland Nissan Vehicles for vehicle manufacturing;\nNissan Ashok Leyland Power Train for making power trains and Nissan Ashok Leyland Technologies, which\nis a technology joint venture -in 2008.\n\nThe partners had invested about Rs. 1,000 crore as equity between them.\n\n“Under the agreement signed on September 7, 2016 by senior executives of Nissan and Ashok Leyland,\nthese joint ventures will become wholly owned Ashok Leyland subsidiaries, upon receipt of all necessary\napprovals from the regulatory authorities in India,“ the com panies said in a joint statement. The process is\nexpected to finish this year. The firms declined to disclose details of the financial implications.\n\nAs per the restructured agreement, Ashok Leyland will continue to build under a licensing agreement light\ncommercial vehicles Dost and Partner, which are based on Nissan\'s design, engineering and technology.\nServicing and parts availability for customers will be ensured by a technical support arrangement.\n\nIn addition, the two have agreed to continue a deal to pro reed to continue a deal to procure made-in-India\nparts for Nissan. “We have decided to acquire Nissan\'s stake in the three joint venture companies, and this\nwill help focus our efforts to concentrate on core business initiatives and customers. We will continue our\nrelationship with Nissan under the new arrangement,“ said Ashok Leyland MD Vinod Dasari.\n\n“Nissan and Ashok Leyland coming together was a good idea. There were differences in the way both\ncompanies wanted to approach the market and operationalise their strategies. This impacted volumes &\nculminated in the split,“ said VG Ramakrishnan, managing partner, Avanteum Advisors.\n\nFor Reprint Rights: timescontent.com\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nCompanies\nNovartis Arm, Panacea Biotec End 8-yr-old Vaccine JV\n\nDIVYA RAJAGOPAL MUMBAI\n304 words\n28 August 2013\nThe Economic Times - Mumbai Edition\nECTMUM\nEnglish\nCopyright © 2013. Bennett, Coleman & Co., Ltd.\nSwiss drugmaker Novartis\' subsidiary Chiron has snapped the eight-year-old joint venture which was formed\nwith Delhi-based Panacea Biotec to develop and market paediatric vaccines, a move that comes as Novartis\nplans to go it alone in this business."Novartis wants to own the entire vaccine business and helm it on its\nown," a person familiar with the matter said on condition of anonymity.\n\nBoth Novartis and Panacea did not respond to email queries sent by ET.\n\nChiron Panacea Vaccines, the 50:50 JV, was focused on selling the pentavalent vaccines used in the\nimmunisation of kids.\n\nAt the time of the announcement of the JV, which was signed in 2004, both the companies had planned to\ninvest $100 million (about.650 crore at current rates) into the company.\n\nIn 2010, Novartis acquired Chiron from its other joint venture partner, Aventis, consolidating its ownership in\nthe company.\n\nAnalysts say Panacea Biotec, which is still recovering from a ban imposed by the World Health Organisation\nand is solely dependent on vaccine sales, may have to find another partner to push its business.\n\nPanacea Biotec\'s shares closed at.88.45, down 2.80%, and Novartis India\'s shares closed at.377.95, down\n2.17%, on BSE on Tuesday.\n\nIndia\'s vaccine market, estimated to be close to.3,000 crore, accounts for less than 2% of the global vaccine\ncoverage, according to a research report by consultancy firm McKinsey.\n\nWith the government\'s intervention and increased awareness, the market can touch.6,000 crore, the report\nsays.\n\nIndia\'s growth potential has attracted multinational vaccine makers such as Novartis, Pfizer, Sanofi and GSK,\nsome of which are focused exclusively on niche paediatric vaccines.divya.rajagopal@timesgroup.com\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. Metis Business Solutions Pvt. Ltd.\nReliance Industries, along with its partner Pioneer Natural Resources Co, plan to divest their JV company\nEagle Ford Shale Midstream Business.\n\nUS-based Pioneer Natural Resources, which holds 50.1% in the JV and is operator of the project, said in a\nstatement that the divestment is part of its strategy to focus more on its shale gas explorations business.\nReliance group, which holds 49.9% in the JV through arm Reliance Holding USA, is also pursuing sale of its\nstake. In a separate statement to Indian bourses, RIL said, "Reliance has also agreed to consider a\ndivestment of its shareholding in this joint venture...The current investments in EFS Midstream LLC is $ 208\nmillion."\n\nThe Midstream business of Eagle Ford owns and runs 10 gathering plants and around 460 miles of pipelines.\nThe JV, which was formed in 2010, is likely to generate $100 million in cash flow in 2015, the statement said.\n"The sale of EFS Midstream would allow us to strategically redeploy capital to our core, oil-rich\nSpraberry/Wolfcamp assets in the Permian Basin of West Texas, where we are successfully transforming the\nsubstantial resource potential we delineated in 2013 into strong production growth," said Scott D Sheffield,\nchairman and CEO, Pioneer Natural Resources, in the statement.\n\n"We currently have no plans to divest our Eagle Ford Shale upstream assets. The sale of EFS Midstream is\nnot expected to impact our ability to export processed Eagle Ford condensate," he said. Reliance Industries,\nPioneer Resources to sell off stake in US company Last month, commenting on media reports that RIL may\nsell its stake in the Eagle Ford JV at an estimated $4.5 billion, RIL\'s chief financial officer Alok Agarwal said,\n"Eagle Ford is the most successful joint venture and it has gained a very decent amount of valuation in the\nlast 12 months. Our partners and we are looking at what\'s best for the JV going forward."\n\nBesides, its stake in Eagle Ford, RIL owns stakes in two more shale ventures in the US. RIL owns 40% in\nChevron\'s Marcellus shale asset and 60% in and asset of the Carrizo Oil and Gas Inc in Central and\nNortheast Pennsylvania.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. A year ago RTL expanded the channel with an English-language feed.\n\nThe split, which marks the exit of RTL from Indian TV, was mooted at the end of April when Anil Ambani’s\nReliance bought out the company’s stake in the 50/50 JV.\n\nJust months ago Reliance and CBS Studios International ended their three-year-old JV, which operated Big\nCBS Prime, Big CBS Love and youth-skewing Big CBS Spark.\n\nBig RTL Thrill will be rebranded as Big Thrill. Reliance CEO Tarun Katial said the firm will begin investing in\nregional programming by the end of the year and hopes to add “local male action content” and new concepts.\n\nBig Thrill and its sister channel Big Magic, which focuses on comedy, are available on DTH platforms Dish TV,\nReliance Digital TV and Videocon d2h, and most of India’s major cable platforms.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nFinance\nReligare to exit life insurance venture with Aegon\n\nTEAM VCC\n431 words\n26 September 2014\nVC Circle\nMMVVCC\nEnglish\nCopyright 2014. Mosaic Media Ventures Pvt. Ltd.\nAd-for-equity media investor BCCL is a shareholder in the venture.\n\nReligare Enterprises Ltd, the public listed holding company of a string of financial services businesses, said\non Thursday that it would exit its life insurance joint venture with its Dutch partner Aegon.\n\nThe firm currently holds 44 per cent in Aegon Religare Life Insurance Co Ltd, while Aegon owns 26 per cent\nstake. The remaining 30 per cent is with ad-for-equity media investor Bennett, Coleman and Company Ltd\n(BCCL), the firm behind media publications and TV channels like The Times of India and Times Now.\n\n“After a strategic review, Religare has expressed a desire to exit the joint venture. Religare and Aegon have\nagreed that Religare will exit once a replacement shareholder is identified and is approved by the regulatory\nauthorities,” Religare said.\n\nThe FDI ceiling for insurance sector is in the process of being hiked to 49 per cent which would allow Aegon\nto buy a part of the stake held by Religare. However, Religare would need to find other buyers for its\nremaining holding.\n\nAegon is an international provider of life insurance, pension and asset management. With headquarters in\nThe Hague, the Netherlands, its companies employ over 27,500 people serving millions of customers across\nthe globe. Its main operations are in the US, the Netherlands and the UK, but in recent years the company\nhas expanded into new growth markets in Asia, Central & Eastern Europe and Latin America.\n\nThere are 24 life insurance firms in the country including state-run Life Insurance Co. Religare Aegon is the\n21st ranked life insurer among the 23 private life insurers in the country as per first premium collection for the\nperiod ended June 30, 2014.\n\nIt had launched its pan-India operations in July, 2008 following a multi-channel distribution strategy.\n\nReligare Enterprises share price closed at Rs 301.5 each, down 1.86 per cent on the BSE in a weak Mumbai\nmarket on Thursday.\n\nIn another deal in the life insurance space, Kishore Biyani-led Future Group sold 22.5 per cent stake in Future\nGenerali India Life Insurance Company Ltd to Industrial Investment Trust Ltd (IITL) last year.\n\nAlso real estate developer DLF had sold its 74 per cent stake sale in DLF Pramerica Life Insurance Company\nLtd -- its life insurance joint venture with Prudential International Inc – to Dewan Finance Corporation Ltd and\nits group entities. The firm has now been renamed as DHFL Pramerica Life Insurance.\n\n(Edited by Joby Puthuparampil Johnson)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nBUSINESS\nReligare exits MF biz, sells 51% to partner Invesco\n\n461 words\n19 November 2015\nPress Trust of India\nPRTRIN\nEnglish\nCopyright 2015. The Press Trust of India Limited.\nNew Delhi, Nov 19 (PTI) After life insurance, financial services group Religare Enterprises has decided to exit\nmutual fund business with sale of its controlling 51 per cent stake in Religare Invesco AMC to the foreign\npartner Invesco.\n\nWhile a number of foreign fund houses have exited the Indian mutual fund industry -- the latest being\nGoldman Sachs -- there have not been many cases where Indian entities have sold the asset management\nbusiness.\n\nEarlier this year, Religare had sold its stake in its life insurance join venture. In May 2015, Religare had\nannounced that it will exit Aegon Religare Life Insurance Company by selling its stake to existing partner\nBennett, Coleman and Company Ltd (BCCL) of the Netherlands.\n\nReligare did not disclose the exact reasons for the sale of mutual fund business but sources said that the\ncapital is being unlocked through mutual fund. The funds through stake sale will be used for health insurance\nand lending platform.\n\nThe shares of Religare reacted negatively to the announcement and settled down at 2.04 per cent on the\nBSE in a strong broader market today.\n\nWhile the Indian mutual fund industry has been growing steadily, Religare Invesco has not seen any major\nupsurge in its asset under management in the recent past.\n\nIts average assets under management (AUM) stood at Rs 21,593 crore for the quarter ended September,\nonly marginally higher than Rs 21,009 crore as on March 31 this year. In between, it had fallen to Rs 19,518\ncrore in the quarter ended June.\n\nWithout disclosing the deal size, Religare said in a statement that it has entered into a definitive agreement\nunder which Invesco would increase its stake to 100 per cent in the joint venture. The transaction is subject to\nregulatory approvals.\n\nReligare held 51 per cent in the JV while Invesco currently has 49 per cent ownership.\n\nInvesco\'s Senior Managing Director and Head of Asia Pacific Andrew Lo said it would further deepen its\npresence in India by taking full ownership of this business.\n\nReligare Group CEO Shachindra Nath termed Invesco\'s decision as "an endorsement of the Indian macros"\nand also of the overall quality of the management team.\n\nSaurabh Nanavati will continue as CEO, along with the existing senior management team of the fund house.\n\nInvesco had purchased 49 per cent stake in March 2013, wherein it was also given an option to further\nincrease its stake before March 2016.\n\nIn the recent past, a number of foreign fund houses have exited the Indian mutual fund market, but in most of\nthose cases, the businesses were acquired by Indian entities. The latest deal, therefore, goes against the\nprevailing trend. PTI BJ SP MR\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nNews\nRuchi Soya, Kagome end India tomato joint venture.\n\nDean Best\n236 words\n23 May 2016\nJust-Food\nJUFOO\nEnglish\n© 2016 Aroq Limited. All rights reserved\nRuchi Soya, the Indian edible oil and soya foods business, and Japanese food and beverage group Kagome\nCo. have agreed to end their tomato products venture in India.\n\nIn a statement to the Bombay Stock Exchange yesterday (22 May), Ruchi Soya said it had sold its stake in\nRuchi Kagome Foods India for INR630m (US$9.3m).\n\nRuchi Soya added it hadentered into a "termination agreement" and a "share purchase agreement" with\nKagome and "other" investors.\n\nTheRuchi Kagome Foods India venture was set up in 2013 after a deal between Ruchi Soya, Kagome and\nJapanese conglomerate Mitsui Co. The agreement saw Ruchi Soya take a 40% stake in the venture, with a\nseparateentity owned by Kagome and Mitsui owning the rest of the business.\n\nThe venture was set up to sell products including "premium" tomato puree, sauces and ketchup.\n\nThe most recent financial results from Ruchi Soya came in February, when the company filed its results for\nthe nine months to the end of December.\n\nRuchi Soya said revenue from food products stood at INR371.8m, down from INR454.9m a year earlier.\n\nHowever, profit before tax and finance costs from each segment rose from INR60.7m to INR242m.\n\nThis article was originally published on just-food.com on 23 May 2016. For authoritative and timely food\nbusiness information visit http://www.just-food.com.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nBUSINESS\nStreparava buys out Indian joint venture partner\n\n202 words\n22 July 2013\nPress Trust of India\nPRTRIN\nEnglish\nCopyright 2013. The Press Trust of India Limited.\nNew Delhi, Jul 22 (PTI) Italian auto component maker Streparava Holding SPA today said it has bought out\nits Indian partner Sansera Engineering from their joint venture that makes engine parts for an undisclosed\namount.\n\nStreparava Holding SPA has now taken over 100 per cent of the equity of Sansera Streparava Engineering\nPvt Ltd, the company said in a statement.\n\nStreparava earlier held 49 per cent equity in the company and the remaining 51 per cent was held by\nSansera Engineering Pvt Ltd, it added.\n\nThe company is located in Bangalore and will now be Streparava\'s wholly-owned Indian venture, it added.\n\n"Streparava is committed to strengthen its presence in India beyond the current range of products being\nproduced in the Bangalore facility to other areas such as driveline and chassis components, in which\nStreparava is a market leader," a Streparava spokesperson said.\n\nThe company, which is also present in various other markets, including Brazil, Spain and China, makes auto\ncomponents, including chassis components and bearing cups, for the commercial vehicle industry.\n\nDelhi-based Tecnova India, a consulting firm specialising in India entry, acted as advisors to the deal. All rights reserved.\n\nSBI drops plan for merchant acquiring biz JV with Visa, Elavon\n\n238 words\n3 January 2012\nThe Press Trust of India Limited\nPRTRIN\nEnglish\n(c) 2012 Asia Pulse Pty Limited.\nNew Delhi, January 03, 2011 (PTI) -- India\'s largest lender State Bank\n\nof India (SBI) today said it has cancelled a proposed merchant acquiring business joint venture with\nUS-based Elavon Incorporation and Visa International.\n\nThe bank has cancelled the negotiations for establishing a joint venture entity with Visa Inc and Elavon Inc for\nconducting the merchant acquiring business, SBI informed the BSE.\n\nThe merchant acquiring business involves facilitation of payments through debit or credit cards at retail\noutlets.\n\nThe RBI had already approved the setting up of a wholly owned subsidiary by SBI in the name of SBI\nPayment Services for conducting the merchant acquiring business.\n\nThe proposed joint venture between SBI Payment Services Pvt Ltd (a wholly owned subsidiary of SBI), Visa\nInc and Elavon Inc was first mooted in 2010, it said.\n\nIn 2009, the bank had floated a Request For Proposal (RFP) for selection of joint venture (JV) partners for the\nmerchant acquiring business.\n\nThe business was to include acquisition of bank identification numbers (BINs) and providing managed\nservices for point-of-sale (PoS) terminals. The managed services would have included deployment of POS\nterminals at customer locations, their replacement, merchant training and maintenance, among others.\n\nState Bank of India Group presently has over 26,000 ATMs across the country and has issued over 80 million\ndebit cards. PTI DP ARV ARV 01031746\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nStar India exits from its home shop business\n\nBS Reporter\n436 words\n5 June 2014\nBusiness Standard\nBSTN\nEnglish\n(c) 2014 Business Standard Ltd.\nStar HS Ltd., an affiliate of media and entertainment conglomerate STAR India, has completed the sale of its\n50% stake in STAR CJ Network India Pvt. Ltd., the home shopping joint venture with Korea\'s CJO Shopping\nCo. Ltd. Star\'s stake has been acquired by Providence Equity Partners LLC.\n\nProvidence is the world\'s leading private equity firm focused on media, communications, education\nandinformation investments. The firm manages funds with $40 billion incommitments and has invested in\nmore than 140 companies globally since its inception in 1989.\n\nUday Shankar, CEO, STAR India said,"STAR CJ provides world class home shopping experiences\ntoconsumers in India and has been a valuable investment for us. We and CJ have enjoyed an excellent\nworking relationship and we expect thisto continue unaffected by the sale." We\nlook forward to working withthe STAR CJ team and adding lasting value to the company in the years ahead."\n\nKim Yun Koo, Executive Vice Presidentof CJ O Shopping said, "STAR India has been a close and valued\npartner for CJ O Shopping in building STAR CJ into a premier homeshopping platform in India. (STARCJ), formed in 2009 as a 50:50\npartnership between STAR and CJ, is apart of CJ O Shopping Co. Ltd. of South Korea, the world\'s\nsecond-largest home shopping network.\n\nSTAR CJ operates a 24x7 homeshopping channel called "STAR CJ alive" and provides a web-based portal\nwww.starcj.com to third party sellers who list their products for sale, reaching more than 50 million\nhouseholds and having added 5 million shoppers to its network within four and a half years of its\noperation.STAR CJ will continue to use STAR\'s brand for up to one year.\n\nKenny Shin, CEO of STAR CJ said "Weare happy to have Providence as our strategic and financial partner.It\nhas been a pleasure and delight to deal with such a highly professional investment firm that shares our vision\nand understanding of the media as well as the home shopping industry.
