All rights reserved.\n\nCorporate\nTata Metaliks Ends Water Pipes JV with Japanese Cos\n\nOUR BUREAU KOLKATA\n545 words\n29 March 2013\nThe Economic Times - Mumbai Edition\nECTMUM\nEnglish\nCopyright © 2013. Bennett, Coleman & Co., Ltd.\nMove seen to be in line with plan to integrate the pipe-making facility with itself\n\nTata Metaliks has ended its joint venture for manufacturing drinking water pipes with Japanese partners,\nKubota and Metal One.\n\nThe move is seen as a prelude to a larger plan towards integrating the pipe-making facility with TML.\n\nThe joint venture, Tata MetaliksKubota Pipes (TMKPL) was incorporated in July 2007 as a 51% subsidiary of\nTML, with the Japanese partners Kubota and Metal One holding 44% and 5% stake, respectively."To start\nwith, TML will acquire 100% stake by buying out its Japanese partners in TMKPL.\n\nAfter which, the pipemaking business will be brought under TML\'s fold.\n\nWe continue to see a lot of prospect in the business," said Harsh Jha, managing director of Tata Metaliks,\nwho is due to retire on Friday."We have separate agreements through which Tata Metaliks will continue to get\ntechnical and international marketing support from Kubota," he added.\n\nWhile there is an obvious tax advantage in the proposed move, TML\'s board is also weighing other options\nfor TMKPL that will attract tax benefits.\n\nThis includes making TMKPL a conversion agent of TML.\n\nA clearer picture may emerge shortly, with the board due to take a call on it in the next three to four\nweeks."The company signed an agreement with Kubota and Metal One on March 25,2013, terminating the\njoint venture agreement being executed from July 20,2007 in relation to Tata MetaliksKubota Pipes,\nsubsidiary of the company," Tata Metaliks said to the BSE.\n\nSEVERE COMPETITION\n\nTMKPL, in which the partners had invested around.185 crore, was affected by severe price competition in\nductile iron (DI) pipes and was upstaged by intense price cutting by regional players in the last four to five\nyears.\n\nHit by low net realisations in an industry facing overcapacity, especially in the eastern region, TMKPL\'s\nmargins suffered."At one point, price of pig iron and DI pipes were at the same level.\n\nThere was no premium on value addition which is absurd.\n\nThe DI pipe market is essentially led by projects.\n\nThere is no concept of marketshare.\n\nThe situation worsened till it became economically unsustainable for a lot of companies that were operating at\nvery low capacity," said an industry analyst.\n\nMINING CRISIS\n\n\n\nPage 2 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nTata Metaliks\' main business, too, has been affected due to irregular supplies of iron ore since the mining\ncrisis broke out in Karnataka and Goa.\n\nIn particular, it was forced to close down operations at its Redi plant at Sindhudurg, Maharashtra in October\n2011.\n\nEarlier this week, it signed a memorandum of settlement with the Tata Metaliks Workers\' Union at Redi in\nrespect of all permanent employees in pursuance of its plans to close down operation there.\n\nPlans to sell off its Redi plant last year suffered after it failed to clinch a deal with the proposed buyer,\nFomento.\n\nSnapping Ties\n\nJV WAS INCORPORATED IN 2007 with Japanese partners Kubota and Metal One holding 44% and 5%\nstake, respectively WHILE THERE IS AN OBVIous tax advantage in the proposed move, TML\'s board is also\nweighing other options for TMKPL that will attract tax benefits\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nFront Page\nFiat goes solo on logistics, snapping last link with Tata\n\n416 words\n8 March 2013\nFinancial Express\nAIWFIE\nEnglish\nCopyright 2013 Indian Express Online Media Pvt. Ltd.\nThe last of the links between Fiat in India and Tata Motors as far as sales and distribution goes has come to\nan end. While Fiat went independent with its sales and dealership network from May 2012, the distribution\nand outbound logistics piece was still being handled by Tata Motors. Fiat\'s dependence on Tata Motor\'s\nnetwork will end in March.\n\nFrom April 1, Fiat Group Automobiles India, Fiat\'s sales and distribution arm, will be switching over to a new\npartner. Fiat has brought in their distribution and logistic partner from Italy to handle their logistics and\ndistribution in India from their plant at Ranjangaon, near Pune. Mercurio Pallia Logistics will take over the\ndistribution logistics of Fiat cars.\n\nMercurio Pallia a joint venture company between Gruppo Mercurio of Italy and Pallia Transport of India.\nGruppo Mercurio is owned by Gefco Logistics. Fiat works with Gefco in Italy and some European markets.\nGefco is a subsidiary of Peugeot of France and is into vehicle transport and distribution business across the\nglobe with a turnover of 3.8 billion euro.\n\nRobert DeCrick, head, supply chain management (APAC), Fiat Chrysler, said, "They chose to go with an\nexpert in the business rather than doing it themselves. This is not about fencing some agriculture land and\nstarting to park on it. Unlike the car yards in India, the new Fiat stockyard was built on a solid surface with\nsafety and security that ensure a better quality car was delivered to the customer. The yard also used IT\nextensively to offer better visibility for the dealership from invoice to delivery at the dealerships."\n\nOn whether this investment in logistics would put an additional burden on the comapny\'s costs, DeCrick said\nthey did not view logistics as cost but as a key part of their business.\n\nThe new logistics partner will be able to handle customer demands better and with the use of technology\ndealers will he happier as they will be able to track their supplies from invoice to the delivery of cars at their\ndealerships, DeCrick said.\n\nAs of now Fiat has 25 dealerships and is adding six nee dealership in two weeks. The target is to reach 110\ndealerships by December 2013. Fiat earlier had a network of 170 dealers through Tata Motors. Though the\nsix year sales tie-up has ended, the manufacturing JV between Tata Motors and Fiat India remains intact.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nBUSINESS\nRBI clears way for Tatas to buy back from DOCOMO\n\nSpecial Correspondent\n231 words\n15 January 2015\nThe Hindu\nTHINDU\nEnglish\n(c) 2015 Kasturi & Sons Ltd\nMUMBAI,BUSINESS The Tatas are close to buying back NTT DOCOMO’s 26.5 per cent stake in Tata\nTeleservices Ltd (TTSL) at an earlier agreed upon price of Rs.7,250 crore as the Reserve Bank of India (RBI)\nis understood to have relaxed its fair value pricing norm as a special case to enable them to honour their\ncommitment made to the Japanese company. The easing of norms comes following enhanced business ties\nbetween India and Japan.\n\nThe RBI’s fair value pricing norm does not allow companies to buy back shares at more price than the fair\nmarket value, and this is why the Tata- NTT DOCOMO deal could not be completed despite several notices\nfrom NTT DOCOMO and even the Japanese company initiating arbitration proceedings against Tata Sons\nand TTSL in London to recover its money. “Tata Sons has made the necessary application to the Reserve\nBank of India. The company is awaiting a response,” a Tata Sons spokesperson said while responding to\nqueries.\n\nIn March, 2009, NTT DOCOMO had invested $2.22 billion in TTSL to pick up 26.5 per cent stake. The\nshareholder’s agreement had guaranteed it at least 50 per cent of the investment if it wished to exit in case of\nTTSL failing to meet certain performance targets.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nCorporate\nPE Firm Actis to Exit Road JV with Tatas\n\nARIJIT BARMAN MUMBAI\n657 words\n17 May 2013\nThe Economic Times - Mumbai Edition\nECTMUM\nEnglish\nCopyright © 2013. Bennett, Coleman & Co., Ltd.\nTata Opportunity Fund to buy out the PE firm in the JV and form an infra entity that will, to start with, acquire\nthree road projects of IVRCL\n\nThree years after private equity firm Actis and the Tata Group formed a $200-million JV - with an ambitious\nplan to spend ten times of that sum in building roads over five years - the venture is coming to an end.\n\nActis is set to pull out of the JV and the Tatas have agreed to buy them out, said multiple sources aware of\nthe ongoing transaction.\n\nCurrently, Tata Realty & Infrastructure (TRIL), a 100% subsidiary of Tata Sons, owns 65% of the venture\ncalled TRIL Roads while Actis owns the rest.\n\nTRIL was Tata Sons\' initial vehicle for its foray into infrastructure and real estate development.\n\nThe Tata-Actis disengagement is likely to conclude within a month."Actis will make a marginal return on its\ninvestments.\n\nIts focus has moved away from roads into power generation and distribution and it will continue to focus on\nthese sectors through its infrastructure funds.\n\nThis will be an amenable exit," said an official.\n\nActis\' exit is being facilitated by another Tata Group entity, Tata Opportunities Fund (TOF), the group\'s\ncaptive PE fund which will buy them out.\n\nActis PE\'s India head JM Trivedi could not be reached for comments.\n\nSpokespersons from Tata Groups\' external media agency Rediffusion did not respond to ET\'s detailed\nquestionnaire.\n\nLondon headquartered Actis - which was spun off from the Commonwealth Development Corporation nine\nyears ago - had invested $77.5 million (.345 crore) for its minority stake, in what was then its first investment\nin the Indian infrastructure space.\n\nThis money was deployed from its $750-million (.3,333 crore) emerging markets focussed infrastructure fund.\n\nClose to 30% of the fund\'s proceeds were initially earmarked for India.\n\nDespite its initial ambitious plans, TRIL Roads and Actis has till date built only one project, the 110-km\nPune-Solapur highway with Italian company Atlantia SpA as its technical partner, for.1,371 crore.\n\nBut with TOF on board, TRIL Roads plans to pursue inorganic opportunities in the sector.\n\nTRIL-TOF TO BUY 3 IVRCL ROAD PROJECTS\n\nTo start with, it is already in negotiations to buy the three road projects of cash-strapped infrastructutre\ncompany IVRCL - Salem Tollways, Kumarapalayam Tollways and Changapally-Wallayar Tollways.\n\nThe three roads have been built on an estimated cost of.2,200 crore.\n\n\n\nPage 2 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nIn April this year, IVRCL entered into an agreement with TRIL Roads to transfer control in these three road\nprojects, in an effort to monetise its build-operate-transfer assets.\n\nBut in accordance with the terms of the concession agreement, TRIL Roads will separately buy 74% in Salem\nand Kumarapalayam Tollways as they are already operational.\n\nIVRCL will continue with a 26% exposure.\n\nHowever, for the Changapally-Wallayar Tollways, initially TRIL Roads will pick up only 49% and upon\ncompletion of the project in the next five months, it will hike its stake to 74%.\n\nAfter two years, IVRCL will exit entirely as the model concession agreement signed post 2009 allows it to do\nso.\n\nConcessional agreement signed before 2009 requires the original promoter to hold a minimum 26%."We\nhave all the necessary approvals from NHAI.\n\nWe are just awaiting the lenders nod.\n\nWe hope to conclude the deal in the next 45 days," said S Ramachandran, director, IVRCL Infrastructures &\nProjects.\n\nTatas will be shelling out around.425 crore as equity for the IVRCL deal, while.2,200 crore of debt and other\nliabilities will get transferred to them."One good thing about the three roads is that by FY14, all three are\nexpected to achieve breakeven.\n\nBut these are just four-lane state highways with moderate traffic growth projections," said Abhinav Bhandari,\ninfrastructure analyst at Elara Capital.arijit.barman@timesgroup.com\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nIndian billionaire Dilip Shanghvi drops plans to form payments bank with IDFC, Telenor\n\n199 words\n20 May 2016\n18:50\nReuters News\nLBA\nEnglish\nCopyright 2016 Thomson Reuters. All Rights Reserved.\nMUMBAI, May 20 (Reuters) - India\'s second richest man, Dilip Shanghvi, said on Friday he had shelved plans\nto form a payments bank jointly with the Indian financial firm IDFC Bank and an arm of Norway\'s Telenor, but\ndid not disclose the reason.\n\nShanghvi\'s company, Dilip Shanghvi Family and Associates, was among 11 firms that were awarded licences\nlast August to set up niche "payments banks" aimed at granting millions of Indians access to basic banking.\n\nThe banks are a part of India\'s financial inclusion push and are meant to expand banking services in a\ncountry where less than half of the adult population holds a bank account.\n\nShanghvi, who is the founder and head of India\'s largest drugmaker Sun Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd, said\nhe had worked with IDFC and Telenor over the past eight months to make a framework and governance\nstructure for the joint venture.\n\n"Following the mutual decision to withdraw these plans, the payment bank license will not be pursued,"\nShanghvi said in a statement.\n\n(Reporting by Zeba Siddiqui in Mumbai, editing by David Evans)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nFront Page\nUnitech settles dispute with Telenor, to exit JV\n\n389 words\n12 October 2012\nFinancial Express\nAIWFIE\nEnglish\nCopyright 2012 Indian Express Online Media Pvt. Ltd.\nNorwegian telecom operator Telenor and India\'s real estate firm Unitech on Thursday agreed to settle all their\ndisputes amicably by withdrawing all the cases slapped against each other.\n\nThe development brings to an end the long-drawn out dispute between the two since the Supreme Court\ncancelled their JV firm Uninor\'s 22 licences in its February 2 order. Under the terms of agreement while\nUnitech, which holds 32.75%, will exit the JV upon receiving payment of a nominal amount, Telenor would be\nable to transfer all assets of Uninor to a new company and bid in the upcoming 2G spectrum auction.\n\nTelenor would be free to get a new Indian partner to meet the mandatory 26% stake by an Indian firm in a\ntelecom services company. However, Unitech would continue to retain economic rights in the company as per\nits current shareholding. This means that if any benefits accrue to the firm in terms of refund of licence fees of\ntaxes, Unitech would be entitled to them as per its shareholding.\n\nThe two parties also informed the Delhi High Court on Thursday that they have resolved their disputes\namicably.\n\nTelenor had bought 67.25% stake in Unitech Wireless (Uninor) in 2008 for R6,120 crore.\n\n"Telenor and Unitech are pleased to announce that on October 10, 2012, they have reached an agreement to\namicably settle all disputes between the two parties. The parties are bound by confidentiality obligations, and\nare, therefore, not able to provide any further comments on specific terms and conditions of the settlement.\nHowever, it can be confirmed that the parties agree to support the transfer of the business in Unitech\nWireless (Uninor) to a new entity controlled by Telenor," the statement issued by the two sides said.\n\nWith immediate effect, Unitech would withdraw all its nominees from Uninor\'s board and all its special\nshareholder rights will stand suspended.\n\nAs for Unitech, with the settlement of disputes with Telenor, the realty firm will focus on its core business of\nreal estate. "We are pleased with the settlement reached between Unitech and Telenor. All existing disputes\nwith Telenor are suspended and will be withdrawn upon successful transfer of business of Uninor to a new\nentity controlled by Telenor," Unitech chairman Ramesh Chandra said.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nFT.com site : Tesco ends talks on India joint venture.\n\nElizabeth Rigby and Nayantara Rai in London\n295 words\n24 November 2006\nFinancial Times (FT.Com)\nFTCOM\nEnglish\n(c) 2006 The Financial Times Limited. All rights reserved\nTesco of the UK admitted on Friday that its plan to be the first multinational supermarket retailer in India has\nunravelled.\n\nThe world\'s fifth-biggest supermarket chain said it had ended talks with Bharti Enterprises to set up a joint\nventure in India\'s GBP145bn-a-year ($280bn) retail sector after discussions failed.\n\nIt now looks like Wal-Mart, the biggest global retailer, could lead the advance into the world\'s eighth-largest\nretail market.\n\nSunil Mittal, the telecommunications tycoon who controls Bharti, refused to be drawn on his negotiations with\nTesco.\n\n"We will make an announcement shortly on a global partner for our retail foray," he told the Financial Times.\n\nTesco, Carrefour and Wal-Mart have been linked to Bharti, but it appears that only the US chain is still in the\nrace.\n\nIt is thought that the Tesco-Bharti deal fell apart in the final stages of the talks after the two parties failed to\nfind common ground on the pace of expansion, with Bharti opting for a more aggressive opening programme\nthan Tesco envisaged.\n\nTesco is also thought to have felt frustrated by leaks about the talks.\n\nUnder Indian rules, no foreign direct investment is allowed in the retail sector, except for single-brand stores,\nwhich means big groups have to sign a franchise or licensing agreement with local companies.\n\nIndia is on track to become the fifth-biggest retail market by 2010, according to McKinsey. Organised retailing\nmakes up 3 per cent of the market, giving big chains scope to expand.\n\nConfirming that it had walked away from discussions with Bharti, Tesco said: "We remain excited by the\nopportunities available in India."\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nCompanies\nTitagarh Wagons-FreightCar America dissolve Indian JV\n\nP. R. Sanjai\n252 words\n23 February 2013\nMint\nHNMINT\nEnglish\nCopyright 2013. HT Media Limited. All rights reserved.\nMumbai, Feb. 23 -- Wgaon manufacturing company Titagarh Wagons Ltd (TWL) and FreightCar America Inc.\n(FCA), on Saturday, said they have agreed to wind up and dissolve their Indian joint venture company.\n\nThe joint venture company, Titagarh FreightCar Pvt. Ltd, was incorporated in India pursuant to a 2008\njoint-venture agreement between the parties with the objective of manufacturing and selling aluminium\ncoal-carrying rail wagons in India.\n\nSoon after its incorporation, the joint venture company had begun the process of obtaining approval from the\nIndian Railways-Research Designs and Standards Organisation (RDSO) for aluminium wagon designs\nadapted for use on the Indian rail system, TWL said in stock exchange filing.\n\nHowever, they said that over time it became clear that approval from the RDSO would not be obtained in an\nacceptable time-frame.\n\n"The joint venture company formally notified the RDSO in June 2012 that it would not further pursue its\nrequest for design approval," the statement said.\n\n"We had big plans for the joint venture company when it was incorporated in 2008. However, those plans\nwere not realized despite considerable effort. After lengthy discussions, Titagarh Wagons and FreightCar\nAmerica have decided to dissolve the joint venture company and part ways amicably," said Umesh\nChowdhary, vice-chairman and managing director of TWL.Published by HT Syndication with permission from\nMINT.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nBharti Airtel acquires 49% in Qualcomm India for Rs 907 cr\n\nBS Reporter New Delhi\n902 words\n25 May 2012\nBusiness Standard\nBSTN\n1\nEnglish\n(c) 2012 Business Standard Ltd.\nEnterprise valued at Rs 6,000 cr; Bharti can offer 4G services in key Mumbai, Delhi circles\n\nBharti Airtel, the country’s largest mobile operator, today announced the acquisition of 49 per cent stake in\nUS telecom major Qualcomm Inc’s broadband wireless access (BWA) company in India for an initial\ninvestment of $165 million (Rs 907 crore).\n\nWith this move, Bharti Airtel will become a key player in the 4G LTE market, with a presence in eight of the 22\ncircles in the country. The acquisition of Qualcomm’s licence is crucial, as it will give Bharti an entry into four\nkey circles: the lucrative Delhi and Mumbai markets as well as Haryana and Kerala. Bharti, on its own, has\n4G spectrum in four circles, including Kolkata, where it has already launched services, Karnataka, Punjab\nand Maharashtra.\n\nUnder the agreement, Bharti will acquire the 13 per cent each held by Global Holding Corporation Private Ltd\n(part of the GTL group) and Tulip Telecom Ltd, to whom it is paying around Rs 140 crore each. The premium\nthe two investors will earn from the deal comes to an annualised return of around 28 per cent on their\ninvestment. The balance equity has been bought by way of subscription of fresh equity in the entity. The deal\nalso contemplates that once commercial operations are launched, subject to certain terms and conditions\nbeing met, Bharti would also pick up the remaining 51 per cent stake by May 2014.\n\nQualcomm had forked out Rs 4,912 crore to win the BWA licence and paid the money through a combination\nof debt and equity. That included about Rs 1,000 crore in equity and the rest through debt. The interest on the\ndebt for the last two years that the company forked out while waiting for spectrum comes to around Rs 1,000\ncrore. Based on this, the enterprise value of the company stands around Rs 6,000 crore. Barclays was\nmandated by Qualcomm to structure the deal.\n\nThe US company received its spectrum just a few weeks ago after a bitter battle with the DoT (Department of\nTelecommunications) and after it moved the TDSAT following a delay of nearly two years. The DoT gave it\nthe spectrum but with the licence period reduced from 20 years to 18.5. The roll-out obligation time was also\nreduced from five years to three and a half.\n\nCommenting on the deal, Sunil Bharti Mittal, chairman and managing director, Bharti Airtel, said, “This\npartnership will combine the strength of Bharti’s national telecom footprint and Qualcomm’s technological\nleadership in the LTE TDD space. With a broadband-ready network across India, Bharti is well positioned to\nlead the next phase of Indian’s telecom revolution.” Apart from 4G, Bharti has 3G services in 13 circles. Bharti\nadded in its press release that with the deal, “it secured nationwide broadband leadership through a\ncombination of 4G and 3G, with its own networks in 18 circles”.\n\n“One of our key objectives has been to include a strong partner in the Indian venture with the scale,\nexperience and resources to deploy LTE TDD networks. We are pleased to have Bharti’s participation and\nsupport in this effort,” said Paul E Jacobs, chairman and CEO of Qualcomm.\n\nTulip Telecom chairman H S Bedi confirmed his company had been paid Rs 140 crore for the 13 per cent\nstake. “Yes, we have been paid Rs 140 crore, which is at a premium to what we had spent.” Asked how the\nRs 410 crore that Qualcomm has paid to the DoT on Tulip Telecom’s behalf for disputed dues, as directed by\nthe TDSAT, Bedi said, “We had an agreement with Qualcomm that only after we had exhausted all options\nand not found a remedy would we pay the money back. However, I am confident this is an erroneous demand\nby the DoT.”\n\n\n\nPage 2 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nAccording to top sources, Bharti has also been talking to Aircel for an alliance in the BWA space, which could\ninclude using its network to get into seven more circles. According to sources, the circles that have been\nidentified include Andhra Pradesh, Assam, Bihar, the north-east, Odisha, Tamil Nadu and West Bengal.\n\nDepending on the final policy and judgments on whether inter-circle roaming would be deemed legal, the\nmove could help Bharti become a pan-India 4G player, with presence in 15 circles. That would bring it head\nto head with the only other pan-India player, Reliance Infotel, which is preparing for a major launch by the end\nof this year. Bharti, however, said it would not like to comment on speculation. Aircel did not comment.\n\nQualcomm had made it public it would not like to get into the services business and would divest stake to\npartners. Its main interest in bidding for BWA spectrum was to ensure operators used it to launch services on\nLTE, a technology it has been backing over Wimax.\n\nThe US company’s main interest is to make money by selling chipsets for 4G devices. The company is\nworking on chipsets that will support devices to seamlessly move between 2G, 3G and 4G without the\ncustomer realising the change. Qualcomm expects to provide technical assistance to Bharti in connection\nwith network architecture and optimisation, infrastructure and device testing.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nBharti Airtel acquires 49% in Qualcomm India for Rs 907 cr\n\nBS Reporter New Delhi\n902 words\n25 May 2012\nBusiness Standard\nBSTN\n1\nEnglish\n(c) 2012 Business Standard Ltd.\nEnterprise valued at Rs 6,000 cr; Bharti can offer 4G services in key Mumbai, Delhi circles\n\nBharti Airtel, the country’s largest mobile operator, today announced the acquisition of 49 per cent stake in\nUS telecom major Qualcomm Inc’s broadband wireless access (BWA) company in India for an initial\ninvestment of $165 million (Rs 907 crore).\n\nWith this move, Bharti Airtel will become a key player in the 4G LTE market, with a presence in eight of the 22\ncircles in the country. The acquisition of Qualcomm’s licence is crucial, as it will give Bharti an entry into four\nkey circles: the lucrative Delhi and Mumbai markets as well as Haryana and Kerala. Bharti, on its own, has\n4G spectrum in four circles, including Kolkata, where it has already launched services, Karnataka, Punjab\nand Maharashtra.\n\nUnder the agreement, Bharti will acquire the 13 per cent each held by Global Holding Corporation Private Ltd\n(part of the GTL group) and Tulip Telecom Ltd, to whom it is paying around Rs 140 crore each. The premium\nthe two investors will earn from the deal comes to an annualised return of around 28 per cent on their\ninvestment. The balance equity has been bought by way of subscription of fresh equity in the entity. The deal\nalso contemplates that once commercial operations are launched, subject to certain terms and conditions\nbeing met, Bharti would also pick up the remaining 51 per cent stake by May 2014.\n\nQualcomm had forked out Rs 4,912 crore to win the BWA licence and paid the money through a combination\nof debt and equity. That included about Rs 1,000 crore in equity and the rest through debt. The interest on the\ndebt for the last two years that the company forked out while waiting for spectrum comes to around Rs 1,000\ncrore. Based on this, the enterprise value of the company stands around Rs 6,000 crore. Barclays was\nmandated by Qualcomm to structure the deal.\n\nThe US company received its spectrum just a few weeks ago after a bitter battle with the DoT (Department of\nTelecommunications) and after it moved the TDSAT following a delay of nearly two years. The DoT gave it\nthe spectrum but with the licence period reduced from 20 years to 18.5. The roll-out obligation time was also\nreduced from five years to three and a half.\n\nCommenting on the deal, Sunil Bharti Mittal, chairman and managing director, Bharti Airtel, said, “This\npartnership will combine the strength of Bharti’s national telecom footprint and Qualcomm’s technological\nleadership in the LTE TDD space. With a broadband-ready network across India, Bharti is well positioned to\nlead the next phase of Indian’s telecom revolution.” Apart from 4G, Bharti has 3G services in 13 circles. Bharti\nadded in its press release that with the deal, “it secured nationwide broadband leadership through a\ncombination of 4G and 3G, with its own networks in 18 circles”.\n\n“One of our key objectives has been to include a strong partner in the Indian venture with the scale,\nexperience and resources to deploy LTE TDD networks. We are pleased to have Bharti’s participation and\nsupport in this effort,” said Paul E Jacobs, chairman and CEO of Qualcomm.\n\nTulip Telecom chairman H S Bedi confirmed his company had been paid Rs 140 crore for the 13 per cent\nstake. “Yes, we have been paid Rs 140 crore, which is at a premium to what we had spent.” Asked how the\nRs 410 crore that Qualcomm has paid to the DoT on Tulip Telecom’s behalf for disputed dues, as directed by\nthe TDSAT, Bedi said, “We had an agreement with Qualcomm that only after we had exhausted all options\nand not found a remedy would we pay the money back. However, I am confident this is an erroneous demand\nby the DoT.”\n\n\n\nPage 2 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nAccording to top sources, Bharti has also been talking to Aircel for an alliance in the BWA space, which could\ninclude using its network to get into seven more circles. According to sources, the circles that have been\nidentified include Andhra Pradesh, Assam, Bihar, the north-east, Odisha, Tamil Nadu and West Bengal.\n\nDepending on the final policy and judgments on whether inter-circle roaming would be deemed legal, the\nmove could help Bharti become a pan-India 4G player, with presence in 15 circles. That would bring it head\nto head with the only other pan-India player, Reliance Infotel, which is preparing for a major launch by the end\nof this year. Bharti, however, said it would not like to comment on speculation. Aircel did not comment.\n\nQualcomm had made it public it would not like to get into the services business and would divest stake to\npartners. Its main interest in bidding for BWA spectrum was to ensure operators used it to launch services on\nLTE, a technology it has been backing over Wimax.\n\nThe US company’s main interest is to make money by selling chipsets for 4G devices. The company is\nworking on chipsets that will support devices to seamlessly move between 2G, 3G and 4G without the\ncustomer realising the change. Qualcomm expects to provide technical assistance to Bharti in connection\nwith network architecture and optimisation, infrastructure and device testing.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nVarroc sheds its stake in JV\n\nSatnam Singh\n282 words\n24 September 2012\nPlastics News\nPLCN\n4\nVolume 24; Number 28\nEnglish\n(c) 2012 Crain Communications, Inc. All rights reserved.\nIndian auto parts supplier Varroc Group and France’s Cie. Plastic Omnium SA have ended their joint venture\nin India, and now Varroc is moving forward with its own expansion plans.\n\nAurangabad-based Varroc sold its 46 percent stake in the auto exterior venture to Levallois, France-based\nOmnium.\n\nThe joint venture, Plastic Omnium Varroc Pvt. Ltd., has operated in Chakan, India, since 2007.\n\n“We have amicably decided to grow on our own in the growing Indian automobile market,” said M.P. Sharma,\nVarroc’s vice president for material and projects, in a telephone interview.\n\nDetails on the buyout were finalized in mid-August, he said. Terms were not disclosed.\n\nNow Varroc is expanding its polymer division by setting up three new facilities in different parts of India to\ncater to the various automobile hubs, according to Sharma.\n\nThe company is investing around $20 million in the plants. The first, in Pithampur, will start production in\nOctober. The plant — Varroc’s eighth plastics operation — will supply Mahindra & Mahindra and VE\nCommercial Vehicles Ltd.\n\nThe plant, on a 121/2-acre site, has injection presses ranging from 450-850 tons of clamping force.\n\nThe second plant, in Bangalore, will open next year. It will supply Honda Motorcycle & Scooters India (HMSI)\nand automotive plants around Bangalore, Sharma said.\n\nThe third plant, in Chennai, will open in 2014 and serve the fast-growing automotive hub in that region, he\nsaid.\n\nIn August, Varroc bought Visteon Corp.’s global lighting business. That business has 4,200 employees at\nplants in Monterrey, Mexico; Pune, India; and two sites in Czech Republic — Nový Jicín and Rychvald.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nEssar exits Vodafone-Essar JV for USD 5 billion\n\n429 words\n31 March 2011\n21:10\nOrganisation of Asia-Pacific News Agencies\nOANA\nEnglish\n© Copyright 2011. OANA. All rights reserved.\nNew Delhi (PTI) Putting an end to the\n\ncorporate battle, UK-based Vodafone Thursday announced it\n\nwould exercise the option to acquire its Indian partner\n\nEssar\'s 33 per cent stake which will result in payment of USD\n\nfive billion.\n\nWith this, Vodafone may have to look for another\n\ndomestic partner to remain compliant with the FDI norms in the\n\ntelecom sector of a maximum stake of 74 per cent.\n\n"Vodafone Group announces that the Essar Group has\n\nexercised its underwritten put option over 22 per cent of\n\nVodafone Essar Limited (VEL).\n"Following the exercise by the Essar Group of its put\n\noption, Vodafone has exercised its call option over the\n\nremaining 11 per cent of VEL owned by the Essar Group,\n\nresulting in a total cash payment of USD 5 billion," Vodafone\n\nsaid in a statement.\n\nCall Option allows an investor the right but not the\n\nobligation to buy a stock, bond, commodity or other instrument\n\nat a specified price within a specific time period.\n\nOn the other hand, Put Option is an option contract\n\ngiving the owner the right but not the obligation to sell a\n\nspecified amount of an underlying security at a specified\n\nprice within a specified time.\n\nWith this, Essar will exit completely from the joint\n\nventure, which is offering nationwide mobile services in\n\nIndia. Vodafone has over 130 million subscribers and is the\n\nthird largest operator in India.\nPage 2 of 2 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nVodafone also said that final settlement is\n\nanticipated to be completed by November, 2011.\n\nSources in the know said that the completion of deal\n\nwould be subject to meeting certain conditions which include\n\nReserve Bank of India\'s permission as well as valuation of the\n\ndeal.\n\nThe final shareholding pattern post this deal was not\n\nprovided by the company as it was not clear whether\n\nVodafone\'s stake would exceed the 74 per cent FDI limit.\n\nVodafone had entered Indian market in 2007 when it\n\nbought Hutchison\'s stake in the joint venture for over USD 11\n\nbillion and after that it had entered into an agreement with\n\nEssar for a call and put option for its stake.\n\nThe two firms were locked in battle over Essar\'s plan\n\nto list a firm that had part stake in the joint venture to\n\nfind out market value of its 33 per cent stake.\n\nThe move was opposed by Vodafone saying this may not\n\ngive true value of Vodafone\'s stake. It had approached the\n\nmarket regulator SEBI and also filed a petition in the Madras\n\nHigh Court.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nVOLTAS TO EXIT SERMO-PM VENTURE FULLY (Voltas no longer considers Sermo-PM a part of its\ncore business)\n\nEconomic Times. All rights reserved.\nRESOURCES CONSTRUCTION giant Leighton Holdings has struck a multi-million dollar deal to buy out in\nfull its Indian-based joint venture, Leighton Welspun.\n\nLeighton said yesterday it had bought the Welspun Group’s 39.9 per cent stake for $US99 million ($112\nmillion).\n\nThe move will give Leighton 100 per cent ownership of the joint venture, which was set up in 2010 to tap into\nopportunities in India’s infrastructure sector.\n\nThe business will be renamed Leighton India.\n\n“Leighton continues to see strong long-term prospects in the Indian market,” the construction and mining\ngroup said yesterday.\n\nThe company said the opportunity to buy out the venture came on the back of a decision by Welspun to\nreposition its infrastructure business and focus on its other activities, which include textiles, pipes energy and\nsteel.\n\nLeighton said it will review the operations of Leighton India and consider integrating several business units to\nlower costs.\n\nThe company said its 2013 underlying profit would not be affected by the transaction, which is expected to be\ncompleted in the first quarter of 2014.\nLeighton’s forecast underlying profit remains at $520 million to $600 million. Leighton shares closed 1.1 per\ncent down at $16.08.with AAP\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. The\njoint venture, WMNetServ, was signed in 2006 between the two companies with Wipro holding majority stake.\n\nWNNetServ, headquartered in Europe with a branch office in London and development centres in Bangalore\nand New Delhi, was formed to offer services such as network planning and deployment, network optimisation,\nsecurity, operations and support among others. Wipro will buy out Motorola’s stake in the deal. The\njoint venture, WMNetServ, was signed in 2006 between the two companies with Wipro holding majority stake.\n\nWNNetServ, headquartered in Europe with a branch office in London and development centres in Bangalore\nand New Delhi, was formed to offer services such as network planning and deployment, network optimisation,\nsecurity, operations and support among others. But the deal did not see any great value addition, said Wipro,\nin a press communication.\n\nMr Sudip Nandy, President - Technology, Communications and Telecom Vertical, Wipro Technologies, said:\n“Wipro and Motorola will continue to work closely in the engineering space. ”–\n\nOur Bureau\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage 1 of 1 © 2020 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nWipro of India acquires Motorola stake in JV WMNetServ, provider of network engineering services\nAnnounced Date: 6/16/2008 Wipro Technologies, the global IT arm of India\'s Wipro Limited, has\nannounced that it has exited its joint venture with Motorola. Wipro and Motorola formed the joint\nventure - WMNetServ - in 2006, with Wipro holding the majority stake.\n\n126 words\n19 June 2008\nOptical Networks Daily\nOBSERV\nEnglish\n(c) 2008 Electronics International Disclaimer: Whilst every effort has been taken to ensure the accuracy of the\ninformation contained in this report, neither Electronics International nor its agents or sources can be held\nresponsible for any inaccuracy.\nWipro stated that it has acquired 100% of Motorola\'s stake in the venture, adding that the two companies\nwould continue to collaborate in the engineering space.\n\nWMNetServ focuses on delivering network engineering services to equipment vendors and wireless\noperators worldwide. It operates a framework for remote delivery of network services such as network\nplanning and design and network optimisation.\n\nFor further information go to http://www.opticalkeyhole.com\n'

'\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nReliance Cap to buy AMP Sanmar for Rs   crore ; Reliance Capital will acquire AMP Sanmar Life\nInsurance Company for...\n\nFRENY PATEL & KAUSIK DATTA Mumbai\n  words\n  August  \nBusiness Standard\nBSTN\n \nEnglish\n(c)   Business Standard Ltd.\nReliance Capital will acquire AMP Sanmar Life Insurance Company for Rs   crore. Since the\nChennai-based life insurance entity has net free assets of Rs  -  crore, Reliance Cap will pay a premium\nof Rs  -  crore.\n\nNet free assets essentially denote the book value of an insurance company, calculated after deducting losses\nfrom its share capital. AMP Sanmar has a capital base of Rs  .  crore.\n\nThe non-banking finance arm of the Anil Dhirubhai Ambani Enterprise (ADAE) had initially decided to acquire\nAMP Sanmar through Reliance Life Insurance Company. But it was not possible as Reliance Life Insurance\nwas not a legal entity since it did not have a licence from the Insurance Regulatory and Development\nAuthority (IRDA).\n\nIRDA Chairman CS Rao told Business Standard since Reliance Life Insurance was not a legal entity, it could\nnot acquire AMP Sanmar. "It is important for Reliance to identify the acquirer as the next step will be the due\ndiligence exercise to be undertaken by the insurance regulator," he added. Declining to comment on the\nactual value of the deal, Graham Meyer, AMP Sanmar CEO, said it had not been a distress sale.\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nBANKING/FINANCE\nAMP Sanmar Life is now Reliance Life\n\nOur Bureau\n  words\n  February  \nBusiness Line (The Hindu)\nBSNLNE\n \nEnglish\n(c)   The Hindu Business Line\nHyderabad , Feb.  \n\nCONSEQUENT to the acquisition by Reliance Capital Ltdof the entire equity capital of AMP of Australia and\nSanmar Group in AMP Sanmar Life Insurance Co Ltd , the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority\n(IRDA) has taken note of the change of company name, `AMP Sanmar Life Insurance Co Ltd\', to that of\nReliance Life Insurance Co Ltd (RLICL) and the fresh certificate of incorporation consequent to change of\nname issued by the Registrar of Companies, Tamil Nadu, dated January  .\n\nThe insurance regulator said it had permitted RLICL to carry on life insurance business in India subject to the\ncondition that RLICL should honour its commitments to the policyholders of AMP Sanmar Life Insurance on\nthe same terms and conditions subject to which they were issued.\n\nFurther, the regulator said in a notice here that RLICL should take necessary steps to protect the interests of\nthe policyholders in accordance with the provisions of IRDA Act   and Insurance Act  .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nMax Hypermarkets, Auchan end ties\n\nRaghavendra Kamath\n  words\n  August  \nBusiness Standard\nBSTN\nEnglish\n(c)   Business Standard Ltd.\nMax Hypermarkets, part of Dubai\'s Landmark Group, and French retailer Groupe Auchan have ended their\ntwo year old licence agreement in India.\n\nThe failure to convert that agreement into a joint venture is the reason for ending the relationship, Max\nHypermarkets said today.\n\n"Max Hypermarkets and Groupe Auchan continued deep into   to look into the possibilities of creating a\njoint venture to facilitate Groupe Auchan investment in India, which could comply with Indian FDI regulations.\nDespite their best efforts, the parties could not facilitate this proposition," Max said in a statement.\n\n"Therefore, by common agreement, the   Max Hypermarkets will no longer operate under the Auchan\nbanner by January   at the latest," it said\n\nThis is the second break-up for Max as it ended its ties with Dutch retailer Spar International in May  .\nAfter tying up with Auchan, Max rebranded its existing \'SPAR\' stores in Bangalore and Mangalore to\n\'Auchan\'.\n\nIn September  , the UPA government allowed foreign direct investment in multi brand retail subject to\napproval of respective states. Barring UK-based Tesco, none of the foreign chains has applied for FDI in multi\nbrand retail so far.\n\nMax Hypermarket is committed to growth and development of the hypermarket and supermarket business in\nIndia and will continue its investments under a new brand name, the Bangalore based company said.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nRetail\nWalmart Stores spent $  mn to end its deal with Bharti Enterprises, resulting in a net loss of $ \nmn\n\nRasul Bailay & Sagar Malviya\n  words\n  April  \nThe Economic Times\nECTIM\nEnglish\n(c)   The Times of India Group. All rights reserved.\nNEW DELHI | MUMBAI: Walmart Stores spent $  million (Rs ,  crore at current rates) to end its\nhigh-profile retail partnership with Bharti Enterprises, resulting in a net loss of $  million (Rs .  crore)\naccruing to the US company’s consolidated income in  .\n\nWhile the world’s largest retailer paid $  million (Rs  crore) to acquire Bharti’s stake in its India\nwholesale joint venture and go solo, it also took a $ -million (Rs ,  crore) hit that included debt and\nother investments in back-end partner Bharti Retail that it waived as part of the October   separation,\naccording to its annual report issued last week.\n\nWalmart paid the $  million to acquire Bharti Enterprises’  % stake in the erstwhile Bharti Walmart Pvt Ltd\nthat ran   Best Price-branded cash-andcarry stores. It was widely speculated that Walmart had\ncompensated Bharti well to call off their six-year-old alliance but this is the first time the amount of money the\nUS company paid to end its India equal JV has come to light. Bharti officials couldn’t be reached immediately\nfor comment. Walmart India said it had nothing to add to the information already disclosed.\n\nET reported previously that it cost Walmart around Rs ,  crore to purchase Bharti’s stake in the joint\nventure. After going well for the first four years since its inception in  , the Bharti-Walmart alliance turned\nrocky in the last two as the US firm focused attention on an internal probe to check if the unit had in any way\nviolated US anti-bribery laws.\n\nBharti, Walmart Trying to Expand Independently\n\nScott Price, Walmart’s Asia head who has now been elevated to a global role, told ET in an interview earlier\nthis month that the two partners had an "amicable" end to their six-year alliance. The two-year probe carried\nout by independent investigators, including US law firm Greenberg Traurig and consulting firm KPMG,\nprompted Bharti-Walmart to stall all expansion, suspend or sack top officials and ultimately drove a wedge\nbetween the partners.\n\nWalmart was intent on making sure that it hadn’t committed any violations of the US Foreign Corrupt\nPractices Act, which outlaws bribes to foreign government officials by US-listed entities to run or secure\nbusinesses.\n\nThis followed a corruption scandal in Mexico, where company officials allegedly paid tens of millions of dollars\nin bribes to local officials to expand faster in the biggest foreign market for Walmart. After the Mexico episode,\nWalmart started investigating global operations including India and China. Walmart faced other difficulties in\nIndia as well. The Bentonville-based retail giant was hounded by Indian politicians for what was construed as\nlobbying to get India to open multi-brand retail to global supermarket chains.\n\nIt also came under attack for its $ -million investment in Bharti Retail’s holding firm in   at a time India\nbarred any sort of overseas investment in multi-brand retail. Politicians alleged that Walmart broke India’s\nforeign exchange laws through what they called illegal and indirect capital infinfusion into Bharti Retail, which\nran a nationwide network of Easyday stores. Subsequently, India would change its rules to allow foreign\ndirect investment in multi-brand retail but with strict conditions attached.\n\nBharti will acquire the compulsory convertible debentures (CCDs) worth $  million that Walmart’s\nMauritius-based investment arm had infused into Cedar Support Services, which owned Bharti Retail, as part\nof the separation agreement. In addition to the termination of the wholesale joint venture, Walmart also\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nsnapped its "franchisee and supply agreement with Bharti Retail Ltd which operates Bharti’s retail business in\nIndia and transferred its (Walmart’s) investment in that business to Bharti", the annual report said, apparently\nwith reference to the $ -million CCD investment.\n\nBoth Walmart and Bharti are trying to expand their businesses independent of each other. Walmart this\nmonth said it’s bullish on the India cash-and-carry business and plans to add   Best Price stores in the next\nfive years. ET has reported that Walmart, which has formed a new company called Walmart India, has\ninjected an additional Rs ,  crore into its operations in the country after its break-up with Bharti. A\nsubstantial chunk of this will go into developing the cash-and-carry stores and allied infrastructure, according\nto people aware of the plans.\n\nFor Reprint Rights: timescontent.com\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nEmerging Markets\nBP Walks Away From India\'s Refining Renaissance\n\n  words\n  April  \nInternational Petroleum Finance\nIPF\nEnglish\n(c)   Energy Intelligence Group. All rights reserved\nHarsh market conditions for downstream companies in India -- including hefty losses from sales of petroleum\nproducts below cost and a potential glut in domestic refining capacity -- are being blamed for last month\'s\ndecision by BP to pull out of a mooted refining and marketing joint venture with Hindustan Petroleum.\n\nBP had informed Hindustan that its board had found other projects more attractive at this time than the\nproposed Bhatinda refining venture, Hindustan Chief Executive MB Lal told a Mar.   press conference in\nNew Delhi.\n\nLal noted that India\'s downstream conditions had worsened since BP signed a letter of intent last October\nwith Hindustan to invest in a $  billion refinery in Bhatinda in northern India. The agreement also involved\nsetting up a joint venture to market products from the proposed  ,  barrel per day inland refinery through\na chain of cobranded retail outlets across India. "They had ambitious plans," Lal told IPF.\n\nBP explained that its decision to abandon the joint venture with Hindustan was made because the project\ndidn\'t fit with its current plans. "It\'s a robust project, but it\'s just not the right project for us at this moment in\ntime," a BP spokeswoman told IPF. "It doesn\'t fit in with what we\'re doing at the moment, so we\'ve decided\nthat we\'re not going to take the letter of intent forward." India remains "a place we would still look at," for both\nupstream and downstream, she added.\n\nShortly after the letter of intent was signed, BP Chief Executive John Browne cautioned that this was no\nguarantee of any future alliance. "We have a letter of intent, which is an agreement to agree," Browne had\nsaid. "We do not have a deal."\n\nLal told reporters that Hindustan would go ahead with the refinery, which will be designed to process  %\nsour crudes. "We have a refinery on the east coast and one on the west," Lal said. "The Bhatinda refinery is\ninland and complements the other two refineries."\n\nIndia\'s northern region is short of products, and Bhatinda would help plug that gap, Lal said. Hindustan also\nplans to expand the east coast Vizag refinery, which processes  ,  b/d, by  ,  b/d at a cost of $ . \nbillion. "By   we want to process  % sour crudes in all our refineries," said Lal. "Our refineries will have\nan  % distillate content and make products suiting Euro-  and Euro-  standards."\n\nLal said Hindustan\'s coastal refineries could become largely export oriented, with Bhatinda catering to the\ndomestic market, if Indian product demand remains largely flat at  .  million b/d.\n\nBP\'s decision marks a blow to India\'s attempt to attract foreign investments in the energy sector. The country\nderegulated its petroleum sector in April  , but oil companies were not allowed to raise pump prices in line\nwith global price levels for the past year, leading to huge losses -- Hindustan incurred losses of around $ \nmillion for the nine months ending December   from selling petroleum products below cost.\n\nIndia\'s petroleum sector, once touted as a high-growth market, is in the doldrums. The country\'s existing  . \nmillion b/d capacity, spread across   refineries, is already  % higher than current product demand, which\nhas been negative in the current fiscal year to end-March.\n\nBut this has not stopped the country from witnessing a boom in domestic refining investment, aimed at\nturning India into a global refining hub targeting export markets in Europe and the US. Hindustan\'s Bathinda\nplant is one of eight refining projects that are set to add some  .  million b/d of new refining capacity to the\nIndian market by  , at a cost of around $  billion.\n\nThe export drive has been led by private refiners such as Reliance Industries, which is adding a further\n ,  b/d of processing capacity to its giant  ,  b/d Jamnagar plant between now and   (IPF\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nOct.,p ). But Oil & Natural Gas Corp. (ONGC) and Indian Oil Corp. (IOC) look set to jump on the export\nbandwagon, with both following the Jamnagar model by developing integrated refining and petrochemical\ncomplexes at Mangalore and Paradip, respectively.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nFood\nBritannia to buy out NZ dairy partner Fonterra\n\n  words\n  April  \nThe Economic Times\nECTIM\nEnglish\n(c)   The Times of India Group. All rights reserved.\nBANGALORE: Nusli Wadia-controlled Britannia Industries has agreed to buy out New Zealand\'s Fonterra\nfrom an existing dairy joint venture, Britannia New Zealand Foods.\n\nBoth Britannia and Fonterra, one of the world\'s biggest milk co-operatives, agreed to call off the  :  JV,\nwith the acquirer assuming the cumulative losses and the exiting foreign partner writing down the investments\nmade into venture.\n\nThe deal will bolster and unlock further synergies in Britannia\'s go-to-market strategy. The company in recent\nmonths brought biscuits, cakes & rusks and dairy products like cheese, butter, ghee and dairy whitener under\none distribution vertical, while the \'daily fresh\' products, such as bread and dahi fall into another.\n\nThe company\'s distribution was fragmented till some time back, with all the business units approaching the\ntrade separately.\n\nThe mainstay biscuits, non-biscuit bakery (breads, cakes & rusks) and dairy constitute three strategic\nbusiness units within the Rs  ,  crore company.\n\n"We have a single go-to-market strategy for Britannia as far as possible, which is helping us, especially with\nthe modern trade. The distribution has been streamlined into two verticals, with the fresh consumption\nproducts like bread and curd forming one and remaining products going to the market under a separate\nvertical," Britannia Industries MD Vinita Bali told ET.\n\nIn fact, Britannia has tweaked its brand strategy to accommodate the fresh consumption products under a\nnewly-scripted Britannia Daily Fresh umbrella. Ms Bali said the dairy JV was reporting a turnover of Rs  \ncrore and an annualized growth of  - %.\n\nThe JV, which had turned profitable in recent years, has accumulated losses of around Rs   crore. "We will\nbe taking over the P/L of the JV and so the losses," she added.\n\nFonterra, a significant supplier of milk ingredients to global food giants such as Danone and Nestle, wanted to\nexit the Indian market since it could not deliver much value addition, given the fragmented nature of India\'s\ndairy industry.\n\nFonterra is known for managing large dairy farms. It is not a big player in the branded dairy sector even\nthough it has milk powder offering under Anchor brand in several south east Asian markets.\n\nBritannia will ramp up its presence in the dairy space through new product offerings post acquisition of the\nFonterra stake. "We will be looking at differentiated SKUs where we can innovate on the basic dairy\ntechnology.\n\nTake our cheese offering, for instance, where we have a market share of nearly  %. We came out with slim\ncheese (with  % lower fat) as well as cheese cubes and spreads that are clearly differentiated," Ms Bali\nsaid.\n\nThe Britannia-Fonterra JV exited the liquid milk market in   in wake of mounting losses and has no plans\nof re-looking at the segment. "It is a high volume low margin play that does not fit into our business model in\ndairy," she explained, suggesting that Britannia\'s dairy play will essentially revolve around milk derivatives.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nAccel Buys British Telecom\'s  % Stake In Accel Frontline\n\nCharmi Gutka\n  words\n  August  \nDealCurry\nDEALCU\nEnglish\nCopyright ©  . EagleEye Research & Media Pvt. Ltd.\nIT firm, Accel Limited has bought out  % stake held by British Telecom in Accel Frontline Limited for Rs. . \nCr.\n\nWith this buyout, Accel holds a majority  . % stake in Accel Frontline.\n\nAccel Limited is the promoter of Accel Frontline Ltd. In  , Frontline Technologies Corporation acquired a\n % stake in Accel ICIM which was later renamed \'Accel Frontline Ltd\'.\n\nIn  , British Telecommunications Plc acquired  % stake in Frontline Technologies Corporation Limited,.\nThereafter, Accel Ltd sold  % stake in Accel Frontline to BT for Rs.  Cr, thereby making Accel Frontline a\nsubsidiary of BT with  % holding.\n\nTransacton Reference: Times Of India\n\nTransaction Note Founded in   by N.R.Panicker, Chennai-based Accel Frontline provides system\nintegration solutions comprising network design, hardware, software, and website development and\nimplementation of customized software products.\n\nIt\'s products are used in various industries including banking, healthcare, manufacturing, education and\ngovernment.\n\nIn  , Accel Frontline received first round of venture capital from ICICI Ventures, while second round of PE\ninvestment came from Intel Asia Pacific (the investment arm of Intel) in  .\n\nAccel Limited operates in the domains of systems integration, technology services, software development\nand business process outsourcing. Accel\'s operations are spread across   cities in India, Singapore, Middle\nEast and US.\n\nAccel Limited operates through four independent corporate entities namely Accel Frontline Ltd, Accel\nTransmatic Ltd, Accel Systems Group Inc and Accel BPO.\n\nThe market cap of Accel Frontline is Rs.  Cr. It posted total revenue of Rs. .  Cr with PAT of Rs. .  Cr\nfor FY , while for quarter ending March  , it posted total revenue of Rs. .  Cr with PAT of Rs. .  Cr.\n\nIn December  , BT sold  . % in Tech Mahindra to partner Mahindra & Mahindra for about Rs   Cr.\nPost sale, BT\'s holding came down to  . % in Tech Mahindra.\n\nKVEZAR VIEW\n\nDEAL TRACKER FOR\n\nDate\nType\nSub Type\nBuyer\nSize\nBritish Telecom - Accel Frontline -\nAccel Ltd\n\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/Accel-buys-out-BT-stake-in-Accel-Frontline/articleshow/ .cms\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. Ltd.\nFrench menswear brand Celio has raised its stake to  % in the  :  Future Group JV and would invest\nnearly R  Cr to open new stores, BS states.\n\nCelio is a  :  JV between Celio International and Indus-League Clothing Limited. Celio International is a\nleader in men’s wear in France and has an international presence through   stores in   countries. It\noperated through   exclusive brand outlets and   multi-brand outlets.\n\nThe company is now planning to increase its store presence to   by the end of this year, besides also\nadding over   shops every year. Celio currently sources nearly  % of its requirements in India and is\ntargeting to raise it to over  % by early next year.\n\nFuture\'s newly listed company Future Lifestyle Fashions owns  % stake in the company Celio Future\nFashions, a JV between Indus-League Clothing Ltd. and Celio International. Celio International S.A. has also\nfiled an application with the GOI to increase its stake in Celio Future Fashion Ltd, to up to  %.\n\nIndia is an important market for any international brand for a foray in Asia. Celio is in a position now to commit\nto the market. The approval will bring about more infusion of capital.\n\nRecently Future Lifestyle Fashion Limited exited its investment in ethnic wear firm BIBA apparel and Anita\nDongre owned AND for R  Cr.\n\nThe Future Group’s sales and divestments are part of Biyani’s efforts to restructure and revive his retail\nempire that paid the price for rapid, and debt-fuelled expansion.\n\nIn this space, Mandhana Retail Ventures, the licensee of Salman Khan\'s Being Human brand was planning to\nraise R -  Cr by divesting  % stake in the company. Also, L Capital Asia was planning to exit Genesis\nLuxury.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nContinental Acquires Joint-Venture Shares from RICO Auto\n\n  words\n  March  \nENP Newswire\nENPNEW\nEnglish\n(c)  , Electronic News Publishing. All Rights Reserved.\nRelease date -  \n\nFrankfurt am Main, Germany/New Delhi, India. The international automotive supplier Continental, has\nacquired Rico Auto Industries Limited’s   percent shares in the joint venture Continental Rico Hydraulic\nBrakes India Ltd. With this transaction the company will be fully owned subsidiary of Continental.\n\nSince   the plant in Gurgaon near New Delhi has been producing and supplying components for hydraulic\nbrake systems to OEM customers in India. These include products and services consisting of calipers for\nfront and rear axles, drum brakes, master cylinders, brake boosters and load sensing proportioning valves for\nall kind of passenger cars.\n\n‘India plays an important role in the growth strategy of our hydraulic brake systems business unit. The\ninvestment in the Gurgaon activities underlines our intention to add even more value to driving safety for the\nIndian automotive industry and end consumers. With our Indian operations we support worldwide OEMs with\ntheir production locations in India as well as Indian homebased OEMs’, said Dr. Peter Laier, Executive Vice\nPresident of the Hydraulic Brake Systems business unit, Continental Chassis & Safety division.\n\nAccording to Claude dGama Rose, Country Head of Continental in India ‘This acquisition also reinforces our\ncommitment to the Indian market. We have strong growth plans and we will continue to invest in both\ndevelopment and manufacturing to introduce future technologies to this lucrative market, both in our\nAutomotive and Rubber businesses in India.’\n\nContinental is continuing to concentrate on the key components of its business strategy, one of the main ones\nbeing above-average profitable growth in the growth regions, including BRIC, especially in China, India and\nother Asian countries.\n\nIn India, Continental had made significant investments in   by acquiring Modi Tyres and further\ncommitting to an investment of   million Euros to ramp up the tyre business in the country. They also\nexpanded the India Technical Centre in  , and are planning expansion of its automotive facilities in Pune\nand Manesar in  . The company believes that India will see improvements and capacity addition in\ninfrastructure, which will trigger continuous growth.\n\n[Editorial queries for this story should be sent to newswire@enpublishing.co.uk]\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nBUSINESS & ECONOMY\nDBS exits India NBFC biz\n\nKhyati Dharamsi\n  words\n  March  \nDNA - Daily News & Analysis\nDNADAI\nEnglish\nCopyright  . Diligent Media Corporation Ltd.\nSells  . % in Cholamandalam DBS Finance to Murugappa Group\n\nDBS, Singapore\'s largest bank, is exiting its non-banking finance venture in India. It is selling off its  . %\nstake in Cholamandalam DBS Finance to partner Murugappa Group in a deal worth Rs   crore.\n\nThe shares would be purchased at Rs   per share, which is a  . % premium to the closing price of Rs  . \nat the Bombay Stock Exchange on Monday. Shares of Cholamandalam DBS Finance closed on Tuesday at\nRs   per share after touching a high of Rs  .  intraday.\n\n"The transaction is expected to be completed on or before   April  ," a statement issued on Tuesday\nsaid.\n\nThe bank said the move was in line with its new target customer group. "DBS remains committed to India, a\nhigh-growth market, where it has enjoyed stellar performance over the past five years. The bank is executing\nswiftly on the new strategic roadmap unveiled by chief executive officer Piyush Gupta in February. In India,\nthe bank wants to focus on corporate clients as well as high-networth individuals and emerging affluent\nsegments," it said in a response to DNA Money.\n\nGupta took charge of DBS\'s India operations in November,  . The Murugappa Group also clarified on\nTuesday that options were open for future tie-ups.\n\nIndia contributes  % to DBS\' total business, the third-largest after Singapore and Hong Kong. The India\nbusiness is seen growing  - % in  - . "DBS and Murugappa Group remain open to future\ncollaboration opportunities in areas such as wealth management, distribution of financial products, etc."\n\nDBS had also earlier exited its mutual fund venture in the country, which was again in tie-up with Murugappa\nGroup, after DBS Cholamandalam Mutual Fund was acquired by L&T Finance early this year.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nTop Stories\nMahindra to Buy BAE Systems  % Stake in India JV\n\nSantanu Choudhury\n  words\n  February  \n : \nDow Jones Top News & Commentary\nDJCOMM\nEnglish\nCopyright (c)  , Dow Jones & Company, Inc.\nMahindra & Mahindra Ltd. ( .BY) will buy BAE Systems PLC\'s (BAESY) stake in Defence Land\nSystems, a joint venture, the two companies said Saturday.\n\n"This decision is a reflection of the shareholders\' belief that they can best meet emerging customer\nrequirements and address the opportunities in this dynamic market with a flexible, tailored approach that was\nnot easily facilitated by the structure of the existing Joint Venture entity," they said in a joint statement, without\nspecifying details of the stake buy.\n\nMahindra and BAE Systems will consider opportunities for working together on specific projects, they added.\n\nDefence Land Systems makes military vehicles at a facility on the outskirts of New Delhi.\n\nThe partners had said in January that they were reviewing the JV.\n\nMahindra also has a JV with U.S.-based Telephonics Corp. a unit of Griffon Corp. (GFF), to make radar\nsystems in India, and another with United Arab Emirates-based Arabia Holdings and Ras Al Khaimah\nTransport Investments LLC to make and sell armored vehicles in the Middle East and Central Asia as well as\nin Africa.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. Bennett, Coleman & Co., Ltd.\nWith losses mounting, auto instruments manufacturer Pricol has exited its joint venture with Japanese partner\nDenso Corporation, when it sold its  % stake in Denso Pricol India (DPIN) to Denso for a consideration of\nRs   crore. DPIN has now become the wholly-owned subsidiary of Denso. "The JV was making huge\nlosses. The business was not going as per plan," said Vikram Mohan, MD of Pricol. DPIN, which had\nrevenues of around Rs   crore in  , was supplying instrument clusters exclusively to Japanese\ncarmakers Toyota, Honda and Suzuki. The JV envisaged total buyout of Pricol by Denso in five years and\ninvolved transfer by Pricol, of its \'Denso Technology Instrument Cluster Undertaking\' relating to four-wheeler\npersonal passenger vehicles, situated at Coimbatore and Gurgaon to Pricol Components, a wholly-owned\nsubsidiary of Pricol. Denso acquired  % stake in Pricol Components after the transfer.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. Ltd.\nContinental Equipment India has acquired complete stake of its JV partner, Desmon in Desmon Continental\nFrigo Pvt. Ltd, HospitalityBizIndia states. The company bought its partners  % stake to make it a  %\nsubsidiary.\n\nDesmon Continental Frigo Pvt. Ltd was formed in   as a JV between Continental Equipment and Desmon\nSpA wherein both the partners held equal stake. It had set up a manufacturing facility for professional\nrefrigerators near Bhiwadi in Rajasthan. Post acquisition, the JV would be named Continental Frostline Pvt.\nLtd. and its products would be branded under the name Frostline.\n\nContinental Equipment, started in  , is a commercial food service equipment manufacturer and supplier.\nThe company\'s products include counter top range , ovens, veggie washer; its imported product portfolio\nincludes dish washer, coffee machine, food processing machine, etc.\n\nContinental is focused in the areas of Project and Key Accounts Management. The projects executed in India\nand abroad, range from   &   star hotels to canteens, schools, ashrams, hospitals, specialty restaurants etc.\n\nIt is a supplier to McDonalds, KFC, Pizza Hut, Papa Johns, Sbarro, Yo China, Nirula’s, Barista, Café coffee\nday, Costa and many other International and Indian QSRs and provides services in the form of equipment\ndesign, equipment fabrication, imported and indian equipment distribution, installation, warranty, service etc.\n\nDesmon SpA which was founded by the family De Santis in   in Italy as a company for the marketing of\ncatering equipment however later it began production of refrigerators under its own brand. It has two factories\nin Nusco (AV) and other manufacturing facilities in India and China with three distribution centers live in\nFrance, UK and Germany.\n\nOther deals include;\n\nKVEZAR VIEW\n\nDEAL TRACKER FOR\n\nDate\nType\nSub Type\nBuyer\nSize ($mn)\nDesmon SpA - Desmon Continental Frigo - Continental Equipment\n / /  M&A Acquisition Continental Equipment India Private Limited  . \n\nRecent Transactions In The Sector\n\nDate\nType\nBuyer\nTarget\nSize ($mn)\nState\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc.
