All rights reserved.\n\nUPDATE: DLF To Exit Mutual Fund JV With Prudential - Source\n\n  words\n  January  \n : \nDow Jones International News\nDJI\nEnglish\n(c)   Dow Jones & Company, Inc.\n\n(Adds details on the mutual fund JV, background)\n\nBy Nikhil Gulati\nOf DOW JONES NEWSWIRES\n\nNEW DELHI (Dow Jones)--DLF Ltd. ( .BY), India\'s biggest realty company by sales, will exit a mutual\nfund joint venture in the country with Prudential Financial Inc. (PRU) because of a proposed regulatory\nchange, a person with direct knowledge of the matter said Monday.\n\n"The move is prompted by a proposed regulatory change, which makes it mandatory for a company to have\nfive years of experience before selling mutual funds," the person, who didn\'t wish to be named, told Dow\nJones Newswires.\n\nThe move is also in line with the New Delhi-based company\'s strategy to focus on real estate development,\nthe person added.\n\nDLF currently owns  % in the joint venture--DLF Pramerica Asset Managers Pvt. Ltd.--while Prudential\nowns the remaining  %.\n\n"DLF will sell its  % stake to Prudential," the person said, without disclosing details of the likely valuation of\nDLF\'s stake in the venture.\n\nSpokespeople from Prudential weren\'t immediately available for comment.\n\nThe person said also that the time frame for DLF\'s exit from the joint venture is yet to be decided.\n\nIn November  , DLF and Prudential had received an approval from the markets regulator, the Securities &\nExchange Board of India, to jointly sell mutual funds and said they will jointly invest $  million in DLF\nPramerica.\n\nDLF Pramerica was planning to start selling mutual funds in  .\n\nEarlier Monday, The Economic Times newspaper reported that DLF plans to exit the venture to reduce its\ndebt of nearly INR  billion.\n\nDLF has been exiting its non-core businesses as part of its strategy to focus more on property development.\nThe company\'s founders recently sold its multiplex-chain, DT Cinemas, to Indian multiplex operator PVR Ltd.\nThe real estate developer also previously announced plans to sell its wind power business.\n\nStill, DLF has a separate life insurance venture with Prudential, DLF Pramerica Life Insurance Co. Ltd., in\nwhich the Indian realty firm owns a majority  % stake, while the remaining stake is held by the U.S.-based\ninsurance company.\n\n"The life insurance business is continuing and is doing very well for DLF," the person said.\n\nThe life insurance business began operations in September   with an equity base of INR .  billion. In\nNovember  , DLF had said that the companies will jointly infuse INR  billion of capital over next five to\nsix years in the life insurance venture.\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\n-By Nikhil Gulati, Dow Jones Newswires; + - - - ; nikhil.gulati@dowjones.com\n\n(Shikhar Balwani in Mumbai also contributed to this story.) [  - -   GMT ]\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nDLF buys out Hiltons in  :  hotel JV\n\nDistributed by Contify.com\n  words\n  December  \nRealty Plus\nATREAP\nEnglish\nCopyright ©   Adsert Web Solutions Pvt. Ltd.\nThe country\'s largest realty firm DLF has bought out its foreign partner Hilton in its hospitality firm DLF Hotels\n(formerly known as DLF Hilton Hotels Ltd) for an undisclosed sum. DLF held majority stake in the  :  joint\nventure that clocked revenues of Rs  .  crore with profit after tax of Rs  .  crore during the year ended\nMarch  ,  . The financial details of the latest transaction stands undisclosed but it would run into several\ncrores, reports VCCircle.\n\nAlthough the JV did not manage to scale up as fast as hospitality industry analysts had hoped for, arguably\ndue to the economic slowdown that hit the hospitality business specially hard during  - , the JV had paid\nup capital of Rs  .  crore as per balance sheet disclosure for FY .\n\nAmong the listed peers, a company like Hotel Leelaventure Ltd is currently trading   times its FY  net\nprofit. If this is taken as a benchmark, DLF Hotels could be valued at around Rs   crore or more and\nHilton\'s stake could then be worth around Rs   crore ($  million), as per VCCircle estimates.\n\nDLF, which also owns and operates the luxury segment hospitality brand Aman Resorts across the world,\nhad formed an alliance with Hilton for development and management of hotels in India a few years ago.\n\nThe debt-laden realty firm had been taking a hard look at the hotel business and among the many options, it\nhas been looking at the possibility of selling Aman Resorts.\n\nDLF had formed the JV with Hilton a few years ago, in one of the first large foreign direct investment\ntransactions in the hospitality sector in the country. Although various international hotel brands operate in\nIndia, with some of them having been here for decades, most of them entered the market through\nmanagement contracts by lending their brand names to local partners.\n\nImages, graphs or charts, if any, have been removed\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nLimitless to divest Indian JV\n\n  words\n  December  \nMubasher\nMUBEN\nEnglish\n©   Mubasher Info. All Rights Reserved. Provided by Syndigate.info, an Albawaba.com company\nThe Indian government has reported approved plans by Dubai-based developer\n\nLimitless to exit its joint venture with a real estate major after failing\n\nto progress on a proposed project, Arabian Business reported.Its\n\n  partnership with DLF, one of India\'s largest real estate companies,\n\nhad planned to develop a township in Karnataka.But according to\n\nlocal media reports, the venture failed to acquire the land required for\n\nthe project and no building work has taken place.Now, the\n\ngovernment has allowed Limitless to walk away while repatriating some of\n\nthe capital it put in to the joint venture, reports added.The\n\nForeign Investment Promotion Board (FIPB) has approved the proposal of DLF\n\nLimitless Developers Pvt Ltd, an official statement said."The\n\nproposal was related to exit of foreign investors and the repatriation of\n\ncapital as the construction sector project could not even acquire land,"\n\nit added.Last month, Limitless said it is set to restart\n\nconstruction of its first residential tower at The Galleries, with  \n\nunits for lease at the company’s flagship project in Dubai.It\n\nsaid Galleries at Downtown Jebel Ali already comprised four completed,\n\nfully operational commercial buildings. Under an agreement with sister\n\ncompany Nakheel, Limitless will restart work on the first apartment\n\nbuilding, it said.\n\n;\n\nAll Rights Reserved - Mubasher Info\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nDubai s Limitless said to exit Indian joint venture\n\nAndy Sambidge\n  words\n  December  \nArabianBusiness.com\nARBUS\nEnglish\n©  , ArabianBusiness.com, All rights Reserved - Provided by SyndiGate Media Inc.\nThe Indian government has reported approved plans by Dubai-based developer Limitless to exit its joint\nventure with a real estate major after failing to progress on a proposed project.Its   partnership with DLF,\none of India\'s largest real estate companies, had planned to develop a township in Karnataka.But according\nto local media reports, the venture failed to acquire the land required for the project and no building work has\ntaken place.Now, the government has allowed Limitless to walk away while repatriating some of the capital it\nput in to the joint venture, reports added.The Foreign Investment Promotion Board (FIPB) has approved the\nproposal of DLF Limitless Developers Pvt Ltd, an official statement said."The proposal was related to exit of\nforeign investors and the repatriation of capital as the construction sector project could not even acquire\nland," it added.Last month, Limitless said it is set to restart construction of its first residential tower at The\nGalleries, with\n\n  units for lease at the company’s flagship project in Dubai.It said Galleries at Downtown Jebel Ali already\ncomprised four completed, fully operational commercial buildings. Under an agreement with sister company\nNakheel, Limitless will restart work on the first apartment building, it said.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nDubai s Limitless said to exit Indian joint venture\n\nAndy Sambidge\n  words\n  December  \nArabianBusiness.com\nARBUS\nEnglish\n©   IPT Digital. Provided by Syndigate.info, an Albawaba.com Company All Rights Reserved.\nThe Indian government has reported approved plans by Dubai-based developer Limitless to exit its joint\nventure with a real estate major after failing to progress on a proposed project.Its   partnership with DLF,\none of India\'s largest real estate companies, had planned to develop a township in Karnataka.But according\nto local media reports, the venture failed to acquire the land required for the project and no building work has\ntaken place.Now, the government has allowed Limitless to walk away while repatriating some of the capital it\nput in to the joint venture, reports added.The Foreign Investment Promotion Board (FIPB) has approved the\nproposal of DLF Limitless Developers Pvt Ltd, an official statement said."The proposal was related to exit of\nforeign investors and the repatriation of capital as the construction sector project could not even acquire\nland," it added.Last month, Limitless said it is set to restart construction of its first residential tower at The\nGalleries, with\n\n  units for lease at the company’s flagship project in Dubai.It said Galleries at Downtown Jebel Ali already\ncomprised four completed, fully operational commercial buildings. Under an agreement with sister company\nNakheel, Limitless will restart work on the first apartment building, it said.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nLimitless to divest Indian JV\n\n  words\n  December  \nMubasher\nMUBEN\nEnglish\n©   Mubasher Info. All Rights Reserved. Provided by Syndigate.info, an Albawaba.com company\nThe Indian government has reported approved plans by Dubai-based developer\n\nLimitless to exit its joint venture with a real estate major after failing\n\nto progress on a proposed project, Arabian Business reported.Its\n\n  partnership with DLF, one of India\'s largest real estate companies,\n\nhad planned to develop a township in Karnataka.But according to\n\nlocal media reports, the venture failed to acquire the land required for\n\nthe project and no building work has taken place.Now, the\n\ngovernment has allowed Limitless to walk away while repatriating some of\n\nthe capital it put in to the joint venture, reports added.The\n\nForeign Investment Promotion Board (FIPB) has approved the proposal of DLF\n\nLimitless Developers Pvt Ltd, an official statement said."The\n\nproposal was related to exit of foreign investors and the repatriation of\n\ncapital as the construction sector project could not even acquire land,"\n\nit added.Last month, Limitless said it is set to restart\n\nconstruction of its first residential tower at The Galleries, with  \n\nunits for lease at the company’s flagship project in Dubai.It\n\nsaid Galleries at Downtown Jebel Ali already comprised four completed,\n\nfully operational commercial buildings. Under an agreement with sister\n\ncompany Nakheel, Limitless will restart work on the first apartment\n\nbuilding, it said.\n\n;\n\nAll Rights Reserved - Mubasher Info\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nCorporate\nDLF to End Ties with Ferragamo\n\nRAVI TEJA SHARMA NEW DELHI\n  words\n  May  \nThe Economic Times - Mumbai Edition\nECTMUM\nEnglish\nCopyright ©  . Bennett, Coleman & Co., Ltd.\nRealtor to focus on selling premium, luxury fashion brands in the country\n\nLess than a fortnight after ending its joint venture with Giorgio Armani, DLF said it is in the process of\nbreaking its partnership with another Italian luxury brand Salvatore Ferragamo as part of a move to exit luxury\nbrands business."Luxury is a futuristic business in India at the moment and does not have scale," DLF\nBrands Chief Executive Officer Dipak Agarwal says.\n\nThe real estate major will instead focus on selling premium and bridge-to-luxury fashion brands such as\nBoggi, Alcott, Mango, Mothercare, Claire\'s and DKNY."This segment is much more profitable and scalable,"\nAgarwal says.\n\nHe says that while luxury brands have a big future in India, it will require another five to seven years to\nachieve scale and market size."For us, size with speed was important," he says.\n\nThe company has had only four Ferragamo and three Armani stores since it entered the luxury brands\nsegment in   as expansion of these brands in a limited market was getting difficult.\n\nIn comparison, UK retailer Mothercare, which sells prams, pushchairs, car seats, baby clothes and also\nmaternity clothes, entered India in   and already has   stores in the country.\n\nIt will add   more stores this year.\n\nBoggi has   stores and DLF will add another three stores in the next one-year.\n\nThe luxury market in India is bogged down with issues such as high import duties and lack of skilled\nmanpower and quality real estate.\n\nThere is only one luxury mall in the country currently, the DLF Emporio in Delhi, and brands are reluctant to\nenter high street locations due to poor infrastructure around them.\n\nThe cost of retail real estate is very high and that has been nibbling into the profits of luxury retailers in the\ncountry.\n\nToday, it costs. -  crore to set up a luxury store while a store for a premium brand can be made for. - \nlakh.\n\nTo offset this cost, some luxury brands have resorted to reducing the size of their stores to improve the sales\nper sq ft of space.\n\nDLF Brands currently operates   stores for its brands and Agarwal hopes to take the number to   in the\nnext three to four years.\n\nWhile the company has decided not to invest in new luxury brands at the moment, Agarwal says it may help\nsome top brands enter the country through support on the real estate and supply chain fronts.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nEducomp Sells Its  % Stake in IndiaCan To Pearson; Selling To Consolidate\n\nBrindaalakshmi K\n  words\n  April  \nMediaNama\nHTMEDN\nEnglish\nCopyright  . MixedBag Media Pvt. Ltd.\nRIL_button( "http://www.medianama.com/ / / -educomp-indiacan-pearson/", "Educomp Sells Its  %\nStake in IndiaCan To Pearson; Selling To Consolidate" );\n\nEducation company, Educomp has sold  % of its stake in IndiaCan, a vocational training business to\nPearson, its JV partner in the venture,  according to BSE filing.\n\nIndiaCan is a JV that was started between Educomp and Pearson in   to tap on the vocational training\nmarket in India. Educomp in its press release has stated that this move is part of their “consolidation\nstrategy", a third in a series of exits from non-core businesses. The company says that this stake sale has\nbeen made to avoid the need to fund losses and other capital needs of a non-core business. It is not clear if\nIndiaCan has been making losses that Educomp has not been able to fund.\n\nEducomp\'s Consolidation: \n\nEducomp further plans to focus on digital content & IP offering and asset backed offerings like schools and\ncolleges.  Note that Educomp Online is Educomp\'s online education platform. It is not clear if there are other\nIP offerings or any in the pipeline. But it is clear that Educomp plans to keep its focus on digital. In January\n , Authorgen, a subsidiary of Educomp Solutions Ltd, had raised Rs   crore from Kaizen, a private\nequity firm and a German media company, Bertelsmann. Authorgen through its website, WizIQ.com enables\neducation service providers to create virtual classrooms and also convert document to flash. It appears that\nEducomp has also sold  % stake in Eurokids International Ltd to a group of investors led by GPE India, last\nmonth. In  , Educomp merged Studyplaces.com after being acquired in  .  It is worth noting that\nKleiner Perkins, Caulfield & Byers (KPCB), Sherpalo Ventures and InfoEdge, all investors in Studyplaces.com\nhad reported that they lost money in the business.  Educomp plans to further continue this consolidation\nprocess.\n\nOther Developments in the Education Sector\n\nNote that IndiaCan is the second acquistion for Pearson this year. In February  , Pearson had\nacquired the remaining  % stake in TutorVista thereby increasing its stake in the company to  %.\nTutorVista provides online tutoring service to students. In the same month, e-learning site\nMeritNationraised Rs   crore funding from Info Edge (India). With this investment, InfoEdge became a\nmajority stakeholder in Applect Learning Systems, the company that owns MeritNation. In March  , online\ntest platform, Rank Junction had raised undisclosed sum of money from Indian Angel Network. In the same\nmonth, Skoolshop.com, an ecommerce site run by Occasion Kommerce Pvt. Ltd had raised series A funding\nfrom Blume Ventures & others.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nReal Estate\nEmaar to end JV with Indian partner MGF\n\nSwet Sarika\n  words\n  April  \nVC Circle\nMMVVCC\nEnglish\nCopyright  . Mosaic Media Ventures Pvt. Ltd.\nEmaar Properties PJSC, Dubai’s biggest developer, has decided to end its  -year-old joint venture with\nMGF Developments Ltd in India following a year-long separation tussle between the partners.\n\nEmaar said in a statement on Wednesday it will take steps to reorganise Emaar MGF Land Ltd via a\ndemerger to sharpen its focus on its Indian operations and develop ongoing projects.\n\nThe development comes almost a year after reports first surfaced about a possible split due to disagreement\nbetween the partners but Emaar had denied any such move. The Dubai developer had brought in about Rs\n ,  crore in the joint venture and owned roughly   per cent stake along with loans and guarantees while\nMGF held the remaining stake.\n\nWhile Emaar didn’t disclose details of the demerger, media reports have suggested that the Dubai firm is\nlikely to get a bigger share when the two partners split assets.\n\n“They were in discussion to thrash out the various issues with regard to debt and partly completed projects\nthat were stuck due to paucity of funds. It was a complicated process as it involves many running projects\nand large land parcels of about  ,  acres spread over various cities in India," The Economic Times\nreported citing a person familiar with the development.\n\nEmaar MGF, formed in  , is known mainly for building the Commonwealth Games Village for athletes\ntaking part in the event’s   edition in New Delhi. However, it faced massive criticism for delays and poor\nconstruction quality. It also tried to float an initial public offering but couldn’t do so after the stock markets\nplunged following the global economic crisis in  . It made more attempts to launch an IPO in   and\n  but ultimately scrapped the plans.\n\nEmaar is famous for developing the world’s tallest building, the Burj Khalifa, in Dubai. Headed by chairman\nMohamed Ali Rashad Alabbar, Emaar has operations in   countries in the Middle East, North Africa, Asia\nand Europe.\n\nMGF Development was started by Shravan Gupta in  . It claims to have delivered   million square feet of\nretail space and is developing about   million square feet of retail space and   million square feet of\nresidential space.\n\nKnown for its retail assets at the time of forming the JV, MGF now has presence across residential,\ncommercial and retail segments with projects in Gurgaon, Mohali, Jaipur, Indore and Hyderabad. \n\nThe joint venture was formed during the heyday of real estate when huge capital flowed in. But exits have\nbeen a pain point with some markets under the grip of a slowdown. The past two years have been particularly\npainful for developers as tepid forced them to look for various financing options to survive. \n\nThe national capital region, where the company has maximum exposure, has been worst hit by the slowdown\nwith sales slipping significantly over the years. This has taken the unsold stock with developers to an\nalarming level.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nERGO, HERO GROUP NOT TO PURSUE JOINT VENTURE (Hero Group has decided against\ndiversification into life insurance)\n\nBusiness Line. Mar  ,  ; pg  \n  words\n  March  \nIndian Business Insight\nWIBI\n - \nEnglish\nCopyright (c)   Informatics (India) Ltd.\nMunich Re\'s primary insurance unit ERGO Insurance Group and the Hero Group have called off their planned\nlife insurance joint venture. They had signed an agreement in May   and the proposed venture was to\nstart operations in  . The Hero Group has decided against diversification into the life insurance business\nat this point while ERGO Insurance Group sees good potential in the domestic life insurance market and will\nactively seek an entry into the market.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. ( .BY) are up  . % at  . \nrupees after it said over the weekend that it will sell to Indian outsourcing firm HCL Technologies Ltd.\n( .BY). Shareholders of Geometric will receive ten shares in HCL for every   shares held in a deal\nanalysts pegged at $  million. Geometric\'s  % share in its venture with Dassault Systemes S.A.\n(DSY.FR) will be deal with separately, with the Indian company merged into the venture  DPLM Software\nSolutions Ltd. and the entire shareholding sold to Dassault. Geometric shareholders will get one listed\nredeemable preference share of   rupees carrying a dividend of  % a year in  DPLM.\n(kenan.machado@wsj.com)\n\nEditor: KLH\n\n(END) Dow Jones Newswires\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nHershey to Acquire All Outstanding Shares of the Godrej Hershey Joint Venture\n\n ,  words\n  September  \n : \nBusiness Wire\nBWR\nEnglish\n(c)   Business Wire. All Rights Reserved.\n\nHERSHEY, Pa.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--September  ,  --\nThe Hershey Company ("Hershey") (NYSE: HSY) today announced that it has reached an agreement to\nacquire the   percent stake in Godrej Hershey Ltd. that it does not own, primarily from Godrej Industries Ltd.\n("Godrej") and another minority shareholder. Including the assumption of about $ .  million in debt, which is\nalready consolidated by Hershey as the majority shareholder, the company will own the Maha Lacto and\nNutrine candy brands and the Jumpin and Sofit beverage brands as well as the related manufacturing\nfacilities. The transaction is expected to close by the end of the third quarter and the new entity will transition\nto use the name Hershey India as it becomes a wholly owned subsidiary of The Hershey Company. As part of\nthe transaction, the minority shareholders will receive an undisclosed cash consideration.\n\n"India is a key focus market for The Hershey Company," said J.P. Bilbrey, President and Chief Executive\nOfficer, The Hershey Company. "We have a great deal of respect for Godrej. Our partnership provided us\nwith insights and an understanding of the consumers and customers in India. Confectionery and beverage\ncategory growth in India is solid and we\'re excited about our opportunities. We\'ll make the necessary\ninvestments in India to accelerate growth, leveraging our core strengths and business model."\n\nThe transaction gives Hershey an opportunity to integrate Godrej Hershey into the company\'s global business\nplatform and leverage corporate resources across the chocolate and sweets and refreshment strategic\nbusiness units. Over time, Hershey\'s goal is to evolve into a faster growing India market leader in the food\nand beverage space.\n\n"With this new phase of the Hershey business in India, we aim to drive growth in this important market\nthrough product innovation, brand building and investment in our people and processes," said Matthew\nLindsay, Managing Director, Hershey India. "Leveraging the learnings from our Godrej partnership and the\nstrong management team in place, we are excited to move forward in this rapidly growing market," Lindsay\nconcluded.\n\nFor the year ended December  ,  , the Godrej Hershey joint venture had net sales of about $  million.\nThe portion of the net loss for the full year attributable to Hershey was approximately $  million. When the\nGodrej Hershey joint venture was announced in  , annual net sales were about $  million.\n\nAs a result of this transaction there is no change to the financial outlook provided by Hershey on July  ,\n  in its second quarter earnings release.\n\nSafe Harbor Statement\n\nThis release contains statements that are forward-looking. These statements are made based upon current\nexpectations that are subject to risk and uncertainty. Because actual results may differ materially from those\ncontained in the forward-looking statements you should not place undue reliance on the forward looking\nstatements when deciding whether to buy, sell or hold the Company\'s securities. Factors that could cause\nresults to differ materially include, but are not limited to: issues or concerns related to the quality and safety of\nour products, ingredients or packaging; changes in raw material and other costs; selling price increases,\nincluding volume declines associated with pricing elasticity; market demand for our new and existing\nproducts; increased marketplace competition; disruption to our supply chain; failure to successfully identify,\nexecute and integrate acquisitions, divestitures and joint ventures; changes in governmental laws and\nregulations, including taxes; political, economic, and/or financial market conditions; risks and uncertainties\nrelated to our international operations and related growth targets; disruptions, failures or security breaches of\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nour information technology infrastructure; the impact of future developments related to the investigation by\ngovernment regulators of alleged pricing practices by members of the confectionery industry, including risks\nof subsequent litigation or further government action; pension cost factors, such as actuarial assumptions,\nmarket performance and employee retirement decisions and funding requirements; the ability to implement\nour supply chain realignment initiatives within the anticipated timeframe in accordance with our cost estimates\nand our ability to achieve the expected ongoing annual savings from these initiatives; and such other matters\nas discussed in our Annual Report on Form  -K for  .\n\nAll information in this press release is as of September  ,  . The Company undertakes no duty to update\nany forward-looking statement to conform the statement to actual results or changes in the Company\'s\nexpectations.\n\nAbout The Hershey Company\n\nThe Hershey Company (NYSE: HSY) is the largest producer of quality chocolate in North America and a\nglobal leader in chocolate and sugar confectionery. Headquartered in Hershey, Pa., The Hershey Company\nhas operations throughout the world and approximately  ,  employees. With revenues of more than $ \nbillion, Hershey offers confectionery products under more than   brand names, including such iconic brands\nas Hershey\'s, Reese\'s, Hershey\'s Kisses, Hershey\'s Bliss, Hershey\'s Special Dark, Kit Kat, Twizzlers, Jolly\nRancher and Ice Breakers. Hershey also offers premium and artisan chocolate products under such brands\nas Scharffen Berger and Dagoba through the Artisan Confections Company, a wholly owned subsidiary. The\ncompany is focused on growing its presence in key international markets such as China and Mexico while\ncontinuing to build its competitive advantage in the United States and Canada.\n\nFor more than   years, The Hershey Company has been a leader in making a positive difference in the\ncommunities where its employees live, work and do business. Corporate Social Responsibility is an integral\npart of the company\'s global business strategy, which includes goals and priorities focused on fair and ethical\nbusiness dealings, environmental stewardship, fostering a desirable workplace for employees, and positively\nimpacting society and local communities.\n\nMilton Hershey School, established in   by the company\'s founder and administered by Hershey Trust\nCompany, provides a quality education, housing, and medical care at no cost to children in social and\nfinancial need. Students of Milton Hershey School are direct beneficiaries of The Hershey Company\'s\nsuccess.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nHershey to Acquire All Outstanding Shares of the Godrej Hershey Joint Venture\n\n ,  words\n  September  \n : \nBusiness Wire\nBWR\nEnglish\n(c)   Business Wire. All Rights Reserved.\n\nHERSHEY, Pa.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--September  ,  --\nThe Hershey Company ("Hershey") (NYSE: HSY) today announced that it has reached an agreement to\nacquire the   percent stake in Godrej Hershey Ltd. that it does not own, primarily from Godrej Industries Ltd.\n("Godrej") and another minority shareholder. Including the assumption of about $ .  million in debt, which is\nalready consolidated by Hershey as the majority shareholder, the company will own the Maha Lacto and\nNutrine candy brands and the Jumpin and Sofit beverage brands as well as the related manufacturing\nfacilities. The transaction is expected to close by the end of the third quarter and the new entity will transition\nto use the name Hershey India as it becomes a wholly owned subsidiary of The Hershey Company. As part of\nthe transaction, the minority shareholders will receive an undisclosed cash consideration.\n\n"India is a key focus market for The Hershey Company," said J.P. Bilbrey, President and Chief Executive\nOfficer, The Hershey Company. "We have a great deal of respect for Godrej. Our partnership provided us\nwith insights and an understanding of the consumers and customers in India. Confectionery and beverage\ncategory growth in India is solid and we\'re excited about our opportunities. We\'ll make the necessary\ninvestments in India to accelerate growth, leveraging our core strengths and business model."\n\nThe transaction gives Hershey an opportunity to integrate Godrej Hershey into the company\'s global business\nplatform and leverage corporate resources across the chocolate and sweets and refreshment strategic\nbusiness units. Over time, Hershey\'s goal is to evolve into a faster growing India market leader in the food\nand beverage space.\n\n"With this new phase of the Hershey business in India, we aim to drive growth in this important market\nthrough product innovation, brand building and investment in our people and processes," said Matthew\nLindsay, Managing Director, Hershey India. "Leveraging the learnings from our Godrej partnership and the\nstrong management team in place, we are excited to move forward in this rapidly growing market," Lindsay\nconcluded.\n\nFor the year ended December  ,  , the Godrej Hershey joint venture had net sales of about $  million.\nThe portion of the net loss for the full year attributable to Hershey was approximately $  million. When the\nGodrej Hershey joint venture was announced in  , annual net sales were about $  million.\n\nAs a result of this transaction there is no change to the financial outlook provided by Hershey on July  ,\n  in its second quarter earnings release.\n\nSafe Harbor Statement\n\nThis release contains statements that are forward-looking. These statements are made based upon current\nexpectations that are subject to risk and uncertainty. All rights reserved.\n\nour information technology infrastructure; the impact of future developments related to the investigation by\ngovernment regulators of alleged pricing practices by members of the confectionery industry, including risks\nof subsequent litigation or further government action; pension cost factors, such as actuarial assumptions,\nmarket performance and employee retirement decisions and funding requirements; the ability to implement\nour supply chain realignment initiatives within the anticipated timeframe in accordance with our cost estimates\nand our ability to achieve the expected ongoing annual savings from these initiatives; and such other matters\nas discussed in our Annual Report on Form  -K for  .\n\nAll information in this press release is as of September  ,  . The Company undertakes no duty to update\nany forward-looking statement to conform the statement to actual results or changes in the Company\'s\nexpectations.\n\nAbout The Hershey Company\n\nThe Hershey Company (NYSE: HSY) is the largest producer of quality chocolate in North America and a\nglobal leader in chocolate and sugar confectionery. Headquartered in Hershey, Pa., The Hershey Company\nhas operations throughout the world and approximately  ,  employees. With revenues of more than $ \nbillion, Hershey offers confectionery products under more than   brand names, including such iconic brands\nas Hershey\'s, Reese\'s, Hershey\'s Kisses, Hershey\'s Bliss, Hershey\'s Special Dark, Kit Kat, Twizzlers, Jolly\nRancher and Ice Breakers. Hershey also offers premium and artisan chocolate products under such brands\nas Scharffen Berger and Dagoba through the Artisan Confections Company, a wholly owned subsidiary. Now it owns   per cent.\n\nWith the acquisition of the balance   per cent stake in the firm, "Godrej SCA Hygiene has become a wholly\nowned subsidiary of the company with effect from April  ," it said in a filing to the Bombay Stock Exchange.\n\nHowever, the financial details were not disclosed.\n\nGodrej SCA Hygiene was a joint venture between Godrej Consumer Products and SCA Hygiene Products\nAB.\n\nThe board of Godrej Consumer Products had approved the acquisition of the   per cent stake in the joint\nventure on December  ,  .\n\nShares of Godrej Consumer today closed at Rs  . , down  .  per cent from its previous close on the\nBSE.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nNEC Acquires Full Ownership of Indian Software Company\n\n  words\n  March  \n : \nJCN Newswire\nJAPCOR\nEnglish\nCopyright   JCN Newswire, a division of Japan Corporate News Network K.K. All rights reserved.\n- NEC Technologies India established -\n\nTokyo, Mar  ,   - (JCN Newswire) - NEC Corporation (NEC; TSE:  ) and HCL Technologies Limited\n(HCLT) reached an agreement for NEC to obtain full control of NEC HCL Systems Technologies (NHST), a\njoint venture software company. Based on the agreement, NEC will acquire HCLT\'s  % share of NHST. As\na result, NHST will become a wholly owned subsidiary of NEC. The subsidiary\'s name is scheduled to\nbecome NEC Technologies India Limited in April  .\n\nNHST was established in October   in order to enhance software developing resources in India. Since\nthen, the company has developed software products for the platform business in partnership with the\nexperience and knowledge of HCLT. The new subsidiary will play a key role in the development and system\nintegration of NEC\'s solutions business throughout the emerging India and Asia Pacific markets, as well as\nEurope and the US.\n\n"NEC Technologies India will lead a global deployment of product technology and development," said\nTakaaki Shimizu, Senior Vice President of NEC. "The company will become an offshore software\ndevelopment base for systems in Asia Pacific, Europe, the US and Japan, in addition to its current software\ndevelopment for the platform business. Moreover, NEC will strengthen its global sales and support by\nleveraging the new company\'s experience and know-how in development, technology and business\nchannels."\n\nGoing forward, NEC aims to continue strengthening the global competitiveness of its products, costs,\nbusiness promotions and human resources. Furthermore, NEC will create new value for customers as an IT\npartner that provides competitive products and support throughout the world.\n\nAbout NEC Corporation\n\nNEC Corporation (TSE:  ) is a leader in the integration of IT and network technologies that benefit\nbusinesses and people around the world. By providing a combination of products and solutions that cross\nutilize the company\'s experience and global resources, NEC\'s advanced technologies meet the complex and\never-changing needs of its customers. NEC brings more than   years of expertise in technological\ninnovation to empower people, businesses and society. For more information, visit NEC at\nhttp://www.nec.com.\n\nSource: NEC Corporation\n\nContact:\n\nTakehiko Kato\nNEC Corporation\n+ - - - \nE-Mail: t-kato@cj.jp.nec.com\n\nJoseph Jasper\nNEC Corporation\n+ - - - \nE-Mail: j-jasper@ax.jp.nec.com\n\nhttp://www.nec.com\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nHome Page\nHDFC buys Chubb out of JV\n\nGayatri Ramanathan,feedback@livemint.com\nlivemint\n  words\n  May  \nMint\nHNMINT\nEnglish\nCopyright  . HT Media Ltd. All Rights Reserved.\nMortgage major Housing Development Finance Corporation (HDFC) on Tuesday announced it has bought\nthe  % stake of Chubb Global Financial Services Corp. in their joint venture, HDFC Chubb General\nInsurance Co., for an undisclosed amount.\n\nThe general insurance joint venture was set up in  .\n\nAn executive at HDFC, who did not wish to be named, said the book value of the equity in the joint venture\nwas Rs  crore; that would mean the book value of Chubb’s stake is Rs  crore.\n\nConrad D’Souza, treasurer at HDFC, said the company has applied to the Insurance Regulatory and\nDevelopment Authority (Irda), the watchdog for the sector, seeking its approval for the change in the holding\npattern.\n\nPeople close to the development at HDFC, who did not wish to be identified, said Ergo, the insurance arm of\nthe world’s second-largest reinsurance company—Germany’s €  billion (more than Rs  lakh crore) Munich\nRe—is the front-runner to pick up the Chubb stake.\n\n“Till such time the Ergo deal is finalized, HDFC will hold  % stake in the general insurance venture,” said\none of these people.\n\n“Initial joint venture strategies did not get translated,” said D’Souza.\n\nHDFC Chubb lags behind other general insurers such as ICICI Lombard General Insurance Co., Bajaj Allianz\nGeneral Insurance Co., and others in terms of premiums collected. HDFC Chubb collected premiums of\nRs  crore for the year ended March  , compared with Bajaj Allianz’s Rs ,  crore and ICICI\nLombard’s Rs ,  crore.\n\nIn fact, according to figures provided by Irda, while companies such as ICICI Lombard and Reliance General\nInsurance are growing at  - %, HDFC Chubb was actually not growing at all.\n\nThe two companies differed on strategy, with HDFC favouring an aggressive customer acquisition strategy\nwith a range of products and Chubb preferring a more conservative approach; “Chubb’s focus and HDFC’s\nfocus were not the same,” said the executive at HDFC.\n\nShrirang Samant, the insurance firm’s chief executive officer, quit two weeks ago.\n\nIndian insurance law caps an overseas partner’s stake in an insurance venture at  %, which restricts the\namount of equity a foreign partner can put into a business that is highly capital-intensive.\n\nHDFC, which also has a life insurance joint venture with the UK’s Standard Life, wants a strategic partner\nwith experience in general insurance, said the HDFC executive.\n\n“There are people interested in partnering with us,” said the executive.\n\nD’Souza said the proposed stake sale would be finalized only after the regulator’s approval. D’Souza also\nsaid insurance firms, both international and domestic, have expressed interest in picking up the Chubb stake.\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\n“As of now, we will run the business as it is. Who comes in as a partner or who will be the CEO will be\ndecided only after the regulator’s approval of the buyout,’’ D’Souza said.\n\nIndia has licensed   overseas and local non-life insurers as part of its plan to open the sector to expand\ncoverage of insurance in the world’s second fastest growing major economy. The foreign investment cap of\n % has been an irritant for most foreign firms, which claim that this restricts their ability to invest in the\nbusiness.\n\nThe industry has been lobbying to raise the limit on foreign investment to  %, but this has met with political\nopposition from some quarters. Several foreign insurance firms have informal arrangements with their Indian\npartners to increase their stake to  %, should this be allowed.\n\nReuters andGautam Chakravorthy of Bloomberg contributed to this story.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nBUSINESS & ECONOMY\nHDFC, Chubb to go their separate ways\n\nNandini Goswami\n  words\n  May  \nDNA - Daily News & Analysis\nDNADAI\nEnglish\nCopyright  . Diligent Media Corporation Ltd.\nLocal partner will buy out Canadian major\'s  % stake in the JV\n\nIt\'s almost official. HDFC and Chubb, financial giants in their own right who had joined hands for a general\ninsurance venture in the country, are parting ways.\n\nHDFC has agreed to buy out the  % stake held by the foreign partner in the joint venture HDFC Chubb\nGeneral Insurance Company and has applied to the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority (IRDA)\nfor requisite approvals, an HDFC official told DNA Money on Tuesday.\n\nThe company will continue as HDFC Chubb till a name change comes about, for which it has to apply to the\nRegistrar of Companies.\n\nHDFC will now hold  % in the venture, though it is open to a  % foreign equity participation once it finds\nan appropriate foreign partner. The JV currently has an equity base of Rs   crore.\n\n"All employees will continue to be a part of the same company, where HDFC will have the entire stake and\nwe will chose someone to head the company once all this is through," the official said.\n\nFissures in the over four-year relationship have grown since last year because of differing risk appetites of the\npartners.\n\nHDFC, given its size and distribution strength, was keen to move fast.\n\nHowever, Chubb had an overcautious approach, particularly on commercial insurance, which was proving to\nbe a drag on the company, the official said.\n\nWhile all general insurance companies have grown their business, HDFC Chubb General reported a decline\nin business by  . % for  - . Its total business premium was Rs  .  crore, one of the lowest in the\ngeneral insurance industry. Its counterparts and even later entrants have marched way ahead, even as the\npublic sector companies with a large base have also grown at higher rates.\n\nAlso, the dynamics of the Rs  ,  crore general insurance industry has changed since the detariff regime\nkicked off in January this year and there was a crying need for a cohesive management structure to fight it\nout in the fiercely competitive market place. A formal split was thus waiting to happen.\n\nOn the kind of signals the split sends out, the official said, "In fact, investors should be happy as there was a\ngenuine concern for the company\'s falling numbers and now there is a concerted effort to grow the company.\nEveryone has a different way of functioning, and given the fact that all our other companies, like life\ninsurance, asset management, bank and the BPO, are doing so well, there should not be any misconception\non the break-up, which has been mutually agreed upon," the official added.\n\nSo, what happens to Chubb now? Sources indicated that the global insurance giant is unlikely to discontinue\ninsurance business in India. More so, as insurance analysts say, it would be a costly proposition to leave\nIndia at this juncture, at a time when the economy is booming, and re-entering later may see it lose two to\nthree years straightaway.\n\nMarket grapevine has it that Chubb is also scouting around for partners. This time, though, it may find some\ncomfort with a clutch of investors instead of one single company, possibly including some high net-worth\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nindividuals as well. The model could be on the lines of Metlife India. Whether it will be called \'Chubb India\' or\nnot, though, remains to be seen. This, however, could not be confirmed.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nEIH terminates co-branding alliance with Hilton ; EIH Ltd, the flagship company of The Oberoi Group,\ntoday...\n\nBS REPORTER New Delhi\n  words\n  September  \nBusiness Standard\nBSTN\nEnglish\n(c)   Business Standard Ltd.\nEIH Ltd, the flagship company of The Oberoi Group, today announced that it has terminated a strategic\nmarketing and co-branding alliance with leading global hotel chain Hilton International Co. The decision will\ncome into effect from April  ,  .\n\nUnder the alliance, EIH managed and ran seven five-star hotels under the Trident Hilton brand Gurgaon,\nAgra, Cochin, Jaipur, Udaipur, Bhubaneshwar and Chennai. It also has a five-star deluxe property christened\nHilton Towers in Mumbai.\n\nEIH will develop the Trident brand independently. All seven hotels will now be called The Trident and the\ndeluxe property Trident Towers.\n\n"We felt there was a possibility of a dilution in the Trident brand with Hilton\'s overall development strategy in\nIndia. With Hilton planning to open the more downmarket Hilton Garden Inn in the country, we felt customers\nwould get confused between that and the Trident Hilton," said SS Mukherji, vice-chairman, EIH.\n\nRealty firm DLF Ltd had forged a  :  joint venture with Hilton International last year. It is this joint venture\ncompany that will be setting up the Hilton Garden Inn brand.\n\n"The first Trident opened way back in   and we entered into an alliance with Hilton only in  . So we\nhave always had our own marketing set-up which only has to be revamped. The company is already\nmarketing The Oberoi brand very successfully," said Mukherji.\n\nOver the next three years, EIH will add  ,  rooms across three Trident Hotels in Mumbai, Bangalore and\nHyderabad.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nFRONT PAGE\nICI India to sell entire stake in Quest\n\nOur Bureau\n  words\n  November  \nBusiness Line (The Hindu)\nBSNLNE\nEnglish\n(c)   The Hindu Business Line\nNov.  \n\nPaints and chemicals firm ICI India Ltd, a subsidiary of UK\'s ICI Plc, has announced its plans to sell its entire\nstake in its wholly owned subsidiary Quest International India Ltd (Quest India) for not less than Rs   crore\nto Switzerland\'s Givaudan Group.\n\nThe company\'s board of directors, at its meeting on Wednesday, approved the sale of its entire stake in\nQuest India — its flavours and fragrances business — to Givaudan Group, for a total consideration of not less\nthan Rs   crore, ICI India informed the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE).\n\nThe announcement followed news that ICI Plc had agreed to sell Netherlands-based Quest International B.V.\nto Givaudan for $  .  billion (around Rs  ,  crore).\n\nICI India said in a statement that "ICI Plc has, after due evaluation, agreed to accept the offer for sale of\nQuest International business received by them very recently from the Givaudan Group, who has expressed\ninterest in purchase of Quest India also. Considering the heavy linkages on the international business and the\nnature of the customers and the market, the board has decided to divest the company\'s entire shareholding in\nits subsidiary Quest lndia to the said Givaudan Group." The Indian transaction is expected to be completed\nbefore the end of the financial year, subject to the global deal happening within the same timeframe, it said.\n\nICI India has controlling interest in Quest India, which was established in   as a joint venture between the\nICI Group and Hindustan Lever Ltd (HLL).\n\nAs per the joint venture agreement, ICI India acquired HLL\'s   per cent shareholding in May this year and\nsubsequently acquired the remaining one per cent of the share capital held by a group company of ICI Plc.\nConsequently, Quest India became a wholly owned subsidiary of ICI India. Quest India reported net sales of\nRs   crore and a net profit of Rs  .  crore for the financial year ended March  . The company is\nheadquartered in Mumbai and has its manufacturing sites in Daman with about   employees on its rolls.\nShares of ICI India were up seven per cent at Rs  .  on BSE on Wednesday. ICI has been carrying out a\nrestructuring exercise wherein it will exit from non-core areas and focus on growing the core ones both\norganically and inorganically. As a step in this direction, ICI India, in June this year, announced the sale of the\ncompany\'s Uniqema business to UK-based Croda Group for around Rs   crore.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. The transaction was concluded in February, which was when Gerdau had announced the\nstart of commercial production at the  ,  metric tons/year specialty steelworks at Tadipatri in southern\nIndia’s Andhra Pradesh state.\n\nKalyani’s decision to exit the venture was owing to uncertainties in iron ore supplies in India, the official said.\n“We want to wait for a better situation before proceeding with expansions,” he said, adding that Kalyani’s own\nplant – a  ,  mt/y integrated alloy steelworks at Ginigera in Karnataka – has been operating at only  %\ncapacity for nearly a year on ore supply disruptions.\n\nIron ore for the Tadipatri works is being sourced from the ongoing electronic auction sales in Karnataka and\nfrom elsewhere, the official added.\n\nThe jv – Kalyani Gerdau Steels – was formed in   through the acquisition of the assets of the  , \nmillion mt/y SJK Steel Plant in Tadipatri. Each partner held a  % shareholding.\n\nLast month, Gerdau revealed it had begun commercial production at the mill now comprising a  , \nmillion mt/y blast furnace, a  -megawatt power plant using gases from the furnace, a sintering plant, and a\nnew  ,  mt/y rolling mill for special quality steel (SBQ) for the automobile industry.\n\n“As we begin our  th year of business, the start of the production of special steel in India represents our\nexpansion to an important country, with an impressive cultural richness, good economic prospects and very\ndedicated people,” said André B. The joint venture, which was set up in   for making plastics machinery, has ended after\nDemag’s new parent, Sumitomo, decided to go it alone in the Indian market by floating a wholly-owned\nsubsidiary.\n\n“L&T-Demag Plastics Machinery, the Chennai-based joint venture company, will no longer be in existence as\nL&T has bought out its partner’s   per cent stake. Sumitomo, which acquired Demag in early- , has its\nown plan for India and it decided to break the relations with L&T,” said a company executive.\n\nThe purchase gives L&T complete ownership of the operations in Chennai. After announcing its exit from the\njoint venture, Sumitomo Demag Plastics Machinery said in a statement, “As already announced in March\n , Sumitomo Heavy Industries is proceeding to establish a subsidiary in India.” L&T officials declined to\ncomment on the development.\n\nIn  , the joint venture company had built its first factory for injection moulding machines. Three years\nlater, it built a second factory in Chennai that doubled its production capacity to a thousand machines a year.\n\nSumitomo Heavy Industries inherited the   per cent stake in the operation when it bought Demag in March\n . However, for more that   years, Sumitomo has had a technical collaboration with another Indian\ninjection machinery maker, Windsor Machines in Mumbai.\n\nL&T had started manufacturing injection moulding machines in   in association with Demag Plastics\nGroup. But the two formed the  :  joint venture company only after nine years. Soon after, the venture had\nemerged as the leading injection moulding solutions provider in India.\n\nL&T Demag launched a petition last year to the India government in which it accused Chinese rivals of\ndumping presses at below cost in the Indian market. The government responded earlier this year by imposing\nanti-dumping duties of up to   per cent on   Chinese companies. Among these, three are associated with\nChina’s largest injection machine maker, Ningbo Haitian Plastic Machinery Group.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. Though the companies have\ndiscontinued that agreement, they will continue to collaborate on marketing TB drugs in South Africa as per a\nprevious agreement.\n\nAt the time of the signing of the February   agreement, the companies believed that there would be\nstrength in the combination of Lupin\'s TB and active pharmaceutical ingredient pipeline and Aspen\'s\nmultidrug-resistant TB product line and experience with antiretroviral drugs. The companies had also planned\nto explore opportunities in the malaria market.\n\nAspen is the largest generic drugmaker in the Southern Hemisphere and one of the top   generic\nmanufacturers worldwide, according to the company. It is also Africa\'s largest pharmaceutical company.\n\nRelease date: Jan.  ,  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nEmerging Business & IT\nHetero Drugs buys out Lyka\'s stake in JV\n\n  words\n  March  \nThe Economic Times\nECTIM\nEnglish\n(c)   The Times of India Group. All rights reserved.\nHYDERABAD: Hyderabad-based Hetero Drugs, makers of the Tamiflu capsules, has bought out the stake of\nGujarat-based Lyka Labs in the joint venture Lyka Hetero Healthcare for a consideration of Rs  .  crore.\n\nAfter gaining control of Lyka Hetero Healthcare, the company is busy drawing up a turnaround plan that\nincludes fresh investments for improving sales margins and addition of new molecules in cardiology and\nantibiotics.\n\nHetero expects the buyout of the JV partner\'s stake in Lyka Hetero will give them the much-needed stability\nand foothold in the domestic market.\n\nWith its expanded basket, including formulations in antibiotics, pain management and anti- asthmatic, Hetero\nis expecting to reduce its dependency on APIs considerably. "Most of our turnover comes from export of\nAPIs, where price volatility is high.\n\nBy attaining full ownership of Lyka Hetero Healthcare, we will be able to focus on marketing formulations in\ndomestic market. This will help us to circumvent the volatility, making our bottomline stronger," Hetero Drugs\ndirector (marketing), Srinivas Reddy, told ET.\n\nThe company is likely to undertake a management restructuring as part of the turnaround. For the erstwhile\njoint venture, Hetero Drugs is looking to achieve a turnover of Rs   crore in one year against the present Rs\n  crore.\n\n"We found it difficult to chalk out marketing strategies within the confinement of a JV. Now we can focus on\nachieving sales volumes for the existing products. It will take  -  months for the new molecules to attain\ncritical mass," Mr Reddy said.\n\nHowever, the company refused to make any comments on management restructuring. "The valuation process\nis on. It will take at least one month for us to finalise investments and other changes," he said.\n\nLyka Hetero Healthcare was a  :  joint venture between Gujarat-based Lyka Labs and Hetero. It was\nfloated to market Lyka\'s products in the domestic market.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nMahindra & Mahindra ends  -year defence JV with BAE Systems\n\nDistributed by Contify.com\n  words\n  February  \nDomain-B\nATDOMB\nEnglish\nCopyright ©  . The Information Company Pvt. Ltd.\nMahindra & Mahindra (M&M) today said that its subsidiary Mahindra Defence Systems will acquire BAE\nSystems\'  -per cent stake in their defence joint venture, Defence Land Systems India (DLSI), ending a\nthree-year partnership with Britain\'s biggest aerospace company.\n\nThe move comes just a year after the London-based company appointed Dean McCumiskey as managing\ndirector and chief executive of its Indian operations in place of Andrew Gallagher in order to lead the next\nphase of BAE Systems\' business development in the country. (See: Dean McCumiskey to head BAE\nSystems in India (http://www.domain-b.com/people/in_the_news/ _bae_systems.html))\n\n"This decision is a reflection of the shareholders\' belief that they can best meet emerging customer\nrequirements and address the opportunities in this dynamic market with a flexible, tailored approach that was\nnot easily facilitated by the structure of the existing joint-venture entity," both companies said in a joint\nstatement.\n\nThe two companies had set up the JV in   to develop new technologies and the manufacture of trusted\narmoured vehicles like the Axe, Rakshak, Marksman, up-armoured and bulletproof Scorpios and Boleros, and\nRapid Intervention Vehicles. (See: Mahindra, BAE Systems set up defence JV for land systems\n(http://www.domain-b.com/companies/companies_m/Mahindra/ _mahindra_group_oneView.html))\n\nAt present, DLSI produces combat vehicles such as Rakshak, Rakshak Plus, Marksman and MPVi, armoured\nbus, riot intervention vehicle and Scorpio Uparmoured for VIP security.\n\nThe company\'s Prithla plant has a capacity to produce up to   vehicles a year, of which up to   are\nMPV-Is. In the last three to four years the company has invested about Rs  crore on the plant.\n\nCommenting on the development, Brigadier (Retd) Khutub Hai, chairman and MD of Mahindra Defence\nSystems, "This is a strategic decision and will enable both the companies to approach opportunities\nindividually and to offer customised solutions to meet the needs of the Indian defence land systems domain."\n\nDean McCumiskey said, "Building domestic capabilities in partnership with Indian companies will remain a\ncornerstone of our strategy in India. We look forward to opportunities to collaborate with Mahindra and others\nto enhance the role of the private sector in the defence industry."\n\nM&M also has a JV with US-based Telephonics Corp to make radar systems and another with UAE-based\nArabia Holdings and Ras Al Khaimah Transport Investments to develop armored vehicles for the Middle East,\nCentral Asia and African market.\n\nBAE also has a software engineering joint venture in India called BAeHA with Hindustan Aeronautics Limited\n(HAL).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nM&M to acquire Navistar\'s stake in MNAL\n\nDistributed by Contify.com\n  words\n  January  \nCommercial Vehicle\nACOMVE\nEnglish\nCopyright ©   Next Gen Publishing, distributed by Contify.com\nM&M and partner Navistar International Corporation have entered into an MoU, wherein the former will buy\nout the latter\'s equity in their JVs, Mahindra Navistar Automotives Ltd (MNAL) and Mahindra Navistar Engines\nPvt Ltd (MNEPL). Following the purchase, both MNAL and MNEPL would become wholly-owned subsidiaries\nof Mahindra. Mahindra would take complete ownership of operations and continue to sell MNEPL and MNAL\nproducts albeit under its own brand name. The sale requires regulatory approval in India, is subject to the\nconclusion of definitive agreements, and is expected to be completed in early  . The terms of the\nproposed transaction call for Mahindra to pay approximately Rs.  crores or USD   million, for Navistar\ngroup\'s stake in both ventures. The payout will happen in two parts.\n\nWhile,   percent will be paid out as and when the deal goes through (upon the receipt of regulatory\napprovals), the remainder will be payable five years from the date of the first payment.\n\nThe agreement allows Navistar to continue sourcing components from India while Mahindra would continue\nto provide engineering services to Navistar. Navistar Group would continue to support M&M through a license\nagreement and extend necessary support to MNAL and MNEPL for the purposes of business continuity.\nCrucially, the agreement covers the localised Maxxforce  .  litre engine. \'Under the terms of our agreement,\nwe can use the Maxxforce engine for as long as needed for business continuity. The engine may be deployed\nfor the domestic market as well as export operations,\' explains Dr. Goenka, President Automotive and Farm\nEquipment Sector. But, the engine is not exclusive to M&M.; Navistar can still commercially exploit it, subject\nto, \'a non-compete clause\'.\n\nFurther investments\n\nSo far, MNAL has registered sales of just  ,  units in the last  -  years, significantly below expectation.\nThis is because, any new player entering the Indian truck market has to contend with the strong incumbents.\nAnd the going has not been easy this year, thanks to the slowdown-induced spell of heavy discounting.\nTherefore, the JV has seen accumulated losses to the tune of Rs   crore, as against investments of Rs\n ,  crore. But this scenario has not dampened M&M\'s commitment to the CV industry. \'We stay committed\nto the truck and bus industry. Our dealers and trade partners are extremely happy with our intent to acquire\nNavistar\'s stake. As a matter of fact, we shall be investing more into the truck and bus business,\' asserts Dr.\nGoenka. M&M reportedly intends to plough Rs  -  crore in a bid to turnaround MNAL\'s operations over\nthe next three years. The investment is meant to support and expand the range of almost completely\nlocalised trucks and engines as also its robust dealer and service network.\n\nM&M is confident that it can succeed in the truck business on its own steam. \'Given that we have a product\nrange that is well-suited to the Indian market\'s needs, we do not feel the immediate need for a foreign JV\npartner. But, to be honest, we have not yet applied serious thought to this aspect,\' reveals Dr. Goenka.\n\nNavistar has decided to exit the JV because its finances are not in good shape. It has been the subject of\ninvestor activism and also the target of a speculated takeover by VW. What is more, a failed EPA  \nemissions compliance strategy saw longstanding Chairman Dan Ustian quit his position.\n\nNot surprisingly, the new management led by President and Chief Operating Officer, Troy Clarke is focussing\non only those business areas that promise immediate return on capital under the \'Drive to Deliver\'\nprogramme. \'While the Indian market has not expanded as we had originally expected and industry\nchallenges there continue in the near term, we still see promise in India going forward. But given Navistar\'s\n  priorities, our capital and focus needs to be allocated to other business opportunities in the near term.\'\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nThe end to the MNAL JV follows the recent dissolution of the MANFORCE JV. Industry observers believes\nthat given the tough and competitive nature of India\'s auto industry, it is often difficult to align the visions of\nIndian and foreign partners. Indeed, buyout of a partner\'s stake is not an alien concept for M&M.; It has\nacquired Renault\'s stake in the erstwhile JV covering the localisation and sales of cars and utility vehicles\nunder the Logan brand. In a possibly encouraging precedent for the truck business, the Logan, now badged\nVerito has been performing better than it did under Mahindra- Renault.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nM&M TO BUY OUT RENAULT STAKE, MAKE LOGAN ON ITS OWN (the company is likely to price the\nLogan at below Rs  lakh)\n\nBusiness Line. Apr  ,  ; pg  \n  words\n  April  \nIndian Business Insight\nWIBI\n - \nEnglish\nCopyright (c)   Informatics (India) Ltd.\nMahindra & Mahindra Ltd (M&M) has decided to buy out the  - percent stake of Renault in the Mahindra\nRenault joint venture. The company has received the licence from Renault to produce the Logan on its own.\nM&M will also export the sedan to markets like South Africa. The company is likely to modify the Logan and\nprice it below Rs  lakh to increase the sales. M&M will retain the name of the Logan and Renault till   Dec\n . The company is also planning to launch a passenger version of the Maxximo.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. Force Motors is selling its   percent stake in MFPTL to its partner MTBA for  \nmillion euros or about Rs ,  crore. The tie-up was intended to introduce world\nclass trucks at Indian prices. But soon differences between the two arose over specification of trucks for\nIndian and overseas markets. This led to low sales and under utilisation of Pithampur capacity. India Business Journal.\nSun Pharmaceutical and Merck Sharp & Dohme (MSD) have mutually decided to wind down their joint\nventure due to changes in the strategic priorities of both the parent companies. The decision to snap ties\ncomes almost five years after the two companies came together. Sun, however, clarified that both partners\nwould continue their collaboration for other businesses, including the strategic India-specific co-marketing\npartnership for diabetes drug Sitagliptin and the global Tildrakizumab programme. MSD and Sun had\ncollaborated to develop and manufacture innovative and branded generic medicines for the emerging\nmarkets.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nApollo gets t(y)red, rolls out of Michelin JV\n\n  words\n  October  \nThe Times of India\nTOI\nEnglish\n(c)   The Times of India Group\nNEW DELHI: It was a mega tyre deal that Onkar Kanwar got tired of. Kanwar\'s Rs  ,  crore Apollo Tyres\non Friday scrapped its much-touted two-year-old truck and bus radial tyre making joint venture with French\ntyre maker Michelin.\n\nApollo has decided to walk out of the venture blaming the slow growth in the radial tyre market and deferment\nin project implementation.\n\nApollo will now sell its  % stake in the the JV - christened Michelin Apollo Tyres Pvt Ltd (MATPL) - to its\nFrench partner at book value. Though company officials refused to divulge details of the financial transaction,\nsources said Apollo would get around $  million for its  % holding in the JV.\n\nThe two firms, however, still remain partners as Michelin continues to hold  . % stake in Apollo Tyres.\n"There is no intention of buying back this stake from Michelin, and we will…\n\n… continue to explore opportunities for co-operation in India," a source said.\n\nThe board of directors of Apollo Tyres on Friday approved the transfer of the JV\'s assets to Michelin. The\nproceeds from the stake sale will be used to expand Apollo\'s existing facilities and grow its presence in tyre\nmarket.\n\nMATPL was floated nearly two years back and the partners had agreed to set up a plant in Ranjangaon\n(Pune) with an initial investment of $  million, the project is yet to get underway.\n\n"The decision is based on prevailing market conditions and the pace of radialisation in the truck and bus tyre\nsegments. While the use of radial tyres has gone up in the past two years, it is at a pace slower than what\nwas projected by the partners," Apollo said.\n\nThe Ranjangaon venture will offer the existing range of Michelin products, it said.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nCORPORATE\n`Exit from Michelin joint venture not a setback for Apollo Tyres\'\n\nK.R. Srivats\n  words\n  October  \nBusiness Line (The Hindu)\nBSNLNE\n \nEnglish\n(c)   The Hindu Business Line\nNew Delhi , Oct  \n\nAPOLLO Tyres Ltd does not see its exit from the Michelin Apollo Tyres Pvt Ltd (MATPL), a  :   joint\nventure company with the Michelin group, as a "setback" in its efforts towards getting a slice of the\nhigh-potential truck and bus radial segment pie.\n\n"We will evolve a strategy for the truck and bus radial segment in the coming days. Our exit from the joint\nventure does not mean that we have had a setback or would not foray into truck and bus radial manufacturing\nin the future," Mr Sunam Sarkar, a member on the Apollo board, told Business Line. ,\n\nThe company and the Michelin group on Friday agreed to "realign their business plans" and announced\nApollo\'s exit from MATPL.\n\nApollo Tyres had invested close to $  million in the joint venture company, which was set up to manufacture\ntruck and bus radial tyre for the domestic market.\n\nMr Sarkar said that the slow pace of radialisation in the Indian truck and bus tyre segment (contributed by\nsomewhat moderate progress in infrastructure build-up) had prompted Apollo Tyres to take a close look at its\nengagement with the joint venture company. "We will get almost entire amount invested in the joint venture\ncompany. We have neither lost or gained in financial terms," Mr Sarkar said.\n\nHe added that the Michelin group would continue to hold the  .  per cent stake it acquired in Apollo Tyres\ntwo years ago.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nMICHELIN GEARS UP FOR ITS STRATEGY ROLL SANS APOLLO (the joint venture will be renamed,\ndual branded truck and bus tyres will be replaced by single branded Michelin tyres)\n\nEconomic Times. Oct  ,  ; pg  \n  words\n  October  \nIndian Business Insight\nWIBI\n - \nEnglish\nCopyright (c)   Informatics (India) Ltd.\nMichelin, the French tyre company, wants to continue its market approach strategy in India despite having\nlost its partner, Apollo Tyres, in its joint venture company, Michelin Apollo Tyres Ltd (MATL). The original plan\nwill continue and the focus will be on becoming the leader in the truck and bus radial market by  . The\njoint venture company will be renamed to reflect its new ownership structure and single branded Michelin\ntyres would replace the dual-branded truck and bus tyres. The proposed $ -million truck and bus radial plant\nat Ranjangaon, near Pune, to produce   lakh tyres has been temporarily shelved but will be taken up once\nthe radial market matures. In the meanwhile, Michelin will continue to import tyres mainly from China and\nThailand, depending on the specific requirements of the Indian market.\n\nABSTRACT|DAILY\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\nNEW DELHI: New York Life Insurance Company plans to sell its near- % stake in Max New York Life\nInsurance in a transaction that could see it sharing about one-third of its sale proceeds with Analjit Singh-led\nMax India, its local partner in the joint venture.\n\nAccording to a person familiar with the development, New York Life, the US-based insurer, is in talks with a\nfew European and Japanese companies as it seeks to exit India as part of its strategy to withdraw from Asia\nand focus on its home market of North America. As part of the strategy, New York Life has divested its stake\nin operations in Thailand, Hong Kong, South Korea and China since last year.\n\nThe US insurer has agreed to pay around one-third of the sale proceeds to its local partner for its contribution\nin building the business and creating its valuation as well as for giving consent for the deal, even though Max\nIndia is not selling any shares itself.\n\nNew York Life\'s stake in the Indian insurance JV is estimated to be worth around Rs  ,  crore and Max\nIndia could end up earning Rs  , - ,  crore on the basis of this valuation.\n\n"Our JV is a highly successful operation that provides important insurance products to the people of India. We\ndo not comment on rumours," said a New York Life spokesman. Max India did not respond to an emailed\nquery. Max New York Life, the country\'s largest non-banking private insurer, was incorporated in   and is\none of the earliest joint venture companies involving a foreign partner.\n\nIn addition to New York Life, Max India has a  % stake in the company and Axis Bank holds the remaining\n %. The money earned by Max India from the transaction will be used to make good its accumulated losses\nin the insurance business and also scout for inorganic growth opportunities, said the person quoted above.\n\nFor Reprint Rights: timescontent.com\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nNippon Chemiphar, Ranbaxy Terminate Alliance\n\n  words\n  December  \nPharma Japan\nPHJP\n \nEnglish\n(c)  . Jiho, Inc. All rights reserved.\nNippon Chemiphar and Ranbaxy Laboratories terminated their comprehensive business alliance, including\ncapital ties, on December  . How the two companies will move in the market for generics in Japan has been\nwatched with great interest since Daiichi Sankyo acquired Ranbaxy in  . They have finally decided to\nterminate their relationship initiated in   and independently follow their own path.\n\nFifty percent of the shares of Nihon Pharmaceutical Industry (NPI) owned by Ranbaxy were acquired by\nNippon Chemiphar for Y .  billion on the same day. NPI will continue to market four generics introduced from\nRanbaxy and sell them through Nippon Chemiphar in Japan. Annual sales of these four products are\napproximately Y  billion. The effect of the deal on its business will be “minimal,”according to Nippon\nChemiphar.\n\nRanbaxy acquired  % of shares of NPI, a subsidiary of Nippon Chemiphar, in  , and increased its\nownership to  % in  . However, its acquisition by Daiichi Sankyo has basically changed its strategy, and\nit has been obliged to reconsider its relationship with Nippon Chemiphar.\n\nAccording to Nippon Chemiphar, the two companies have been discussing the new partnership since\nsummer in  . At the beginning, they discussed how to continue, not to terminate, their partnership. As\nthey reviewed their mutual strategy, however, they have reached a conclusion that the best for both\ncompanies is to independently develop their own business. “This is a friendly, forward-looking\ndecision,”according to Nippon Chemiphar.\n\n“I don\'t think Nippon Chemiphar will be able to fully develop its generics business on its own. We will consider\npartnering,”said President Kazushiro Yamaguchi of Nippon Chemiphar at a press conference in July  \ncommenting on the possibility of M&As and alliances for the development of his company\'s generics\nbusiness. At present, however, the company is not negotiating alliances with any foreign-affiliated generic\ncompany, according to the company\'s Public Relations Department.\n\nDaiichi Sankyo has not clarified its generics business policy in Japan. “We are analyzing recent market trends\nand weighing all possible options,”said a spokesperson for the company.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc.
