All rights reserved.\n\nAshok Leyland completes acquisition of LCV JVs with Nissan\n\nAnil Sharma\n  words\n  November  \nIHS Global Insight Daily Analysis\nWDAN\nEnglish\nCopyright  , IHS Global Insight Limited. All Rights Reserved.\nAshok Leyland has completed the acquisition of three joint ventures (JVs) with Nissan, the company said in a\nstatement. The three JVs in question are Ashok Leyland Nissan Vehicles Ltd (ALNVL) for vehicle\nmanufacturing; Nissan Ashok Leyland Power Train Ltd (NALPT) for making powertrains; and Nissan Ashok\nLeyland Technologies Ltd (NALT), a technology JV. All the three JVs operate in the light commercial vehicle\n(LCV) space. As part of the agreement reached between Ashok Leyland and Nissan, the latter transferred its\nshareholding in the three ventures to the former for a consolidated consideration of INR  (USD . ). Ashok\nLeyland will continue to build the Dost, Partner, and Mitr LCVs, while servicing and parts availability for\ncustomers will be taken care of by a Nissan technical support team.\n\nSignificance: The completion of the transaction is on expected lines as the competition watchdog in India had\nalready cleared the deal agreed between the partners (see India:   November  : ). The two companies\nsigned the JVs in   in an effort to gain a foothold in India\'s light and medium commercial vehicle market.\nHowever, the partnership did not go as planned with delays in product launches, declining sales, widening\nlosses, and write-offs. Except for the Dost, the venture did not have any commercial success and the slower\nintroduction of additional variants further contributed to the losses. Early this year, the differences between\nthe partners came out into the public domain and subsequent development resulted in an exchange of legal\nnotices to each other before both the parties decided to call off the partnership in September (see Japan –\nIndia:   September  : ).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nIndustry\nEnd of the Road for Nissan\'s JVs with Ashok Leyland\n\n  words\n  September  \nThe Economic Times\nECTIM\nEnglish\n(c)   The Times of India Group. All rights reserved.\nNew Delhi: Japanese auto major Nissan Motor agreed to sell its entire stake in three joint ventures to partner\nAshok Leyland, ending their eight-yearold collaboration.\n\nAshok Leyland and Nissan had formed the JVs -Ashok Leyland Nissan Vehicles for vehicle manufacturing;\nNissan Ashok Leyland Power Train for making power trains and Nissan Ashok Leyland Technologies, which\nis a technology joint venture -in  .\n\nThe partners had invested about Rs.  ,  crore as equity between them.\n\n“Under the agreement signed on September  ,   by senior executives of Nissan and Ashok Leyland,\nthese joint ventures will become wholly owned Ashok Leyland subsidiaries, upon receipt of all necessary\napprovals from the regulatory authorities in India,“ the com panies said in a joint statement. The process is\nexpected to finish this year. The firms declined to disclose details of the financial implications.\n\nAs per the restructured agreement, Ashok Leyland will continue to build under a licensing agreement light\ncommercial vehicles Dost and Partner, which are based on Nissan\'s design, engineering and technology.\nServicing and parts availability for customers will be ensured by a technical support arrangement.\n\nIn addition, the two have agreed to continue a deal to pro reed to continue a deal to procure made-in-India\nparts for Nissan. “We have decided to acquire Nissan\'s stake in the three joint venture companies, and this\nwill help focus our efforts to concentrate on core business initiatives and customers. We will continue our\nrelationship with Nissan under the new arrangement,“ said Ashok Leyland MD Vinod Dasari.\n\n“Nissan and Ashok Leyland coming together was a good idea. There were differences in the way both\ncompanies wanted to approach the market and operationalise their strategies. This impacted volumes &\nculminated in the split,“ said VG Ramakrishnan, managing partner, Avanteum Advisors.\n\nFor Reprint Rights: timescontent.com\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nCompanies\nNovartis Arm, Panacea Biotec End  -yr-old Vaccine JV\n\nDIVYA RAJAGOPAL MUMBAI\n  words\n  August  \nThe Economic Times - Mumbai Edition\nECTMUM\nEnglish\nCopyright ©  . Bennett, Coleman & Co., Ltd.\nSwiss drugmaker Novartis\' subsidiary Chiron has snapped the eight-year-old joint venture which was formed\nwith Delhi-based Panacea Biotec to develop and market paediatric vaccines, a move that comes as Novartis\nplans to go it alone in this business."Novartis wants to own the entire vaccine business and helm it on its\nown," a person familiar with the matter said on condition of anonymity.\n\nBoth Novartis and Panacea did not respond to email queries sent by ET.\n\nChiron Panacea Vaccines, the  :  JV, was focused on selling the pentavalent vaccines used in the\nimmunisation of kids.\n\nAt the time of the announcement of the JV, which was signed in  , both the companies had planned to\ninvest $  million (about.  crore at current rates) into the company.\n\nIn  , Novartis acquired Chiron from its other joint venture partner, Aventis, consolidating its ownership in\nthe company.\n\nAnalysts say Panacea Biotec, which is still recovering from a ban imposed by the World Health Organisation\nand is solely dependent on vaccine sales, may have to find another partner to push its business.\n\nPanacea Biotec\'s shares closed at. . , down  . %, and Novartis India\'s shares closed at. . , down\n . %, on BSE on Tuesday.\n\nIndia\'s vaccine market, estimated to be close to. ,  crore, accounts for less than  % of the global vaccine\ncoverage, according to a research report by consultancy firm McKinsey.\n\nWith the government\'s intervention and increased awareness, the market can touch. ,  crore, the report\nsays.\n\nIndia\'s growth potential has attracted multinational vaccine makers such as Novartis, Pfizer, Sanofi and GSK,\nsome of which are focused exclusively on niche paediatric vaccines.divya.rajagopal@timesgroup.com\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. Metis Business Solutions Pvt. Ltd.\nReliance Industries, along with its partner Pioneer Natural Resources Co, plan to divest their JV company\nEagle Ford Shale Midstream Business.\n\nUS-based Pioneer Natural Resources, which holds  . % in the JV and is operator of the project, said in a\nstatement that the divestment is part of its strategy to focus more on its shale gas explorations business.\nReliance group, which holds  . % in the JV through arm Reliance Holding USA, is also pursuing sale of its\nstake. In a separate statement to Indian bourses, RIL said, "Reliance has also agreed to consider a\ndivestment of its shareholding in this joint venture...The current investments in EFS Midstream LLC is $  \nmillion."\n\nThe Midstream business of Eagle Ford owns and runs   gathering plants and around   miles of pipelines.\nThe JV, which was formed in  , is likely to generate $  million in cash flow in  , the statement said.\n"The sale of EFS Midstream would allow us to strategically redeploy capital to our core, oil-rich\nSpraberry/Wolfcamp assets in the Permian Basin of West Texas, where we are successfully transforming the\nsubstantial resource potential we delineated in   into strong production growth," said Scott D Sheffield,\nchairman and CEO, Pioneer Natural Resources, in the statement.\n\n"We currently have no plans to divest our Eagle Ford Shale upstream assets. The sale of EFS Midstream is\nnot expected to impact our ability to export processed Eagle Ford condensate," he said. Reliance Industries,\nPioneer Resources to sell off stake in US company Last month, commenting on media reports that RIL may\nsell its stake in the Eagle Ford JV at an estimated $ .  billion, RIL\'s chief financial officer Alok Agarwal said,\n"Eagle Ford is the most successful joint venture and it has gained a very decent amount of valuation in the\nlast   months. Our partners and we are looking at what\'s best for the JV going forward."\n\nBesides, its stake in Eagle Ford, RIL owns stakes in two more shale ventures in the US. RIL owns  % in\nChevron\'s Marcellus shale asset and  % in and asset of the Carrizo Oil and Gas Inc in Central and\nNortheast Pennsylvania.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. A year ago RTL expanded the channel with an English-language feed.\n\nThe split, which marks the exit of RTL from Indian TV, was mooted at the end of April when Anil Ambani’s\nReliance bought out the company’s stake in the  /  JV.\n\nJust months ago Reliance and CBS Studios International ended their three-year-old JV, which operated Big\nCBS Prime, Big CBS Love and youth-skewing Big CBS Spark.\n\nBig RTL Thrill will be rebranded as Big Thrill. Reliance CEO Tarun Katial said the firm will begin investing in\nregional programming by the end of the year and hopes to add “local male action content” and new concepts.\n\nBig Thrill and its sister channel Big Magic, which focuses on comedy, are available on DTH platforms Dish TV,\nReliance Digital TV and Videocon d h, and most of India’s major cable platforms.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. Ltd.\nAd-for-equity media investor BCCL is a shareholder in the venture.\n\nReligare Enterprises Ltd, the public listed holding company of a string of financial services businesses, said\non Thursday that it would exit its life insurance joint venture with its Dutch partner Aegon.\n\nThe firm currently holds   per cent in Aegon Religare Life Insurance Co Ltd, while Aegon owns   per cent\nstake. The remaining   per cent is with ad-for-equity media investor Bennett, Coleman and Company Ltd\n(BCCL), the firm behind media publications and TV channels like The Times of India and Times Now.\n\n“After a strategic review, Religare has expressed a desire to exit the joint venture. Religare and Aegon have\nagreed that Religare will exit once a replacement shareholder is identified and is approved by the regulatory\nauthorities,” Religare said.\n\nThe FDI ceiling for insurance sector is in the process of being hiked to   per cent which would allow Aegon\nto buy a part of the stake held by Religare. However, Religare would need to find other buyers for its\nremaining holding.\n\nAegon is an international provider of life insurance, pension and asset management. With headquarters in\nThe Hague, the Netherlands, its companies employ over  ,  people serving millions of customers across\nthe globe. Its main operations are in the US, the Netherlands and the UK, but in recent years the company\nhas expanded into new growth markets in Asia, Central & Eastern Europe and Latin America.\n\nThere are   life insurance firms in the country including state-run Life Insurance Co. Religare Aegon is the\n st ranked life insurer among the   private life insurers in the country as per first premium collection for the\nperiod ended June  ,  .\n\nIt had launched its pan-India operations in July,   following a multi-channel distribution strategy.\n\nReligare Enterprises share price closed at Rs  .  each, down  .  per cent on the BSE in a weak Mumbai\nmarket on Thursday.\n\nIn another deal in the life insurance space, Kishore Biyani-led Future Group sold  .  per cent stake in Future\nGenerali India Life Insurance Company Ltd to Industrial Investment Trust Ltd (IITL) last year.\n\nAlso real estate developer DLF had sold its   per cent stake sale in DLF Pramerica Life Insurance Company\nLtd -- its life insurance joint venture with Prudential International Inc – to Dewan Finance Corporation Ltd and\nits group entities. The firm has now been renamed as DHFL Pramerica Life Insurance.\n\n(Edited by Joby Puthuparampil Johnson)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nBUSINESS\nReligare exits MF biz, sells  % to partner Invesco\n\n  words\n  November  \nPress Trust of India\nPRTRIN\nEnglish\nCopyright  . The Press Trust of India Limited.\nNew Delhi, Nov   (PTI) After life insurance, financial services group Religare Enterprises has decided to exit\nmutual fund business with sale of its controlling   per cent stake in Religare Invesco AMC to the foreign\npartner Invesco.\n\nWhile a number of foreign fund houses have exited the Indian mutual fund industry -- the latest being\nGoldman Sachs -- there have not been many cases where Indian entities have sold the asset management\nbusiness.\n\nEarlier this year, Religare had sold its stake in its life insurance join venture. In May  , Religare had\nannounced that it will exit Aegon Religare Life Insurance Company by selling its stake to existing partner\nBennett, Coleman and Company Ltd (BCCL) of the Netherlands.\n\nReligare did not disclose the exact reasons for the sale of mutual fund business but sources said that the\ncapital is being unlocked through mutual fund. The funds through stake sale will be used for health insurance\nand lending platform.\n\nThe shares of Religare reacted negatively to the announcement and settled down at  .  per cent on the\nBSE in a strong broader market today.\n\nWhile the Indian mutual fund industry has been growing steadily, Religare Invesco has not seen any major\nupsurge in its asset under management in the recent past.\n\nIts average assets under management (AUM) stood at Rs  ,  crore for the quarter ended September,\nonly marginally higher than Rs  ,  crore as on March   this year. In between, it had fallen to Rs  , \ncrore in the quarter ended June.\n\nWithout disclosing the deal size, Religare said in a statement that it has entered into a definitive agreement\nunder which Invesco would increase its stake to   per cent in the joint venture. The transaction is subject to\nregulatory approvals.\n\nReligare held   per cent in the JV while Invesco currently has   per cent ownership.\n\nInvesco\'s Senior Managing Director and Head of Asia Pacific Andrew Lo said it would further deepen its\npresence in India by taking full ownership of this business.\n\nReligare Group CEO Shachindra Nath termed Invesco\'s decision as "an endorsement of the Indian macros"\nand also of the overall quality of the management team.\n\nSaurabh Nanavati will continue as CEO, along with the existing senior management team of the fund house.\n\nInvesco had purchased   per cent stake in March  , wherein it was also given an option to further\nincrease its stake before March  .\n\nIn the recent past, a number of foreign fund houses have exited the Indian mutual fund market, but in most of\nthose cases, the businesses were acquired by Indian entities. The latest deal, therefore, goes against the\nprevailing trend. PTI BJ SP MR\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved\nRuchi Soya, the Indian edible oil and soya foods business, and Japanese food and beverage group Kagome\nCo. have agreed to end their tomato products venture in India.\n\nIn a statement to the Bombay Stock Exchange yesterday (  May), Ruchi Soya said it had sold its stake in\nRuchi Kagome Foods India for INR m (US$ . m).\n\nRuchi Soya added it hadentered into a "termination agreement" and a "share purchase agreement" with\nKagome and "other" investors.\n\nTheRuchi Kagome Foods India venture was set up in   after a deal between Ruchi Soya, Kagome and\nJapanese conglomerate Mitsui Co. The agreement saw Ruchi Soya take a  % stake in the venture, with a\nseparateentity owned by Kagome and Mitsui owning the rest of the business.\n\nThe venture was set up to sell products including "premium" tomato puree, sauces and ketchup.\n\nThe most recent financial results from Ruchi Soya came in February, when the company filed its results for\nthe nine months to the end of December.\n\nRuchi Soya said revenue from food products stood at INR . m, down from INR . m a year earlier.\n\nHowever, profit before tax and finance costs from each segment rose from INR . m to INR m.\n\nThis article was originally published on just-food.com on   May  . All rights reserved.\n\nCorporate\nTata Metaliks Ends Water Pipes JV with Japanese Cos\n\nOUR BUREAU KOLKATA\n  words\n  March  \nThe Economic Times - Mumbai Edition\nECTMUM\nEnglish\nCopyright ©  . Bennett, Coleman & Co., Ltd.\nMove seen to be in line with plan to integrate the pipe-making facility with itself\n\nTata Metaliks has ended its joint venture for manufacturing drinking water pipes with Japanese partners,\nKubota and Metal One.\n\nThe move is seen as a prelude to a larger plan towards integrating the pipe-making facility with TML.\n\nThe joint venture, Tata MetaliksKubota Pipes (TMKPL) was incorporated in July   as a  % subsidiary of\nTML, with the Japanese partners Kubota and Metal One holding  % and  % stake, respectively."To start\nwith, TML will acquire  % stake by buying out its Japanese partners in TMKPL.\n\nAfter which, the pipemaking business will be brought under TML\'s fold.\n\nWe continue to see a lot of prospect in the business," said Harsh Jha, managing director of Tata Metaliks,\nwho is due to retire on Friday."We have separate agreements through which Tata Metaliks will continue to get\ntechnical and international marketing support from Kubota," he added.\n\nWhile there is an obvious tax advantage in the proposed move, TML\'s board is also weighing other options\nfor TMKPL that will attract tax benefits.\n\nThis includes making TMKPL a conversion agent of TML.\n\nA clearer picture may emerge shortly, with the board due to take a call on it in the next three to four\nweeks."The company signed an agreement with Kubota and Metal One on March  , , terminating the\njoint venture agreement being executed from July  ,  in relation to Tata MetaliksKubota Pipes,\nsubsidiary of the company," Tata Metaliks said to the BSE.\n\nSEVERE COMPETITION\n\nTMKPL, in which the partners had invested around.  crore, was affected by severe price competition in\nductile iron (DI) pipes and was upstaged by intense price cutting by regional players in the last four to five\nyears.\n\nHit by low net realisations in an industry facing overcapacity, especially in the eastern region, TMKPL\'s\nmargins suffered."At one point, price of pig iron and DI pipes were at the same level.\n\nThere was no premium on value addition which is absurd.\n\nThe DI pipe market is essentially led by projects.\n\nThere is no concept of marketshare.\n\nThe situation worsened till it became economically unsustainable for a lot of companies that were operating at\nvery low capacity," said an industry analyst.\n\nMINING CRISIS\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nTata Metaliks\' main business, too, has been affected due to irregular supplies of iron ore since the mining\ncrisis broke out in Karnataka and Goa.\n\nIn particular, it was forced to close down operations at its Redi plant at Sindhudurg, Maharashtra in October\n .\n\nEarlier this week, it signed a memorandum of settlement with the Tata Metaliks Workers\' Union at Redi in\nrespect of all permanent employees in pursuance of its plans to close down operation there.\n\nPlans to sell off its Redi plant last year suffered after it failed to clinch a deal with the proposed buyer,\nFomento.\n\nSnapping Ties\n\nJV WAS INCORPORATED IN   with Japanese partners Kubota and Metal One holding  % and  %\nstake, respectively WHILE THERE IS AN OBVIous tax advantage in the proposed move, TML\'s board is also\nweighing other options for TMKPL that will attract tax benefits\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nFront Page\nFiat goes solo on logistics, snapping last link with Tata\n\n  words\n  March  \nFinancial Express\nAIWFIE\nEnglish\nCopyright   Indian Express Online Media Pvt. Ltd.\nThe last of the links between Fiat in India and Tata Motors as far as sales and distribution goes has come to\nan end. While Fiat went independent with its sales and dealership network from May  , the distribution\nand outbound logistics piece was still being handled by Tata Motors. Fiat\'s dependence on Tata Motor\'s\nnetwork will end in March.\n\nFrom April  , Fiat Group Automobiles India, Fiat\'s sales and distribution arm, will be switching over to a new\npartner. Fiat has brought in their distribution and logistic partner from Italy to handle their logistics and\ndistribution in India from their plant at Ranjangaon, near Pune. Mercurio Pallia Logistics will take over the\ndistribution logistics of Fiat cars.\n\nMercurio Pallia a joint venture company between Gruppo Mercurio of Italy and Pallia Transport of India.\nGruppo Mercurio is owned by Gefco Logistics. Fiat works with Gefco in Italy and some European markets.\nGefco is a subsidiary of Peugeot of France and is into vehicle transport and distribution business across the\nglobe with a turnover of  .  billion euro.\n\nRobert DeCrick, head, supply chain management (APAC), Fiat Chrysler, said, "They chose to go with an\nexpert in the business rather than doing it themselves. This is not about fencing some agriculture land and\nstarting to park on it. Unlike the car yards in India, the new Fiat stockyard was built on a solid surface with\nsafety and security that ensure a better quality car was delivered to the customer. The yard also used IT\nextensively to offer better visibility for the dealership from invoice to delivery at the dealerships."\n\nOn whether this investment in logistics would put an additional burden on the comapny\'s costs, DeCrick said\nthey did not view logistics as cost but as a key part of their business.\n\nThe new logistics partner will be able to handle customer demands better and with the use of technology\ndealers will he happier as they will be able to track their supplies from invoice to the delivery of cars at their\ndealerships, DeCrick said.\n\nAs of now Fiat has   dealerships and is adding six nee dealership in two weeks. The target is to reach  \ndealerships by December  . Fiat earlier had a network of   dealers through Tata Motors. Though the\nsix year sales tie-up has ended, the manufacturing JV between Tata Motors and Fiat India remains intact.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nBUSINESS\nRBI clears way for Tatas to buy back from DOCOMO\n\nSpecial Correspondent\n  words\n  January  \nThe Hindu\nTHINDU\nEnglish\n(c)   Kasturi & Sons Ltd\nMUMBAI,BUSINESS The Tatas are close to buying back NTT DOCOMO’s  .  per cent stake in Tata\nTeleservices Ltd (TTSL) at an earlier agreed upon price of Rs. ,  crore as the Reserve Bank of India (RBI)\nis understood to have relaxed its fair value pricing norm as a special case to enable them to honour their\ncommitment made to the Japanese company. The easing of norms comes following enhanced business ties\nbetween India and Japan.\n\nThe RBI’s fair value pricing norm does not allow companies to buy back shares at more price than the fair\nmarket value, and this is why the Tata- NTT DOCOMO deal could not be completed despite several notices\nfrom NTT DOCOMO and even the Japanese company initiating arbitration proceedings against Tata Sons\nand TTSL in London to recover its money. “Tata Sons has made the necessary application to the Reserve\nBank of India. The company is awaiting a response,” a Tata Sons spokesperson said while responding to\nqueries.\n\nIn March,  , NTT DOCOMO had invested $ .  billion in TTSL to pick up  .  per cent stake. The\nshareholder’s agreement had guaranteed it at least   per cent of the investment if it wished to exit in case of\nTTSL failing to meet certain performance targets.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nCorporate\nPE Firm Actis to Exit Road JV with Tatas\n\nARIJIT BARMAN MUMBAI\n  words\n  May  \nThe Economic Times - Mumbai Edition\nECTMUM\nEnglish\nCopyright ©  . Bennett, Coleman & Co., Ltd.\nTata Opportunity Fund to buy out the PE firm in the JV and form an infra entity that will, to start with, acquire\nthree road projects of IVRCL\n\nThree years after private equity firm Actis and the Tata Group formed a $ -million JV - with an ambitious\nplan to spend ten times of that sum in building roads over five years - the venture is coming to an end.\n\nActis is set to pull out of the JV and the Tatas have agreed to buy them out, said multiple sources aware of\nthe ongoing transaction.\n\nCurrently, Tata Realty & Infrastructure (TRIL), a  % subsidiary of Tata Sons, owns  % of the venture\ncalled TRIL Roads while Actis owns the rest.\n\nTRIL was Tata Sons\' initial vehicle for its foray into infrastructure and real estate development.\n\nThe Tata-Actis disengagement is likely to conclude within a month."Actis will make a marginal return on its\ninvestments.\n\nIts focus has moved away from roads into power generation and distribution and it will continue to focus on\nthese sectors through its infrastructure funds.\n\nThis will be an amenable exit," said an official.\n\nActis\' exit is being facilitated by another Tata Group entity, Tata Opportunities Fund (TOF), the group\'s\ncaptive PE fund which will buy them out.\n\nActis PE\'s India head JM Trivedi could not be reached for comments.\n\nSpokespersons from Tata Groups\' external media agency Rediffusion did not respond to ET\'s detailed\nquestionnaire.\n\nLondon headquartered Actis - which was spun off from the Commonwealth Development Corporation nine\nyears ago - had invested $ .  million (.  crore) for its minority stake, in what was then its first investment\nin the Indian infrastructure space.\n\nThis money was deployed from its $ -million (. ,  crore) emerging markets focussed infrastructure fund.\n\nClose to  % of the fund\'s proceeds were initially earmarked for India.\n\nDespite its initial ambitious plans, TRIL Roads and Actis has till date built only one project, the  -km\nPune-Solapur highway with Italian company Atlantia SpA as its technical partner, for. ,  crore.\n\nBut with TOF on board, TRIL Roads plans to pursue inorganic opportunities in the sector.\n\nTRIL-TOF TO BUY   IVRCL ROAD PROJECTS\n\nTo start with, it is already in negotiations to buy the three road projects of cash-strapped infrastructutre\ncompany IVRCL - Salem Tollways, Kumarapalayam Tollways and Changapally-Wallayar Tollways.\n\nThe three roads have been built on an estimated cost of. ,  crore.\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nIn April this year, IVRCL entered into an agreement with TRIL Roads to transfer control in these three road\nprojects, in an effort to monetise its build-operate-transfer assets.\n\nBut in accordance with the terms of the concession agreement, TRIL Roads will separately buy  % in Salem\nand Kumarapalayam Tollways as they are already operational.\n\nIVRCL will continue with a  % exposure.\n\nHowever, for the Changapally-Wallayar Tollways, initially TRIL Roads will pick up only  % and upon\ncompletion of the project in the next five months, it will hike its stake to  %.\n\nAfter two years, IVRCL will exit entirely as the model concession agreement signed post   allows it to do\nso.\n\nConcessional agreement signed before   requires the original promoter to hold a minimum  %."We\nhave all the necessary approvals from NHAI.\n\nWe are just awaiting the lenders nod.\n\nWe hope to conclude the deal in the next   days," said S Ramachandran, director, IVRCL Infrastructures &\nProjects.\n\nTatas will be shelling out around.  crore as equity for the IVRCL deal, while. ,  crore of debt and other\nliabilities will get transferred to them."One good thing about the three roads is that by FY , all three are\nexpected to achieve breakeven.\n\nBut these are just four-lane state highways with moderate traffic growth projections," said Abhinav Bhandari,\ninfrastructure analyst at Elara Capital.arijit.barman@timesgroup.com\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nIndian billionaire Dilip Shanghvi drops plans to form payments bank with IDFC, Telenor\n\n  words\n  May  \n : \nReuters News\nLBA\nEnglish\nCopyright   Thomson Reuters. All Rights Reserved.\nMUMBAI, May   (Reuters) - India\'s second richest man, Dilip Shanghvi, said on Friday he had shelved plans\nto form a payments bank jointly with the Indian financial firm IDFC Bank and an arm of Norway\'s Telenor, but\ndid not disclose the reason.\n\nShanghvi\'s company, Dilip Shanghvi Family and Associates, was among   firms that were awarded licences\nlast August to set up niche "payments banks" aimed at granting millions of Indians access to basic banking.\n\nThe banks are a part of India\'s financial inclusion push and are meant to expand banking services in a\ncountry where less than half of the adult population holds a bank account.\n\nShanghvi, who is the founder and head of India\'s largest drugmaker Sun Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd, said\nhe had worked with IDFC and Telenor over the past eight months to make a framework and governance\nstructure for the joint venture.\n\n"Following the mutual decision to withdraw these plans, the payment bank license will not be pursued,"\nShanghvi said in a statement.\n\n(Reporting by Zeba Siddiqui in Mumbai, editing by David Evans)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nFront Page\nUnitech settles dispute with Telenor, to exit JV\n\n  words\n  October  \nFinancial Express\nAIWFIE\nEnglish\nCopyright   Indian Express Online Media Pvt. Ltd.\nNorwegian telecom operator Telenor and India\'s real estate firm Unitech on Thursday agreed to settle all their\ndisputes amicably by withdrawing all the cases slapped against each other.\n\nThe development brings to an end the long-drawn out dispute between the two since the Supreme Court\ncancelled their JV firm Uninor\'s   licences in its February   order. Under the terms of agreement while\nUnitech, which holds  . %, will exit the JV upon receiving payment of a nominal amount, Telenor would be\nable to transfer all assets of Uninor to a new company and bid in the upcoming  G spectrum auction.\n\nTelenor would be free to get a new Indian partner to meet the mandatory  % stake by an Indian firm in a\ntelecom services company. However, Unitech would continue to retain economic rights in the company as per\nits current shareholding. This means that if any benefits accrue to the firm in terms of refund of licence fees of\ntaxes, Unitech would be entitled to them as per its shareholding.\n\nThe two parties also informed the Delhi High Court on Thursday that they have resolved their disputes\namicably.\n\nTelenor had bought  . % stake in Unitech Wireless (Uninor) in   for R ,  crore.\n\n"Telenor and Unitech are pleased to announce that on October  ,  , they have reached an agreement to\namicably settle all disputes between the two parties. The parties are bound by confidentiality obligations, and\nare, therefore, not able to provide any further comments on specific terms and conditions of the settlement.\nHowever, it can be confirmed that the parties agree to support the transfer of the business in Unitech\nWireless (Uninor) to a new entity controlled by Telenor," the statement issued by the two sides said.\n\nWith immediate effect, Unitech would withdraw all its nominees from Uninor\'s board and all its special\nshareholder rights will stand suspended.\n\nAs for Unitech, with the settlement of disputes with Telenor, the realty firm will focus on its core business of\nreal estate. "We are pleased with the settlement reached between Unitech and Telenor. All existing disputes\nwith Telenor are suspended and will be withdrawn upon successful transfer of business of Uninor to a new\nentity controlled by Telenor," Unitech chairman Ramesh Chandra said.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nFT.com site : Tesco ends talks on India joint venture.\n\nElizabeth Rigby and Nayantara Rai in London\n  words\n  November  \nFinancial Times (FT.Com)\nFTCOM\nEnglish\n(c)   The Financial Times Limited. All rights reserved\nTesco of the UK admitted on Friday that its plan to be the first multinational supermarket retailer in India has\nunravelled.\n\nThe world\'s fifth-biggest supermarket chain said it had ended talks with Bharti Enterprises to set up a joint\nventure in India\'s GBP bn-a-year ($ bn) retail sector after discussions failed.\n\nIt now looks like Wal-Mart, the biggest global retailer, could lead the advance into the world\'s eighth-largest\nretail market.\n\nSunil Mittal, the telecommunications tycoon who controls Bharti, refused to be drawn on his negotiations with\nTesco.\n\n"We will make an announcement shortly on a global partner for our retail foray," he told the Financial Times.\n\nTesco, Carrefour and Wal-Mart have been linked to Bharti, but it appears that only the US chain is still in the\nrace.\n\nIt is thought that the Tesco-Bharti deal fell apart in the final stages of the talks after the two parties failed to\nfind common ground on the pace of expansion, with Bharti opting for a more aggressive opening programme\nthan Tesco envisaged.\n\nTesco is also thought to have felt frustrated by leaks about the talks.\n\nUnder Indian rules, no foreign direct investment is allowed in the retail sector, except for single-brand stores,\nwhich means big groups have to sign a franchise or licensing agreement with local companies.\n\nIndia is on track to become the fifth-biggest retail market by  , according to McKinsey. Organised retailing\nmakes up   per cent of the market, giving big chains scope to expand.\n\nConfirming that it had walked away from discussions with Bharti, Tesco said: "We remain excited by the\nopportunities available in India."\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nCompanies\nTitagarh Wagons-FreightCar America dissolve Indian JV\n\nP. R. Sanjai\n  words\n  February  \nMint\nHNMINT\nEnglish\nCopyright  . HT Media Limited. All rights reserved.\nMumbai, Feb.   -- Wgaon manufacturing company Titagarh Wagons Ltd (TWL) and FreightCar America Inc.\n(FCA), on Saturday, said they have agreed to wind up and dissolve their Indian joint venture company.\n\nThe joint venture company, Titagarh FreightCar Pvt. Ltd, was incorporated in India pursuant to a  \njoint-venture agreement between the parties with the objective of manufacturing and selling aluminium\ncoal-carrying rail wagons in India.\n\nSoon after its incorporation, the joint venture company had begun the process of obtaining approval from the\nIndian Railways-Research Designs and Standards Organisation (RDSO) for aluminium wagon designs\nadapted for use on the Indian rail system, TWL said in stock exchange filing.\n\nHowever, they said that over time it became clear that approval from the RDSO would not be obtained in an\nacceptable time-frame.\n\n"The joint venture company formally notified the RDSO in June   that it would not further pursue its\nrequest for design approval," the statement said.\n\n"We had big plans for the joint venture company when it was incorporated in  . However, those plans\nwere not realized despite considerable effort. After lengthy discussions, Titagarh Wagons and FreightCar\nAmerica have decided to dissolve the joint venture company and part ways amicably," said Umesh\nChowdhary, vice-chairman and managing director of TWL.Published by HT Syndication with permission from\nMINT.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nBharti Airtel acquires  % in Qualcomm India for Rs   cr\n\nBS Reporter New Delhi\n  words\n  May  \nBusiness Standard\nBSTN\n \nEnglish\n(c)   Business Standard Ltd.\nEnterprise valued at Rs  ,  cr; Bharti can offer  G services in key Mumbai, Delhi circles\n\nBharti Airtel, the country’s largest mobile operator, today announced the acquisition of   per cent stake in\nUS telecom major Qualcomm Inc’s broadband wireless access (BWA) company in India for an initial\ninvestment of $  million (Rs   crore).\n\nWith this move, Bharti Airtel will become a key player in the  G LTE market, with a presence in eight of the  \ncircles in the country. The acquisition of Qualcomm’s licence is crucial, as it will give Bharti an entry into four\nkey circles: the lucrative Delhi and Mumbai markets as well as Haryana and Kerala. Bharti, on its own, has\n G spectrum in four circles, including Kolkata, where it has already launched services, Karnataka, Punjab\nand Maharashtra.\n\nUnder the agreement, Bharti will acquire the   per cent each held by Global Holding Corporation Private Ltd\n(part of the GTL group) and Tulip Telecom Ltd, to whom it is paying around Rs   crore each. The premium\nthe two investors will earn from the deal comes to an annualised return of around   per cent on their\ninvestment. The balance equity has been bought by way of subscription of fresh equity in the entity. The deal\nalso contemplates that once commercial operations are launched, subject to certain terms and conditions\nbeing met, Bharti would also pick up the remaining   per cent stake by May  .\n\nQualcomm had forked out Rs  ,  crore to win the BWA licence and paid the money through a combination\nof debt and equity. That included about Rs  ,  crore in equity and the rest through debt. The interest on the\ndebt for the last two years that the company forked out while waiting for spectrum comes to around Rs  , \ncrore. Based on this, the enterprise value of the company stands around Rs  ,  crore. Barclays was\nmandated by Qualcomm to structure the deal.\n\nThe US company received its spectrum just a few weeks ago after a bitter battle with the DoT (Department of\nTelecommunications) and after it moved the TDSAT following a delay of nearly two years. The DoT gave it\nthe spectrum but with the licence period reduced from   years to  . . The roll-out obligation time was also\nreduced from five years to three and a half.\n\nCommenting on the deal, Sunil Bharti Mittal, chairman and managing director, Bharti Airtel, said, “This\npartnership will combine the strength of Bharti’s national telecom footprint and Qualcomm’s technological\nleadership in the LTE TDD space. With a broadband-ready network across India, Bharti is well positioned to\nlead the next phase of Indian’s telecom revolution.” Apart from  G, Bharti has  G services in   circles. Bharti\nadded in its press release that with the deal, “it secured nationwide broadband leadership through a\ncombination of  G and  G, with its own networks in   circles”.\n\n“One of our key objectives has been to include a strong partner in the Indian venture with the scale,\nexperience and resources to deploy LTE TDD networks. We are pleased to have Bharti’s participation and\nsupport in this effort,” said Paul E Jacobs, chairman and CEO of Qualcomm.\n\nTulip Telecom chairman H S Bedi confirmed his company had been paid Rs   crore for the   per cent\nstake. “Yes, we have been paid Rs   crore, which is at a premium to what we had spent.” Asked how the\nRs   crore that Qualcomm has paid to the DoT on Tulip Telecom’s behalf for disputed dues, as directed by\nthe TDSAT, Bedi said, “We had an agreement with Qualcomm that only after we had exhausted all options\nand not found a remedy would we pay the money back. However, I am confident this is an erroneous demand\nby the DoT.”\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nAccording to top sources, Bharti has also been talking to Aircel for an alliance in the BWA space, which could\ninclude using its network to get into seven more circles. According to sources, the circles that have been\nidentified include Andhra Pradesh, Assam, Bihar, the north-east, Odisha, Tamil Nadu and West Bengal.\n\nDepending on the final policy and judgments on whether inter-circle roaming would be deemed legal, the\nmove could help Bharti become a pan-India  G player, with presence in   circles. That would bring it head\nto head with the only other pan-India player, Reliance Infotel, which is preparing for a major launch by the end\nof this year. Bharti, however, said it would not like to comment on speculation. Aircel did not comment.\n\nQualcomm had made it public it would not like to get into the services business and would divest stake to\npartners. Its main interest in bidding for BWA spectrum was to ensure operators used it to launch services on\nLTE, a technology it has been backing over Wimax.\n\nThe US company’s main interest is to make money by selling chipsets for  G devices. The company is\nworking on chipsets that will support devices to seamlessly move between  G,  G and  G without the\ncustomer realising the change. Qualcomm expects to provide technical assistance to Bharti in connection\nwith network architecture and optimisation, infrastructure and device testing.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nBharti Airtel acquires  % in Qualcomm India for Rs   cr\n\nBS Reporter New Delhi\n  words\n  May  \nBusiness Standard\nBSTN\n \nEnglish\n(c)   Business Standard Ltd.\nEnterprise valued at Rs  ,  cr; Bharti can offer  G services in key Mumbai, Delhi circles\n\nBharti Airtel, the country’s largest mobile operator, today announced the acquisition of   per cent stake in\nUS telecom major Qualcomm Inc’s broadband wireless access (BWA) company in India for an initial\ninvestment of $  million (Rs   crore).\n\nWith this move, Bharti Airtel will become a key player in the  G LTE market, with a presence in eight of the  \ncircles in the country. However, I am confident this is an erroneous demand\nby the DoT.”\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nAccording to top sources, Bharti has also been talking to Aircel for an alliance in the BWA space, which could\ninclude using its network to get into seven more circles. That would bring it head\nto head with the only other pan-India player, Reliance Infotel, which is preparing for a major launch by the end\nof this year. Bharti, however, said it would not like to comment on speculation. Aircel did not comment.\n\nQualcomm had made it public it would not like to get into the services business and would divest stake to\npartners. All rights reserved.\n\nVarroc sheds its stake in JV\n\nSatnam Singh\n  words\n  September  \nPlastics News\nPLCN\n \nVolume  ; Number  \nEnglish\n(c)   Crain Communications, Inc. All rights reserved.\nIndian auto parts supplier Varroc Group and France’s Cie. Plastic Omnium SA have ended their joint venture\nin India, and now Varroc is moving forward with its own expansion plans.\n\nAurangabad-based Varroc sold its   percent stake in the auto exterior venture to Levallois, France-based\nOmnium.\n\nThe joint venture, Plastic Omnium Varroc Pvt. Ltd., has operated in Chakan, India, since  .\n\n“We have amicably decided to grow on our own in the growing Indian automobile market,” said M.P. Sharma,\nVarroc’s vice president for material and projects, in a telephone interview.\n\nDetails on the buyout were finalized in mid-August, he said. Terms were not disclosed.\n\nNow Varroc is expanding its polymer division by setting up three new facilities in different parts of India to\ncater to the various automobile hubs, according to Sharma.\n\nThe company is investing around $  million in the plants. The first, in Pithampur, will start production in\nOctober. The plant — Varroc’s eighth plastics operation — will supply Mahindra & Mahindra and VE\nCommercial Vehicles Ltd.\n\nThe plant, on a  / -acre site, has injection presses ranging from  -  tons of clamping force.\n\nThe second plant, in Bangalore, will open next year. It will supply Honda Motorcycle & Scooters India (HMSI)\nand automotive plants around Bangalore, Sharma said.\n\nThe third plant, in Chennai, will open in   and serve the fast-growing automotive hub in that region, he\nsaid.\n\nIn August, Varroc bought Visteon Corp.’s global lighting business. That business has  ,  employees at\nplants in Monterrey, Mexico; Pune, India; and two sites in Czech Republic — Nový Jicín and Rychvald.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nEssar exits Vodafone-Essar JV for USD   billion\n\n  words\n  March  \n : \nOrganisation of Asia-Pacific News Agencies\nOANA\nEnglish\n© Copyright  . OANA. All rights reserved.\nNew Delhi (PTI) Putting an end to the\n\ncorporate battle, UK-based Vodafone Thursday announced it\n\nwould exercise the option to acquire its Indian partner\n\nEssar\'s   per cent stake which will result in payment of USD\n\nfive billion.\n\nWith this, Vodafone may have to look for another\n\ndomestic partner to remain compliant with the FDI norms in the\n\ntelecom sector of a maximum stake of   per cent.\n\n"Vodafone Group announces that the Essar Group has\n\nexercised its underwritten put option over   per cent of\n\nVodafone Essar Limited (VEL).\n"Following the exercise by the Essar Group of its put\n\noption, Vodafone has exercised its call option over the\n\nremaining   per cent of VEL owned by the Essar Group,\n\nresulting in a total cash payment of USD   billion," Vodafone\n\nsaid in a statement.\n\nCall Option allows an investor the right but not the\n\nobligation to buy a stock, bond, commodity or other instrument\n\nat a specified price within a specific time period.\n\nOn the other hand, Put Option is an option contract\n\ngiving the owner the right but not the obligation to sell a\n\nspecified amount of an underlying security at a specified\n\nprice within a specified time.\n\nWith this, Essar will exit completely from the joint\n\nventure, which is offering nationwide mobile services in\n\nIndia. Vodafone has over   million subscribers and is the\n\nthird largest operator in India.\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nVodafone also said that final settlement is\n\nanticipated to be completed by November,  .\n\nSources in the know said that the completion of deal\n\nwould be subject to meeting certain conditions which include\n\nReserve Bank of India\'s permission as well as valuation of the\n\ndeal.\n\nThe final shareholding pattern post this deal was not\n\nprovided by the company as it was not clear whether\n\nVodafone\'s stake would exceed the   per cent FDI limit.\n\nVodafone had entered Indian market in   when it\n\nbought Hutchison\'s stake in the joint venture for over USD  \n\nbillion and after that it had entered into an agreement with\n\nEssar for a call and put option for its stake.\n\nThe two firms were locked in battle over Essar\'s plan\n\nto list a firm that had part stake in the joint venture to\n\nfind out market value of its   per cent stake.\n\nThe move was opposed by Vodafone saying this may not\n\ngive true value of Vodafone\'s stake. It had approached the\n\nmarket regulator SEBI and also filed a petition in the Madras\n\nHigh Court.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nBusiness\nLEIGHTON BUYS OUT INDIAN VENTURE\n\nJANE HARPER with AAP\n  words\n  December  \nHerald-Sun\nHERSUN\nHeraldSun\n \nEnglish\n©   News Limited. All rights reserved.\nRESOURCES CONSTRUCTION giant Leighton Holdings has struck a multi-million dollar deal to buy out in\nfull its Indian-based joint venture, Leighton Welspun.\n\nLeighton said yesterday it had bought the Welspun Group’s  .  per cent stake for $US  million ($ \nmillion).\n\nThe move will give Leighton   per cent ownership of the joint venture, which was set up in   to tap into\nopportunities in India’s infrastructure sector.\n\nThe business will be renamed Leighton India.\n\n“Leighton continues to see strong long-term prospects in the Indian market,” the construction and mining\ngroup said yesterday.\n\nThe company said the opportunity to buy out the venture came on the back of a decision by Welspun to\nreposition its infrastructure business and focus on its other activities, which include textiles, pipes energy and\nsteel.\n\nLeighton said it will review the operations of Leighton India and consider integrating several business units to\nlower costs.\n\nThe company said its   underlying profit would not be affected by the transaction, which is expected to be\ncompleted in the first quarter of  .\nLeighton’s forecast underlying profit remains at $  million to $  million. Leighton shares closed  .  per\ncent down at $ . .with AAP\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nINFO-TECH\nWipro buys out Motorola stake\n\n  words\n  June  \nBusiness Line (The Hindu)\nBSNLNE\n \nEnglish\n(c)   The Hindu Business Line\nBangalore, June  \n\nWipro Technologies has pulled out of its joint venture with Motorola Inc – WMNetServ, for managing\ntele-communication networks and services for operators. Wipro will buy out Motorola’s stake in the deal. The\njoint venture, WMNetServ, was signed in   between the two companies with Wipro holding majority stake.\n\nWNNetServ, headquartered in Europe with a branch office in London and development centres in Bangalore\nand New Delhi, was formed to offer services such as network planning and deployment, network optimisation,\nsecurity, operations and support among others. But the deal did not see any great value addition, said Wipro,\nin a press communication.\n\nMr Sudip Nandy, President - Technology, Communications and Telecom Vertical, Wipro Technologies, said:\n“Wipro and Motorola will continue to work closely in the engineering space. ”–\n\nOur Bureau\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nINFO-TECH\nWipro buys out Motorola stake\n\n  words\n  June  \nBusiness Line (The Hindu)\nBSNLNE\n \nEnglish\n(c)   The Hindu Business Line\nBangalore, June  \n\nWipro Technologies has pulled out of its joint venture with Motorola Inc – WMNetServ, for managing\ntele-communication networks and services for operators. Wipro will buy out Motorola’s stake in the deal. The\njoint venture, WMNetServ, was signed in   between the two companies with Wipro holding majority stake.\n\nWNNetServ, headquartered in Europe with a branch office in London and development centres in Bangalore\nand New Delhi, was formed to offer services such as network planning and deployment, network optimisation,\nsecurity, operations and support among others. But the deal did not see any great value addition, said Wipro,\nin a press communication.\n\nMr Sudip Nandy, President - Technology, Communications and Telecom Vertical, Wipro Technologies, said:\n“Wipro and Motorola will continue to work closely in the engineering space. ”–\n\nOur Bureau\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPage   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.\n\nWipro of India acquires Motorola stake in JV WMNetServ, provider of network engineering services\nAnnounced Date:  / /  Wipro Technologies, the global IT arm of India\'s Wipro Limited, has\nannounced that it has exited its joint venture with Motorola. Wipro and Motorola formed the joint\nventure - WMNetServ - in  , with Wipro holding the majority stake.\n\n  words\n  June  \nOptical Networks Daily\nOBSERV\nEnglish\n(c)   Electronics International Disclaimer: Whilst every effort has been taken to ensure the accuracy of the\ninformation contained in this report, neither Electronics International nor its agents or sources can be held\nresponsible for any inaccuracy.\nWipro stated that it has acquired  % of Motorola\'s stake in the venture, adding that the two companies\nwould continue to collaborate in the engineering space.\n\nWMNetServ focuses on delivering network engineering services to equipment vendors and wireless\noperators worldwide. It operates a framework for remote delivery of network services such as network\nplanning and design and network optimisation.\n\nFor further information go to http://www.opticalkeyhole.com\n'
In [8]:
me=re.findall(r"[^\n]+",x)  #removing \n
In [9]:
y=' '.join(me)
y
Out[9]:
'Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Reliance Cap to buy AMP Sanmar for Rs   crore ; Reliance Capital will acquire AMP Sanmar Life Insurance Company for... FRENY PATEL & KAUSIK DATTA Mumbai   words   August   Business Standard BSTN   English (c)   Business Standard Ltd. Reliance Capital will acquire AMP Sanmar Life Insurance Company for Rs   crore. Since the Chennai-based life insurance entity has net free assets of Rs  -  crore, Reliance Cap will pay a premium of Rs  -  crore. Net free assets essentially denote the book value of an insurance company, calculated after deducting losses from its share capital. AMP Sanmar has a capital base of Rs  .  crore. The non-banking finance arm of the Anil Dhirubhai Ambani Enterprise (ADAE) had initially decided to acquire AMP Sanmar through Reliance Life Insurance Company. But it was not possible as Reliance Life Insurance was not a legal entity since it did not have a licence from the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority (IRDA). IRDA Chairman CS Rao told Business Standard since Reliance Life Insurance was not a legal entity, it could not acquire AMP Sanmar. "It is important for Reliance to identify the acquirer as the next step will be the due diligence exercise to be undertaken by the insurance regulator," he added. Declining to comment on the actual value of the deal, Graham Meyer, AMP Sanmar CEO, said it had not been a distress sale.   Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. BANKING/FINANCE AMP Sanmar Life is now Reliance Life Our Bureau   words   February   Business Line (The Hindu) BSNLNE   English (c)   The Hindu Business Line Hyderabad , Feb.   CONSEQUENT to the acquisition by Reliance Capital Ltdof the entire equity capital of AMP of Australia and Sanmar Group in AMP Sanmar Life Insurance Co Ltd , the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority (IRDA) has taken note of the change of company name, `AMP Sanmar Life Insurance Co Ltd\', to that of Reliance Life Insurance Co Ltd (RLICL) and the fresh certificate of incorporation consequent to change of name issued by the Registrar of Companies, Tamil Nadu, dated January  . The insurance regulator said it had permitted RLICL to carry on life insurance business in India subject to the condition that RLICL should honour its commitments to the policyholders of AMP Sanmar Life Insurance on the same terms and conditions subject to which they were issued. Further, the regulator said in a notice here that RLICL should take necessary steps to protect the interests of the policyholders in accordance with the provisions of IRDA Act   and Insurance Act  . Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Max Hypermarkets, Auchan end ties Raghavendra Kamath   words   August   Business Standard BSTN English (c)   Business Standard Ltd. Max Hypermarkets, part of Dubai\'s Landmark Group, and French retailer Groupe Auchan have ended their two year old licence agreement in India. The failure to convert that agreement into a joint venture is the reason for ending the relationship, Max Hypermarkets said today. "Max Hypermarkets and Groupe Auchan continued deep into   to look into the possibilities of creating a joint venture to facilitate Groupe Auchan investment in India, which could comply with Indian FDI regulations. Despite their best efforts, the parties could not facilitate this proposition," Max said in a statement. "Therefore, by common agreement, the   Max Hypermarkets will no longer operate under the Auchan banner by January   at the latest," it said This is the second break-up for Max as it ended its ties with Dutch retailer Spar International in May  . After tying up with Auchan, Max rebranded its existing \'SPAR\' stores in Bangalore and Mangalore to \'Auchan\'. In September  , the UPA government allowed foreign direct investment in multi brand retail subject to approval of respective states. Barring UK-based Tesco, none of the foreign chains has applied for FDI in multi brand retail so far. Max Hypermarket is committed to growth and development of the hypermarket and supermarket business in India and will continue its investments under a new brand name, the Bangalore based company said. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Retail Walmart Stores spent $  mn to end its deal with Bharti Enterprises, resulting in a net loss of $  mn Rasul Bailay & Sagar Malviya   words   April   The Economic Times ECTIM English (c)   The Times of India Group. All rights reserved. NEW DELHI | MUMBAI: Walmart Stores spent $  million (Rs ,  crore at current rates) to end its high-profile retail partnership with Bharti Enterprises, resulting in a net loss of $  million (Rs .  crore) accruing to the US company’s consolidated income in  . While the world’s largest retailer paid $  million (Rs  crore) to acquire Bharti’s stake in its India wholesale joint venture and go solo, it also took a $ -million (Rs ,  crore) hit that included debt and other investments in back-end partner Bharti Retail that it waived as part of the October   separation, according to its annual report issued last week. Walmart paid the $  million to acquire Bharti Enterprises’  % stake in the erstwhile Bharti Walmart Pvt Ltd that ran   Best Price-branded cash-andcarry stores. It was widely speculated that Walmart had compensated Bharti well to call off their six-year-old alliance but this is the first time the amount of money the US company paid to end its India equal JV has come to light. Bharti officials couldn’t be reached immediately for comment. Walmart India said it had nothing to add to the information already disclosed. ET reported previously that it cost Walmart around Rs ,  crore to purchase Bharti’s stake in the joint venture. After going well for the first four years since its inception in  , the Bharti-Walmart alliance turned rocky in the last two as the US firm focused attention on an internal probe to check if the unit had in any way violated US anti-bribery laws. Bharti, Walmart Trying to Expand Independently Scott Price, Walmart’s Asia head who has now been elevated to a global role, told ET in an interview earlier this month that the two partners had an "amicable" end to their six-year alliance. The two-year probe carried out by independent investigators, including US law firm Greenberg Traurig and consulting firm KPMG, prompted Bharti-Walmart to stall all expansion, suspend or sack top officials and ultimately drove a wedge between the partners. Walmart was intent on making sure that it hadn’t committed any violations of the US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, which outlaws bribes to foreign government officials by US-listed entities to run or secure businesses. This followed a corruption scandal in Mexico, where company officials allegedly paid tens of millions of dollars in bribes to local officials to expand faster in the biggest foreign market for Walmart. After the Mexico episode, Walmart started investigating global operations including India and China. Walmart faced other difficulties in India as well. The Bentonville-based retail giant was hounded by Indian politicians for what was construed as lobbying to get India to open multi-brand retail to global supermarket chains. It also came under attack for its $ -million investment in Bharti Retail’s holding firm in   at a time India barred any sort of overseas investment in multi-brand retail. Politicians alleged that Walmart broke India’s foreign exchange laws through what they called illegal and indirect capital infinfusion into Bharti Retail, which ran a nationwide network of Easyday stores. Subsequently, India would change its rules to allow foreign direct investment in multi-brand retail but with strict conditions attached. Bharti will acquire the compulsory convertible debentures (CCDs) worth $  million that Walmart’s Mauritius-based investment arm had infused into Cedar Support Services, which owned Bharti Retail, as part of the separation agreement. In addition to the termination of the wholesale joint venture, Walmart also Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. snapped its "franchisee and supply agreement with Bharti Retail Ltd which operates Bharti’s retail business in India and transferred its (Walmart’s) investment in that business to Bharti", the annual report said, apparently with reference to the $ -million CCD investment. Both Walmart and Bharti are trying to expand their businesses independent of each other. Walmart this month said it’s bullish on the India cash-and-carry business and plans to add   Best Price stores in the next five years. ET has reported that Walmart, which has formed a new company called Walmart India, has injected an additional Rs ,  crore into its operations in the country after its break-up with Bharti. A substantial chunk of this will go into developing the cash-and-carry stores and allied infrastructure, according to people aware of the plans. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Emerging Markets BP Walks Away From India\'s Refining Renaissance   words   April   International Petroleum Finance IPF English (c)   Energy Intelligence Group. All rights reserved Harsh market conditions for downstream companies in India -- including hefty losses from sales of petroleum products below cost and a potential glut in domestic refining capacity -- are being blamed for last month\'s decision by BP to pull out of a mooted refining and marketing joint venture with Hindustan Petroleum. BP had informed Hindustan that its board had found other projects more attractive at this time than the proposed Bhatinda refining venture, Hindustan Chief Executive MB Lal told a Mar.   press conference in New Delhi. Lal noted that India\'s downstream conditions had worsened since BP signed a letter of intent last October with Hindustan to invest in a $  billion refinery in Bhatinda in northern India. The agreement also involved setting up a joint venture to market products from the proposed  ,  barrel per day inland refinery through a chain of cobranded retail outlets across India. "They had ambitious plans," Lal told IPF. BP explained that its decision to abandon the joint venture with Hindustan was made because the project didn\'t fit with its current plans. "It\'s a robust project, but it\'s just not the right project for us at this moment in time," a BP spokeswoman told IPF. "It doesn\'t fit in with what we\'re doing at the moment, so we\'ve decided that we\'re not going to take the letter of intent forward." India remains "a place we would still look at," for both upstream and downstream, she added. Shortly after the letter of intent was signed, BP Chief Executive John Browne cautioned that this was no guarantee of any future alliance. "We have a letter of intent, which is an agreement to agree," Browne had said. "We do not have a deal." Lal told reporters that Hindustan would go ahead with the refinery, which will be designed to process  % sour crudes. "We have a refinery on the east coast and one on the west," Lal said. "The Bhatinda refinery is inland and complements the other two refineries." India\'s northern region is short of products, and Bhatinda would help plug that gap, Lal said. Hindustan also plans to expand the east coast Vizag refinery, which processes  ,  b/d, by  ,  b/d at a cost of $ .  billion. "By   we want to process  % sour crudes in all our refineries," said Lal. "Our refineries will have an  % distillate content and make products suiting Euro-  and Euro-  standards." Lal said Hindustan\'s coastal refineries could become largely export oriented, with Bhatinda catering to the domestic market, if Indian product demand remains largely flat at  .  million b/d. BP\'s decision marks a blow to India\'s attempt to attract foreign investments in the energy sector. The country deregulated its petroleum sector in April  , but oil companies were not allowed to raise pump prices in line with global price levels for the past year, leading to huge losses -- Hindustan incurred losses of around $  million for the nine months ending December   from selling petroleum products below cost. India\'s petroleum sector, once touted as a high-growth market, is in the doldrums. The country\'s existing  .  million b/d capacity, spread across   refineries, is already  % higher than current product demand, which has been negative in the current fiscal year to end-March. But this has not stopped the country from witnessing a boom in domestic refining investment, aimed at turning India into a global refining hub targeting export markets in Europe and the US. Hindustan\'s Bathinda plant is one of eight refining projects that are set to add some  .  million b/d of new refining capacity to the Indian market by  , at a cost of around $  billion. The export drive has been led by private refiners such as Reliance Industries, which is adding a further  ,  b/d of processing capacity to its giant  ,  b/d Jamnagar plant between now and   (IPF Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Oct.,p ). But Oil & Natural Gas Corp. (ONGC) and Indian Oil Corp. (IOC) look set to jump on the export bandwagon, with both following the Jamnagar model by developing integrated refining and petrochemical complexes at Mangalore and Paradip, respectively. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Food Britannia to buy out NZ dairy partner Fonterra   words   April   The Economic Times ECTIM English (c)   The Times of India Group. All rights reserved. BANGALORE: Nusli Wadia-controlled Britannia Industries has agreed to buy out New Zealand\'s Fonterra from an existing dairy joint venture, Britannia New Zealand Foods. Both Britannia and Fonterra, one of the world\'s biggest milk co-operatives, agreed to call off the  :  JV, with the acquirer assuming the cumulative losses and the exiting foreign partner writing down the investments made into venture. The deal will bolster and unlock further synergies in Britannia\'s go-to-market strategy. The company in recent months brought biscuits, cakes & rusks and dairy products like cheese, butter, ghee and dairy whitener under one distribution vertical, while the \'daily fresh\' products, such as bread and dahi fall into another. The company\'s distribution was fragmented till some time back, with all the business units approaching the trade separately. The mainstay biscuits, non-biscuit bakery (breads, cakes & rusks) and dairy constitute three strategic business units within the Rs  ,  crore company. "We have a single go-to-market strategy for Britannia as far as possible, which is helping us, especially with the modern trade. The distribution has been streamlined into two verticals, with the fresh consumption products like bread and curd forming one and remaining products going to the market under a separate vertical," Britannia Industries MD Vinita Bali told ET. In fact, Britannia has tweaked its brand strategy to accommodate the fresh consumption products under a newly-scripted Britannia Daily Fresh umbrella. Ms Bali said the dairy JV was reporting a turnover of Rs   crore and an annualized growth of  - %. The JV, which had turned profitable in recent years, has accumulated losses of around Rs   crore. "We will be taking over the P/L of the JV and so the losses," she added. Fonterra, a significant supplier of milk ingredients to global food giants such as Danone and Nestle, wanted to exit the Indian market since it could not deliver much value addition, given the fragmented nature of India\'s dairy industry. Fonterra is known for managing large dairy farms. It is not a big player in the branded dairy sector even though it has milk powder offering under Anchor brand in several south east Asian markets. Britannia will ramp up its presence in the dairy space through new product offerings post acquisition of the Fonterra stake. "We will be looking at differentiated SKUs where we can innovate on the basic dairy technology. Take our cheese offering, for instance, where we have a market share of nearly  %. We came out with slim cheese (with  % lower fat) as well as cheese cubes and spreads that are clearly differentiated," Ms Bali said. The Britannia-Fonterra JV exited the liquid milk market in   in wake of mounting losses and has no plans of re-looking at the segment. "It is a high volume low margin play that does not fit into our business model in dairy," she explained, suggesting that Britannia\'s dairy play will essentially revolve around milk derivatives. EagleEye Research & Media Pvt. Ltd. IT firm, Accel Limited has bought out  % stake held by British Telecom in Accel Frontline Limited for Rs. .  Cr. In  , Frontline Technologies Corporation acquired a  % stake in Accel ICIM which was later renamed \'Accel Frontline Ltd\'. In  , British Telecommunications Plc acquired  % stake in Frontline Technologies Corporation Limited,. Thereafter, Accel Ltd sold  % stake in Accel Frontline to BT for Rs.  Cr, thereby making Accel Frontline a subsidiary of BT with  % holding. Transacton Reference: Times Of India Transaction Note Founded in   by N.R.Panicker, Chennai-based Accel Frontline provides system integration solutions comprising network design, hardware, software, and website development and implementation of customized software products. It\'s products are used in various industries including banking, healthcare, manufacturing, education and government. In  , Accel Frontline received first round of venture capital from ICICI Ventures, while second round of PE investment came from Intel Asia Pacific (the investment arm of Intel) in  . Accel Limited operates in the domains of systems integration, technology services, software development and business process outsourcing. Accel\'s operations are spread across   cities in India, Singapore, Middle East and US. Accel Limited operates through four independent corporate entities namely Accel Frontline Ltd, Accel Transmatic Ltd, Accel Systems Group Inc and Accel BPO. The market cap of Accel Frontline is Rs.  Cr. It posted total revenue of Rs. .  Cr with PAT of Rs. .  Cr for FY , while for quarter ending March  , it posted total revenue of Rs. .  Cr with PAT of Rs. .  Cr. In December  , BT sold  . % in Tech Mahindra to partner Mahindra & Mahindra for about Rs   Cr. Post sale, BT\'s holding came down to  . % in Tech Mahindra. Continental Acquires Joint-Venture Shares from RICO Auto   words   March   ENP Newswire ENPNEW English (c)  , Electronic News Publishing. All Rights Reserved. Release date -   Frankfurt am Main, Germany/New Delhi, India. The international automotive supplier Continental, has acquired Rico Auto Industries Limited’s   percent shares in the joint venture Continental Rico Hydraulic Brakes India Ltd. With this transaction the company will be fully owned subsidiary of Continental. Since   the plant in Gurgaon near New Delhi has been producing and supplying components for hydraulic brake systems to OEM customers in India. These include products and services consisting of calipers for front and rear axles, drum brakes, master cylinders, brake boosters and load sensing proportioning valves for all kind of passenger cars. ‘India plays an important role in the growth strategy of our hydraulic brake systems business unit. The investment in the Gurgaon activities underlines our intention to add even more value to driving safety for the Indian automotive industry and end consumers. With our Indian operations we support worldwide OEMs with their production locations in India as well as Indian homebased OEMs’, said Dr. Peter Laier, Executive Vice President of the Hydraulic Brake Systems business unit, Continental Chassis & Safety division. According to Claude dGama Rose, Country Head of Continental in India ‘This acquisition also reinforces our commitment to the Indian market. We have strong growth plans and we will continue to invest in both development and manufacturing to introduce future technologies to this lucrative market, both in our Automotive and Rubber businesses in India.’ Continental is continuing to concentrate on the key components of its business strategy, one of the main ones being above-average profitable growth in the growth regions, including BRIC, especially in China, India and other Asian countries. In India, Continental had made significant investments in   by acquiring Modi Tyres and further committing to an investment of   million Euros to ramp up the tyre business in the country. They also expanded the India Technical Centre in  , and are planning expansion of its automotive facilities in Pune and Manesar in  . The company believes that India will see improvements and capacity addition in infrastructure, which will trigger continuous growth. BUSINESS & ECONOMY DBS exits India NBFC biz Khyati Dharamsi   words   March   DNA - Daily News & Analysis DNADAI English Copyright  . Diligent Media Corporation Ltd. Sells  . % in Cholamandalam DBS Finance to Murugappa Group DBS, Singapore\'s largest bank, is exiting its non-banking finance venture in India. It is selling off its  . % stake in Cholamandalam DBS Finance to partner Murugappa Group in a deal worth Rs   crore. The shares would be purchased at Rs   per share, which is a  . % premium to the closing price of Rs  .  at the Bombay Stock Exchange on Monday. Shares of Cholamandalam DBS Finance closed on Tuesday at Rs   per share after touching a high of Rs  .  intraday. "The transaction is expected to be completed on or before   April  ," a statement issued on Tuesday said. The bank said the move was in line with its new target customer group. "DBS remains committed to India, a high-growth market, where it has enjoyed stellar performance over the past five years. The bank is executing swiftly on the new strategic roadmap unveiled by chief executive officer Piyush Gupta in February. In India, the bank wants to focus on corporate clients as well as high-networth individuals and emerging affluent segments," it said in a response to DNA Money. Gupta took charge of DBS\'s India operations in November,  . The Murugappa Group also clarified on Tuesday that options were open for future tie-ups. India contributes  % to DBS\' total business, the third-largest after Singapore and Hong Kong. The India business is seen growing  - % in  - . "DBS and Murugappa Group remain open to future collaboration opportunities in areas such as wealth management, distribution of financial products, etc." DBS had also earlier exited its mutual fund venture in the country, which was again in tie-up with Murugappa Group, after DBS Cholamandalam Mutual Fund was acquired by L&T Finance early this year. Top Stories Mahindra to Buy BAE Systems  % Stake in India JV Santanu Choudhury   words   February    :  Dow Jones Top News & Commentary DJCOMM English Copyright (c)  , Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Mahindra & Mahindra Ltd. ( .BY) will buy BAE Systems PLC\'s (BAESY) stake in Defence Land Systems, a joint venture, the two companies said Saturday. "This decision is a reflection of the shareholders\' belief that they can best meet emerging customer requirements and address the opportunities in this dynamic market with a flexible, tailored approach that was not easily facilitated by the structure of the existing Joint Venture entity," they said in a joint statement, without specifying details of the stake buy. Mahindra and BAE Systems will consider opportunities for working together on specific projects, they added. Defence Land Systems makes military vehicles at a facility on the outskirts of New Delhi. The partners had said in January that they were reviewing the JV. Mahindra also has a JV with U.S.-based Telephonics Corp. a unit of Griffon Corp. (GFF), to make radar systems in India, and another with United Arab Emirates-based Arabia Holdings and Ras Al Khaimah Transport Investments LLC to make and sell armored vehicles in the Middle East and Central Asia as well as in Africa. With losses mounting, auto instruments manufacturer Pricol has exited its joint venture with Japanese partner Denso Corporation, when it sold its  % stake in Denso Pricol India (DPIN) to Denso for a consideration of Rs   crore. DPIN has now become the wholly-owned subsidiary of Denso. "The JV was making huge losses. The business was not going as per plan," said Vikram Mohan, MD of Pricol. DPIN, which had revenues of around Rs   crore in  , was supplying instrument clusters exclusively to Japanese carmakers Toyota, Honda and Suzuki. The JV envisaged total buyout of Pricol by Denso in five years and involved transfer by Pricol, of its \'Denso Technology Instrument Cluster Undertaking\' relating to four-wheeler personal passenger vehicles, situated at Coimbatore and Gurgaon to Pricol Components, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Pricol. Ltd was formed in   as a JV between Continental Equipment and Desmon SpA wherein both the partners held equal stake. It had set up a manufacturing facility for professional refrigerators near Bhiwadi in Rajasthan. Post acquisition, the JV would be named Continental Frostline Pvt. Ltd. and its products would be branded under the name Frostline. Continental Equipment, started in  , is a commercial food service equipment manufacturer and supplier. The company\'s products include counter top range , ovens, veggie washer; its imported product portfolio includes dish washer, coffee machine, food processing machine, etc. Continental is focused in the areas of Project and Key Accounts Management. The projects executed in India and abroad, range from   &   star hotels to canteens, schools, ashrams, hospitals, specialty restaurants etc. It is a supplier to McDonalds, KFC, Pizza Hut, Papa Johns, Sbarro, Yo China, Nirula’s, Barista, Café coffee day, Costa and many other International and Indian QSRs and provides services in the form of equipment design, equipment fabrication, imported and indian equipment distribution, installation, warranty, service etc. Desmon SpA which was founded by the family De Santis in   in Italy as a company for the marketing of catering equipment however later it began production of refrigerators under its own brand. It has two factories in Nusco (AV) and other manufacturing facilities in India and China with three distribution centers live in France, UK and Germany.
