All rights reserved. UPDATE: DLF To Exit Mutual Fund JV With Prudential - Source   words   January    :  Dow Jones International News DJI English (c)   Dow Jones & Company, Inc. (Adds details on the mutual fund JV, background) By Nikhil Gulati Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES NEW DELHI (Dow Jones)--DLF Ltd. ( .BY), India\'s biggest realty company by sales, will exit a mutual fund joint venture in the country with Prudential Financial Inc. (PRU) because of a proposed regulatory change, a person with direct knowledge of the matter said Monday. "The move is prompted by a proposed regulatory change, which makes it mandatory for a company to have five years of experience before selling mutual funds," the person, who didn\'t wish to be named, told Dow Jones Newswires. The move is also in line with the New Delhi-based company\'s strategy to focus on real estate development, the person added. DLF currently owns  % in the joint venture--DLF Pramerica Asset Managers Pvt. Ltd.--while Prudential owns the remaining  %. "DLF will sell its  % stake to Prudential," the person said, without disclosing details of the likely valuation of DLF\'s stake in the venture. Spokespeople from Prudential weren\'t immediately available for comment. The person said also that the time frame for DLF\'s exit from the joint venture is yet to be decided. In November  , DLF and Prudential had received an approval from the markets regulator, the Securities & Exchange Board of India, to jointly sell mutual funds and said they will jointly invest $  million in DLF Pramerica. DLF Pramerica was planning to start selling mutual funds in  . Earlier Monday, The Economic Times newspaper reported that DLF plans to exit the venture to reduce its debt of nearly INR  billion. DLF has been exiting its non-core businesses as part of its strategy to focus more on property development. The company\'s founders recently sold its multiplex-chain, DT Cinemas, to Indian multiplex operator PVR Ltd. The real estate developer also previously announced plans to sell its wind power business. Still, DLF has a separate life insurance venture with Prudential, DLF Pramerica Life Insurance Co. Ltd., in which the Indian realty firm owns a majority  % stake, while the remaining stake is held by the U.S.-based insurance company. "The life insurance business is continuing and is doing very well for DLF," the person said. The life insurance business began operations in September   with an equity base of INR .  billion. In November  , DLF had said that the companies will jointly infuse INR  billion of capital over next five to six years in the life insurance venture. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. -By Nikhil Gulati, Dow Jones Newswires; + - - - ; nikhil.gulati@dowjones.com (Shikhar Balwani in Mumbai also contributed to this story.) [  - -   GMT ] Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. DLF buys out Hiltons in  :  hotel JV Distributed by Contify.com   words   December   Realty Plus ATREAP English Copyright ©   Adsert Web Solutions Pvt. Ltd. The country\'s largest realty firm DLF has bought out its foreign partner Hilton in its hospitality firm DLF Hotels (formerly known as DLF Hilton Hotels Ltd) for an undisclosed sum. DLF held majority stake in the  :  joint venture that clocked revenues of Rs  .  crore with profit after tax of Rs  .  crore during the year ended March  ,  . The financial details of the latest transaction stands undisclosed but it would run into several crores, reports VCCircle. Although the JV did not manage to scale up as fast as hospitality industry analysts had hoped for, arguably due to the economic slowdown that hit the hospitality business specially hard during  - , the JV had paid up capital of Rs  .  crore as per balance sheet disclosure for FY . Among the listed peers, a company like Hotel Leelaventure Ltd is currently trading   times its FY  net profit. If this is taken as a benchmark, DLF Hotels could be valued at around Rs   crore or more and Hilton\'s stake could then be worth around Rs   crore ($  million), as per VCCircle estimates. DLF, which also owns and operates the luxury segment hospitality brand Aman Resorts across the world, had formed an alliance with Hilton for development and management of hotels in India a few years ago. The debt-laden realty firm had been taking a hard look at the hotel business and among the many options, it has been looking at the possibility of selling Aman Resorts. DLF had formed the JV with Hilton a few years ago, in one of the first large foreign direct investment transactions in the hospitality sector in the country. Although various international hotel brands operate in India, with some of them having been here for decades, most of them entered the market through management contracts by lending their brand names to local partners. Images, graphs or charts, if any, have been removed Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Limitless to divest Indian JV   words   December   Mubasher MUBEN English ©   Mubasher Info. All Rights Reserved. Provided by Syndigate.info, an Albawaba.com company The Indian government has reported approved plans by Dubai-based developer Limitless to exit its joint venture with a real estate major after failing to progress on a proposed project, Arabian Business reported.Its   partnership with DLF, one of India\'s largest real estate companies, had planned to develop a township in Karnataka.But according to local media reports, the venture failed to acquire the land required for the project and no building work has taken place.Now, the government has allowed Limitless to walk away while repatriating some of the capital it put in to the joint venture, reports added.The Foreign Investment Promotion Board (FIPB) has approved the proposal of DLF Limitless Developers Pvt Ltd, an official statement said."The proposal was related to exit of foreign investors and the repatriation of capital as the construction sector project could not even acquire land," it added.Last month, Limitless said it is set to restart construction of its first residential tower at The Galleries, with   units for lease at the company’s flagship project in Dubai.It said Galleries at Downtown Jebel Ali already comprised four completed, fully operational commercial buildings. Under an agreement with sister company Nakheel, Limitless will restart work on the first apartment building, it said. ; All Rights Reserved - Mubasher Info Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Dubai s Limitless said to exit Indian joint venture Andy Sambidge   words   December   ArabianBusiness.com ARBUS English ©  , ArabianBusiness.com, All rights Reserved - Provided by SyndiGate Media Inc. The Indian government has reported approved plans by Dubai-based developer Limitless to exit its joint venture with a real estate major after failing to progress on a proposed project.Its   partnership with DLF, one of India\'s largest real estate companies, had planned to develop a township in Karnataka.But according to local media reports, the venture failed to acquire the land required for the project and no building work has taken place.Now, the government has allowed Limitless to walk away while repatriating some of the capital it put in to the joint venture, reports added.The Foreign Investment Promotion Board (FIPB) has approved the proposal of DLF Limitless Developers Pvt Ltd, an official statement said."The proposal was related to exit of foreign investors and the repatriation of capital as the construction sector project could not even acquire land," it added.Last month, Limitless said it is set to restart construction of its first residential tower at The Galleries, with   units for lease at the company’s flagship project in Dubai.It said Galleries at Downtown Jebel Ali already comprised four completed, fully operational commercial buildings. Under an agreement with sister company Nakheel, Limitless will restart work on the first apartment building, it said. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Provided by Syndigate.info, an Albawaba.com company The Indian government has reported approved plans by Dubai-based developer Limitless to exit its joint venture with a real estate major after failing to progress on a proposed project, Arabian Business reported.Its   partnership with DLF, one of India\'s largest real estate companies, had planned to develop a township in Karnataka.But according to local media reports, the venture failed to acquire the land required for the project and no building work has taken place.Now, the government has allowed Limitless to walk away while repatriating some of the capital it put in to the joint venture, reports added.The Foreign Investment Promotion Board (FIPB) has approved the proposal of DLF Limitless Developers Pvt Ltd, an official statement said."The proposal was related to exit of foreign investors and the repatriation of capital as the construction sector project could not even acquire land," it added.Last month, Limitless said it is set to restart construction of its first residential tower at The Galleries, with   units for lease at the company’s flagship project in Dubai.It said Galleries at Downtown Jebel Ali already comprised four completed, fully operational commercial buildings. All rights reserved. Corporate DLF to End Ties with Ferragamo RAVI TEJA SHARMA NEW DELHI   words   May   The Economic Times - Mumbai Edition ECTMUM English Copyright ©  . Bennett, Coleman & Co., Ltd. Realtor to focus on selling premium, luxury fashion brands in the country Less than a fortnight after ending its joint venture with Giorgio Armani, DLF said it is in the process of breaking its partnership with another Italian luxury brand Salvatore Ferragamo as part of a move to exit luxury brands business."Luxury is a futuristic business in India at the moment and does not have scale," DLF Brands Chief Executive Officer Dipak Agarwal says. The real estate major will instead focus on selling premium and bridge-to-luxury fashion brands such as Boggi, Alcott, Mango, Mothercare, Claire\'s and DKNY."This segment is much more profitable and scalable," Agarwal says. He says that while luxury brands have a big future in India, it will require another five to seven years to achieve scale and market size."For us, size with speed was important," he says. The company has had only four Ferragamo and three Armani stores since it entered the luxury brands segment in   as expansion of these brands in a limited market was getting difficult. In comparison, UK retailer Mothercare, which sells prams, pushchairs, car seats, baby clothes and also maternity clothes, entered India in   and already has   stores in the country. It will add   more stores this year. Boggi has   stores and DLF will add another three stores in the next one-year. The luxury market in India is bogged down with issues such as high import duties and lack of skilled manpower and quality real estate. There is only one luxury mall in the country currently, the DLF Emporio in Delhi, and brands are reluctant to enter high street locations due to poor infrastructure around them. The cost of retail real estate is very high and that has been nibbling into the profits of luxury retailers in the country. Today, it costs. -  crore to set up a luxury store while a store for a premium brand can be made for. -  lakh. To offset this cost, some luxury brands have resorted to reducing the size of their stores to improve the sales per sq ft of space. DLF Brands currently operates   stores for its brands and Agarwal hopes to take the number to   in the next three to four years. While the company has decided not to invest in new luxury brands at the moment, Agarwal says it may help some top brands enter the country through support on the real estate and supply chain fronts. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Educomp Sells Its  % Stake in IndiaCan To Pearson; Selling To Consolidate Brindaalakshmi K   words   April   MediaNama HTMEDN English Copyright  . MixedBag Media Pvt. Ltd. RIL_button( "http://www.medianama.com/ / / -educomp-indiacan-pearson/", "Educomp Sells Its  % Stake in IndiaCan To Pearson; Selling To Consolidate" ); Education company, Educomp has sold  % of its stake in IndiaCan, a vocational training business to Pearson, its JV partner in the venture,  according to BSE filing. IndiaCan is a JV that was started between Educomp and Pearson in   to tap on the vocational training market in India. Educomp in its press release has stated that this move is part of their “consolidation strategy", a third in a series of exits from non-core businesses. The company says that this stake sale has been made to avoid the need to fund losses and other capital needs of a non-core business. It is not clear if IndiaCan has been making losses that Educomp has not been able to fund. Educomp\'s Consolidation:  Educomp further plans to focus on digital content & IP offering and asset backed offerings like schools and colleges.  Note that Educomp Online is Educomp\'s online education platform. It is not clear if there are other IP offerings or any in the pipeline. But it is clear that Educomp plans to keep its focus on digital. In January  , Authorgen, a subsidiary of Educomp Solutions Ltd, had raised Rs   crore from Kaizen, a private equity firm and a German media company, Bertelsmann. Authorgen through its website, WizIQ.com enables education service providers to create virtual classrooms and also convert document to flash. It appears that Educomp has also sold  % stake in Eurokids International Ltd to a group of investors led by GPE India, last month. In  , Educomp merged Studyplaces.com after being acquired in  .  It is worth noting that Kleiner Perkins, Caulfield & Byers (KPCB), Sherpalo Ventures and InfoEdge, all investors in Studyplaces.com had reported that they lost money in the business.  Educomp plans to further continue this consolidation process. Other Developments in the Education Sector Note that IndiaCan is the second acquistion for Pearson this year. In February  , Pearson had acquired the remaining  % stake in TutorVista thereby increasing its stake in the company to  %. TutorVista provides online tutoring service to students. In the same month, e-learning site MeritNationraised Rs   crore funding from Info Edge (India). With this investment, InfoEdge became a majority stakeholder in Applect Learning Systems, the company that owns MeritNation. In March  , online test platform, Rank Junction had raised undisclosed sum of money from Indian Angel Network. In the same month, Skoolshop.com, an ecommerce site run by Occasion Kommerce Pvt. Ltd had raised series A funding from Blume Ventures & others. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Real Estate Emaar to end JV with Indian partner MGF Swet Sarika   words   April   VC Circle MMVVCC English Copyright  . Mosaic Media Ventures Pvt. Ltd. Emaar Properties PJSC, Dubai’s biggest developer, has decided to end its  -year-old joint venture with MGF Developments Ltd in India following a year-long separation tussle between the partners. Emaar said in a statement on Wednesday it will take steps to reorganise Emaar MGF Land Ltd via a demerger to sharpen its focus on its Indian operations and develop ongoing projects. The development comes almost a year after reports first surfaced about a possible split due to disagreement between the partners but Emaar had denied any such move. The Dubai developer had brought in about Rs  ,  crore in the joint venture and owned roughly   per cent stake along with loans and guarantees while MGF held the remaining stake. While Emaar didn’t disclose details of the demerger, media reports have suggested that the Dubai firm is likely to get a bigger share when the two partners split assets. “They were in discussion to thrash out the various issues with regard to debt and partly completed projects that were stuck due to paucity of funds. It was a complicated process as it involves many running projects and large land parcels of about  ,  acres spread over various cities in India," The Economic Times reported citing a person familiar with the development. Emaar MGF, formed in  , is known mainly for building the Commonwealth Games Village for athletes taking part in the event’s   edition in New Delhi. However, it faced massive criticism for delays and poor construction quality. It also tried to float an initial public offering but couldn’t do so after the stock markets plunged following the global economic crisis in  . It made more attempts to launch an IPO in   and   but ultimately scrapped the plans. Emaar is famous for developing the world’s tallest building, the Burj Khalifa, in Dubai. Headed by chairman Mohamed Ali Rashad Alabbar, Emaar has operations in   countries in the Middle East, North Africa, Asia and Europe. MGF Development was started by Shravan Gupta in  . It claims to have delivered   million square feet of retail space and is developing about   million square feet of retail space and   million square feet of residential space. Known for its retail assets at the time of forming the JV, MGF now has presence across residential, commercial and retail segments with projects in Gurgaon, Mohali, Jaipur, Indore and Hyderabad.  The joint venture was formed during the heyday of real estate when huge capital flowed in. But exits have been a pain point with some markets under the grip of a slowdown. The past two years have been particularly painful for developers as tepid forced them to look for various financing options to survive.  The national capital region, where the company has maximum exposure, has been worst hit by the slowdown with sales slipping significantly over the years. This has taken the unsold stock with developers to an alarming level. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. ERGO, HERO GROUP NOT TO PURSUE JOINT VENTURE (Hero Group has decided against diversification into life insurance) Business Line. Mar  ,  ; pg     words   March   Indian Business Insight WIBI  -  English Copyright (c)   Informatics (India) Ltd. Munich Re\'s primary insurance unit ERGO Insurance Group and the Hero Group have called off their planned life insurance joint venture. They had signed an agreement in May   and the proposed venture was to start operations in  . The Hero Group has decided against diversification into the life insurance business at this point while ERGO Insurance Group sees good potential in the domestic life insurance market and will actively seek an entry into the market. Geometric Rises on Deal With HCL Tech, Dassault -- Market Talk   words   April    :  Dow Jones Institutional News DJDN English Copyright ©  , Dow Jones & Company, Inc.   GMT [Dow Jones] Shares of Indian software firm Geometric Ltd. ( .BY) are up  . % at  .  rupees after it said over the weekend that it will sell to Indian outsourcing firm HCL Technologies Ltd. ( .BY). Shareholders of Geometric will receive ten shares in HCL for every   shares held in a deal analysts pegged at $  million. Geometric\'s  % share in its venture with Dassault Systemes S.A. (DSY.FR) will be deal with separately, with the Indian company merged into the venture  DPLM Software Solutions Ltd. and the entire shareholding sold to Dassault. Geometric shareholders will get one listed redeemable preference share of   rupees carrying a dividend of  % a year in  DPLM. Hershey to Acquire All Outstanding Shares of the Godrej Hershey Joint Venture  ,  words   September    :  Business Wire BWR English (c)   Business Wire. All Rights Reserved. HERSHEY, Pa.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--September  ,  -- The Hershey Company ("Hershey") (NYSE: HSY) today announced that it has reached an agreement to acquire the   percent stake in Godrej Hershey Ltd. that it does not own, primarily from Godrej Industries Ltd. ("Godrej") and another minority shareholder. Including the assumption of about $ .  million in debt, which is already consolidated by Hershey as the majority shareholder, the company will own the Maha Lacto and Nutrine candy brands and the Jumpin and Sofit beverage brands as well as the related manufacturing facilities. The transaction is expected to close by the end of the third quarter and the new entity will transition to use the name Hershey India as it becomes a wholly owned subsidiary of The Hershey Company. As part of the transaction, the minority shareholders will receive an undisclosed cash consideration. "India is a key focus market for The Hershey Company," said J.P. Bilbrey, President and Chief Executive Officer, The Hershey Company. "We have a great deal of respect for Godrej. Our partnership provided us with insights and an understanding of the consumers and customers in India. Confectionery and beverage category growth in India is solid and we\'re excited about our opportunities. We\'ll make the necessary investments in India to accelerate growth, leveraging our core strengths and business model." The transaction gives Hershey an opportunity to integrate Godrej Hershey into the company\'s global business platform and leverage corporate resources across the chocolate and sweets and refreshment strategic business units. Over time, Hershey\'s goal is to evolve into a faster growing India market leader in the food and beverage space. "With this new phase of the Hershey business in India, we aim to drive growth in this important market through product innovation, brand building and investment in our people and processes," said Matthew Lindsay, Managing Director, Hershey India. "Leveraging the learnings from our Godrej partnership and the strong management team in place, we are excited to move forward in this rapidly growing market," Lindsay concluded. For the year ended December  ,  , the Godrej Hershey joint venture had net sales of about $  million. The portion of the net loss for the full year attributable to Hershey was approximately $  million. When the Godrej Hershey joint venture was announced in  , annual net sales were about $  million. As a result of this transaction there is no change to the financial outlook provided by Hershey on July  ,   in its second quarter earnings release. Safe Harbor Statement This release contains statements that are forward-looking. These statements are made based upon current expectations that are subject to risk and uncertainty. Because actual results may differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements you should not place undue reliance on the forward looking statements when deciding whether to buy, sell or hold the Company\'s securities. Factors that could cause results to differ materially include, but are not limited to: issues or concerns related to the quality and safety of our products, ingredients or packaging; changes in raw material and other costs; selling price increases, including volume declines associated with pricing elasticity; market demand for our new and existing products; increased marketplace competition; disruption to our supply chain; failure to successfully identify, execute and integrate acquisitions, divestitures and joint ventures; changes in governmental laws and regulations, including taxes; political, economic, and/or financial market conditions; risks and uncertainties related to our international operations and related growth targets; disruptions, failures or security breaches of Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. our information technology infrastructure; the impact of future developments related to the investigation by government regulators of alleged pricing practices by members of the confectionery industry, including risks of subsequent litigation or further government action; pension cost factors, such as actuarial assumptions, market performance and employee retirement decisions and funding requirements; the ability to implement our supply chain realignment initiatives within the anticipated timeframe in accordance with our cost estimates and our ability to achieve the expected ongoing annual savings from these initiatives; and such other matters as discussed in our Annual Report on Form  -K for  . All information in this press release is as of September  ,  . The Company undertakes no duty to update any forward-looking statement to conform the statement to actual results or changes in the Company\'s expectations. About The Hershey Company The Hershey Company (NYSE: HSY) is the largest producer of quality chocolate in North America and a global leader in chocolate and sugar confectionery. Headquartered in Hershey, Pa., The Hershey Company has operations throughout the world and approximately  ,  employees. With revenues of more than $  billion, Hershey offers confectionery products under more than   brand names, including such iconic brands as Hershey\'s, Reese\'s, Hershey\'s Kisses, Hershey\'s Bliss, Hershey\'s Special Dark, Kit Kat, Twizzlers, Jolly Rancher and Ice Breakers. Hershey also offers premium and artisan chocolate products under such brands as Scharffen Berger and Dagoba through the Artisan Confections Company, a wholly owned subsidiary. The company is focused on growing its presence in key international markets such as China and Mexico while continuing to build its competitive advantage in the United States and Canada. For more than   years, The Hershey Company has been a leader in making a positive difference in the communities where its employees live, work and do business. Corporate Social Responsibility is an integral part of the company\'s global business strategy, which includes goals and priorities focused on fair and ethical business dealings, environmental stewardship, fostering a desirable workplace for employees, and positively impacting society and local communities. Milton Hershey School, established in   by the company\'s founder and administered by Hershey Trust Company, provides a quality education, housing, and medical care at no cost to children in social and financial need. Students of Milton Hershey School are direct beneficiaries of The Hershey Company\'s success. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. ("Godrej") and another minority shareholder. Godrej Consumer acquires Godrej SCA Hygiene   words   June   The Press Trust of India Limited PRTRIN English (c)   Asia Pulse Pty Limited. Mumbai, June   (PTI) FMCG major Godrej Consumer Products has bought out Sweden-based SCA Hygiene Products AB in the joint venture Godrej SCA Hygiene. Godrej Consumer Products was a   per cent shareholder in Godrej SCA Hygiene, the company that owns the "Snuggy" brand of baby diapers, among others. Now it owns   per cent. With the acquisition of the balance   per cent stake in the firm, "Godrej SCA Hygiene has become a wholly owned subsidiary of the company with effect from April  ," it said in a filing to the Bombay Stock Exchange. However, the financial details were not disclosed. Godrej SCA Hygiene was a joint venture between Godrej Consumer Products and SCA Hygiene Products AB. The board of Godrej Consumer Products had approved the acquisition of the   per cent stake in the joint venture on December  ,  . Shares of Godrej Consumer today closed at Rs  . , down  .  per cent from its previous close on the BSE. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. NEC Acquires Full Ownership of Indian Software Company   words   March    :  JCN Newswire JAPCOR English Copyright   JCN Newswire, a division of Japan Corporate News Network K.K. All rights reserved. - NEC Technologies India established - Tokyo, Mar  ,   - (JCN Newswire) - NEC Corporation (NEC; TSE:  ) and HCL Technologies Limited (HCLT) reached an agreement for NEC to obtain full control of NEC HCL Systems Technologies (NHST), a joint venture software company. Based on the agreement, NEC will acquire HCLT\'s  % share of NHST. As a result, NHST will become a wholly owned subsidiary of NEC. The subsidiary\'s name is scheduled to become NEC Technologies India Limited in April  . NHST was established in October   in order to enhance software developing resources in India. Since then, the company has developed software products for the platform business in partnership with the experience and knowledge of HCLT. The new subsidiary will play a key role in the development and system integration of NEC\'s solutions business throughout the emerging India and Asia Pacific markets, as well as Europe and the US. "NEC Technologies India will lead a global deployment of product technology and development," said Takaaki Shimizu, Senior Vice President of NEC. "The company will become an offshore software development base for systems in Asia Pacific, Europe, the US and Japan, in addition to its current software development for the platform business. Moreover, NEC will strengthen its global sales and support by leveraging the new company\'s experience and know-how in development, technology and business channels." Going forward, NEC aims to continue strengthening the global competitiveness of its products, costs, business promotions and human resources. Furthermore, NEC will create new value for customers as an IT partner that provides competitive products and support throughout the world. About NEC Corporation NEC Corporation (TSE:  ) is a leader in the integration of IT and network technologies that benefit businesses and people around the world. By providing a combination of products and solutions that cross utilize the company\'s experience and global resources, NEC\'s advanced technologies meet the complex and ever-changing needs of its customers. NEC brings more than   years of expertise in technological innovation to empower people, businesses and society. For more information, visit NEC at http://www.nec.com. Home Page HDFC buys Chubb out of JV Gayatri Ramanathan,feedback@livemint.com livemint   words   May   Mint HNMINT English Copyright  . HT Media Ltd. All Rights Reserved. Mortgage major Housing Development Finance Corporation (HDFC) on Tuesday announced it has bought the  % stake of Chubb Global Financial Services Corp. in their joint venture, HDFC Chubb General Insurance Co., for an undisclosed amount. The general insurance joint venture was set up in  . An executive at HDFC, who did not wish to be named, said the book value of the equity in the joint venture was Rs  crore; that would mean the book value of Chubb’s stake is Rs  crore. Conrad D’Souza, treasurer at HDFC, said the company has applied to the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority (Irda), the watchdog for the sector, seeking its approval for the change in the holding pattern. People close to the development at HDFC, who did not wish to be identified, said Ergo, the insurance arm of the world’s second-largest reinsurance company—Germany’s €  billion (more than Rs  lakh crore) Munich Re—is the front-runner to pick up the Chubb stake. “Till such time the Ergo deal is finalized, HDFC will hold  % stake in the general insurance venture,” said one of these people. “Initial joint venture strategies did not get translated,” said D’Souza. HDFC Chubb lags behind other general insurers such as ICICI Lombard General Insurance Co., Bajaj Allianz General Insurance Co., and others in terms of premiums collected. HDFC Chubb collected premiums of Rs  crore for the year ended March  , compared with Bajaj Allianz’s Rs ,  crore and ICICI Lombard’s Rs ,  crore. In fact, according to figures provided by Irda, while companies such as ICICI Lombard and Reliance General Insurance are growing at  - %, HDFC Chubb was actually not growing at all. The two companies differed on strategy, with HDFC favouring an aggressive customer acquisition strategy with a range of products and Chubb preferring a more conservative approach; “Chubb’s focus and HDFC’s focus were not the same,” said the executive at HDFC. Shrirang Samant, the insurance firm’s chief executive officer, quit two weeks ago. Indian insurance law caps an overseas partner’s stake in an insurance venture at  %, which restricts the amount of equity a foreign partner can put into a business that is highly capital-intensive. HDFC, which also has a life insurance joint venture with the UK’s Standard Life, wants a strategic partner with experience in general insurance, said the HDFC executive. “There are people interested in partnering with us,” said the executive. D’Souza said the proposed stake sale would be finalized only after the regulator’s approval. D’Souza also said insurance firms, both international and domestic, have expressed interest in picking up the Chubb stake. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. “As of now, we will run the business as it is. Who comes in as a partner or who will be the CEO will be decided only after the regulator’s approval of the buyout,’’ D’Souza said. India has licensed   overseas and local non-life insurers as part of its plan to open the sector to expand coverage of insurance in the world’s second fastest growing major economy. The foreign investment cap of  % has been an irritant for most foreign firms, which claim that this restricts their ability to invest in the business. The industry has been lobbying to raise the limit on foreign investment to  %, but this has met with political opposition from some quarters. Several foreign insurance firms have informal arrangements with their Indian partners to increase their stake to  %, should this be allowed. Reuters andGautam Chakravorthy of Bloomberg contributed to this story. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. BUSINESS & ECONOMY HDFC, Chubb to go their separate ways Nandini Goswami   words   May   DNA - Daily News & Analysis DNADAI English Copyright  . Diligent Media Corporation Ltd. Local partner will buy out Canadian major\'s  % stake in the JV It\'s almost official. HDFC and Chubb, financial giants in their own right who had joined hands for a general insurance venture in the country, are parting ways. HDFC has agreed to buy out the  % stake held by the foreign partner in the joint venture HDFC Chubb General Insurance Company and has applied to the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority (IRDA) for requisite approvals, an HDFC official told DNA Money on Tuesday. The company will continue as HDFC Chubb till a name change comes about, for which it has to apply to the Registrar of Companies. HDFC will now hold  % in the venture, though it is open to a  % foreign equity participation once it finds an appropriate foreign partner. The JV currently has an equity base of Rs   crore. "All employees will continue to be a part of the same company, where HDFC will have the entire stake and we will chose someone to head the company once all this is through," the official said. Fissures in the over four-year relationship have grown since last year because of differing risk appetites of the partners. HDFC, given its size and distribution strength, was keen to move fast. However, Chubb had an overcautious approach, particularly on commercial insurance, which was proving to be a drag on the company, the official said. While all general insurance companies have grown their business, HDFC Chubb General reported a decline in business by  . % for  - . Its total business premium was Rs  .  crore, one of the lowest in the general insurance industry. Its counterparts and even later entrants have marched way ahead, even as the public sector companies with a large base have also grown at higher rates. Also, the dynamics of the Rs  ,  crore general insurance industry has changed since the detariff regime kicked off in January this year and there was a crying need for a cohesive management structure to fight it out in the fiercely competitive market place. A formal split was thus waiting to happen. On the kind of signals the split sends out, the official said, "In fact, investors should be happy as there was a genuine concern for the company\'s falling numbers and now there is a concerted effort to grow the company. Everyone has a different way of functioning, and given the fact that all our other companies, like life insurance, asset management, bank and the BPO, are doing so well, there should not be any misconception on the break-up, which has been mutually agreed upon," the official added. So, what happens to Chubb now? Sources indicated that the global insurance giant is unlikely to discontinue insurance business in India. More so, as insurance analysts say, it would be a costly proposition to leave India at this juncture, at a time when the economy is booming, and re-entering later may see it lose two to three years straightaway. Market grapevine has it that Chubb is also scouting around for partners. This time, though, it may find some comfort with a clutch of investors instead of one single company, possibly including some high net-worth Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. individuals as well. The model could be on the lines of Metlife India. Whether it will be called \'Chubb India\' or not, though, remains to be seen. This, however, could not be confirmed. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. EIH terminates co-branding alliance with Hilton ; EIH Ltd, the flagship company of The Oberoi Group, today... BS REPORTER New Delhi   words   September   Business Standard BSTN English (c)   Business Standard Ltd. EIH Ltd, the flagship company of The Oberoi Group, today announced that it has terminated a strategic marketing and co-branding alliance with leading global hotel chain Hilton International Co. The decision will come into effect from April  ,  . Under the alliance, EIH managed and ran seven five-star hotels under the Trident Hilton brand Gurgaon, Agra, Cochin, Jaipur, Udaipur, Bhubaneshwar and Chennai. It also has a five-star deluxe property christened Hilton Towers in Mumbai. EIH will develop the Trident brand independently. All seven hotels will now be called The Trident and the deluxe property Trident Towers. "We felt there was a possibility of a dilution in the Trident brand with Hilton\'s overall development strategy in India. With Hilton planning to open the more downmarket Hilton Garden Inn in the country, we felt customers would get confused between that and the Trident Hilton," said SS Mukherji, vice-chairman, EIH. Realty firm DLF Ltd had forged a  :  joint venture with Hilton International last year. It is this joint venture company that will be setting up the Hilton Garden Inn brand. "The first Trident opened way back in   and we entered into an alliance with Hilton only in  . So we have always had our own marketing set-up which only has to be revamped. The company is already marketing The Oberoi brand very successfully," said Mukherji. Over the next three years, EIH will add  ,  rooms across three Trident Hotels in Mumbai, Bangalore and Hyderabad. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. FRONT PAGE ICI India to sell entire stake in Quest Our Bureau   words   November   Business Line (The Hindu) BSNLNE English (c)   The Hindu Business Line Nov.   Paints and chemicals firm ICI India Ltd, a subsidiary of UK\'s ICI Plc, has announced its plans to sell its entire stake in its wholly owned subsidiary Quest International India Ltd (Quest India) for not less than Rs   crore to Switzerland\'s Givaudan Group. The company\'s board of directors, at its meeting on Wednesday, approved the sale of its entire stake in Quest India — its flavours and fragrances business — to Givaudan Group, for a total consideration of not less than Rs   crore, ICI India informed the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE). The announcement followed news that ICI Plc had agreed to sell Netherlands-based Quest International B.V. to Givaudan for $  .  billion (around Rs  ,  crore). ICI India said in a statement that "ICI Plc has, after due evaluation, agreed to accept the offer for sale of Quest International business received by them very recently from the Givaudan Group, who has expressed interest in purchase of Quest India also. Considering the heavy linkages on the international business and the nature of the customers and the market, the board has decided to divest the company\'s entire shareholding in its subsidiary Quest lndia to the said Givaudan Group." The Indian transaction is expected to be completed before the end of the financial year, subject to the global deal happening within the same timeframe, it said. ICI India has controlling interest in Quest India, which was established in   as a joint venture between the ICI Group and Hindustan Lever Ltd (HLL). As per the joint venture agreement, ICI India acquired HLL\'s   per cent shareholding in May this year and subsequently acquired the remaining one per cent of the share capital held by a group company of ICI Plc. Consequently, Quest India became a wholly owned subsidiary of ICI India. Quest India reported net sales of Rs   crore and a net profit of Rs  .  crore for the financial year ended March  . The company is headquartered in Mumbai and has its manufacturing sites in Daman with about   employees on its rolls. Shares of ICI India were up seven per cent at Rs  .  on BSE on Wednesday. ICI has been carrying out a restructuring exercise wherein it will exit from non-core areas and focus on growing the core ones both organically and inorganically. As a step in this direction, ICI India, in June this year, announced the sale of the company\'s Uniqema business to UK-based Croda Group for around Rs   crore. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. Gerdau buys partner out of Indian joint venture   words   March   Steel Business Briefing STSCNW English ©   McGraw-Hill, Inc. India’s Kalyani Group has exited its steelmaking joint venture with Gerdau with the sale of its  % shareholding in the venture to the Brazilian steelmaking group, a Pune-based Kalyani Steel official confirmed to Platts Monday. The transaction was concluded in February, which was when Gerdau had announced the start of commercial production at the  ,  metric tons/year specialty steelworks at Tadipatri in southern India’s Andhra Pradesh state. Kalyani’s decision to exit the venture was owing to uncertainties in iron ore supplies in India, the official said. “We want to wait for a better situation before proceeding with expansions,” he said, adding that Kalyani’s own plant – a  ,  mt/y integrated alloy steelworks at Ginigera in Karnataka – has been operating at only  % capacity for nearly a year on ore supply disruptions. Iron ore for the Tadipatri works is being sourced from the ongoing electronic auction sales in Karnataka and from elsewhere, the official added. The jv – Kalyani Gerdau Steels – was formed in   through the acquisition of the assets of the  ,  million mt/y SJK Steel Plant in Tadipatri. Each partner held a  % shareholding. Last month, Gerdau revealed it had begun commercial production at the mill now comprising a  ,  million mt/y blast furnace, a  -megawatt power plant using gases from the furnace, a sintering plant, and a new  ,  mt/y rolling mill for special quality steel (SBQ) for the automobile industry. “As we begin our  th year of business, the start of the production of special steel in India represents our expansion to an important country, with an impressive cultural richness, good economic prospects and very dedicated people,” said André B. Gerdau Johannpeter, Gerdau’s CEO. For questions about editorial content, or to subscribe call +  ( )      , info@steelbb.com © Steel Business Briefing   Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. Accord Fintech India, Dec.   -- Kemrock Industries and Exports (Kemrock) has discontinued its joint venture (JV) - SAERTEX-KEMROCK India with effect from December  ,  . The JV is been discontinued with the mutual agreement of both the partners, in view of the change in business plan of the foreign JV partner. SAERTEX-KEMROCK India is a  :  JV between Kemrock Industries and Exports and SAERTEX Beteiligungsgesellschaft mbH, Germany.Further, the said entity is now being a wholly owned subsidiary and has been renamed as Kemrock Aerospace India. The company shall continue to forge ahead with its plan to manufacture materials and components for aeronautical industry with suitable partner(s) already under consideration.Kemrock manufactures and exports high-performance reinforced thermoset composites, commercially known as GRP/FRP Composites. L&T buys out Demag from joint venture ; After   years of joint operations, Larsen and Toubro (L&T)... NEVIN JOHN Mumbai   words   June   Business Standard BSTN   English (c)   Business Standard Ltd. After   years of joint operations, Larsen and Toubro (L&T) and Germany’s Demag Plastics Group have parted ways. The joint venture, which was set up in   for making plastics machinery, has ended after Demag’s new parent, Sumitomo, decided to go it alone in the Indian market by floating a wholly-owned subsidiary. “L&T-Demag Plastics Machinery, the Chennai-based joint venture company, will no longer be in existence as L&T has bought out its partner’s   per cent stake. Sumitomo, which acquired Demag in early- , has its own plan for India and it decided to break the relations with L&T,” said a company executive. The purchase gives L&T complete ownership of the operations in Chennai. After announcing its exit from the joint venture, Sumitomo Demag Plastics Machinery said in a statement, “As already announced in March  , Sumitomo Heavy Industries is proceeding to establish a subsidiary in India.” L&T officials declined to comment on the development. In  , the joint venture company had built its first factory for injection moulding machines. Three years later, it built a second factory in Chennai that doubled its production capacity to a thousand machines a year. Sumitomo Heavy Industries inherited the   per cent stake in the operation when it bought Demag in March  . However, for more that   years, Sumitomo has had a technical collaboration with another Indian injection machinery maker, Windsor Machines in Mumbai. L&T had started manufacturing injection moulding machines in   in association with Demag Plastics Group. But the two formed the  :  joint venture company only after nine years. Soon after, the venture had emerged as the leading injection moulding solutions provider in India. L&T Demag launched a petition last year to the India government in which it accused Chinese rivals of dumping presses at below cost in the Indian market. The government responded earlier this year by imposing anti-dumping duties of up to   per cent on   Chinese companies. Among these, three are associated with China’s largest injection machine maker, Ningbo Haitian Plastic Machinery Group. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. ASPEN, LUPIN DISCONTINUE TB JOINT VENTURE   words   January   Daily International Pharma Alert FDAIA English Copyright (c)   Washington Business Information, Inc. South African drugmaker Aspen Pharmacare and Lupin announced they have mutually agreed not to pursue the memorandum of understanding they signed in February   for the development, manufacture and marketing of tuberculosis (TB) drugs. The companies had agreed to a  -  joint global marketing agreement. Though the companies have discontinued that agreement, they will continue to collaborate on marketing TB drugs in South Africa as per a previous agreement. At the time of the signing of the February   agreement, the companies believed that there would be strength in the combination of Lupin\'s TB and active pharmaceutical ingredient pipeline and Aspen\'s multidrug-resistant TB product line and experience with antiretroviral drugs. The companies had also planned to explore opportunities in the malaria market. Aspen is the largest generic drugmaker in the Southern Hemisphere and one of the top   generic manufacturers worldwide, according to the company. It is also Africa\'s largest pharmaceutical company. Release date: Jan.  ,   Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Emerging Business & IT Hetero Drugs buys out Lyka\'s stake in JV   words   March   The Economic Times ECTIM English (c)   The Times of India Group. All rights reserved. HYDERABAD: Hyderabad-based Hetero Drugs, makers of the Tamiflu capsules, has bought out the stake of Gujarat-based Lyka Labs in the joint venture Lyka Hetero Healthcare for a consideration of Rs  .  crore. After gaining control of Lyka Hetero Healthcare, the company is busy drawing up a turnaround plan that includes fresh investments for improving sales margins and addition of new molecules in cardiology and antibiotics. Hetero expects the buyout of the JV partner\'s stake in Lyka Hetero will give them the much-needed stability and foothold in the domestic market. With its expanded basket, including formulations in antibiotics, pain management and anti- asthmatic, Hetero is expecting to reduce its dependency on APIs considerably. "Most of our turnover comes from export of APIs, where price volatility is high. By attaining full ownership of Lyka Hetero Healthcare, we will be able to focus on marketing formulations in domestic market. This will help us to circumvent the volatility, making our bottomline stronger," Hetero Drugs director (marketing), Srinivas Reddy, told ET. The company is likely to undertake a management restructuring as part of the turnaround. For the erstwhile joint venture, Hetero Drugs is looking to achieve a turnover of Rs   crore in one year against the present Rs   crore. "We found it difficult to chalk out marketing strategies within the confinement of a JV. Now we can focus on achieving sales volumes for the existing products. It will take  -  months for the new molecules to attain critical mass," Mr Reddy said. However, the company refused to make any comments on management restructuring. "The valuation process is on. It will take at least one month for us to finalise investments and other changes," he said. Lyka Hetero Healthcare was a  :  joint venture between Gujarat-based Lyka Labs and Hetero. It was floated to market Lyka\'s products in the domestic market. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Mahindra & Mahindra ends  -year defence JV with BAE Systems Distributed by Contify.com   words   February   Domain-B ATDOMB English Copyright ©  . The Information Company Pvt. Ltd. Mahindra & Mahindra (M&M) today said that its subsidiary Mahindra Defence Systems will acquire BAE Systems\'  -per cent stake in their defence joint venture, Defence Land Systems India (DLSI), ending a three-year partnership with Britain\'s biggest aerospace company. The move comes just a year after the London-based company appointed Dean McCumiskey as managing director and chief executive of its Indian operations in place of Andrew Gallagher in order to lead the next phase of BAE Systems\' business development in the country. (See: Dean McCumiskey to head BAE Systems in India (http://www.domain-b.com/people/in_the_news/ _bae_systems.html)) "This decision is a reflection of the shareholders\' belief that they can best meet emerging customer requirements and address the opportunities in this dynamic market with a flexible, tailored approach that was not easily facilitated by the structure of the existing joint-venture entity," both companies said in a joint statement. The two companies had set up the JV in   to develop new technologies and the manufacture of trusted armoured vehicles like the Axe, Rakshak, Marksman, up-armoured and bulletproof Scorpios and Boleros, and Rapid Intervention Vehicles. (See: Mahindra, BAE Systems set up defence JV for land systems (http://www.domain-b.com/companies/companies_m/Mahindra/ _mahindra_group_oneView.html)) At present, DLSI produces combat vehicles such as Rakshak, Rakshak Plus, Marksman and MPVi, armoured bus, riot intervention vehicle and Scorpio Uparmoured for VIP security. The company\'s Prithla plant has a capacity to produce up to   vehicles a year, of which up to   are MPV-Is. In the last three to four years the company has invested about Rs  crore on the plant. Commenting on the development, Brigadier (Retd) Khutub Hai, chairman and MD of Mahindra Defence Systems, "This is a strategic decision and will enable both the companies to approach opportunities individually and to offer customised solutions to meet the needs of the Indian defence land systems domain." Dean McCumiskey said, "Building domestic capabilities in partnership with Indian companies will remain a cornerstone of our strategy in India. We look forward to opportunities to collaborate with Mahindra and others to enhance the role of the private sector in the defence industry." M&M also has a JV with US-based Telephonics Corp to make radar systems and another with UAE-based Arabia Holdings and Ras Al Khaimah Transport Investments to develop armored vehicles for the Middle East, Central Asia and African market. BAE also has a software engineering joint venture in India called BAeHA with Hindustan Aeronautics Limited (HAL). Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. M&M to acquire Navistar\'s stake in MNAL Distributed by Contify.com   words   January   Commercial Vehicle ACOMVE English Copyright ©   Next Gen Publishing, distributed by Contify.com M&M and partner Navistar International Corporation have entered into an MoU, wherein the former will buy out the latter\'s equity in their JVs, Mahindra Navistar Automotives Ltd (MNAL) and Mahindra Navistar Engines Pvt Ltd (MNEPL). Following the purchase, both MNAL and MNEPL would become wholly-owned subsidiaries of Mahindra. Mahindra would take complete ownership of operations and continue to sell MNEPL and MNAL products albeit under its own brand name. The sale requires regulatory approval in India, is subject to the conclusion of definitive agreements, and is expected to be completed in early  . The terms of the proposed transaction call for Mahindra to pay approximately Rs.  crores or USD   million, for Navistar group\'s stake in both ventures. The payout will happen in two parts. While,   percent will be paid out as and when the deal goes through (upon the receipt of regulatory approvals), the remainder will be payable five years from the date of the first payment. The agreement allows Navistar to continue sourcing components from India while Mahindra would continue to provide engineering services to Navistar. Navistar Group would continue to support M&M through a license agreement and extend necessary support to MNAL and MNEPL for the purposes of business continuity. Crucially, the agreement covers the localised Maxxforce  .  litre engine. \'Under the terms of our agreement, we can use the Maxxforce engine for as long as needed for business continuity. The engine may be deployed for the domestic market as well as export operations,\' explains Dr. Goenka, President Automotive and Farm Equipment Sector. But, the engine is not exclusive to M&M.; Navistar can still commercially exploit it, subject to, \'a non-compete clause\'. Further investments So far, MNAL has registered sales of just  ,  units in the last  -  years, significantly below expectation. This is because, any new player entering the Indian truck market has to contend with the strong incumbents. And the going has not been easy this year, thanks to the slowdown-induced spell of heavy discounting. Therefore, the JV has seen accumulated losses to the tune of Rs   crore, as against investments of Rs  ,  crore. But this scenario has not dampened M&M\'s commitment to the CV industry. \'We stay committed to the truck and bus industry. Our dealers and trade partners are extremely happy with our intent to acquire Navistar\'s stake. As a matter of fact, we shall be investing more into the truck and bus business,\' asserts Dr. Goenka. M&M reportedly intends to plough Rs  -  crore in a bid to turnaround MNAL\'s operations over the next three years. The investment is meant to support and expand the range of almost completely localised trucks and engines as also its robust dealer and service network. M&M is confident that it can succeed in the truck business on its own steam. \'Given that we have a product range that is well-suited to the Indian market\'s needs, we do not feel the immediate need for a foreign JV partner. But, to be honest, we have not yet applied serious thought to this aspect,\' reveals Dr. Goenka. Navistar has decided to exit the JV because its finances are not in good shape. It has been the subject of investor activism and also the target of a speculated takeover by VW. What is more, a failed EPA   emissions compliance strategy saw longstanding Chairman Dan Ustian quit his position. Not surprisingly, the new management led by President and Chief Operating Officer, Troy Clarke is focussing on only those business areas that promise immediate return on capital under the \'Drive to Deliver\' programme. \'While the Indian market has not expanded as we had originally expected and industry challenges there continue in the near term, we still see promise in India going forward. But given Navistar\'s   priorities, our capital and focus needs to be allocated to other business opportunities in the near term.\' Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. The end to the MNAL JV follows the recent dissolution of the MANFORCE JV. Industry observers believes that given the tough and competitive nature of India\'s auto industry, it is often difficult to align the visions of Indian and foreign partners. Indeed, buyout of a partner\'s stake is not an alien concept for M&M.; It has acquired Renault\'s stake in the erstwhile JV covering the localisation and sales of cars and utility vehicles under the Logan brand. In a possibly encouraging precedent for the truck business, the Logan, now badged Verito has been performing better than it did under Mahindra- Renault. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. M&M TO BUY OUT RENAULT STAKE, MAKE LOGAN ON ITS OWN (the company is likely to price the Logan at below Rs  lakh) Business Line. Apr  ,  ; pg     words   April   Indian Business Insight WIBI  -  English Copyright (c)   Informatics (India) Ltd. Mahindra & Mahindra Ltd (M&M) has decided to buy out the  - percent stake of Renault in the Mahindra Renault joint venture. The company has received the licence from Renault to produce the Logan on its own. M&M will also export the sedan to markets like South Africa. The company is likely to modify the Logan and price it below Rs  lakh to increase the sales. M&M will retain the name of the Logan and Renault till   Dec  . The company is also planning to launch a passenger version of the Maxximo. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. FORCE MOTORS EXITS JV WITH MAN (Force Motors to sell its   percent stake in MFPTL to its partner MTBA for   million euros) Commercial Vehicle. Dec  ,  ; pg     words   December   Indian Business Insight WIBI English Copyright (c)   Informatics (India) Ltd. Force Motors is exiting from its joint venture, MAN Force Trucks Private Limited (MFTPL), with MAN Truck and Bus AG (MTBA). Force Motors is selling its   percent stake in MFPTL to its partner MTBA for   million euros or about Rs ,  crore. The joint venture had come into being in   with MTBA picking up   percent stake in MFTPL, which was later raised to   percent. The tie-up was intended to introduce world class trucks at Indian prices. But soon differences between the two arose over specification of trucks for Indian and overseas markets. This led to low sales and under utilisation of Pithampur capacity. Meanwhile MTBA also underwent management changes with Volkswagen raising its stake in MTBA. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Mastek, Deloitte end JV   words   March   The Press Trust of India Limited PRTRIN English (c)   Asia Pulse Pty Limited. Mumbai, Mar   (PTI) IT major, Mastek Limited, today said it has sold its entire equity interest in the joint venture Mastek-DC Offshore Development Company Pvt Ltd to affiliates of Deloitte Consulting LLP. Deloite Consulting LLP is a subsidiary of Deloitte & Touche USA LLP. The five-year-old joint venture was created to deliver a wide range of technology integration and related solutions for US clients of Deloitte Consulting. However, around   professionals employed in Mumbai will remain employees of the existing entity, a press release here said. Doug Lattner, Chairman and CEO of Deloitte Consulting, said, "our alliance with Mastek was instrumental in helping Deloitte Consulting build its business centre in Mumbai....It is now time to further commit to our offshore capabilities as an integral part of our service delivery and our purchase of Mastek\'s interest is a demonstration of that commitment." Sudhakar Ram, CMD, Mastek, said, "the joint venture has more than accomplished the objective we have set out and we wish Deloitte all the best in taking its Mumbai business centre forward." Sun Pharmaceutical and Merck Sharp & Dohme (MSD) have mutually decided to wind down their joint venture due to changes in the strategic priorities of both the parent companies. Apollo gets t(y)red, rolls out of Michelin JV   words   October   The Times of India TOI English (c)   The Times of India Group NEW DELHI: It was a mega tyre deal that Onkar Kanwar got tired of. Kanwar\'s Rs  ,  crore Apollo Tyres on Friday scrapped its much-touted two-year-old truck and bus radial tyre making joint venture with French tyre maker Michelin. Apollo has decided to walk out of the venture blaming the slow growth in the radial tyre market and deferment in project implementation. Apollo will now sell its  % stake in the the JV - christened Michelin Apollo Tyres Pvt Ltd (MATPL) - to its French partner at book value. Though company officials refused to divulge details of the financial transaction, sources said Apollo would get around $  million for its  % holding in the JV. The two firms, however, still remain partners as Michelin continues to hold  . % stake in Apollo Tyres. "There is no intention of buying back this stake from Michelin, and we will… … continue to explore opportunities for co-operation in India," a source said. The board of directors of Apollo Tyres on Friday approved the transfer of the JV\'s assets to Michelin. The proceeds from the stake sale will be used to expand Apollo\'s existing facilities and grow its presence in tyre market. MATPL was floated nearly two years back and the partners had agreed to set up a plant in Ranjangaon (Pune) with an initial investment of $  million, the project is yet to get underway. "The decision is based on prevailing market conditions and the pace of radialisation in the truck and bus tyre segments. While the use of radial tyres has gone up in the past two years, it is at a pace slower than what was projected by the partners," Apollo said. The Ranjangaon venture will offer the existing range of Michelin products, it said. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. CORPORATE `Exit from Michelin joint venture not a setback for Apollo Tyres\' K.R. Srivats   words   October   Business Line (The Hindu) BSNLNE   English (c)   The Hindu Business Line New Delhi , Oct   APOLLO Tyres Ltd does not see its exit from the Michelin Apollo Tyres Pvt Ltd (MATPL), a  :   joint venture company with the Michelin group, as a "setback" in its efforts towards getting a slice of the high-potential truck and bus radial segment pie. "We will evolve a strategy for the truck and bus radial segment in the coming days. Our exit from the joint venture does not mean that we have had a setback or would not foray into truck and bus radial manufacturing in the future," Mr Sunam Sarkar, a member on the Apollo board, told Business Line. , The company and the Michelin group on Friday agreed to "realign their business plans" and announced Apollo\'s exit from MATPL. Apollo Tyres had invested close to $  million in the joint venture company, which was set up to manufacture truck and bus radial tyre for the domestic market. Mr Sarkar said that the slow pace of radialisation in the Indian truck and bus tyre segment (contributed by somewhat moderate progress in infrastructure build-up) had prompted Apollo Tyres to take a close look at its engagement with the joint venture company. "We will get almost entire amount invested in the joint venture company. We have neither lost or gained in financial terms," Mr Sarkar said. He added that the Michelin group would continue to hold the  .  per cent stake it acquired in Apollo Tyres two years ago. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. MICHELIN GEARS UP FOR ITS STRATEGY ROLL SANS APOLLO (the joint venture will be renamed, dual branded truck and bus tyres will be replaced by single branded Michelin tyres) Economic Times. Oct  ,  ; pg     words   October   Indian Business Insight WIBI  -  English Copyright (c)   Informatics (India) Ltd. Michelin, the French tyre company, wants to continue its market approach strategy in India despite having lost its partner, Apollo Tyres, in its joint venture company, Michelin Apollo Tyres Ltd (MATL). The original plan will continue and the focus will be on becoming the leader in the truck and bus radial market by  . The joint venture company will be renamed to reflect its new ownership structure and single branded Michelin tyres would replace the dual-branded truck and bus tyres. The proposed $ -million truck and bus radial plant at Ranjangaon, near Pune, to produce   lakh tyres has been temporarily shelved but will be taken up once the radial market matures. In the meanwhile, Michelin will continue to import tyres mainly from China and Thailand, depending on the specific requirements of the Indian market. ABSTRACT|DAILY Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. Corporate Trends New York Life to exit Indian insurance JV Khomba Singh   words   February   The Economic Times ECTIM English (c)   The Times of India Group. All rights reserved. NEW DELHI: New York Life Insurance Company plans to sell its near- % stake in Max New York Life Insurance in a transaction that could see it sharing about one-third of its sale proceeds with Analjit Singh-led Max India, its local partner in the joint venture. According to a person familiar with the development, New York Life, the US-based insurer, is in talks with a few European and Japanese companies as it seeks to exit India as part of its strategy to withdraw from Asia and focus on its home market of North America. As part of the strategy, New York Life has divested its stake in operations in Thailand, Hong Kong, South Korea and China since last year. The US insurer has agreed to pay around one-third of the sale proceeds to its local partner for its contribution in building the business and creating its valuation as well as for giving consent for the deal, even though Max India is not selling any shares itself. New York Life\'s stake in the Indian insurance JV is estimated to be worth around Rs  ,  crore and Max India could end up earning Rs  , - ,  crore on the basis of this valuation. "Our JV is a highly successful operation that provides important insurance products to the people of India. We do not comment on rumours," said a New York Life spokesman. Max India did not respond to an emailed query. Max New York Life, the country\'s largest non-banking private insurer, was incorporated in   and is one of the earliest joint venture companies involving a foreign partner. In addition to New York Life, Max India has a  % stake in the company and Axis Bank holds the remaining  %. The money earned by Max India from the transaction will be used to make good its accumulated losses in the insurance business and also scout for inorganic growth opportunities, said the person quoted above. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Nippon Chemiphar, Ranbaxy Terminate Alliance   words   December   Pharma Japan PHJP   English (c)  . Jiho, Inc. All rights reserved. Nippon Chemiphar and Ranbaxy Laboratories terminated their comprehensive business alliance, including capital ties, on December  . How the two companies will move in the market for generics in Japan has been watched with great interest since Daiichi Sankyo acquired Ranbaxy in  . They have finally decided to terminate their relationship initiated in   and independently follow their own path. Fifty percent of the shares of Nihon Pharmaceutical Industry (NPI) owned by Ranbaxy were acquired by Nippon Chemiphar for Y .  billion on the same day. NPI will continue to market four generics introduced from Ranbaxy and sell them through Nippon Chemiphar in Japan. Annual sales of these four products are approximately Y  billion. The effect of the deal on its business will be “minimal,”according to Nippon Chemiphar. Ranbaxy acquired  % of shares of NPI, a subsidiary of Nippon Chemiphar, in  , and increased its ownership to  % in  . However, its acquisition by Daiichi Sankyo has basically changed its strategy, and it has been obliged to reconsider its relationship with Nippon Chemiphar. According to Nippon Chemiphar, the two companies have been discussing the new partnership since summer in  . At the beginning, they discussed how to continue, not to terminate, their partnership. As they reviewed their mutual strategy, however, they have reached a conclusion that the best for both companies is to independently develop their own business. “This is a friendly, forward-looking decision,”according to Nippon Chemiphar. “I don\'t think Nippon Chemiphar will be able to fully develop its generics business on its own. We will consider partnering,”said President Kazushiro Yamaguchi of Nippon Chemiphar at a press conference in July   commenting on the possibility of M&As and alliances for the development of his company\'s generics business. At present, however, the company is not negotiating alliances with any foreign-affiliated generic company, according to the company\'s Public Relations Department. Daiichi Sankyo has not clarified its generics business policy in Japan. “We are analyzing recent market trends and weighing all possible options,”said a spokesperson for the company. Ashok Leyland completes acquisition of LCV JVs with Nissan Anil Sharma   words   November   IHS Global Insight Daily Analysis WDAN English Copyright  , IHS Global Insight Limited. All Rights Reserved. Ashok Leyland has completed the acquisition of three joint ventures (JVs) with Nissan, the company said in a statement. The three JVs in question are Ashok Leyland Nissan Vehicles Ltd (ALNVL) for vehicle manufacturing; Nissan Ashok Leyland Power Train Ltd (NALPT) for making powertrains; and Nissan Ashok Leyland Technologies Ltd (NALT), a technology JV. All the three JVs operate in the light commercial vehicle (LCV) space. As part of the agreement reached between Ashok Leyland and Nissan, the latter transferred its shareholding in the three ventures to the former for a consolidated consideration of INR  (USD . ). Ashok Leyland will continue to build the Dost, Partner, and Mitr LCVs, while servicing and parts availability for customers will be taken care of by a Nissan technical support team. Significance: The completion of the transaction is on expected lines as the competition watchdog in India had already cleared the deal agreed between the partners (see India:   November  : ). The two companies signed the JVs in   in an effort to gain a foothold in India\'s light and medium commercial vehicle market. However, the partnership did not go as planned with delays in product launches, declining sales, widening losses, and write-offs. Except for the Dost, the venture did not have any commercial success and the slower introduction of additional variants further contributed to the losses. Early this year, the differences between the partners came out into the public domain and subsequent development resulted in an exchange of legal notices to each other before both the parties decided to call off the partnership in September (see Japan – India:   September  : ). Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Industry End of the Road for Nissan\'s JVs with Ashok Leyland   words   September   The Economic Times ECTIM English (c)   The Times of India Group. All rights reserved. New Delhi: Japanese auto major Nissan Motor agreed to sell its entire stake in three joint ventures to partner Ashok Leyland, ending their eight-yearold collaboration. Ashok Leyland and Nissan had formed the JVs -Ashok Leyland Nissan Vehicles for vehicle manufacturing; Nissan Ashok Leyland Power Train for making power trains and Nissan Ashok Leyland Technologies, which is a technology joint venture -in  . The partners had invested about Rs.  ,  crore as equity between them. “Under the agreement signed on September  ,   by senior executives of Nissan and Ashok Leyland, these joint ventures will become wholly owned Ashok Leyland subsidiaries, upon receipt of all necessary approvals from the regulatory authorities in India,“ the com panies said in a joint statement. The process is expected to finish this year. The firms declined to disclose details of the financial implications. As per the restructured agreement, Ashok Leyland will continue to build under a licensing agreement light commercial vehicles Dost and Partner, which are based on Nissan\'s design, engineering and technology. Servicing and parts availability for customers will be ensured by a technical support arrangement. In addition, the two have agreed to continue a deal to pro reed to continue a deal to procure made-in-India parts for Nissan. “We have decided to acquire Nissan\'s stake in the three joint venture companies, and this will help focus our efforts to concentrate on core business initiatives and customers. We will continue our relationship with Nissan under the new arrangement,“ said Ashok Leyland MD Vinod Dasari. “Nissan and Ashok Leyland coming together was a good idea. There were differences in the way both companies wanted to approach the market and operationalise their strategies. This impacted volumes & culminated in the split,“ said VG Ramakrishnan, managing partner, Avanteum Advisors. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Companies Novartis Arm, Panacea Biotec End  -yr-old Vaccine JV DIVYA RAJAGOPAL MUMBAI   words   August   The Economic Times - Mumbai Edition ECTMUM English Copyright ©  . Bennett, Coleman & Co., Ltd. Swiss drugmaker Novartis\' subsidiary Chiron has snapped the eight-year-old joint venture which was formed with Delhi-based Panacea Biotec to develop and market paediatric vaccines, a move that comes as Novartis plans to go it alone in this business."Novartis wants to own the entire vaccine business and helm it on its own," a person familiar with the matter said on condition of anonymity. Both Novartis and Panacea did not respond to email queries sent by ET. Chiron Panacea Vaccines, the  :  JV, was focused on selling the pentavalent vaccines used in the immunisation of kids. At the time of the announcement of the JV, which was signed in  , both the companies had planned to invest $  million (about.  crore at current rates) into the company. In  , Novartis acquired Chiron from its other joint venture partner, Aventis, consolidating its ownership in the company. Analysts say Panacea Biotec, which is still recovering from a ban imposed by the World Health Organisation and is solely dependent on vaccine sales, may have to find another partner to push its business. Panacea Biotec\'s shares closed at. . , down  . %, and Novartis India\'s shares closed at. . , down  . %, on BSE on Tuesday. India\'s vaccine market, estimated to be close to. ,  crore, accounts for less than  % of the global vaccine coverage, according to a research report by consultancy firm McKinsey. With the government\'s intervention and increased awareness, the market can touch. ,  crore, the report says. India\'s growth potential has attracted multinational vaccine makers such as Novartis, Pfizer, Sanofi and GSK, some of which are focused exclusively on niche paediatric vaccines.divya.rajagopal@timesgroup.com Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. The Midstream business of Eagle Ford owns and runs   gathering plants and around   miles of pipelines. The JV, which was formed in  , is likely to generate $  million in cash flow in  , the statement said. Reliance, RTL end Indian venture AndyDickens   words   July   C  Media C MD English (c)  C  Media Ltd India’s Reliance Broadcast Network and Europe’s RTL Group have ended their joint venture behind action-orientated channel Big RTL Thrill. Reliance teamed up with RTL in   to operate the network, which launched in   with dubbed content from FremantleMedia, Endemol and Red Bull. The channel was initially broadcast in the Uttar Pradesh region before expanding into Mumbai, Kolkatta, Delhi, Maharashtra and Gujarat. A year ago RTL expanded the channel with an English-language feed. The split, which marks the exit of RTL from Indian TV, was mooted at the end of April when Anil Ambani’s Reliance bought out the company’s stake in the  /  JV. Just months ago Reliance and CBS Studios International ended their three-year-old JV, which operated Big CBS Prime, Big CBS Love and youth-skewing Big CBS Spark. Big RTL Thrill will be rebranded as Big Thrill. Reliance CEO Tarun Katial said the firm will begin investing in regional programming by the end of the year and hopes to add “local male action content” and new concepts. Big Thrill and its sister channel Big Magic, which focuses on comedy, are available on DTH platforms Dish TV, Reliance Digital TV and Videocon d h, and most of India’s major cable platforms.
