Mosaic Media Ventures Pvt. Ltd. Ad-for-equity media investor BCCL is a shareholder in the venture. Religare Enterprises Ltd, the public listed holding company of a string of financial services businesses, said on Thursday that it would exit its life insurance joint venture with its Dutch partner Aegon. The firm currently holds   per cent in Aegon Religare Life Insurance Co Ltd, while Aegon owns   per cent stake. The remaining   per cent is with ad-for-equity media investor Bennett, Coleman and Company Ltd (BCCL), the firm behind media publications and TV channels like The Times of India and Times Now. “After a strategic review, Religare has expressed a desire to exit the joint venture. Religare and Aegon have agreed that Religare will exit once a replacement shareholder is identified and is approved by the regulatory authorities,” Religare said. The FDI ceiling for insurance sector is in the process of being hiked to   per cent which would allow Aegon to buy a part of the stake held by Religare. However, Religare would need to find other buyers for its remaining holding. Aegon is an international provider of life insurance, pension and asset management. With headquarters in The Hague, the Netherlands, its companies employ over  ,  people serving millions of customers across the globe. Its main operations are in the US, the Netherlands and the UK, but in recent years the company has expanded into new growth markets in Asia, Central & Eastern Europe and Latin America. There are   life insurance firms in the country including state-run Life Insurance Co. Religare Aegon is the  st ranked life insurer among the   private life insurers in the country as per first premium collection for the period ended June  ,  . It had launched its pan-India operations in July,   following a multi-channel distribution strategy. Religare Enterprises share price closed at Rs  .  each, down  .  per cent on the BSE in a weak Mumbai market on Thursday. In another deal in the life insurance space, Kishore Biyani-led Future Group sold  .  per cent stake in Future Generali India Life Insurance Company Ltd to Industrial Investment Trust Ltd (IITL) last year. Also real estate developer DLF had sold its   per cent stake sale in DLF Pramerica Life Insurance Company Ltd -- its life insurance joint venture with Prudential International Inc – to Dewan Finance Corporation Ltd and its group entities. The firm has now been renamed as DHFL Pramerica Life Insurance. (Edited by Joby Puthuparampil Johnson) Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. BUSINESS Religare exits MF biz, sells  % to partner Invesco   words   November   Press Trust of India PRTRIN English Copyright  . The Press Trust of India Limited. New Delhi, Nov   (PTI) After life insurance, financial services group Religare Enterprises has decided to exit mutual fund business with sale of its controlling   per cent stake in Religare Invesco AMC to the foreign partner Invesco. While a number of foreign fund houses have exited the Indian mutual fund industry -- the latest being Goldman Sachs -- there have not been many cases where Indian entities have sold the asset management business. Earlier this year, Religare had sold its stake in its life insurance join venture. In May  , Religare had announced that it will exit Aegon Religare Life Insurance Company by selling its stake to existing partner Bennett, Coleman and Company Ltd (BCCL) of the Netherlands. Religare did not disclose the exact reasons for the sale of mutual fund business but sources said that the capital is being unlocked through mutual fund. The funds through stake sale will be used for health insurance and lending platform. The shares of Religare reacted negatively to the announcement and settled down at  .  per cent on the BSE in a strong broader market today. While the Indian mutual fund industry has been growing steadily, Religare Invesco has not seen any major upsurge in its asset under management in the recent past. Its average assets under management (AUM) stood at Rs  ,  crore for the quarter ended September, only marginally higher than Rs  ,  crore as on March   this year. In between, it had fallen to Rs  ,  crore in the quarter ended June. Without disclosing the deal size, Religare said in a statement that it has entered into a definitive agreement under which Invesco would increase its stake to   per cent in the joint venture. The transaction is subject to regulatory approvals. Religare held   per cent in the JV while Invesco currently has   per cent ownership. Invesco\'s Senior Managing Director and Head of Asia Pacific Andrew Lo said it would further deepen its presence in India by taking full ownership of this business. Religare Group CEO Shachindra Nath termed Invesco\'s decision as "an endorsement of the Indian macros" and also of the overall quality of the management team. Saurabh Nanavati will continue as CEO, along with the existing senior management team of the fund house. Invesco had purchased   per cent stake in March  , wherein it was also given an option to further increase its stake before March  . In the recent past, a number of foreign fund houses have exited the Indian mutual fund market, but in most of those cases, the businesses were acquired by Indian entities. The latest deal, therefore, goes against the prevailing trend. PTI BJ SP MR Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. News Ruchi Soya, Kagome end India tomato joint venture. Dean Best   words   May   Just-Food JUFOO English ©   Aroq Limited. All rights reserved Ruchi Soya, the Indian edible oil and soya foods business, and Japanese food and beverage group Kagome Co. have agreed to end their tomato products venture in India. In a statement to the Bombay Stock Exchange yesterday (  May), Ruchi Soya said it had sold its stake in Ruchi Kagome Foods India for INR m (US$ . m). Ruchi Soya added it hadentered into a "termination agreement" and a "share purchase agreement" with Kagome and "other" investors. TheRuchi Kagome Foods India venture was set up in   after a deal between Ruchi Soya, Kagome and Japanese conglomerate Mitsui Co. The agreement saw Ruchi Soya take a  % stake in the venture, with a separateentity owned by Kagome and Mitsui owning the rest of the business. The venture was set up to sell products including "premium" tomato puree, sauces and ketchup. The most recent financial results from Ruchi Soya came in February, when the company filed its results for the nine months to the end of December. Ruchi Soya said revenue from food products stood at INR . m, down from INR . m a year earlier. However, profit before tax and finance costs from each segment rose from INR . m to INR m. New Delhi, Jul   (PTI) Italian auto component maker Streparava Holding SPA today said it has bought out its Indian partner Sansera Engineering from their joint venture that makes engine parts for an undisclosed amount. Streparava Holding SPA has now taken over   per cent of the equity of Sansera Streparava Engineering Pvt Ltd, the company said in a statement. Streparava earlier held   per cent equity in the company and the remaining   per cent was held by Sansera Engineering Pvt Ltd, it added. The company is located in Bangalore and will now be Streparava\'s wholly-owned Indian venture, it added. "Streparava is committed to strengthen its presence in India beyond the current range of products being produced in the Bangalore facility to other areas such as driveline and chassis components, in which Streparava is a market leader," a Streparava spokesperson said. The company, which is also present in various other markets, including Brazil, Spain and China, makes auto components, including chassis components and bearing cups, for the commercial vehicle industry. Delhi-based Tecnova India, a consulting firm specialising in India entry, acted as advisors to the deal. PTI MSS RKL RAH Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. SBI drops plan for merchant acquiring biz JV with Visa, Elavon   words   January   The Press Trust of India Limited PRTRIN English (c)   Asia Pulse Pty Limited. New Delhi, January  ,   (PTI) -- India\'s largest lender State Bank of India (SBI) today said it has cancelled a proposed merchant acquiring business joint venture with US-based Elavon Incorporation and Visa International. The bank has cancelled the negotiations for establishing a joint venture entity with Visa Inc and Elavon Inc for conducting the merchant acquiring business, SBI informed the BSE. The merchant acquiring business involves facilitation of payments through debit or credit cards at retail outlets. The RBI had already approved the setting up of a wholly owned subsidiary by SBI in the name of SBI Payment Services for conducting the merchant acquiring business. The proposed joint venture between SBI Payment Services Pvt Ltd (a wholly owned subsidiary of SBI), Visa Inc and Elavon Inc was first mooted in  , it said. In  , the bank had floated a Request For Proposal (RFP) for selection of joint venture (JV) partners for the merchant acquiring business. The business was to include acquisition of bank identification numbers (BINs) and providing managed services for point-of-sale (PoS) terminals. The managed services would have included deployment of POS terminals at customer locations, their replacement, merchant training and maintenance, among others. State Bank of India Group presently has over  ,  ATMs across the country and has issued over   million debit cards. PTI DP ARV ARV   Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Star India exits from its home shop business BS Reporter   words   June   Business Standard BSTN English (c)   Business Standard Ltd. Star HS Ltd., an affiliate of media and entertainment conglomerate STAR India, has completed the sale of its  % stake in STAR CJ Network India Pvt. Ltd., the home shopping joint venture with Korea\'s CJO Shopping Co. Ltd. Star\'s stake has been acquired by Providence Equity Partners LLC. Providence is the world\'s leading private equity firm focused on media, communications, education andinformation investments. The firm manages funds with $  billion incommitments and has invested in more than   companies globally since its inception in  . Uday Shankar, CEO, STAR India said,"STAR CJ provides world class home shopping experiences toconsumers in India and has been a valuable investment for us. We and CJ have enjoyed an excellent working relationship and we expect thisto continue unaffected by the sale." Biswajit Subramanian, Managing Director of Providence India said, "Providence is excited about partnering with CJ O Shopping, a global leader in TV home shopping. The significant TV home shopping market opportunity in India, STAR CJ\'s strong management team and CJ\'s deep domain expertise, all makethis a compelling opportunity for us. We look forward to working withthe STAR CJ team and adding lasting value to the company in the years ahead." Kim Yun Koo, Executive Vice Presidentof CJ O Shopping said, "STAR India has been a close and valued partner for CJ O Shopping in building STAR CJ into a premier homeshopping platform in India. CJ O Shopping looks forward to accelerating STAR CJ\'s growth and believes Providence will be a fantastic partner for the next chapter in this journey." STAR CJ Network India Pvt. Ltd. (STARCJ), formed in   as a  :  partnership between STAR and CJ, is apart of CJ O Shopping Co. Ltd. of South Korea, the world\'s second-largest home shopping network. STAR CJ operates a  x  homeshopping channel called "STAR CJ alive" and provides a web-based portal www.starcj.com to third party sellers who list their products for sale, reaching more than   million households and having added   million shoppers to its network within four and a half years of its operation.STAR CJ will continue to use STAR\'s brand for up to one year. Kenny Shin, CEO of STAR CJ said "Weare happy to have Providence as our strategic and financial partner.It has been a pleasure and delight to deal with such a highly professional investment firm that shares our vision and understanding of the media as well as the home shopping industry. We are glad tocement this joint venture." Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Corporate Tata Metaliks Ends Water Pipes JV with Japanese Cos OUR BUREAU KOLKATA   words   March   The Economic Times - Mumbai Edition ECTMUM English Copyright ©  . Bennett, Coleman & Co., Ltd. Move seen to be in line with plan to integrate the pipe-making facility with itself Tata Metaliks has ended its joint venture for manufacturing drinking water pipes with Japanese partners, Kubota and Metal One. The move is seen as a prelude to a larger plan towards integrating the pipe-making facility with TML. The joint venture, Tata MetaliksKubota Pipes (TMKPL) was incorporated in July   as a  % subsidiary of TML, with the Japanese partners Kubota and Metal One holding  % and  % stake, respectively."To start with, TML will acquire  % stake by buying out its Japanese partners in TMKPL. After which, the pipemaking business will be brought under TML\'s fold. We continue to see a lot of prospect in the business," said Harsh Jha, managing director of Tata Metaliks, who is due to retire on Friday."We have separate agreements through which Tata Metaliks will continue to get technical and international marketing support from Kubota," he added. While there is an obvious tax advantage in the proposed move, TML\'s board is also weighing other options for TMKPL that will attract tax benefits. This includes making TMKPL a conversion agent of TML. A clearer picture may emerge shortly, with the board due to take a call on it in the next three to four weeks."The company signed an agreement with Kubota and Metal One on March  , , terminating the joint venture agreement being executed from July  ,  in relation to Tata MetaliksKubota Pipes, subsidiary of the company," Tata Metaliks said to the BSE. SEVERE COMPETITION TMKPL, in which the partners had invested around.  crore, was affected by severe price competition in ductile iron (DI) pipes and was upstaged by intense price cutting by regional players in the last four to five years. Hit by low net realisations in an industry facing overcapacity, especially in the eastern region, TMKPL\'s margins suffered."At one point, price of pig iron and DI pipes were at the same level. There was no premium on value addition which is absurd. The DI pipe market is essentially led by projects. There is no concept of marketshare. The situation worsened till it became economically unsustainable for a lot of companies that were operating at very low capacity," said an industry analyst. MINING CRISIS Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Tata Metaliks\' main business, too, has been affected due to irregular supplies of iron ore since the mining crisis broke out in Karnataka and Goa. In particular, it was forced to close down operations at its Redi plant at Sindhudurg, Maharashtra in October  . Earlier this week, it signed a memorandum of settlement with the Tata Metaliks Workers\' Union at Redi in respect of all permanent employees in pursuance of its plans to close down operation there. Plans to sell off its Redi plant last year suffered after it failed to clinch a deal with the proposed buyer, Fomento. Snapping Ties JV WAS INCORPORATED IN   with Japanese partners Kubota and Metal One holding  % and  % stake, respectively WHILE THERE IS AN OBVIous tax advantage in the proposed move, TML\'s board is also weighing other options for TMKPL that will attract tax benefits Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Front Page Fiat goes solo on logistics, snapping last link with Tata   words   March   Financial Express AIWFIE English Copyright   Indian Express Online Media Pvt. Ltd. The last of the links between Fiat in India and Tata Motors as far as sales and distribution goes has come to an end. While Fiat went independent with its sales and dealership network from May  , the distribution and outbound logistics piece was still being handled by Tata Motors. Fiat\'s dependence on Tata Motor\'s network will end in March. From April  , Fiat Group Automobiles India, Fiat\'s sales and distribution arm, will be switching over to a new partner. Fiat has brought in their distribution and logistic partner from Italy to handle their logistics and distribution in India from their plant at Ranjangaon, near Pune. Mercurio Pallia Logistics will take over the distribution logistics of Fiat cars. Mercurio Pallia a joint venture company between Gruppo Mercurio of Italy and Pallia Transport of India. Gruppo Mercurio is owned by Gefco Logistics. Fiat works with Gefco in Italy and some European markets. Gefco is a subsidiary of Peugeot of France and is into vehicle transport and distribution business across the globe with a turnover of  .  billion euro. Robert DeCrick, head, supply chain management (APAC), Fiat Chrysler, said, "They chose to go with an expert in the business rather than doing it themselves. This is not about fencing some agriculture land and starting to park on it. Unlike the car yards in India, the new Fiat stockyard was built on a solid surface with safety and security that ensure a better quality car was delivered to the customer. The yard also used IT extensively to offer better visibility for the dealership from invoice to delivery at the dealerships." On whether this investment in logistics would put an additional burden on the comapny\'s costs, DeCrick said they did not view logistics as cost but as a key part of their business. The new logistics partner will be able to handle customer demands better and with the use of technology dealers will he happier as they will be able to track their supplies from invoice to the delivery of cars at their dealerships, DeCrick said. As of now Fiat has   dealerships and is adding six nee dealership in two weeks. The target is to reach   dealerships by December  . Fiat earlier had a network of   dealers through Tata Motors. Though the six year sales tie-up has ended, the manufacturing JV between Tata Motors and Fiat India remains intact. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. BUSINESS RBI clears way for Tatas to buy back from DOCOMO Special Correspondent   words   January   The Hindu THINDU English (c)   Kasturi & Sons Ltd MUMBAI,BUSINESS The Tatas are close to buying back NTT DOCOMO’s  .  per cent stake in Tata Teleservices Ltd (TTSL) at an earlier agreed upon price of Rs. ,  crore as the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is understood to have relaxed its fair value pricing norm as a special case to enable them to honour their commitment made to the Japanese company. The easing of norms comes following enhanced business ties between India and Japan. The RBI’s fair value pricing norm does not allow companies to buy back shares at more price than the fair market value, and this is why the Tata- NTT DOCOMO deal could not be completed despite several notices from NTT DOCOMO and even the Japanese company initiating arbitration proceedings against Tata Sons and TTSL in London to recover its money. “Tata Sons has made the necessary application to the Reserve Bank of India. The company is awaiting a response,” a Tata Sons spokesperson said while responding to queries. In March,  , NTT DOCOMO had invested $ .  billion in TTSL to pick up  .  per cent stake. The shareholder’s agreement had guaranteed it at least   per cent of the investment if it wished to exit in case of TTSL failing to meet certain performance targets. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Corporate PE Firm Actis to Exit Road JV with Tatas ARIJIT BARMAN MUMBAI   words   May   The Economic Times - Mumbai Edition ECTMUM English Copyright ©  . Bennett, Coleman & Co., Ltd. Tata Opportunity Fund to buy out the PE firm in the JV and form an infra entity that will, to start with, acquire three road projects of IVRCL Three years after private equity firm Actis and the Tata Group formed a $ -million JV - with an ambitious plan to spend ten times of that sum in building roads over five years - the venture is coming to an end. Actis is set to pull out of the JV and the Tatas have agreed to buy them out, said multiple sources aware of the ongoing transaction. Currently, Tata Realty & Infrastructure (TRIL), a  % subsidiary of Tata Sons, owns  % of the venture called TRIL Roads while Actis owns the rest. TRIL was Tata Sons\' initial vehicle for its foray into infrastructure and real estate development. The Tata-Actis disengagement is likely to conclude within a month."Actis will make a marginal return on its investments. Its focus has moved away from roads into power generation and distribution and it will continue to focus on these sectors through its infrastructure funds. This will be an amenable exit," said an official. Actis\' exit is being facilitated by another Tata Group entity, Tata Opportunities Fund (TOF), the group\'s captive PE fund which will buy them out. Actis PE\'s India head JM Trivedi could not be reached for comments. Spokespersons from Tata Groups\' external media agency Rediffusion did not respond to ET\'s detailed questionnaire. London headquartered Actis - which was spun off from the Commonwealth Development Corporation nine years ago - had invested $ .  million (.  crore) for its minority stake, in what was then its first investment in the Indian infrastructure space. This money was deployed from its $ -million (. ,  crore) emerging markets focussed infrastructure fund. Close to  % of the fund\'s proceeds were initially earmarked for India. Despite its initial ambitious plans, TRIL Roads and Actis has till date built only one project, the  -km Pune-Solapur highway with Italian company Atlantia SpA as its technical partner, for. ,  crore. But with TOF on board, TRIL Roads plans to pursue inorganic opportunities in the sector. TRIL-TOF TO BUY   IVRCL ROAD PROJECTS To start with, it is already in negotiations to buy the three road projects of cash-strapped infrastructutre company IVRCL - Salem Tollways, Kumarapalayam Tollways and Changapally-Wallayar Tollways. The three roads have been built on an estimated cost of. ,  crore. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. In April this year, IVRCL entered into an agreement with TRIL Roads to transfer control in these three road projects, in an effort to monetise its build-operate-transfer assets. But in accordance with the terms of the concession agreement, TRIL Roads will separately buy  % in Salem and Kumarapalayam Tollways as they are already operational. IVRCL will continue with a  % exposure. However, for the Changapally-Wallayar Tollways, initially TRIL Roads will pick up only  % and upon completion of the project in the next five months, it will hike its stake to  %. After two years, IVRCL will exit entirely as the model concession agreement signed post   allows it to do so. Concessional agreement signed before   requires the original promoter to hold a minimum  %."We have all the necessary approvals from NHAI. We are just awaiting the lenders nod. We hope to conclude the deal in the next   days," said S Ramachandran, director, IVRCL Infrastructures & Projects. Tatas will be shelling out around.  crore as equity for the IVRCL deal, while. ,  crore of debt and other liabilities will get transferred to them."One good thing about the three roads is that by FY , all three are expected to achieve breakeven. But these are just four-lane state highways with moderate traffic growth projections," said Abhinav Bhandari, infrastructure analyst at Elara Capital.arijit.barman@timesgroup.com Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Indian billionaire Dilip Shanghvi drops plans to form payments bank with IDFC, Telenor   words   May    :  Reuters News LBA English Copyright   Thomson Reuters. All Rights Reserved. MUMBAI, May   (Reuters) - India\'s second richest man, Dilip Shanghvi, said on Friday he had shelved plans to form a payments bank jointly with the Indian financial firm IDFC Bank and an arm of Norway\'s Telenor, but did not disclose the reason. Shanghvi\'s company, Dilip Shanghvi Family and Associates, was among   firms that were awarded licences last August to set up niche "payments banks" aimed at granting millions of Indians access to basic banking. The banks are a part of India\'s financial inclusion push and are meant to expand banking services in a country where less than half of the adult population holds a bank account. Shanghvi, who is the founder and head of India\'s largest drugmaker Sun Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd, said he had worked with IDFC and Telenor over the past eight months to make a framework and governance structure for the joint venture. "Following the mutual decision to withdraw these plans, the payment bank license will not be pursued," Shanghvi said in a statement. (Reporting by Zeba Siddiqui in Mumbai, editing by David Evans) Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Front Page Unitech settles dispute with Telenor, to exit JV   words   October   Financial Express AIWFIE English Copyright   Indian Express Online Media Pvt. Ltd. Norwegian telecom operator Telenor and India\'s real estate firm Unitech on Thursday agreed to settle all their disputes amicably by withdrawing all the cases slapped against each other. The development brings to an end the long-drawn out dispute between the two since the Supreme Court cancelled their JV firm Uninor\'s   licences in its February   order. Under the terms of agreement while Unitech, which holds  . %, will exit the JV upon receiving payment of a nominal amount, Telenor would be able to transfer all assets of Uninor to a new company and bid in the upcoming  G spectrum auction. Telenor would be free to get a new Indian partner to meet the mandatory  % stake by an Indian firm in a telecom services company. However, Unitech would continue to retain economic rights in the company as per its current shareholding. This means that if any benefits accrue to the firm in terms of refund of licence fees of taxes, Unitech would be entitled to them as per its shareholding. The two parties also informed the Delhi High Court on Thursday that they have resolved their disputes amicably. Telenor had bought  . % stake in Unitech Wireless (Uninor) in   for R ,  crore. "Telenor and Unitech are pleased to announce that on October  ,  , they have reached an agreement to amicably settle all disputes between the two parties. The parties are bound by confidentiality obligations, and are, therefore, not able to provide any further comments on specific terms and conditions of the settlement. However, it can be confirmed that the parties agree to support the transfer of the business in Unitech Wireless (Uninor) to a new entity controlled by Telenor," the statement issued by the two sides said. With immediate effect, Unitech would withdraw all its nominees from Uninor\'s board and all its special shareholder rights will stand suspended. As for Unitech, with the settlement of disputes with Telenor, the realty firm will focus on its core business of real estate. "We are pleased with the settlement reached between Unitech and Telenor. All existing disputes with Telenor are suspended and will be withdrawn upon successful transfer of business of Uninor to a new entity controlled by Telenor," Unitech chairman Ramesh Chandra said. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. FT.com site : Tesco ends talks on India joint venture. Elizabeth Rigby and Nayantara Rai in London   words   November   Financial Times (FT.Com) FTCOM English (c)   The Financial Times Limited. All rights reserved Tesco of the UK admitted on Friday that its plan to be the first multinational supermarket retailer in India has unravelled. The world\'s fifth-biggest supermarket chain said it had ended talks with Bharti Enterprises to set up a joint venture in India\'s GBP bn-a-year ($ bn) retail sector after discussions failed. It now looks like Wal-Mart, the biggest global retailer, could lead the advance into the world\'s eighth-largest retail market. Sunil Mittal, the telecommunications tycoon who controls Bharti, refused to be drawn on his negotiations with Tesco. "We will make an announcement shortly on a global partner for our retail foray," he told the Financial Times. Tesco, Carrefour and Wal-Mart have been linked to Bharti, but it appears that only the US chain is still in the race. It is thought that the Tesco-Bharti deal fell apart in the final stages of the talks after the two parties failed to find common ground on the pace of expansion, with Bharti opting for a more aggressive opening programme than Tesco envisaged. Tesco is also thought to have felt frustrated by leaks about the talks. Under Indian rules, no foreign direct investment is allowed in the retail sector, except for single-brand stores, which means big groups have to sign a franchise or licensing agreement with local companies. India is on track to become the fifth-biggest retail market by  , according to McKinsey. Organised retailing makes up   per cent of the market, giving big chains scope to expand. Confirming that it had walked away from discussions with Bharti, Tesco said: "We remain excited by the opportunities available in India." Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Companies Titagarh Wagons-FreightCar America dissolve Indian JV P. R. Sanjai   words   February   Mint HNMINT English Copyright  . HT Media Limited. All rights reserved. Mumbai, Feb.   -- Wgaon manufacturing company Titagarh Wagons Ltd (TWL) and FreightCar America Inc. (FCA), on Saturday, said they have agreed to wind up and dissolve their Indian joint venture company. The joint venture company, Titagarh FreightCar Pvt. Ltd, was incorporated in India pursuant to a   joint-venture agreement between the parties with the objective of manufacturing and selling aluminium coal-carrying rail wagons in India. Soon after its incorporation, the joint venture company had begun the process of obtaining approval from the Indian Railways-Research Designs and Standards Organisation (RDSO) for aluminium wagon designs adapted for use on the Indian rail system, TWL said in stock exchange filing. However, they said that over time it became clear that approval from the RDSO would not be obtained in an acceptable time-frame. "The joint venture company formally notified the RDSO in June   that it would not further pursue its request for design approval," the statement said. "We had big plans for the joint venture company when it was incorporated in  . However, those plans were not realized despite considerable effort. After lengthy discussions, Titagarh Wagons and FreightCar America have decided to dissolve the joint venture company and part ways amicably," said Umesh Chowdhary, vice-chairman and managing director of TWL.Published by HT Syndication with permission from MINT. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Bharti Airtel acquires  % in Qualcomm India for Rs   cr BS Reporter New Delhi   words   May   Business Standard BSTN   English (c)   Business Standard Ltd. Enterprise valued at Rs  ,  cr; Bharti can offer  G services in key Mumbai, Delhi circles Bharti Airtel, the country’s largest mobile operator, today announced the acquisition of   per cent stake in US telecom major Qualcomm Inc’s broadband wireless access (BWA) company in India for an initial investment of $  million (Rs   crore). With this move, Bharti Airtel will become a key player in the  G LTE market, with a presence in eight of the   circles in the country. The acquisition of Qualcomm’s licence is crucial, as it will give Bharti an entry into four key circles: the lucrative Delhi and Mumbai markets as well as Haryana and Kerala. Bharti, on its own, has  G spectrum in four circles, including Kolkata, where it has already launched services, Karnataka, Punjab and Maharashtra. Under the agreement, Bharti will acquire the   per cent each held by Global Holding Corporation Private Ltd (part of the GTL group) and Tulip Telecom Ltd, to whom it is paying around Rs   crore each. The premium the two investors will earn from the deal comes to an annualised return of around   per cent on their investment. The balance equity has been bought by way of subscription of fresh equity in the entity. The deal also contemplates that once commercial operations are launched, subject to certain terms and conditions being met, Bharti would also pick up the remaining   per cent stake by May  . Qualcomm had forked out Rs  ,  crore to win the BWA licence and paid the money through a combination of debt and equity. That included about Rs  ,  crore in equity and the rest through debt. The interest on the debt for the last two years that the company forked out while waiting for spectrum comes to around Rs  ,  crore. Based on this, the enterprise value of the company stands around Rs  ,  crore. Barclays was mandated by Qualcomm to structure the deal. The US company received its spectrum just a few weeks ago after a bitter battle with the DoT (Department of Telecommunications) and after it moved the TDSAT following a delay of nearly two years. The DoT gave it the spectrum but with the licence period reduced from   years to  . . The roll-out obligation time was also reduced from five years to three and a half. Commenting on the deal, Sunil Bharti Mittal, chairman and managing director, Bharti Airtel, said, “This partnership will combine the strength of Bharti’s national telecom footprint and Qualcomm’s technological leadership in the LTE TDD space. With a broadband-ready network across India, Bharti is well positioned to lead the next phase of Indian’s telecom revolution.” Apart from  G, Bharti has  G services in   circles. Bharti added in its press release that with the deal, “it secured nationwide broadband leadership through a combination of  G and  G, with its own networks in   circles”. “One of our key objectives has been to include a strong partner in the Indian venture with the scale, experience and resources to deploy LTE TDD networks. We are pleased to have Bharti’s participation and support in this effort,” said Paul E Jacobs, chairman and CEO of Qualcomm. Tulip Telecom chairman H S Bedi confirmed his company had been paid Rs   crore for the   per cent stake. “Yes, we have been paid Rs   crore, which is at a premium to what we had spent.” Asked how the Rs   crore that Qualcomm has paid to the DoT on Tulip Telecom’s behalf for disputed dues, as directed by the TDSAT, Bedi said, “We had an agreement with Qualcomm that only after we had exhausted all options and not found a remedy would we pay the money back. However, I am confident this is an erroneous demand by the DoT.” Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. According to top sources, Bharti has also been talking to Aircel for an alliance in the BWA space, which could include using its network to get into seven more circles. According to sources, the circles that have been identified include Andhra Pradesh, Assam, Bihar, the north-east, Odisha, Tamil Nadu and West Bengal. Depending on the final policy and judgments on whether inter-circle roaming would be deemed legal, the move could help Bharti become a pan-India  G player, with presence in   circles. That would bring it head to head with the only other pan-India player, Reliance Infotel, which is preparing for a major launch by the end of this year. Bharti, however, said it would not like to comment on speculation. Aircel did not comment. Qualcomm had made it public it would not like to get into the services business and would divest stake to partners. Its main interest in bidding for BWA spectrum was to ensure operators used it to launch services on LTE, a technology it has been backing over Wimax. The US company’s main interest is to make money by selling chipsets for  G devices. The company is working on chipsets that will support devices to seamlessly move between  G,  G and  G without the customer realising the change. Qualcomm expects to provide technical assistance to Bharti in connection with network architecture and optimisation, infrastructure and device testing. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Bharti Airtel acquires  % in Qualcomm India for Rs   cr BS Reporter New Delhi   words   May   Business Standard BSTN   English (c)   Business Standard Ltd. Enterprise valued at Rs  ,  cr; Bharti can offer  G services in key Mumbai, Delhi circles Bharti Airtel, the country’s largest mobile operator, today announced the acquisition of   per cent stake in US telecom major Qualcomm Inc’s broadband wireless access (BWA) company in India for an initial investment of $  million (Rs   crore). We are pleased to have Bharti’s participation and support in this effort,” said Paul E Jacobs, chairman and CEO of Qualcomm. Tulip Telecom chairman H S Bedi confirmed his company had been paid Rs   crore for the   per cent stake. “Yes, we have been paid Rs   crore, which is at a premium to what we had spent.” Asked how the Rs   crore that Qualcomm has paid to the DoT on Tulip Telecom’s behalf for disputed dues, as directed by the TDSAT, Bedi said, “We had an agreement with Qualcomm that only after we had exhausted all options and not found a remedy would we pay the money back. However, I am confident this is an erroneous demand by the DoT.” Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. According to top sources, Bharti has also been talking to Aircel for an alliance in the BWA space, which could include using its network to get into seven more circles. According to sources, the circles that have been identified include Andhra Pradesh, Assam, Bihar, the north-east, Odisha, Tamil Nadu and West Bengal. Depending on the final policy and judgments on whether inter-circle roaming would be deemed legal, the move could help Bharti become a pan-India  G player, with presence in   circles. That would bring it head to head with the only other pan-India player, Reliance Infotel, which is preparing for a major launch by the end of this year. Bharti, however, said it would not like to comment on speculation. Aircel did not comment. Qualcomm had made it public it would not like to get into the services business and would divest stake to partners. Its main interest in bidding for BWA spectrum was to ensure operators used it to launch services on LTE, a technology it has been backing over Wimax. The US company’s main interest is to make money by selling chipsets for  G devices. The company is working on chipsets that will support devices to seamlessly move between  G,  G and  G without the customer realising the change. Qualcomm expects to provide technical assistance to Bharti in connection with network architecture and optimisation, infrastructure and device testing. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Varroc sheds its stake in JV Satnam Singh   words   September   Plastics News PLCN   Volume  ; Number   English (c)   Crain Communications, Inc. All rights reserved. Indian auto parts supplier Varroc Group and France’s Cie. Plastic Omnium SA have ended their joint venture in India, and now Varroc is moving forward with its own expansion plans. Aurangabad-based Varroc sold its   percent stake in the auto exterior venture to Levallois, France-based Omnium. The joint venture, Plastic Omnium Varroc Pvt. Ltd., has operated in Chakan, India, since  . “We have amicably decided to grow on our own in the growing Indian automobile market,” said M.P. Sharma, Varroc’s vice president for material and projects, in a telephone interview. Details on the buyout were finalized in mid-August, he said. Terms were not disclosed. Now Varroc is expanding its polymer division by setting up three new facilities in different parts of India to cater to the various automobile hubs, according to Sharma. The company is investing around $  million in the plants. The first, in Pithampur, will start production in October. The plant — Varroc’s eighth plastics operation — will supply Mahindra & Mahindra and VE Commercial Vehicles Ltd. The plant, on a  / -acre site, has injection presses ranging from  -  tons of clamping force. The second plant, in Bangalore, will open next year. It will supply Honda Motorcycle & Scooters India (HMSI) and automotive plants around Bangalore, Sharma said. The third plant, in Chennai, will open in   and serve the fast-growing automotive hub in that region, he said. In August, Varroc bought Visteon Corp.’s global lighting business. That business has  ,  employees at plants in Monterrey, Mexico; Pune, India; and two sites in Czech Republic — Nový Jicín and Rychvald. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Essar exits Vodafone-Essar JV for USD   billion   words   March    :  Organisation of Asia-Pacific News Agencies OANA English © Copyright  . OANA. All rights reserved. New Delhi (PTI) Putting an end to the corporate battle, UK-based Vodafone Thursday announced it would exercise the option to acquire its Indian partner Essar\'s   per cent stake which will result in payment of USD five billion. With this, Vodafone may have to look for another domestic partner to remain compliant with the FDI norms in the telecom sector of a maximum stake of   per cent. "Vodafone Group announces that the Essar Group has exercised its underwritten put option over   per cent of Vodafone Essar Limited (VEL). "Following the exercise by the Essar Group of its put option, Vodafone has exercised its call option over the remaining   per cent of VEL owned by the Essar Group, resulting in a total cash payment of USD   billion," Vodafone said in a statement. Call Option allows an investor the right but not the obligation to buy a stock, bond, commodity or other instrument at a specified price within a specific time period. On the other hand, Put Option is an option contract giving the owner the right but not the obligation to sell a specified amount of an underlying security at a specified price within a specified time. With this, Essar will exit completely from the joint venture, which is offering nationwide mobile services in India. Vodafone has over   million subscribers and is the third largest operator in India. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Vodafone also said that final settlement is anticipated to be completed by November,  . Sources in the know said that the completion of deal would be subject to meeting certain conditions which include Reserve Bank of India\'s permission as well as valuation of the deal. The final shareholding pattern post this deal was not provided by the company as it was not clear whether Vodafone\'s stake would exceed the   per cent FDI limit. Vodafone had entered Indian market in   when it bought Hutchison\'s stake in the joint venture for over USD   billion and after that it had entered into an agreement with Essar for a call and put option for its stake. The two firms were locked in battle over Essar\'s plan to list a firm that had part stake in the joint venture to find out market value of its   per cent stake. The move was opposed by Vodafone saying this may not give true value of Vodafone\'s stake. It had approached the market regulator SEBI and also filed a petition in the Madras High Court. Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. VOLTAS TO EXIT SERMO-PM VENTURE FULLY (Voltas no longer considers Sermo-PM a part of its core business) Economic Times. Aug  ,  ; pg     words   August   Indian Business Insight WIBI  -  English Copyright (c)   Informatics (India) Ltd. Voltas Ltd, a Tata Group company, has decided to sell its entire stake of   percent in joint venture company Sermo-PM to its French partner, Sermo Montaigu. Voltas no longer considers Sermo-PM, which manufactures moulded plastics, a part of its core business. Sermo-PM will be wholly owned by Sermo Montaigu once the stake sale is concluded during  - . Business LEIGHTON BUYS OUT INDIAN VENTURE JANE HARPER with AAP   words   December   Herald-Sun HERSUN HeraldSun   English ©   News Limited. All rights reserved. RESOURCES CONSTRUCTION giant Leighton Holdings has struck a multi-million dollar deal to buy out in full its Indian-based joint venture, Leighton Welspun. Leighton said yesterday it had bought the Welspun Group’s  .  per cent stake for $US  million ($  million). The move will give Leighton   per cent ownership of the joint venture, which was set up in   to tap into opportunities in India’s infrastructure sector. The business will be renamed Leighton India. “Leighton continues to see strong long-term prospects in the Indian market,” the construction and mining group said yesterday. The company said the opportunity to buy out the venture came on the back of a decision by Welspun to reposition its infrastructure business and focus on its other activities, which include textiles, pipes energy and steel. Leighton said it will review the operations of Leighton India and consider integrating several business units to lower costs. The company said its   underlying profit would not be affected by the transaction, which is expected to be completed in the first quarter of  . Leighton’s forecast underlying profit remains at $  million to $  million. Leighton shares closed  .  per cent down at $ . .with AAP Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. INFO-TECH Wipro buys out Motorola stake   words   June   Business Line (The Hindu) BSNLNE   English (c)   The Hindu Business Line Bangalore, June   Wipro Technologies has pulled out of its joint venture with Motorola Inc – WMNetServ, for managing tele-communication networks and services for operators. Wipro will buy out Motorola’s stake in the deal. The joint venture, WMNetServ, was signed in   between the two companies with Wipro holding majority stake. WNNetServ, headquartered in Europe with a branch office in London and development centres in Bangalore and New Delhi, was formed to offer services such as network planning and deployment, network optimisation, security, operations and support among others. But the deal did not see any great value addition, said Wipro, in a press communication. Mr Sudip Nandy, President - Technology, Communications and Telecom Vertical, Wipro Technologies, said: “Wipro and Motorola will continue to work closely in the engineering space. ”– Our Bureau Page   of   ©   Factiva, Inc. Wipro will buy out Motorola’s stake in the deal. The joint venture, WMNetServ, was signed in   between the two companies with Wipro holding majority stake. WNNetServ, headquartered in Europe with a branch office in London and development centres in Bangalore and New Delhi, was formed to offer services such as network planning and deployment, network optimisation, security, operations and support among others. But the deal did not see any great value addition, said Wipro, in a press communication. Wipro of India acquires Motorola stake in JV WMNetServ, provider of network engineering services Announced Date:  / /  Wipro Technologies, the global IT arm of India\'s Wipro Limited, has announced that it has exited its joint venture with Motorola. Wipro and Motorola formed the joint venture - WMNetServ - in  , with Wipro holding the majority stake.   words   June   Optical Networks Daily OBSERV English (c)   Electronics International Disclaimer: Whilst every effort has been taken to ensure the accuracy of the information contained in this report, neither Electronics International nor its agents or sources can be held responsible for any inaccuracy. Wipro stated that it has acquired  % of Motorola\'s stake in the venture, adding that the two companies would continue to collaborate in the engineering space. WMNetServ focuses on delivering network engineering services to equipment vendors and wireless operators worldwide. It operates a framework for remote delivery of network services such as network planning and design and network optimisation. For further information go to http://www.opticalkeyhole.com'

Mumbai   words   August   Business Standard BSTN   English (c)   Business Standard Ltd  Reliance Capital will acquire AMP Sanmar Life Insurance Company for Rs   crore  Since the Chennai-based life insurance entity has net free assets of Rs  -  crore  Reliance Cap will pay a premium of Rs  -  crore  Net free assets essentially denote the book value of an insurance company  calculated after deducting losses from its share capital  AMP Sanmar has a capital base of Rs     crore  The non-banking finance arm of the Anil Dhirubhai Ambani Enterprise (ADAE) had initially decided to acquire AMP Sanmar through Reliance Life Insurance Company  But it was not possible as Reliance Life Insurance was not a legal entity since it did not have a licence from the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority (IRDA)  IRDA Chairman CS Rao told Business Standard since Reliance Life Insurance was not a legal entity  it could not acquire AMP Sanmar  "It is important for Reliance to identify the acquirer as the next step will be the due diligence exercise to be undertaken by the insurance regulator " he added  Declining to comment on the actual value of the deal  Graham Meyer  AMP Sanmar CEO  said it had not been a distress sale    Page   of   ©   Factiva  Inc  All rights reserved  BANKING FINANCE AMP Sanmar Life is now Reliance Life Our Bureau   words   February   Business Line (The Hindu) BSNLNE   English (c)   The Hindu Business Line Hyderabad   Feb    CONSEQUENT to the acquisition by Reliance Capital Ltdof the entire equity capital of AMP of Australia and Sanmar Group in AMP Sanmar Life Insurance Co Ltd   the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority (IRDA) has taken note of the change of company name  `AMP Sanmar Life Insurance Co Ltd\'  to that of Reliance Life Insurance Co Ltd (RLICL) and the fresh certificate of incorporation consequent to change of name issued by the Registrar of Companies  Tamil Nadu  dated January    The insurance regulator said it had permitted RLICL to carry on life insurance business in India subject to the condition that RLICL should honour its commitments to the policyholders of AMP Sanmar Life Insurance on the same terms and conditions subject to which they were issued  Further  the regulator said in a notice here that RLICL should take necessary steps to protect the interests of the policyholders in accordance with the provisions of IRDA Act   and Insurance Act    Page   of   ©   Factiva  Inc  All rights reserved  Max Hypermarkets  Auchan end ties Raghavendra Kamath   words   August   Business Standard BSTN English agreement into a joint venture is the reason for ending the relationship  Max Hypermarkets said today  "Max Hypermarkets and Groupe Auchan continued deep into   to look into the possibilities of creating a joint venture to facilitate Groupe Auchan investment in India  which could comply with Indian FDI regulations  Despite their best efforts  the parties could not facilitate this proposition Malviya   words   April   The Economic Times ECTIM English (c)   The Times of India Group  All rights reserved  NEW DELHI | MUMBAI: Walmart Stores spent    million (Rs    crore at current rates) to end its high-profile retail partnership with Bharti Enterprises  resulting in a net loss of    million (Rs    crore) accruing to the US company’s consolidated income in    While the world’s largest retailer paid    million (Rs  crore) to acquire Bharti’s stake in its India wholesale joint venture and go solo  it also took a   -million (Rs    crore) hit that included debt and other investments in back-end partner Bharti Retail that it waived as part of the October   separation  according to its annual report issued last week  Walmart paid the    million to acquire Bharti Enterprises’    stake in the erstwhile Bharti Walmart Pvt Ltd that ran   Best Price-branded cash-andcarry stores  It was widely speculated that Walmart had compensated Bharti well to call off their six-year-old alliance but this is the first time the amount of money the US company paid to end its India equal JV has come to light  Bharti officials couldn’t be reached immediately for comment  Walmart India said it had nothing to add to the information already disclosed  ET reported previously that it cost Walmart around Rs    crore to purchase Bharti’s stake in the joint venture  After going well for the first four years since its inception in    the Bharti-Walmart alliance turned rocky in the last two as the US firm focused attention on an internal probe to check if the unit had in any way violated US anti-bribery laws  Bharti  Walmart Trying to Expand Independently Scott Price  Walmart’s Asia head who has now been elevated to a global role  told ET in an interview earlier this month that the two partners had an "amicable" end to their six-year alliance  The two-year probe carried out by independent investigators  including US law firm Greenberg Traurig and consulting firm KPMG  prompted Bharti-Walmart to stall all expansion  suspend or sack top officials and ultimately drove a wedge between the partners  Walmart was intent on making sure that it hadn’t committed any violations of the US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act  which outlaws bribes to foreign government officials by US-listed entities to run or secure businesses  This followed a corruption scandal in Mexico  where company officials allegedly paid tens of millions of dollars in bribes to local officials to expand faster in the biggest foreign market for Walmart  After the Mexico episode  Walmart started investigating global operations including India and China  Walmart faced other difficulties in India as well  The Bentonville-based retail giant was hounded by Indian politicians for what was construed as lobbying to get India to open multi-brand retail to global supermarket chains  It also came under attack for its   -million investment in Bharti Retail’s holding firm in   at a time India barred any sort of overseas investment in multi-brand retail  Politicians alleged that Walmart broke India’s foreign exchange laws through what they called illegal and indirect capital infinfusion into Bharti Retail  which ran a nationwide network of Easyday stores  Subsequently  India would change its rules to allow foreign direct investment in multi-brand retail but with strict conditions attached  Bharti will acquire the compulsory convertible debentures (CCDs) worth    million that Walmart’s Mauritius-based investment arm had infused into Cedar Support Services  which owned Bharti Retail  as part of the separation agreement  In addition to the termination of the wholesale joint venture  Walmart also Page   of   ©   Factiva  Inc  All rights reserved  snapped its "franchisee and supply agreement with Bharti Retail Ltd which operates Bharti’s retail business in India and transferred its (Walmart’s) investment in that business to Bharti"  the annual report said  apparently with reference to the   -million CCD investment  Both Walmart and Bharti are trying to expand their businesses independent of each other  Walmart this month said it’s bullish on the India cash-and-carry business and plans to add   Best Price stores in the next five years  ET has reported that Walmart  which has formed a new company called Walmart India  has injected an additional Rs    crore into its operations in the country after its break-up with Bharti  A substantial chunk of this will go into developing the cash-and-carry stores and allied infrastructure  according to people aware of the plans  For Reprint Rights: timescontent com Page   of   ©   Factiva  Inc  All rights reserved  Emerging Markets BP Walks Away From India\'s Refining Renaissance   words   April   International Petroleum Finance IPF English (c)   Energy Intelligence Group  All rights reserved Harsh market conditions for downstream companies in India -- including hefty losses from sales of petroleum products below cost and a potential glut in domestic refining capacity -- are being blamed for last month\'s decision by BP to pull out of a mooted refining and marketing joint venture with Hindustan Petroleum  BP had informed Hindustan that its board had found other projects more attractive at this time than the proposed Bhatinda refining venture  Hindustan Chief Executive MB Lal told a Mar    press conference in New Delhi  Lal noted that India\'s downstream conditions had worsened since BP signed a letter of intent last October with Hindustan to invest in a    billion refinery in Bhatinda in northern India  The agreement also involved setting up a joint venture to market products from the proposed     barrel per day inland refinery through a chain of cobranded retail outlets across India  "They had ambitious plans " Lal told IPF  BP explained that its decision to abandon the joint venture with Hindustan was made because the project didn\'t fit with its current plans  "It\'s a robust project  but it\'s just not the right project for us at this moment in time " a BP spokeswoman told IPF  "It doesn\'t fit in with what we\'re doing at the moment  so we\'ve decided that we\'re not going to take the letter of intent forward " India remains "a place we would still look at " for both upstream and downstream  she added  Shortly after the letter of intent was signed  BP Chief Executive John Browne cautioned that this was no guarantee of any future alliance  "We have a letter of intent  which is an agreement to agree " Browne had said  "We do not have a deal " Lal told reporters that Hindustan would go ahead with the refinery  which will be designed to process    sour crudes  "We have a refinery on the east coast and one on the west " Lal said  "The Bhatinda refinery is inland and complements the other two refineries " India\'s northern region is short of products  and Bhatinda would help plug that gap  Lal said  Hindustan also plans to expand the east coast Vizag refinery  which processes     b d  by     b d at a cost of      billion  "By   we want to process    sour crudes in all our refineries " said Lal  "Our refineries will have an    distillate content and make products suiting Euro-  and Euro-  standards " Lal said Hindustan\'s coastal refineries could become largely export oriented  with Bhatinda catering to the domestic market  if Indian product demand remains largely flat at     million b d  BP\'s decision marks a blow to India\'s attempt to attract foreign investments in the energy sector  The country deregulated its petroleum sector in April    but oil companies were not allowed to raise pump prices in line with global price levels for the past year  leading to huge losses -- Hindustan incurred losses of around    million for the nine months ending December   from selling petroleum products below cost  India\'s petroleum sector  once touted as a high-growth market  is in the doldrums  The country\'s existing     million b d capacity  spread across   refineries  is already    higher than current product demand  which has been negative in the current fiscal year to end-March  But this has not stopped the country from witnessing a boom in domestic refining investment  aimed at turning India into a global refining hub targeting export markets in Europe and the US  Hindustan\'s Bathinda plant is one of eight refining projects that are set to add some     million b d of new refining capacity to the Indian market by    at a cost of around    billion  The export drive has been led by private refiners such as Reliance Industries  which is adding a further     b d of processing capacity to its giant     b d Jamnagar plant between now and   (IPF Page   of   ©   Factiva  Inc  All rights reserved  Oct p )  But Oil & Natural Gas Corp  (ONGC) and Indian Oil Corp  (IOC) look set to jump on the export bandwagon  with both following the Jamnagar model by developing integrated refining and petrochemical complexes at Mangalore and Paradip  respectively  Page   of   ©   Factiva  Inc  All rights reserved  Food Britannia to buy out NZ dairy partner Fonterra   words   April   The Economic Times ECTIM English (c)   The Times of India Group  All rights reserved  BANGALORE: Nusli Wadia-controlled Britannia Industries has agreed to buy out New Zealand\'s Fonterra from an existing dairy joint venture  Britannia New Zealand Foods  Both Britannia and Fonterra  one of the world\'s biggest milk co-operatives  agreed to call off the  :  JV  with the acquirer assuming the cumulative losses and the exiting foreign partner writing down the investments made into venture  The deal will bolster and unlock further synergies in Britannia\'s go-to-market strategy  The company in recent months brought biscuits  cakes & rusks and dairy products like cheese  butter  ghee and dairy whitener under one distribution vertical  while the \'daily fresh\' products  such as bread and dahi fall into another  The company\'s distribution was fragmented till some time back  with all the business units approaching the trade separately  The mainstay biscuits  non-biscuit bakery (breads  cakes & rusks) and dairy constitute three strategic business units within the Rs     crore company  "We have a single go-to-market strategy for Britannia as far as possible  which is helping us  especially with the modern trade  The distribution has been streamlined into two verticals  with the fresh consumption products like bread and curd forming one and remaining products going to the market under a separate vertical " Britannia Industries MD Vinita Bali told ET  In fact  Britannia has tweaked its brand strategy to accommodate the fresh consumption products under a newly-scripted Britannia Daily Fresh umbrella  Ms Bali said the dairy JV was reporting a turnover of Rs   crore and an annualized growth of  -   The JV  which had turned profitable in recent years  has accumulated losses of around Rs   crore  "We will be taking over the P L of the JV and so the losses " she added  Fonterra  a significant supplier of milk ingredients to global food giants such as Danone and Nestle  wanted to exit the Indian market since it could not deliver much value addition  given the fragmented nature of India\'s dairy industry  Fonterra is known for managing large dairy farms  It is not a big player in the branded dairy sector even though it has milk powder offering under Anchor brand in several south east Asian markets  Britannia will ramp up its presence in the dairy space through new product offerings post acquisition of the Fonterra stake  "We will be looking at differentiated SKUs where we can innovate on the basic dairy technology  Take our cheese offering  for instance  where we have a market share of nearly    We came out with slim cheese (with    lower fat) as well as cheese cubes and spreads that are clearly differentiated " Ms Bali said  The Britannia-Fonterra JV exited the liquid milk market in   in wake of mounting losses and has no plans of re-looking at the segment  "It is a high volume low margin play that does not fit into our business model in dairy " she explained  suggesting that Britannia\'s dairy play will essentially revolve around milk derivatives  Page   of   ©   Factiva  Inc  All rights reserved  Accel Buys British Telecom\'s    Stake In Accel Frontline infusion of capital  Recently Future Lifestyle Fashion Limited exited its investment in ethnic wear firm BIBA apparel and Anita Dongre owned AND for R  Cr  The Future Group’s sales and divestments are part of Biyani’s efforts to restructure and revive his retail empire that paid the price for rapid  and debt-fuelled expansion  In this space  Mandhana Retail Ventures  the licensee of Salman Khan\'s Being Human brand was planning to raise R -  Cr by divesting    stake in the company  Also  L Capital Asia was planning to exit Genesis Luxury  Page   of   ©   Factiva  Inc  All rights reserved  Continental Acquires Joint-Venture Shares from RICO Auto   words   March   ENP Newswire ENPNEW English (c)    Electronic News Publishing  All Rights Reserved  Release date -   Frankfurt am Main  Germany New Delhi  India  The international automotive supplier Continental  has acquired Rico Auto Industries Limited’s   percent shares in the joint venture Continental Rico Hydraulic Brakes India Ltd  With this transaction the company will be fully owned subsidiary of Continental  Since   the plant in Gurgaon near New Delhi has been producing and supplying components for hydraulic brake systems to OEM customers in India  These include products and services consisting of calipers for front and rear axles  drum brakes  master cylinders  brake boosters and load sensing proportioning valves for all kind of passenger cars  ‘India plays an important role in the growth strategy of our hydraulic brake systems business unit  The investment in the Gurgaon activities underlines our intention to add even more value to driving safety for the Indian automotive industry and end consumers  With our Indian operations we support worldwide OEMs with their production locations in India as well as Indian homebased OEMs’  said Dr  Peter Laier  Executive Vice President of the Hydraulic Brake Systems business unit  Continental Chassis & Safety division  According to Claude dGama Rose  Country Head of Continental in India ‘This acquisition also reinforces our commitment to the Indian market  We have strong growth plans and we will continue to invest in both development and manufacturing to introduce future technologies to this lucrative market  both in our Automotive and Rubber businesses in India ’ Continental is continuing to concentrate on the key components of its business strategy  one of the main ones being above-average profitable growth in the growth regions  including BRIC  especially in China  India and other Asian countries  In India  Continental had made significant investments in   by acquiring Modi Tyres and further committing to an investment of   million Euros to ramp up the tyre business in the country  They also expanded the India Technical Centre in    and are planning expansion of its automotive facilities in Pune and Manesar in    The company believes that India will see improvements and capacity addition in infrastructure  which will trigger continuous growth  [Editorial queries for this story should be sent to newswire@enpublishing co uk] Page   of   ©   Factiva  Inc  All rights reserved  BUSINESS & ECONOMY DBS exits India NBFC biz Khyati Dharamsi   words   March   DNA - Daily News & Analysis DNADAI English Copyright    Diligent Media Corporation Ltd  Sells      in Cholamandalam DBS Finance to Murugappa Group DBS  Singapore\'s largest bank  is exiting its non-banking finance venture in India  It is selling off its      stake in Cholamandalam DBS Finance to partner Murugappa Group in a deal worth Rs   crore  The shares would be purchased at Rs   per share  which is a      premium to the closing price of Rs     at the Bombay Stock Exchange on Monday  Shares of Cholamandalam DBS Finance closed on Tuesday at Rs   per share after touching a high of Rs     intraday  "The transaction is expected to be completed on or before   April   " a statement issued on Tuesday said  The bank said the move was in line with its new target customer group  "DBS remains committed to India  a high-growth market  where it has enjoyed stellar performance over the past five years  The bank is executing swiftly on the new strategic roadmap unveiled by chief executive officer Piyush Gupta in February  In India  the bank wants to focus on corporate clients as well as high-networth individuals and emerging affluent segments " it said in a response to DNA Money  Gupta took charge of DBS\'s India operations in November     The Murugappa Group also clarified on Tuesday that options were open for future tie-ups  India contributes    to DBS\' total business  the third-largest after Singapore and Hong Kong  The India business is seen growing  -   in  -   "DBS and Murugappa Group remain open to future collaboration opportunities in areas such as wealth management  distribution of financial products  etc " DBS had also earlier exited its mutual fund venture in the country  which was again in tie-up with Murugappa Group  after DBS Cholamandalam Mutual Fund was acquired by L&T Finance early this year  Page   of   ©   Factiva  Inc  All rights reserved  Top Stories Mahindra to Buy BAE Systems with Japanese partner Denso Corporation  when it sold its    stake in Denso Pricol India (DPIN) to Denso for a consideration of Rs   crore  DPIN has now become the wholly-owned subsidiary of Denso exclusively to Japanese carmakers Toyota  Honda and Suzuki  The JV envisaged total buyout of Pricol by Denso in five years and involved transfer by Pricol  of its \'Denso Technology Instrument Cluster reserved  UPDATE: DLF To Exit Mutual Fund JV With Prudential - Source   words   January    :  Dow Jones International News DJI English (c)   Dow Jones & Company  Inc  (Adds details on the mutual fund JV  background) By Nikhil Gulati Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES NEW DELHI (Dow Jones)--DLF Ltd  (  BY)  India\'s biggest realty company by sales  will exit a mutual fund joint venture in the country with Prudential Financial Inc  (PRU) because of a proposed regulatory change  a person with direct knowledge of the matter said Monday  "The move is prompted by a proposed regulatory change  which makes it mandatory for a company to have five years of experience before selling mutual funds " the person  who didn\'t wish to be named  told Dow Jones Newswires  The move is also in line with the New Delhi-based company\'s strategy to focus on real estate development  the person added  DLF currently owns    in the joint venture--DLF Pramerica Asset Managers Pvt  Ltd --while Prudential owns the remaining    "DLF will sell its    stake to Prudential " the person said  without disclosing details of the likely valuation of DLF\'s stake in the venture  Spokespeople from Prudential weren\'t immediately available for comment  The person said also that the time frame for DLF\'s exit from the joint venture is yet to be decided  In November    DLF and Prudential had received an approval from the markets regulator  the Securities & Exchange Board of India  to jointly sell mutual funds and said they will jointly invest    million in DLF Pramerica  DLF Pramerica was planning to start selling mutual funds in    Earlier Monday  The Economic Times newspaper reported that DLF plans to exit the venture to reduce its debt of nearly INR  billion  DLF has been exiting its non-core businesses as part of its strategy to focus more on property development  The company\'s founders recently sold its multiplex-chain  DT Cinemas  to Indian multiplex operator PVR Ltd  The real estate developer also previously announced plans to sell its wind power business  Still  DLF has a separate life insurance venture with Prudential  DLF Pramerica Life Insurance Co  Ltd  in which the Indian realty firm owns a majority    stake  while the remaining stake is held by the U S -based insurance company  "The life insurance business is continuing and is doing very well for DLF " the person said  The life insurance business began operations in September   with an equity base of INR    billion  In November    DLF had said that the companies will jointly infuse INR  billion of capital over next five to six years in the life insurance venture  Page   of   ©   Factiva  Inc  All rights reserved  -By Nikhil Gulati  Dow Jones Newswires;   - - - ; nikhil gulati@dowjones com (Shikhar Balwani in Mumbai also contributed to this story ) [  - -   GMT ] Page   of   ©   Factiva  Inc  All rights reserved  DLF buys out Hiltons in  :  hotel JV Distributed by Contify com   words   December   Realty Plus ATREAP English Copyright ©   Adsert Web Solutions Pvt  Ltd  The country\'s largest realty firm DLF has bought out its foreign partner Hilton in its hospitality firm DLF Hotels (formerly known as DLF Hilton Hotels Ltd) for an undisclosed sum  DLF held majority stake in the  :  joint venture that clocked revenues of Rs     crore with profit after tax of Rs     crore during the year ended March       The financial details of the latest transaction stands undisclosed but it would run into several crores  reports VCCircle  Although the JV did not manage to scale up as fast as hospitality industry analysts had hoped for  arguably due to the economic slowdown that hit the hospitality business specially hard during  -   the JV had paid up capital of Rs     crore as per balance sheet disclosure for FY   Among the listed peers  a company like Hotel Leelaventure Ltd is currently trading   times its FY  net profit  If this is taken as a benchmark  DLF Hotels could be valued at around Rs   crore or more and Hilton\'s stake could then be worth around Rs   crore (   million)  as per VCCircle estimates  DLF  which also owns and operates the luxury segment hospitality brand Aman Resorts across the world  had formed an alliance with Hilton for development and management of hotels in India a few years ago  The debt-laden realty firm had been taking a hard look at the hotel business and among the many options  it has been looking at the possibility of selling Aman Resorts  DLF had formed the JV with Hilton a few years ago  in one of the first large foreign direct investment transactions in the hospitality sector in the country  Although various international hotel brands operate in India  with some of them having been here for decades  most of them entered the market through management Factiva  Inc  All rights reserved  Corporate DLF to End Ties with Ferragamo RAVI TEJA SHARMA NEW DELHI   words   May   The Economic Times - Mumbai Edition ECTMUM English Copyright ©    Bennett  Coleman & Co  Ltd  Realtor to focus on selling premium  luxury fashion brands in the country Less than a fortnight after ending its joint venture with Giorgio Armani  DLF said it is in the process of breaking its partnership with another Italian luxury brand Salvatore Ferragamo as part of a move to exit luxury brands business "Luxury is a futuristic business in India at the moment and does not have scale " DLF Brands Chief Executive Officer Dipak Agarwal says  The real estate major will instead focus on selling premium and bridge-to-luxury fashion brands such as Boggi  Alcott  Mango  Mothercare  Claire\'s and DKNY "This segment is much more profitable and scalable " Agarwal says  He says that while luxury brands have a big future in India  it will require another five to seven years to achieve scale and market size "For us  size with speed was important " he says  The company has had only four Ferragamo and three Armani stores since it entered the luxury brands segment in   as expansion of these brands in a limited market was getting difficult  In comparison  UK retailer Mothercare  which sells prams  pushchairs  car seats  baby clothes and also maternity clothes  entered India in   and already has   stores in the country  It will add   more stores this year  Boggi has   stores and DLF will add another three stores in the next one-year  The luxury market in India is bogged down with issues such as high import duties and lack of skilled manpower and quality real estate  There is only one luxury mall in the country currently  the DLF Emporio in Delhi  and brands are reluctant to enter high street locations due to poor infrastructure around them  The cost of retail real estate is very high and that has been nibbling into the profits of luxury retailers in the country  Today  it costs  -  crore to set up a luxury store while a store for a premium brand can be made for  -  lakh  To offset this cost  some luxury brands have resorted to reducing the size of their stores to improve the sales per sq ft of space  DLF Brands currently operates   stores for its brands and Agarwal hopes to take the number to   in the next three to four years  While the company has decided not to invest in new luxury brands at the moment  Agarwal says it may help some top brands enter the country through support on the real estate and supply chain fronts  Page   of
